Definition: In this task you will be given a review body and you have to give review headline

Positive Examples.input: I was very surprised at the high quality of the stitching, the sturdiness of the handles and the padding for my laptop. The price is amazingly low and the look is very good. I am quite happy with this purchase. It fit my MacBook Pro perfectly, with a little bit of room to spare.
Positive Examples.explanation: The title of review is very positive and user liked it very much  based on the given review body , and title correctly resembles to review

Positive Examples.input:
I am a Google employee and had to chance to use the device for a few months now. This is my own opinion of the device.

Overall OnHub is a pretty no nonsense type router that just works. Its super simple to setup with your phone, is fast and auto updates. I have not looked back ever since I set it up. The beauty in this router is that it gets better over time. You know what I mean if you have a ChromeBook. It auto updates and you never have to deal with firmware and security updates or adjusting settings on the device to get the optimal performance for your WiFi network. It just figures it out on its own.

Why I love it:
1) Auto Updates. Probably the one of the main selling points. I have witnessed this first hand. It uses the power of the cloud to update. No security updates to apply, no firmware patches to apply, no need to plug in your laptop to set it up or flash, etc. It does it automatically through the internet.

2) It's fast. I probably have 6-7 devices connected through WiFi and they all perform pretty well. I didn’t notice any performance differences when streaming Netflix or YouTube using the Ethernet connection or Wireless network.

3) The Android app makes it dead simple to share your WiFi password, perform speed tests on your internet connection, see how much bandwidth devices on your network are using, and updated your typical settings you see in a WiFi router. The added bonus is you can even do it from anywhere you have a internet connection. No need to be on your home network. The default settings worked straight out of the box beautifully. (There is an iOS app, which has similar features)

4) There are 2.4GHz and 5GHz antennas which should cover all your devices. The interesting bit for me, was that you only need one SSID for both frequencies. There is no concept of network-name and network-name-5g if you have a used a router in the past that broadcasted both frequencies. It will automatically figure out which is the better frequency for you and use that.

5) No administrator password to remember or gateway ip to remember to update settings. You control everything through your phone, including adding additional managers to administer the device. Although, I haven’t actually had the need to use this, it might come in handy to help a friend or family member if they had some questions.

6) It looks nice enough that I don’t need to hide it in my TV stand and can leave it out in the open.

Why you may not like it:
1) The OnHub only has 1 Ethernet port, where as my old router had 4. While I thought I would miss this early on, I actually found that connecting all my devices via WiFi just seemed so much simpler and cleaner. If you need more ports for wired internet access, you will need a switch.

2) There is no web interface to administrate the device, but I didn’t really miss it. Well, okay I will admit I did at first, since I was so use to it from my old access point. After the initial setup though, you don’t really need to touch any settings. As I mentioned before, you control everything through your phone, if you need to change anything or check the status.

Future Wish List:
There is a pretty nice looking speaker on top that I heard during setup. It would be cool if this could be used in some other ways, other than just for setup. Maybe a future update?use that. 5) No administrator password to remember or gateway ip to remember to update settings. You control everything through your phone, including adding additional managers to administer the device. Although, I haven’t actually had the need to use this, it might come in handy to help a friend or family member if they had some questions. 6) It looks nice enough that I don’t need to hide it in my TV stand and can leave it out in the open. Why you may not like it: 1) The OnHub only has 1 Ethernet port, where as my old router had 4. While I thought I would miss this early on, I actually found that connecting all my devices via WiFi just seemed so much simpler and cleaner. If you need more ports for wired internet access, you will need a switch. 2) There is no web interface to administrate the device, but I didn’t really miss it. Well, okay I will admit I did at first, since I was so use to it from my old access point. After the initial setup though, you don’t really need to touch any settings. As I mentioned before, you control everything through your phone, if you need to change anything or check the status. Future Wish List: There is a pretty nice looking speaker on top that I heard during setup. It would be cool if this could be used in some other ways, other than just for setup. Maybe a future update?
Positive Examples.output: OnHub is a pretty no nonsense type router that just works
Positive Examples.explanation: Give review is very positive in nature and user has liked the product and given title  is based on this review.

I am quite happy with this purchase. It fit my MacBook Pro perfectly, with a little bit of room to spare.

If you are looking for the top all-round professional workstation card for design and engineering projects then this is it. This card is the fastest Maya card you're going to get your hands on in 2010. It is as fast or faster than AMD's $3000 [[ASIN:B0043D2O68 ATI FirePro V9800]] in most benchmarks. Hardware wise this is essentially a slower version of the [[ASIN:B004BDOR74 GTX 580]] with less CUDA cores and 4 times the memory.     I docked 1 star from my rating because of the price. For $160 you can buy an [[ASIN:B003N19VUS ATI FirePro V4800]] which will get you 38-40% of this card's Maya speed at normal resolutions for only 4% of the cost.

The keyboard is slightly difficult to use especially at first, but what can you expect for how small it is. Very well made and the design is great. The USB adapter that comes with it is for apple products i believe. The thicker connector, not the standard android blackberry one that is slender, but you can buy the adapter for 1-2 bucks on amazon if you look hard enough.

You're not gonna write novels probably, but its a protective case and can minimize screen fingerprints. I like using a keyboard even though ive gotten fast at typing one letter at a time like everyone else with touch screens. I can type 70-80 wpm from a regular keyboard and i believe i could probably do 1/2 that on this little guy with a few more errors.
With that said, i like being able to push a button to get out of a screen, if its not obvious, like on a computer. Also, i like being able to press enter to submit and tab through filling out forms. If you use computer messaging services, this would work good for that.

If you've had these devices long enough you realize it can get frustrating to tap on a box to enter data as it can prompt you to a zoom function. Not a big deal and we've all gotten use to it, but hey for 20 bucks for something to make it easier? Count me in. Very happy with this product, but trying to jam a 7" kindle fire hd into it with a slightly larger footprint pushes it just past its design limits, but i make it work. Kindle fire keyboards sell for about 50 bucks when you can find them.
Decent graphics board.  Works fine on my Win 8.1 media center.
Fits computer perfectly just shorter than my old cord

[[VIDEOID:94fdb1db059605a96b157a80dfec0cb3]]I am very happy I got this unit and a $50 Nanostation to extend WiFi for a client to their campus. It came with a mounting bracket I did not expect. It ended up being a very lean and professional install thanks to Ubiquity. My client now has a sirGateway, Picostaion, and nanostation, and can get WiFi everywhere in their 3 story 4000sqft house. the Picostations serves WiFi to the rest of the campus, and the nanostation allows the neighbor to purchase internet, and use it for their kids homework. Thank you Ubiquity  $10 POE injector: [[ASIN:B00HXT8LPW Ubiquiti Networks POE-24-12W POE External Injector]] $72 Picostation: [[ASIN:B00HXT8L4S Ubiquiti PicoStationM2HP - Wireless Access Point - AirMax - 802.11 B/G/N (PICOM2HUS)]] $45 Nanostation:[[ASIN:B00HXT8FFI Ubiquiti NanoStation loco M2 - Wireless Access Point - AirMax (LOCOM2US)]]

Instances.input:
I was a little wary of buying this keyboard because of the fluke reviewers that received a DOA keyboard. I just opened mine out of the box, added 2 AAA batteries and am up in running in no time! It is a great lifesaver for the iPad. I don't know how I got along this far without having a keyboard for the iPad (I use it as my main computing device at home).

It sits very soundly on a table and feels very sturdy. The silver case is plastic, but looks *almost identical to metal. I don't experience much of a delay in typing to screen. It is just miniscule. I wouldn't let that factor scare you away from purchasing this. I like the extra function keys at the top - very similar to the apple keyboard with the iTunes short cuts and volume and brightness.

It is definitely a 5 star $20 product.

Only downside is I might have should have bought a keyboard that has a stand for the iPad or turns into a case for the iPad, but for my at home typing purposing I can just prop up the iPad .

...it looks great but some of the tree base got caught together and had to be very carefully unwoven to get the decal to apply correctly. Minor irritation. Overall, I love it and my little girl loves it also.

I received the Kindle as a gift and wanted something to protect it so that I can throw it in my bag and go. This is perfect! The clip, on the spine, locks the Kindle in perfectly. The strap on the outside of the cover keeps it closed. I also secure the strap across the Kindle when I have the cover open. The leather is very nice and soft and the velvet on the inside of the cover keeps the Kindle protected. I ordered the pink and it is a very bright hot pink. Very satisfied with my purchase.

I recently purchased an iBook G4 on ebay, with only 256 mb of ram.  I purchased this 512 stick, a bit nervous that it wouldn't be enough being that I could have got a 1 gig stick.  However, it has worked out to be more than plenty and seems to be very quality.  I've had no application instability since, including battery, plugged in, and hot conditions.
Solid, light, comfortable sleeve bag made from strong material! My notebook can't be beared without it! Good for price-quality feature!

Edited to say - Amazon is claiming I have not returned this, yet they did receive the case that was in the same box as the two kindles. I have now been on hold with customer service in what sounds like India and they have no clue on how to help.    I really wanted to love this. I have had apple products for years, but wanted to purchase a Kindle for book reading. I had no idea that these flash/flicker with each page turn - especially when there are pictures in a book. I tried to get use to the constant page flickering and even had a replacement sent, but it did the same thing. Sometimes I would have to repeatedly press the page turn area. I liked the feedback given by the device upon page turn, but after using an Apple touch screen, the lack of responsiveness was frustrating. I also wasn't sure that the backlit kindle would protect my eye much over the iPad.  However, Amazon was amazing with their customer service throughout this all. Exchange and returns were excellent!
output: Too much flickering and lack of touch screen responsiveness for this iPad user

Instances.input:
After about a year and a half my OEM battery on my XPS was only charging up to about 60% (and getting worse every single day). I knew I needed a replacement but I'd rather burn the laptop in a fire than give any more money to Dell. So I came to Amazon looking for a compatible replacement.

I have no complaints. The battery charges quickly and powers the laptop for a good 2-3 hours under normal use (browsing, movies, etc). I did get the warning that it is not a compatible battery when I booted up the machine. But it works fine anyway so I went into the BIOS and disabled the warning. I don't remember exactly what I turned off in the BIOS but just drop me a question here if you want to know and I'll retrace those steps.
Adds the right amount of flair to my tablet. Fits my personality.
It's amazing I was able to download 90 GB from my PC to the outside portable  drive in 15 minute. Normally would take ne 11 to 14 hours. Amazing!!!!
Might just order a couple more for friends, so easy and I love the way it stays on for reading
looks like it is all good

I was hesitant at first to buy the Buffalo Link-station, but thought for the money if it worked at all I would be happy. I really have to wonder about how critical some people can be. Everything worked the way I expected. I will admit the instructions are practically worthless, but if you go through the software setup, the install is very intuitive.

Install the drive the way the quick set up recommends, then throw away the instructions. Load the software and go to the browser IP address for the drive. Log in as Admin and set up your shared folders and users. If you have trouble, just Google the answers. After setting up the users and the shared folders, the rest is obvious and easy. I love how quiet this drive is - I don't even know it's there. I would buy another one in a heartbeat.
Good long lasting wire
Perfect fit

This was a great router, until about a year after I bought it. I woke up one morning to find all the lights on the router on, and I tried every way there was to reset the router to no avail. I thought that maybe this was just a problem with my router, so I recommended netgear to a friend who bought a newer version of the same model. His died about 3 months into using it. Go with linksys.

fast shipping, excellent price, simple keyboard. Plugged right in and started working. The keys are soft but feels nice on my fingertips. The color and size are not a problem like some are talking about. Highly satisfied.

I tried another similar \\"third-party supplier\\" product that wasn't included under Prime shipping. That was a nightmare. Fixed now, thanks to Amazon. This cover came very quickly and is excellent in all respects. I was very pleasantly surprised how supple the leather is (but the case itself is more rigid and protective). Fits perfectly. Soft interior to protect the Nexus. I definitely like the auto-on/auto-off function. Only time will tell how user-friendly and durable it continues to be. Not sure what the warranty is -- hope I don't have to care. Appears well worth the slightly higher price.

UPDATE #1:
After using the case for roughly a week, I've found it's still generally a very good product, but it also has an annoyance that I'm having trouble getting used to. To retain the tablet securely, the cover wraps around the front of the Nexus slightly, and in doing so covers a small part of the screen edge. That, plus the thickness of the material covering the edge makes it difficult to sweep your finger all the way to the edge (as in moving apps from one home screen to another). This is sufficiently troublesome to me that I've downgraded my rating from 5 to 4, and have just ordered an \\"official\\" case (since it's finally available) from Google Play. That cover appears to be less intrusive. But after checking with Google, that case apparently doesn't include the magnetic on/off functionality that I like very much. We'll see how it works out after some use. Maybe someone will eventually make a cover that incorporates all these features. This is why I'm not usually first in line for a new product. Still learning, but very impressed with the Nexus itself.

UPDATE #2
Truly exceptional customer CARE -- not just service. Florence from PC Micro Store called me in response to my comment, to make sure I was using the case as intended. I am. It seems a stylus is about the only solution for me to be able to consistently and easily access the full screen (to the edge to move apps). While that's less than a perfect solution I'm going to be shopping more at PMS because they are the kind of organization I like to deal with. And don't be too surprised if there's a second generation case that comes along relatively soon that gives full face access. By the way, the warranty on the case is full lifetime.
Great Product! Hot Swappable and you are good to go! There is no difference from OEM on this American Battery Replacement

If you're looking for something to replace your Klipsch speakers with the broken cord then you will be disappointed with the lack of low end and indistinct low-mids, but these are still a great pair of speakers. $30 was all that I was looking to spend and I don't think I could have found a better pair in that range.

Pros: lightweight, overall good sound
Cons: 3.5mm cord is built in. After suffering broken cords with other speakers I'm wary of non-replaceable parts but no trouble yet.
output: Got these on sale for $30 and was worth every penny

Instances.input: Have been using this for over a year & it still works great. The low profile keys take some getting use to, through. My main reason for posting this review is to point out that this is one of the few (less than 10, I believe) USB keyboards with actual N-key rollover. It is also still resistant meaning it is designed in such a way that liquid is channeled away from the circuitry & out vents on the bottom of the board to prevent damage. These features alone make it worth that price in my opinion, highly recommended!
output: USB keyboard with N-key rollover, spill resistant, built solid as well.

Instances.input: This range adapter works great.  I have not had any problems using it so far.  It picks up a great signal for me to use throughout my house.

I ordered 5, and only one of them failed the sector test before I put them in my iPod minis.  I sent it back and got a quick refund from the seller.  I'll definitely be buying more of these as soon as the need arises!
Excellent piece of equipment.  Works like a CHarm.  The only negative is the plastic component on the end of the Variable Speed switch comes off easily!

Received cover within 2 days of order (granted, I live in Phx and it was shipped from N. Las Vegas).  Price was certainly great, so great value.  Case seems well designed.  It's light weight, so it doesn't add much to the tablet. Fits my new TF700T perfectly.  Camera lenses are a perfect fit, as are the speaker, front facing lense and power connection.  When the case is closed, the power connection is still left exposed so that it is easy to plug in and re-charge.  Tablet slides in and out easily, but there is a protective flap to keep in nicely in place.  Leather is of suitable quality, with a cloth-swede lining which seems to be just right.  Top flap folds in half and slides into little slot which acts like a little stand.  Not sure I'll use that functionality, but it's there for those who want it.  My only complaint...and it is very very minor...is that when reading in portrait mode, you have to hold the back cover such that it doesn't flop open.  All-in-all, it's a really nicely laid-out product at a very reasonable price.

To preface this review, I had this thumb drive for quite a while, and carried it around with me everywhere on my keychain.    But that's still no excuse for the case simply disintegrating in my hand. I pulled on it to remove it from the USB port on my computer and the case came apart into 4 different pieces. The actual drive is still completely functional, but it's too fragile to use in the way that I want to use it without the casing. I'm going to be purchasing a [[ASIN:B001BAW7P4 Super Talent Pico-C 8 GB USB 2.0 Flash Drive STU8GPCS (Silver)]], and I hope I'll have more favorable things to say about its durability.

Great product.  would be nice If I could use this to charge my tablet also, but I am using this with a Dell Venue tablet and this lets me plug in an external drive without any issues.  I was able to plug in an external DVD drive and it recognized it right away.
output: affordable USB adapter for your tablet

Instances.input: I just purchased my first Macbook Pro and wanted to protect my investment. I looked at multiple hardshell cases, and decided this was the best deal. The shipping took around a week and a half- not too bad for free shipping. I thought it came with instructions, but even without them, it was very simple to snap on the top and bottom shells. \\"You need a what?  Why do we NEED a home server?\\" is what my wife asked incredulously when I told her I had to have the EX470 MediaSmart Home Server.  If you're like our family, you have more than 2 PCs (we have 6 PCs, 1 media center, 2 XBOXs, and 2 MP3 players) and your music, photos, and multi-media are spread throughout the network.  You also have never done a single backup of any of the PCs in your house and you're one hard-drive failure from losing those precious moments.    The HP MediaSmart Home Server, based on Microsoft's Home Server Edition is not your plain-vanilla backup drive.  Instead it has some killer features:    -  Speedy, intuitive setup in a great looking machine (took me literally 10 minutes to setup)  -  Automatic backup with optional folder duplication  -  Hot-pluggable storage allows you to expand storage up to 16 terabytes on the fly (we have 1 terabyte)  -  Login remotely and upload/download files from anywhere  -  Access other computers on your network remotely (like Go-to-My-PC)  -  File/media serving and print serving (centralize your media and access it from any device)  - Setup a domain in a few clicks so you can share your folders with friends and family over the web  - Monitor all your PCs for security...you will get alerts if antivirus or the firewall aren't working  - Extensible \\"Add-ins\\" allow developers to build and offer (usually freeware) some cool features like remote management, mobile access, and dozens of other custom applications  - You can also sign-up for internet storage and backup your Home Server automatically (for additional safety) to offsite providers for as little as $5/month for unlimited storage    Overall, I consider the Home Server to be a breakthrough in home technology.  There's no other backup drive or NAS on the market that offers the breadth of features or extensibility, in a centralized and automated fashion (for those lazy home administrators).  I am really happy with this purchase and particularly happy that all of our family pictures are finally safe from hard-drive failure.  I heartily recommend the MediaSmart Home Server.

I figured I should review this item because the reviews seem so mixed. Some people report problems, others say it installed in a snap.

Well, it installed in a snap on my machine and my mother's. We are both running Windows XP sp2. Before installing, I made sure to do Windows update, and installed all non-critical updates and driver updates, as well as the critical updates. I'm wondering if people who are experiencing problems are running older versions of MS Windows, or if they haven't done the latest updates from Microsoft.

My mother lives 2000 miles away, and is technically challenged. We used XP's Remote Assistance feature so that I could remotely go into her machine and do all the updates. I downloaded the latest Logitech software for the camera from their site, and also loaded that on my mother's machine. After the reboot, mom was on her own to plug in the camera and follow the screen directions. Okay, I was actually on the phone with her while she did it, but it went okay with no problems.

I'm having a little problem with my HP All In One scanner/copier/printer since installing the Logitech camera and MSN Messenger 6.2 -- sometimes my computer would freeze when I try to print. I don't know which is causing the conflict (camera software or MSN Messenger) and have temporarily stopped using that printer until I have time to look into it. My other HP printer, a LaserJet, is working perfectly. Mom has an HP photo printer and hers is working perfectly as well.

The microphone is very sensitive, so we have to use headphones when we have an audio conversation or else there is feedback. Moving the speakers to point away from the microphone did not help. The microphone is great, though. I had an audio conversation with a friend using another brand of microphone, and the first syllable of almost every sentence he said was lost. Not so with the microphone in this camera. The sound is really good.

Mom and I chat on Messenger almost every day, and we use the web camera about once a week. For the past 40 years, she and I have always lived less than 20 miles apart. This web camera is making a big difference in helping us make the adjustment to being so far apart. I highly recommend it. Phone calls are great, but nothing can replace seeing the smile and laughter of a loved one in real time.

This has been an excellent keyboard so far! I wanted a mechanical keyboard for gaming that was less "clicky" than my last mechanical keyboard (Tt eSPORTS The POSEIDON Z). The responsiveness of the BlackWidow is infinitely better with no ghosting that I experienced with the Tt keyboard. I am not a keyboard buff and before my Poseidon, I was using a membrane keyboard. I did search for a while before settling on the Poseidon, but after ~2 months of use I started getting pretty extreme ghosting and the spacebar would hang and repeat at least twice for each press. The BlackWidow does not suffer from any of those annoyances and has been a remarkable keyboard so far. The only complaint that I have for this keyboard is the built-in headphone support, which I don't really need, but it makes my turtle beach headset sound tinny and produces an audible background noise for others when talking on TS or Skype. Moving my headset to the case or on-board connectors resolves the issue. I may be unique in my experience with the keyboard headset input, but if I needed the inputs it might be a deal breaker. Since they are not important to me, I'll continue with this keyboard until I am ready to try another.

I gave this product such a low rating because of a major design flaw that led to damage to my kindle screen. There are some things that are good about it. For instance it is lightweight and fits snugly on the device. It also serves well to protect your screen while inside you bag or purse. The problem is that when you use the flap to prop the device up to watch a movie, the flap is not really strong enough to support the weight of the device in a stable position. As others noted this is especially a problem on counters or wood tables. I had this happen numerous times over the past year causing my kindle to fall flat onto the table, an annoyance but nothing terrible...until today. I was watching a video when the case fell causing my kindle to fall onto the floor face first with the case open. Now my screen is cracked and Amazon is charging me $135 to replace it. If you are considering this case I would look elsewhere as there are more protective cases that are cheaper than this one.

I ordered used modem in July 2013, it came with new unused ethernet cable, power cord and modem in open box. No manual or documentations. Well none was needed. I simply plugged in cable and laptop on one end. Opened browser and automatically reached comcast activation screen. Now this part was easier than getting rental modem from comcast itself. All I have to do was enter account number and phone number on activation screen, click next ---> next ...Comcast detected mac address and found the account and went ahead with activation and within couple minutes this modem got activated. Voila!! how easy can comcast make it. Did quick speed test and 27MBps Download, over 5Mbps upload speed, can't beat that.

Feed back from other reviews: Some user complained issues with comcast well I must say that is not true. First try first time flawless activation of used modem without having to call comcast customer service.

I highly recommend this modem if you are switching to comcast and always have your own wifi router seperate from modem, previously I had used rental modems from comcast and those worked but not as flawless as Arris WBM760A.

I have a love/hate relationship with this case. I love the fact that it works better as a stand that the Apple SmartCover, and that's the primary reason I purchased it. I use my iPad at my desk during the day as a secondary computer, and the stand withstands presses on the screen much better and does not fall over. I also love that the stand works well on the arm of a couch and other areas. When you carry it, you can have a couple of fingers in the circle around the Apple logo for extra carrying support.

What I dislike is that the magnetic part of the cover is hit and miss, and just walking around with it can turn the screen on and off again frequently. This causes unexpected battery drain, so if you are walking any significant length with it you definitely want to use the elastic to keep it shut. Even then, since the magnet is hit and miss you still can have the on/off thing happen. The case is also fairly bulky. Lastly, to just open the case and hold the iPad to read is awkward because you end up with a long flap of case to deal with. You can fold it under, which just adds to the bulkiness. You can let it stretch out behind, which then becomes difficult to manage.

Instances.input: Well, the thing does work, so it get's marks for fulfilling the basic requirement of added USB ports.    The blue light that Belkin sells as 'a unique design element' is plainly absurd. Why does a USB port need 2 lights on it? Why would anyone want their desk lit up blue - you can't read by it although it's bright enough to be annoying. It's a waste of electricity, albeit small, but really, do we need big lights on a USB port?????  It's the dumbest aspect of this thing and I wonder what the heck Belkin was thinking, not to mention the jerks in marketing that thought 'unique design' by having blue lights on it.  Anyway, from a functionality perspective, I get error messages all the time 'there is not enough power in the USB source, plug in for more power', when it is actually plugged in, so that's annoying.    The unit could feature claps or hooks so you could hook up to a wall. I use tack putty to keep the thing secure on my desk.    Would not buy one like this again.

PROS:
+ Excellent performance.

+ Relatively small form factor.

CONS:
- Pricey.

A good and consistent power-line adapter, but other that are cheaper and do the same job can be found like this TP Link here: http://amzn.to/1LespXo

Mouse is of good quality, looks nice, the box is full of information and basically serves as the manual. First thing I noticed was that the USB plug is gold plated, something you usually only see on more expensive mice, so that's nice. The drivers took a while to install; I let Windows update find them. The double click works sometimes, which isn't a big deal for me. Buttons have a good sound to them, if a bit loud. Now to the weird stuff: the DPI button. When you press it, it flashes a blue light a certain number of times at a certain speed, which is just weird. Mouse performs well at the highest DPI. The box says you can increase the polling rate by pressing the left, right, and \\"rolling\\" buttons at the same time for 5 seconds. I assumed that the rolling button is the scroll wheel and tried it. There was no indication of it working or not. The mouse is right-handed, so don't buy it if you're a lefty. I like to hold mice with my thumb a bit further forward than most people, but the mouse doesn't really accommodate that very well, as the thumb \\"well\\" ends a little less than an inch from the front. Have not used in any games yet. Overall, I would definitely recommend this to anyone, as it has a lot of features and is only the cost of feeding 15 5-year-olds small fries from Mickey D's.
output: Lots of features from an off-brand.

Screen Protectors - Nobody Likes putting them on. It's always a dicey proposition, and sometimes it feels like it's at least as much luck as skill. Tech Armor decreases the "luck" part by providing you with an excellent product. You can step up your part by following one piece of advice I have seen them mention in comments here but Not in the instructions.

" An easy way to avoid bubbles caused by dust is trying to install the product in a humid environment (i.e. Bathroom with the sink or shower on to create steam)."

An excellent addition to the application process - the water in the air removes dust and particulates from the air.

The result is a smooth and professional application of a tough, protective coating. Well done Tech Armor, and, with a little attention to detail, my fellow users would be hard pressed to find a better screen protector for their device.

I bought this to replace a failing EVGA video card that cost almost twice as much in March 2012 (and lasted less than 1 & 1/2 years with no over-clocking). My last card scored a 7.6 on the Windows Experience rating which was the highest rating Windows gave at the time. This less expensive card only dropped it to 7.3. I tend to go over-kill on my computer parts and rarely play graphic intensive games and rarely do a bit of video editing so I'm sure this card will be more than enough for me (just hope it lasts longer than my last one). The HDMI out appears to be full size rather than a mini needing an adapter, I'm sure this will be appreciated when it is time to replace my monitor (and possibly switch it out with a television). I have only had this card a few days but other than a couple of install issues have had no problems so far.
As far as the install issues there are a couple of things to know. I run Windows 8-64 bit and when I first installed this card I thought it was defective. I had a lot of flickering areas on my screen and Windows Explorer would crash every time I tried to open it. I was able to open Google Chrome and visit Asus' site to download the latest Windows 8-64 bit driver and everything worked fine (I suspect the install disk installed either an outdated driver or one meant for 32 bit). After installing the new driver and everything working fine I installed a Windows recommended update and started getting the same issues I had before installing the Asus driver. I re-installed the Asus driver, didn't check Windows for any recommended updates and everything has been working great ever since. If possible I would recommend downloading the driver before installing the card so that you have the driver to install after you physically install the card. Otherwise Explorer may keep crashing on you and you won't be able to download the driver or download another browser that can be used to get to the driver download.
One thing to know when visiting Asus' website for updates...it is a bit quirky. At the time of this writing you will have an option to manually search for your video card, have a program automatically scan for your card, or use a part # to find downloads for your card. When I tried the automatic scan I had no luck. When I tried to find it manually I found what I thought to be the correct card and downloaded a BIOS update I was told the update didn't match the BIOS series on the card. When I entered the part # (found on a sticker on the box) and did the driver download everything went fine. This card seems to be great for the money but if you plan on playing a lot of graphic intensive games or doing a lot of video editing and nothing but the best will do you may want to consider increasing your budget.

This worked for a few months, then just stopped working yesterday. Avoid.

I was previously using a MediaLink brand USB Bluetooth adapter to connect my Apple Magic Trackpad to my early 2008 MacPro because the MacPro has weak bluetooth and the trackpad movement would often stutter or completely cut out. That adapter just stopped working when I upgraded to Yosemite. I later learned that it is not compatible with Yosemite.

Instances.input:
Bought this headset to replace a much much older Logitech.
Building a new PC required all new accessories for gaming such as this headset. I went through a dozen possible choices before settling on this one and, I have to say, with the price and warranty considered; it's a good price for an excellent headset.

I have had no problems installing the software, it runs smoothly, no bugs or difficulties to speak of. It sounds loud, clear, and the surround sound is spot on.
The cord is long, very long, when you have to charge it up, so there's no worries about being stuck when the battery is drained. It recharges fast, within a few minutes it's back to fully charged and lasts 10+ hours.
It even turns itself off if there is no sound being played through the headset to conserve power.

The mic, from what I am told, is very clear. It picks up all voices and cancels out background noise (such as my fan or doors closing) so well that no one can hear excess noise. You can be a foot away or so from the mic and it'll still pick your voice up and not background noise.

I'm singing praises for this headset because I feel it is a perfect purchase for someone looking into gaming that may or may not require a mic.
For big, cinematic games, this headset is perfect. I can't hear anything outside it, people have to tap on my shoulder to get my attention when I have it on, but it's not so bad as to make you completely deaf.

I love it, I'm beyond happy with it, it's ability to register my games already installed and prepare a profile to make my own personal setting for them is more than what I expected.
Buy it with the warranty! It's worth those few extra bucks, because I don't want to lose this headset and a 2-4 year warranty allows the money you spend on this headset to really last!
output: it's a good price for an excellent headset

Instances.input: I bought my XPS direct from Dell.  I got the tough display, with dual core i7, 256GB SSD and 8 GB RAM.  Here are the Pros: Looks good and feels sturdy.  Aluminum and Carbon Fiber design is top notch.  First Dell laptop that I have owned that did not overheat...Score 1 for Dell.  Doesn't get the battery life they claim of 9 hours, but I get a goo solid 4.  Considering Dell battery life on their other laptops outright suck, at least Dell is getting closer to the numbers they advertise.  Decent port selection, but good have included a full HDMI.  No worries an adapter fixes that issue.  Screen is smaller than what I am used too, but nice.  I don't give a hoot about the 3200+ display.  Who actually uses that?  I got the touch display.  I love touch displays on Lenovo.  I have found them useless on Dell, unless you chop the physical keyboard off.  Why have an onscreen keyboard?  Again Useless feature that you pay a lot more for.    Now for the cons:  This is a very slow laptop.  My 2013 Lenovo with Haswell's i7 dual core kicks the XPS 13 butt.  I am having network problems.  drops network and is very slow on my network.  For instance it takes a long time to download webpages with images...So the Microsoft store is slow...It can't handle multiple jobs at once.  The speakers suck.  They are either too loud or too quiet.  No in between and they sound horrible.  The mic is useless unless you want people to see your hand or up your nose.  The Mic in my laptop doesn't work and Dell will not do anything about it.    And then there is the issue of Dell.  They have the absolute worst tech support and customer care.  The manager actually offered my $50 in grievances for having to deal with their own tech support.  They have done nothing to help me and they honestly don't care.  I have spent the equivalent of 5 days with them on the phone over the course of a few months on issues with this computer and others.    *************This is an update to my review above**********************  I updated all drivers and windows updates that I could find updates for and performance has actually declined.  Cannot stream music from youtube without the audio cutting in and out.  Cannot stream video.  Tried downloading a game from the microsoft store called Talisman.  Runs the game, but very choppy.  It is having trouble with the graphics.  The screen blinks in and out.      Overall, I am so disappointed with Dell.  I have purchased the XPS 13 and XPS 15 in the past 2 months and both have been riddled with hardware and software problems.   My Lenovo Thinkpad (2013 version NOT 2014) was the only computer that I have owned in the past 12 months that actually provided me with the performance and reliability that I wanted...    Read reviews on the XPS 12, 13 and 15.  After about 30 to 60 days the laptops seems to become riddled with issues that Dell doesn't seem to do anything about...Be careful when buying from Dell and be sure that you know what you expect and how to fix things if they break.  Its all on you.
output: Terrible product...Why is this getting rated so highly?

Instances.input:
I switched to this from the InCase case, after one broke on one of my macbooks and I could not replace it due to that cover not being made anymore.

Therefore I will use this review to compare the two, this iPearl cover and my "old" InCase Hard cover.

At first sight I thought that this new case looked cheap and flimsy but ordered one to see for myself (and lacking alternatives, really).

I have never been so wrong! The case is amazing!

Material:
It is super flexible - I tried twisting it a little before putting it on the macbook and it proves to really be sturdy, no cracking noises or anything. Doing the same with my old InCase cover it actually broke right away.

Case layout:
The heat dissipation is so much better than the InCase, as there are more cut-outs on the bottom and it seems they are located better, as well.
With this one the ports have one big cutout, not individual cut-outs, which enhances the usage experience.
With the old one the kensington lock for example had a hard time, since the cover was between the lock and the inlet.

The feet:
One thing I was very skeptical about were the feet. I thought them to be ugly looking, potentially falling out all the time and was already planning on cutting them off.
But they turned out to be very well made, disappearing in the bottom of the cover when not in use and very solidly arrested, whether expanded or collapsed.
They lift the aft of the macbook by about an inch or so when expanded, which makes for a comfortable writing position and also helps dissipating the heat.

The looks:
I chose the clear cover, as I got it for a white macbook and I like the looks of it. The visible color remains the original color of the macbook.

Weight and Bulk:
This cover is very lightweight and adds no bulk to the macbook. I am using a neoprene sleeve for it when out and about and the macbook slidesinto it way easier now, compared to the InCase case, that I used before.

Conclusion:
I am highly satisfied with this case!
I actually ended up dumping the (still good) InCase case on my black macbook and replacing it with one of these as well (also a clear one).
At first I thought it would make my Kindle look small but, I love this case! Its durable, sleek, makes my Kindle look like an ordinary notebook! Its totally awesome!

The only thing I would change, would be making the 3.5 mm cord a bit longer, but it's nice that it wraps around and stays out of the way. I will say that I think it works better when used inside than outside. All in all, it's a pretty good speaker for the price!

Instances.input:
This card comes already slightly overclocked with a 993Mhz core, reference is 925Mhz. They left the memory at the reference 5400Mhz. Unfortunately for overclockers Nvidia put the clamps down on overvolting their GK100 series of GPUs, but left it up to their partners to set the top load voltage on their cards up to their recommended limit of 1.1175V. Most video card makers have been shipping their 650 Ti cards at a 1.087V load voltage. Unfortunately MSI decided to set their load voltage lower at 1.062V. This makes it a bit harder to overclock.

If you plan on overclocking this card further get the latest versions of MSI Afterburner, GPU-Z, and Furmark (easier to use than MSI Komblaster); and the latest Nvidia drivers.
Since the load voltage is locked, the voltage control option in Afterburner has no effect on the GPU core voltage. I put the card under 100% load and monitored the GPU core voltage at both +0 and +100 offset; it never changed from a maximum reading of 1.062V. Also the Power Limit (%) is grayed out. This is because the 650 Ti does not have the Boost Clock feature.

But even with the locked core voltage I was able to overclock the core clock to 1223Mhz and the memory clock to 6600Mhz, not too shabby. I left the fan on Auto. After an hour at full load the fan speed was at 37% and the GPU temp was 51C, cool and quiet.

I'm ready to play some BF3 and Far Cry 3.
output: Best bang for your Buck but could use a bit more load voltage!!!

Instances.input: I don't often review products on Amazon, but I thought this one was worthy of it. Plus, it is giving me a great chance to test out the keyboard. I have had the notebook for about 2 days now, and am very happy with it. It's a solid piece of kit, very well build, and quite handsome. It is also slim, and light, which is exactly what I was looking for when I upgraded from my 1.5 year old Acer Timeline X. It is svelte enough that, at the software company where I work, I had several people stop by when it was sitting on my desk to ask about it, and declare that they want to get the laptop themselves. Also, working at a software company, we were overjoyed that the default browser loaded on the system was Chrome, and that it is relatively free of bloatware. 2 MAJOR pluses for Lenovo.   The performance is solid, although I also purchased a second generation Push2TV device from Netgear, and it won't connect to it. I am going to update all of the drivers on the machine, and see if I can get it to work, as I have tried a number of other solutions (difficulty in getting WiDi to work seems like an extremely common problem which is not confined to Lenovo devices after some quick Google searches).   Also, the keyboard is a touch cramped, a natural extension of the relatively small screen, but I wish the keys would run closer to the edges, and that the shift and ctrl keys were made a little wider. I have big hands, and I have found it virtually impossible to hold shift and hit the question mark next to it without looking down, because of how close the two keys are to each other. I invariably end up adding a \\">\\" instead of a \\"?\\". But I am able to type quite quickly on the keyboard, and I imagine that it will only get better as I get more used to it.  Also, as mentioned by the other reviewer, the battery life isn't great. I have burned through 4% of it just writing this review over the last 8 minutes. Granted, I like to keep my screen bright, and I am running a remote desktop client,with my CPU usage hovering around 30%, so that will naturally drain the battery a little more quickly, but my Timeline X has battery life that exceeds this computer's by miles.  Those are my main gripes with the machine. The build quality is impeccable, unlike what the other reviewer (the only other, thus far) noted, I don't have issues with noises when the lid opens and closes, and none of my keys rub up against the body. Hopefully mine is the more typical, or there will be some very unhappy customers out there.  The screen is bright and I find it to be quite attractive, while the matte finish keeps glare at bay. I also have been running fairly intense processes, and while the 4GB of RAM and 1.8 GHz of i7 doesn't make for the fastest beast on the block, for a computer this size, it is actually quite impressive.  All in all this is a very capable device. If you are looking for a slim computer, I don't think you can do much better. I spent some time with the Acer S3, the Asus UX31, The Toshiba Portege Ultrabook, and the Samsung Series 9, and am very happy that I chose the Lenovo. I like it far more that those computers. If you want to save some money, and need some more battery life, I was very happy with my Timeline X. If you want thinner and lighter, I don't think you will be disappointed by this computer.
output: Great product, though not without flaws

The aluminum external USB DVD Super Drive for Apple I purchased to use with my MacBook Pro. The reason why is that I have some DVDs--a television series--that the MacBook Pro internal DVD player was either stating it could not play or was playing and damaging areas of the discs. It came quickly and is easy to connect to the MacBook Pro.  No software, just plug the cable that comes with it into the USB port and to the DVD player and play. The external device opens the DVD player app automatically after I insert the DVD, or I can open the app first and insert the DVD.  Either way works well.  The device even skips over the damaged areas of the discs with ease and continues on to the next good segment.  The device is lightweight and so far so good with it being able to play DVDs and no damage.  Unlike the DVD player built in to the MacBook Pro in which a disc just sits in it, the external Super Drive has an inner circular slot to which the disc plugs in so that it is stable. Instances.input:
I don't use this for gaming--I am a student and write stacks of papers and do graphic design/ photo editing.

When I first plugged the mouse into the computer, it worked with the basic Windows 8 drivers. I was unimpressed. It had no speed to it, it was difficult to control, and got lost easily.

I went to the website and downloaded the driver (be sure you use the correct one, as they have both 32 and 64 bit drivers). (I use the 64.)

Wow. What a difference! The software allows you to alter the speed and pinpoint accuracy of this mouse. It has pre-programmed choices for the buttons, or you can create custom commands depending on your needs. I changed mine to basic paper-writing commands like copy and paste (for the side buttons) after I found my unique ideal DPI speeds.

I can see how gamers will LOVE this mouse!! Anyone who is stuck at their computer for work or school will love it, as it really does save time and works just perfectly.

It also looks fabulous. The cyclic pulsating blue G on the mouse is pretty tricked out and the design itself very futuristic. I am a 5'9" female and it fits my average sized hand just right. If you have large hands, this might not be the mouse for you.

I know gamers who spend much more than this on their gaming mouses and this one is much better than theirs.

I really recommend this mouse for any heavy computer user. Gamer or not, this can be customized for your needs (and the settings are easy to change, and also simple to return to defaults).
output: Best mouse yet!  Lightening fast, highly accurate: WIN!

Instances.input:
This is to share my experiences getting this card to work on iPAQ 2210 under Windows Mobile 2003 with 128bit WEB encryption.

As was mentioned a number of times the default drivers that come with the card do not work. Get the new ones from Linksys. All these new ones do is enable the default Windows driver.
Now comes the fun part. How do you get it to run 128 bit encryption. The configuration window looks like the Windows drivers were designed only for 64bit, this confused me for a while. Ignore the look though, just enter your 128bit key even though it looks like the \\"Network key\\" text box is too small to accept it and it should work. Seems obvious but took me a while to get to it. Linksys tech support did not know how to deal with this.

I researched range extenders before buying one, and the tech review websites very often warned that range extenders didn't work at all and that they weren't worth the money. After reading the Amazon reviews, however, I decided to give the Almond a try--and it ABSOLUTELY DOES WORK. I have mother-in-law over my garage, and without the Almond, my original wifi router barely permitted me to open my email on a laptop in the mother-in-law. Netflix could not be streamed at all on the Wii up there. After adding the Almond as a range extender, we now have full internet access and no problem streaming Netflix in the mother-in-law.

Furthermore, the set-up is ridiculously easy. I literally did it in less than three minutes, including taking the plastic off the box.

I've never bothered to write an Amazon review before, perhaps because I never thought my purchase so entirely merited a positive review. If you need a range extender, BUY THIS ONE! YOU WON'T BE DISSAPPOINTED!

It's a great mouse.  I bought it for my boyfriend and he loves it!  However, it stopped working after a few months.  Getting Razer to respond to how to get it replaced was a nightmare.  It took weeks to get to the point where we could send it back for a replacement. The replacement was a refurbished mouse that was broken from the moment we got it.  So then there was many more back and forth emails.  The worst part was Razer wanting us to pay for shipping back the second broken mouse they had sent us.  Thankfully Amazon made things right.  Thank you Amazon!  6/25/15 Update: The replacement, new mouse Amazon replaced this with worked great for another year or so. After that, random disconnects made the mouse unusable. Research found that it's a problem with the mouse starting to fail (tried all sorts of solutions, from bios settings to power settings for USB ports to trying different ports: nothing disconnects except the mouse, on any port).  When it works, it's a great mouse, but it seems they are built to last about 6-12 months from my experience (again, we've gone through three of them). Going back to another brand. Again, thank you to Amazon for dealing with this in a professional manner and sending us a new mouse–we feel we got our money's worth ONLY because Amazon fixed the situation with a product that quickly becomes faulty. Very happy Amazon Prime member!
output: This review is more about the awful customer service from Razer (and good service from Amazon)

I was really happy at first to get this card once I got my new phone back in may, that I actually ordered two, one 128gb and one 64gb card just in case I needed more than one for my LG G3. This card performed flawlessly for 3 months, and I had absolutely no problem with it until one day when I was recording a video my sd card just died. While I was recording the video, I felt my phone getting a bit warm, so I shut the phone off. Much to my surprise when I opened it back up, all the pictures and files saved on the sd card were gone.

I have tried various times to recover much over 500 photos that were at critical times in my life, but much to my dismay I could not recover anything from my 128gb Micro sd card. Eventually I was able to recover just the thumbnails, which were extremely low quality when blown up. I proceeded to put in the 64gb card to work as a backup, but I should've expected it to die out like the last one. So today it died out with not as many files on it, but I guess the card was such low quality that it couldn't even try to pretend like it was a real micro sd card....

In losing all my photos I have learned a valuable lesson to back up my files and to actually purchase a good sd card for my phone. I do want all my photos back, but there's nothing I can do about that now since my computer can't even detect a storage device when I plug in my cards (meaning that they're completely burnt). Beggars can't be choosers, but you can choose to not be a beggar by going the extra $10 and purchasing a real sd card, and not this piece of junk (which is non-refundable).
output: Just buy a real sd card

The male end (micro-USB) portion fits firmly into both of my devices, no risk of it falling out during normal use. This is very important. My last OTG adapter became loose and it corrupted my old Samsung phone's photograph folder, and I lost hundreds of photos.

The female USB portion uses gold plating, and is designed to have a very firm hold on your external USB devices. Another winning design feature.

I bought this tablet for a friend and helped him set it up since he's unfamiliar with android. First impression was that the tablet is well made, boots very quickly, apps launch plenty quick for my taste and doesn't come over loaded with a lot of pre installed apps you might not want and can't later get rid of.

On the bad side you have to look directly at the screen for it to be viewable. Even slight angles make the display invisible. There was plastic protector for the screen with instructions to charge the tablet a full 10 hours before use. It worries me a bit about the battery quality seeing as I've never seen such explicit instructions for any other tablet I've had.

Over all it seems like a good tablet for a low price with reasonable usable built in storage and fast enough to run most apps.

Needed an XP machine and bought the T61. On first boot up, I got the error message: TPM device unable to communicate... and so I followed the instructions in the on line help which indicated the TPM chip had been deactivated and I should go into the BIOS and activate it. Well, I did that and then the computer just beeped at me and did nothing else and was as dead as a doorstop.    Another defect is that as shipped, every time you load IE7 and first open a tab, there is about a 3 second delay which has to do with redundant security checking as configured by Lenovo. (There is a workaround posted on the Internet.)  I can't imagine what they were thinking to ship a notebook which throws in a 3 second delay every time you open Internet Explorer. I also can't imagine not turning on the computer before shipping it to me and seeing that error messages were coming up.    Finally, I purchased a 1 year onsite service agreement but the tech support personnel said they had no record of it even though it is clearly marked on my invoice and so they would not send a tech person out. Instead, they told me it needed a new mainboard and I could ship the unit back and wait for them to fix it.    Well, I summarize:    1) Purchased \\"ONSITE\\" warranty but the company refused to send a technician out for a nearly DOA machine.     2) As configured, there is an annoying 3 second delay every time you open a new tab in IE7.     3) Machine shipped with a defective TPM security chip and it appears the manufacturer never even turned the computer on to test the inital bootup and see the error message.

But let me tell you: Windows boots up in around 14 seconds, WITH START UP PROGRAMS loading in like 2 additional seconds... Saving huge CAD files (I work in CAD), takes 2 seconds, whereas before it took around 40 seconds...

The speed increase is phenomenal, you will never again have to wait for your hard drive. EVER. Programs that took 12+ minutes to install before, now install in less than 2 minutes... Highly recommend it.!

I've tried dozens of webcams now, looking for the widest angle webcam possible, and the Genius WideCam F100 is hands down the best I've found. Although several other webcams claimed to be wide angle, in practice I found very little difference between them. Logitech's wide-angle offering (the C930e, which I haven't tried yet) only claims a 90-degree field of view while the Genius claims a whopping 120-degree field of view.

We keep a 24x7 video link open between a main office and a satellite office using two large-screen TVs and a Skype connection (soon to be a homegrown WebRTC application). With normal webcams, we can see a small slice of the other office, but miss out on what happens unless the people are standing almost directly in line of sight of the webcam.

With the Genius, we are able to see almost the entire room on the other end, not just the narrow slice in front of the TV. We'll be buying a second unit to put on the other end of our video tunnel.

It worked out of the box on Ubuntu 12.04 with Skype and PulseAudio.
output: Widest angle webcam I've been able to find

If you are in the market for a wireless adapter for your laptop, BE AWARE that this one is easily bumped while moving the laptop around, sitting in an easy chair, amongst books on a table or desk, etc. It will lose internet connection and then you'll have to re-load your pages again.

I needed a wireless because after a middle of the night automatic Windows update (Windows 7), my computer was completely frozen, and after 'restoring to prior to the update, I no longer had the internal wifi. I spent HOURS AND HOURS trying all kinds of technical things and never got the wifi to work again. It became much easier to purchase an external USB adapter. By the time I gave up on fixing the internal wifi I had been without wifi for several days and was eager to just get back to work. So I did not read too many reviews. I went to radio shack, walking distance from my apt, and asked which one was a good seller with few returns and they pointed to this one.

Installation was quick and easy and I get fast enough connections but no one mentioned that because it sticks out a few inches it is subject to easily getting bumped if you move your notebook from room to room, or have it on your lap. Then you lose your connection and have to unplug and replug, and then wait for the connection to go through. Mostly this is not a terrible hassle, but sometimes, if you want to print something out and it gets bumped, then it becomes annoying.

I've had it for about 6 months now and other than the bumping, it seems to work just fine. If I buy another one it will be more compact in design.
output: gets bumped on the laptop too easily

Be careful. If you are buying it for a specific advertised capability, make sure it actually works. The documentation isn't reflected in the product. This is a home use product. I've been using it for a couple years in my home. If you just want a plug and play wifi router with better bandwidth than a \\"g mode\\" model, you'll be happy with this. If you want to used the advanced features such as filtering access from various devices -- laptops, iPods, etc., it might not satisfy you.  PROS:  -price, advertised capability, range, online customer support (technicians actually know the product vs. reading from a script), works well with my laptop 2ft from my microwave and 5ft from my cordless phone base station.  CONS:  -firmware limitations or bugs.  I have the router installed on the 3rd floor. I consistently get around 100 Mbps throughput on floors 2 and 3. I max out at 130 Mbps. On the first floor, I get around 60 Mbps (still better than \\"g\\"). I was using fw 1.10B13 and everything was fine until I tried filtering my son's new iPod touch via the MAC address. It turned out there was a bug in the MAC address filtering which was fixed in 1.10B19. I upgraded and MAC address filtering worked correctly, but now the LAN wifi client DHCP connection is periodically dropped and not restored until the router is reset. So I can either filter my sons access to internet or have a reliable wifi connection. My solution... time to move on to a different vendor's product. For $24, it is worth buying if you are using g-mode or no wifi while you get educated on what you want to spend \\"real\\" money on.  UPDATE: This is the same hardware as a D-Link unit. I downloaded and installed the D-Link firmware (Google for location & instructions) and I've been very happy with the D-Link firmware, more features and no bugs.
Good value.

Compared to my previous SSD (Vertex2) the octane shows very \\"robust\\" performance - no matter which type of data is written, performance stays the same. This can be a big plus when using encryption, as it basically kills the performance of SandForce based SSDs. The Octane meets my expectations in every way and so far has been absolutly trouble-free with the latest Firmware.

Another plus is the capacity of 128GB, whereas many other \\"120GB class\\" SSDs (like Agility3/Vertex3) only offer 120GB.

My Octane shipped with FW 1313 which is known to cause servere problems - so if you buy an Octane, make sure youhave to latest Firmware and if not update it and you will love this SSD.

I can't believe some of the other reviews on here about this switch. If you're a home user you should have no use for this device as it would be an overkill. I want to touch on some of the other comments.

1 - Yes only half of the ports support POE. Don't assume that they are all POE because it doesn't state anywhere that they are. If you look at the picture you can clearly see that the POE ports have the amber colored LED and are within the box that is labeled POE. Ratings for a product should not be based on your oversight of important facts.

2 - The switch is very quiet, well maybe not if you're putting it next to your child's crib. This is a rack mountable switch designed to support an entire small office. Anyone who owns a rack mount server will agree that the 8+ fans in their server will drown this out. A typical server runs about 70-80 dB while this switch is rated at 40.2 dB, which in turn means that a typical rack mount server is anywhere from 8-16x louder.

The powerful features, Cisco quality, and great price make this switch an absolute awesome device. Although not in the technical specs, this device does support LAG with LACP, 9k jumbo frames, auto voice VLAN, RADIUS, and auto MDI/MDI-X crossover along with much more.

So as soon as the parts arrived, I bench-tested my PC to confirm everything was happy. My board POSTs, got video, etc etc, but I noticed the fan on the power supply would not stay running. It's spin up very fast then slowly spin to a stop. I put the PSU aside and used one of my tester 350w units to power the board for initial configuration and such.

As I began getting the parts together to return it, something on the box caught my attention. Apparently the fans in these won't even spin up until it hits around 35% load or so. So I grabbed my kill-a-watt and did some testing. As expecting, during boot and all, I was pulling about 80 watts. I installed a game, cranked the settings up, and I saw it hit nearly 300 watts. During this time, the power supply was making all kinds of noises and heat was radiating off it. The game locked up, the fan never kicked in... It didn't smell too pleasant afterwards.

So here's hoping nothing got damaged trying to confirm this power supply was indeed bad... I've actually got another PSU almost identical to this one (about 1.5 years old or so). I plan on going back to it since it worked fine since I had it...

Hopefully this review will help others who are having problems connecting the USB DSC9 to IDE drives.

I have been building and working on computers for a long while and thought this device would be good for rescuing old data from old IDE drives. I had one laying around with old photos and music and the like that I would rather save than toss out as junk. So I bought the DSC9 as a solution. I read the brief instructions and hooked up the old formatted seagate ide drive that was the system drive to an old computer running XP, exactly as directed, placing the jumper on the master setting. My destination computer was my laptop, an I7 running windows 7. The drive was recognized but access to it was denied. Looking at the properties, the drive showed no volume information and 0 bytes used. Everything else said it was working, so I tried to force an update to that info using windows drive tools, no luck.

So in reading other reviews here on Amazon, I figured I was doing something wrong. I went to the tried and true method of elimination. I tried the cable select jumper setting and the slave jumper setting and still didn't get a read of the data I knew was on the drive.

Then I decided I needed to be more methodical. So this is what I did.

1) I rebooted my laptop each time before I tried a different jumper setting.
2) I changed the jumper select each time with the test drive unconnected and unpowered.
3) I hooked up the Sabrent to the test drive unpowered each time making sure the connections were solid.
4) I powered up the test drive and waited a minute before making any USB connections to the laptop.
5) Finally, I connected the USB cable to the laptop. I got test drive readability and function only in the slave jumper mode.
6) Everything worked and I recovered the drive's data with no further issues.

I've only tested this one drive, so I can't speak to other drive manufacturers, but I finally got the DSC9 to work with my drive. The jumper select seemed to make the difference. I would try it each way before giving up. One star off for the poor manual and website instructions which really didn't help and were written for the DSC5. I didn't bother to call Sabrent for help.
output: It worked after trying different jumper and connection methods

I find it, in fact,  to be a bit of an awkward novelty that has me using the  Sketchup's hand and orbit tools more often.  On average,  I'd say I'm using the 3D Mouse about 40% of the time.....simply because I bought it (as opposed to "once you get used to this, you never go back". Not true.)

The units are small and well made. When plugged in, it does not block the other outlet. It came with 2 units and 2 ethernet cables. It worked right out of the box. I plugged one unit into the outlet and connected it to my router with the ethernet cable. Router was located in my computer room. I plugged the second unit in behind my TV in my living room which was about 20 feet away. The indicator lights came on and both units were connected. I did not have to push the pairing buttons.

I connected the unit to my G-Box MX2 that was connected to my TV. It made a world of difference.

Initially the G-box was connected to the internet via wireless. I had problems with movies being buffered. The space between the living room and the computer room had water pipes, appliances, metal tubing, etc blocking the signal. After this hook up, I had no problems with buffering.

I do not have a fast internet. My download is only about 16mbps wired. In my computer room, wireless runs almost the same. I did try the G-box in my computer room and it worked well connected wireless. But as I said, wireless speed is not that good in the living room because of the interference.

I am happy with the setup. I might buy another kit to add internet to the back bedrooms. Another possibility would be to buy the TP-LINK TL-WPA4220KIT ADVANCED 300Mbps Universal Wi-Fi Range Extender for the back bedrooms.
output: This is for the TP-LINK TL-PA4010KIT AV500

This drive is amazingly fast, I almost wish I got the 500GB version.

I upgraded my Yoga 2 Pro which came with a Toshiba THNSNH256GMCT. It wasn't exactly slow, but I wanted a bit more performance and I was having an issue with the system randomly freezing for 5 - 10 seconds. Below is the CrystalDiskMark Scores for both the old and new SSD. I should note I have Samsung Magician installed, 10% over provision and RAPID Mode enabled, so this may be inflating the benchmarks. Update: Under USB mode, not detecting 2nd bay may be because of this:

A:Some distributions (notably Red Hat) turn offthe kernel option CONFIG_SCSI_MULTI_LUN [...]

You may check by this:

$ cat /sys/module/scsi_mod/parameters/max_luns
1

If it's one, you can write it with 2 or a larger value; then unplug usb cable and replug,
# echo 2 > /sys/module/scsi_mod/parameters/max_luns

or use scsi_mod.max_luns=2 kernel boot parameter;

[308138.709650] scsi 45:0:0:0: Direct-Access ST910006 40NS CC01 PQ: 0 ANSI: 5
[308138.712780] scsi 45:0:0:1: Direct-Access WDC WD16 00AAJS-00YZCA0 01.0 PQ: 0 ANSI: 5
[308138.713146] sd 45:0:0:0: [sdb] 1953525168 512-byte logical blocks: (1.00 TB/931 GiB)
[308138.716140] sd 45:0:0:1: [sdc] 312581808 512-byte logical blocks: (160 GB/149 GiB)

as the number shown above, under scsi_host45 as a two LUN device, without unplug/replug cable, you may also manually claim the 2nd LUN:

# readlink -f /sys/class/scsi_host/host45
# echo '- - 1' > /sys/devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:1d.0/usb2/2-1/2-1.1/2-1.1:1.0/host45/scsi_host/host45/scan

SCSI has standard REPORT_LUN command but the dock is unable to report lun by itself, driver has to assume 2 lun or more. (the Windows usb-storage driver and some Linux distro assumes default 15 could recognize all drives as multiple lun scsi device) (This should be the product firmware REPORT_LUN defect)

Instances.input:
Have had a total of five wired Apple Kbs.

They typically develop dead keys just outside the one-year warranty period. And this is not due to spills or other \\"abuse.\\"
In the last three months, three of our Apple KBs died. No more Apple replacements for me...

P.S.: Right now, I am evaluating Logitech K750 as a replacement. Looks and feels superior.

I've had this laptop for two days so far and it's a pleasure to use as well as gorgeous to look at!

It cold boots in six seconds and wakes up from suspend-to-RAM in two; the IPS screen is excellent and the i5 CPU, 4 GB RAM, and SSD give the system incredible speed. There are some downsides: I'm still getting used to the trackpad (no distinct buttons - a first for me), and it isn't quite as thin as the marketing pictures would suggest (though the listed product dimensions are accurate), but I think this laptop is a great deal for $800.

After it arrived, I booted into Windows 8 to make sure all the hardware was working. After specifically testing the function keys and the speed of restarts, I updated to the latest BIOS, disabled UEFI Secure Boot, and then installed Ubuntu 13.04 Desktop 64-bit from a USB flash drive. Another reviewer lamented the space lost to the pre-existing partitions (I found boot, efi, Windows recovery, Windows OS, and factory recovery), but I opted to let Ubuntu have the entire disk (minus a couple hundred MB for two boot partitions). After formatting, it gave me 117.3 GB total, with 4.5 GB used by the OS after installing.

Once I was running Ubuntu 13.04, almost all of the top-row function keys (e.g. sleep, keyboard backlight adjust, screen brightness adjust) worked out-of-the-box. The exceptions are that wireless enable/disable doesn't always seem to work and I haven't had a chance to test the video output selector. The screen auto brightness doesn't work, nor do the function keys attached to C, V, and Space (in the factory configuration those last three were attached to software bundled by Asus within Windows, so I suspect that I could configure apps in Ubuntu to respond in a similar fashion, but I have not tested this).

The Bluetooth, USB-to-Ethernet (using the included adapter), web cam, built-in mic, and SD card reader components have all also been tested and they all work well without any configuration.

If you're looking for a sleek, portable, Ubuntu-ready laptop which doesn't sacrifice power or break the bank, I would recommend giving this laptop a chance.

== 2013-11-02: Edited review to add comments after almost five months of use ==

This has continued to be a fantastic mobile computer for me. The performance of this laptop, coupled with its slim and lightweight nature, make this a very easy and plentifully capable computer to take with me on trips or to meetings.

It's not perfect: I've gotten more used to the touchpad, but it will still sometimes 'tap' when I'm typing on the keyboard and my palm brushes the surface of the touchpad. I think this is due to the touchpad driver in Ubuntu, and while I've tried a couple of workarounds I've not been happy with the results and have reverted back to the 'stock' Ubuntu driver configuration.

I have not yet tried Ubuntu 13.10, though I'm looking forward to giving it a spin after any \\"early adopter\\" bugs are found and fixed. :-)

As I said in my original review, if you're interested in a Ubuntu laptop I think you'll find this is a great option!

Pros:

Absolutely silent, and makes good use of the FireWire 800 port, transferring files and close to peak possible speeds. And with USB 3 it'll get even faster when I put upgrade my computer to one with that port, so it was a good future-proof buying decision for me.

Cons:

I use this with my Mac, and at first I formatted it using the application Verbatim includes with the drive. Within a day I started experiencing bad file accesses, and Apple's Disk Utility warned me the drive needed to be reformatted.

In all fairness, I can't say for certain that the problem was caused by formatting with Verbatim's app, and sure enough I was able to copy all of the files off of it before reformatting again, so no harm no foul, just some time lost.

When it came time to reformat I used Apple's Disk Utility, and ever since this drive has been working like a champ.

Bottom line:

Given its silent and efficient performance I would recommend this drive, with the caveat that if you're using it on a Mac you may want to format it using Apple's Disk Utility rather than the included Verbatim app.
output: Great, but if on Mac use Apple's Disk Utility to format

I was hoping, really really hoping... that the reviews here about it not working shortly after purchase were out of the ordinary. Sadly, in less than 48 hours, mine failed too. Heat, the awful smell of charred PCB and plastic. when i unplugged it from my PC, it was nearly too hot to handle. Closer inspection of the casing showed light deformation. The plastic shell has absolutely no vents on it, whereas my old N300 adapter has many slots for some airflow and heat dissipation.

I should have written this review sooner, to maybe save some people some money, or maybe have the manufacturer look into the heat problem. For what I paid for it, it's not even worth sending back for warranty.

BUT... if they can solve the heat problems, this would be a great option for those who need to use a USB adapter. Strong signal acquisition, great speed, and very affordable.

TL;DR: As great as the price is, still not worth it when it melts itself to a useless stick. Fix the heat problem and you have a winner.
