I have used a few of these drives for about a year. While they provide a lot of storage for the money, they have proven unreliable and very prone to data loss and crashes. Files get corrupted or disappear at random intervals. It appears to be due to poor cooling; they overheat after an hour or two of use and then become erratic, even when operated in well-ventilated and open areas. The only solution to keeping semi-reliable operation is installation of a large external fan blowing directly on the drives. While this works, it is a terrible kludge and indicates very poor product design. Mr Porsche may design fine cars but he apparently has no ability to design reliable computer peripherals.

Similar overheating and unreliability problems plague the 1 tb drives sold by LaCie.

The drives also do not spin down after a period of inactivity as do most other competing drives.

If you want durable, reliable storage I recommend you avoid these drives and go with other manufacturers.
output: Nice drive, hobbled by poor design

We had a data entry clerk at work that needed dual monitors on a Windows XP computer. Given the age of that operating system, our choices were limited in video cards that support Windows XP.

I bought the VisionTek ATi Radeon 7000 64 MB DDR2 PCI Graphics Card 900029. The card inserted in the PCI slot with no issue and the drivers installed from the included disc without incident.

The video card has two ports on it – one is a VGA port and the other is a DVI port. The video card includes an adapter so that you can connect a VGA cable to the DVI port if you need to. We’ve tested it both ways successfully.

The clerk has been using this card with dual monitors for several weeks now and it has worked very well for her. I’d recommend this card to anyone who needs dual monitors on a Windows XP computer.
output: Installed easily and works well on Windows XP SP3

Great features are:
- plugs for all buttons/ports to protect from water damage (along with the entire unit of course).
- an adjustable leather strap for one handed support. This swivles 360 degrees.
- a pop-out stand which has a bottle opener (nifty!)
- a clear plastic screen which provides protection for your screen. NOTE: my ipad already has a screen protector, and there is no problem with touch recognition for the screen with this extra layer of protection.

I am a very regular iPad user. As such, I have trialed many case and carrier combinations. This morphie represents my trials with the 'portfolio' school of thought of ipad carriers. as it turns out, i decided not to go with a 'portfolio' style solution for my ipad use, but even if i did, i'd rate this just 'ok.' Thw quality is fine, but nothing spectacular - better than the cheapest chinese junk to be sure, but not so nice that you'd impress anybody. it looks like something which you'd buy at officemax for $20, or $9.99 on sale. the material is reasonably stiff, and while it certainly provides some protection to an ipad (which actually need far less than people, including myself, instinctually think), it's not as nice as my preferred solultion (see last paragaph). however, it does take up less space than m preferred solution.

if you use an ipad in a work environment and you are one of the few people who don't habitually pass the ipad to other people, then this may be ok. but in general, it looks like something wit too many 'moving' parts that will get dirty and wear out quickly. i use the ipad for watching movies, too,and the way this morphie has a built in stand is ok, but for me i'd just as soon hold the thing. i have yet to be in a location where if i do want to stand the thing up to watch a movieat a distance, i can't find some small object nearby that will do the trick.

if i wanted a portfolio type thing, i'd spring fror one of the 'expensive' ones with nice brown genuine leather. and i'd want one that zips up completely (though there are few of those).

after some experimentation, i have concluded that the portfolio school is not for me. thest folder style things are just not useful for the sort of real life use for my ipad. rather, i have gone to a 3 pronged approach of a sheet of protective film for the front glass (everybody should have this), a rubber-esqe guard for the back not very sleek, but protects well and gives a good holding surface), and a neoprene netbook pouch (with suitcase like handles) to carry the thing - provides protection, is handy to carry, and has a pocket for connection cable / power block and cleaning sham).surface), and a neoprene netbook pouch (with suitcase like handles) to carry the thing - provides protection, is handy to carry, and has a pocket for connection cable / power block and cleaning sham).
output: It's ok, but I'm not using it.

The Belkin USB Serial adapter is GREAT for connecting radio programming cables to newer computers and desktops without the formerly standard serial port. This cable has a USB plug on one end and a standard 9 pin male serial connector on the other end. Be sure your operating system is 32 bit, this cable may not have drivers for newer or 64 bit operating systems. Before giving up search the Internet thoroughly for drivers, new drivers are added to the Internet every day (so if I say something is or is not available, that information will be outdated within a matter of moments...)

* This cable is NOT used to connect two computers - for that learn a bit more about networking and building a peer to peer network. There are much easier ways to do to this in the modern era, though, using a very inexpensive router and cat 5 cabling or wireless if all devices have built in Wi-Fi.

* This cable is NOT a monitor cable nor will it support HDTVs or video monitors connected to a laptop. For that you need to look into 15 pin video cables such as [[ASIN:B00030AXNQ C2G / Cables to Go 45138 Ultima HD15 Male/Male SVGA Video Cable (6 Feet/1.82 Meters)]]
output: Use with 32 bit operating systems, great for connecting radio programming cables!

I like this keyboard for all the reasons others have mentioned. Especially convenient are that its light weight, the keys feel good and give excellent tactile feedback, it mimics the Mac keyboard very nicely, and getting rid of the wire is a great boon in my setup. The one thing that you should be careful about if you should buy this keyboard is the on/off switch. It's tiny, plastic, and has a very short throw. It's best operated with a fingernail. I've had the keyboard for less than a month, and its convenience has just about paid for itself already. But I expect that the on/off switch might not last.

Recommended, with one reservation

Update:

I've discovered three more reasons to doubt the quality of this keyboard, and I'm subtracting a star. The bottom has six short anti-skid strips of rubberized material. If you're using the keyboard on a slick surface, they prevent the keyboard from sliding around freely, since the bottom itself is slick plastic. They come off. In about a month of use on such a surface, two have already let go completely, and the residue of glue, both on the keyboard and on the little strips, is not very tacky at all. I've super-glued those two back in place. Also on the bottom surface of the keyboard are two pop-out feet to give the keyboard a more comfortable typing angle. Unfortunately, they are pretty flimsy looking plastic. Use them, and unless you're very careful when you move the keyboard around, these feet would break off easily. Finally, back on the top surface of the keyboard, there's no indicator whatsoever when the caps lock key is on. You have to type something, and if it's in the wrong case, you have to delete it and start over.

Otherwise, the keyboard continues to function as it should. I still enjoy the Mac-like layout. But there are too many indications of shoddy manufacturing and lack of planning in design.

Still recommended, but caveat emptor.

Getting the stick out of the computer is no piece of cake either, it's very very tight, and I worry about damaging the computer.  Once it's in, possible error messages and pop-ups questioning my set-up are gratuitous; everything is just fine--copy the damned file, already!!  Finally, while I'm complaining, can I mention that when the drive is in place it throws up an advertisement on my desk top, which though no big deal is unwelcome.

This camera card allows you to upload photos from your camera direct to a WiFi enabled device, such as a tablet computer. It fits in an ordinary camera SD card slot. To use the card, simply stick it in the card slot of your camera and take photos in JPG format (not RAW). Download the EyeFi app from the company site (or from the Google store), and enter the code on the card case to pair the card with the software. Once paired, anytime you power up your camera and open the EyeFi app on the device to the app's homescreen, any new photos on the card will automatically be copied to your device. Once they are on your device, you can edit them using your regular editing apps and share via email or social networking apps, or you can share them directly from the EyeFi app.

I found this card quite simple to use, once I figured out what settings I needed to use on my camera. The card ships with no instructions, other than a note to download the app from the company website. From the app, you can follow the help icon to get further support and instructions from the website. I tested the card as a second card in my Nikon 7100. I usually shoot in RAW. To make the card work, I had to tell the camera to use card 2 as RAW+JPG (card usage), then tell the camera to save in RAW+JPG (file format; 2 settings with the same label, but doing different things--confusing, but that's Nikon's fault, not EyeFi's). Once I had the camera saving as JPG on card 2, the transfers worked flawlessly onto my Samsung Galaxy Tab. It was quite handy to have instant access to high quality images from my camera that I could share immediately in the field. The transfers are also useful for getting instant backups on the cloud, just in case something should go wrong with my RAW images on my main card. I also tested the card with a Canon PowerShot SX 210, a Nikon D90 and a Nikon D50. The card worked fine with the SX 210 and D90, but could not be used even as a regular camera card in the old D50. You can check the EyeFi website to see if your camera is listed as compatible with the card.

The speed of the transfers isn't exactly instant--they do take some time if your camera produces large files. And the write speed of the disk isn't blazingly fast. On the other hand, it's certainly fast enough for most purposes. The app is relatively easy to figure out. One handy feature offered in the settings menu of the app is the ability to load photos directly to an external storage card, which is essential if you fill the card, since many devices don't have 8Gb of storage available on the main card. I sure wish other apps made saving to the external storage card this easy. Overall, this card provides an inexpensive and easy way to make most modern cameras capable of sharing or transferring photos via WiFi.an check the EyeFi website to see if your camera is listed as compatible with the card.

Instances.input: Wonderful product, gets the job done easily

This was the only product I found that would hold the bluetooth keyboard. I really like it. Would be 5 stars but the keyboard can easily fall out when opening. I had never installed new PC memory before.  It was really easy.  I installed two 1 GB chips to upgrade my PC from 512MB RAM to 2.5GB.  I noticed improved start up time from the first time I powered up.  Improvements have been consistent over the last six weeks.

Drive: Compact, lightweight, handy, nice color, sleak. All that good stuff. I like this drive from the outside, for sure. But when I tried to connect my existing Seagate drive to this as an additional drive, since I already have so much data on it, but it did NOT work. Maybe that's an issue with how my seagate was formatted as opposed to how its needed for WD. I'm not sure. But so far no luck.  So I ended up connecting the Seagate to the laptop and used the software to backup the data from Seagate to WD. That works just fine.    Software: It Sucks. I mean, it works but I don't like how it sets up the data. You have to enter a plan name and then a drive name and then on the WD there will be a long tree of folders like Y:\plan_name\software_name\folder_name\backupDrive_name\data..... Its not easy to configure data back as I want it. Meaning it lets me select the folders I want to back up, but does not let me select how I want them to be arranged in WD. Basically it just maintains the same structure as my local drive.   So, I think instead of using this backup software, I might use something else, or just copy data directly to WD (Y:\). But if I want to use the auto backup feature, then I dont like how the data is arranged.    Performance: It works very well. I tried watching movies, but that was too slow, but I blame that to my super old Router. As for the WD drive, I like its performance, backup speed, copies of backup and so on. Plus since we can access our data through web interface also, I might stick to the backup software for now, for when I travel internationally. So, I can have access to my data. The web interface is not bad. Its fairly easy to use.
output: I love the Drive but not the backup software.

[[VIDEOID:moWGTFOX5Y3PP1]]I build a lot of computers and repair them for friends and I test a lot of USB battery packs, AC wall chargers, solar panels and car chargers. This is a perfect troubleshooting tool for anyone trying to test out how well their USB devices are working and charging. This is a very nice dual display unit that simultaneously shows both the charging voltage and current passing through it. The voltage is displayed in red and the current is displayed in blue with lit LED displays. The meter can measure voltage from 3 to 10 VDC and current from 0 to 3 Amps. You can use it to test your USB power sources, USB devices and how they charge or even test your charging cables themselves to see it they are working.

The meter has a 4 inch cable with a standard USB connector on it to attach to the USB power source. There are two output ports on the device. Output I is designed for use with devices that use combined charging and data cables like Apple devices. Output II is designed for use with Android devices that like to have two wires shorted together to boost the charging current and emulate that the device is plugged into an AC wall charger where it can draw the maximum charging current. Apple devices will charge in the Output II but in my testing they charged at a lower rate than in Output I. I just wanted you to be aware of the difference in the charging rates between the two ports and using the correct output port will provide you a better test result depending on what type of device you are testing.

I compare the unit to another LCD unit that I use and you can see how nice the colored and lit LED display is and how having two displays allows you to see the voltage and current readings simultaneously. The device is rated to be accurate to plus or minus 1%. I liked this meter a lot and the dual display speeds up the testing process. I do not have to switch a switch to read voltage and then current. The lit display is easier to read in bright light and in a darker area like behind a tower computer. This is a good product and it performed well in my testing and evaluation. It comes with a lifetime warranty from AboveTek. I rated it at 5 Stars.

I was supplied a sample for test and evaluation. A review was not promised to the supplier in exchange for the sample. My review is fair and honest and based upon my evaluation and testing of the product sample.ier to read in bright light and in a darker area like behind a tower computer. This is a good product and it performed well in my testing and evaluation. It comes with a lifetime warranty from AboveTek. I rated it at 5 Stars.

I was supplied a sample for test and evaluation. A review was not promised to the supplier in exchange for the sample. My review is fair and honest and based upon my evaluation and testing of the product sample.
output: Excellent quality and accuracy from a dual color display voltage and current power meter for USB ports!

I bought this case the day I bought my iPad 3 instead of spending $70 on the Apple cover. The case fits the iPad almost perfectly (it tends to slide, which can \\"hide\\" the headphone jack) and is pretty well built. The texture of the cover is quite nice, and it works well as a stand (though it does slip out every once in a while).

I do have a couple of issues with it. First, the magnets in the cover that are supposed to automatically turn the iPad on and off when you open and close the cover only work about half the time. I'm not sure if that's due to a change from the iPad 2 or what, but it can be a little annoying. Second, they put a \\"handle\\" on the inside of the cover that, while it won't scratch due to a soft material, does leave an imprint on the screen. Both of these are relatively minor issues and are easy to overlook given the cheap price.

Overall, I'd recommend it if you're looking for a basic case and don't mind having to push the \\"on\\" button yourself every once in awhile.
output: Good Case for the iPad 3 for the Price

My kindle fire HD became more and more difficult to keep charged so I updated to this HDX. so far I love it. It's faster and has more options. I'm still learning to use it and it is a little different than my previous one. I do use it a lot for other things than just reading books.

Yesterday I did a boneheaded thing. I fell asleep on the couch while reading a book on my Kindle. The Kindle dropped to the carpeted floor. That isn't the boneheaded thing. Waking in the middle of the night and stepping on the Kindle on my way to the bedroom. THAT was boneheaded. The display was shattered and, while it lit up, no longer worked as a touch screen.

Since I was in the middle of a book, and since Amazon couldn't immediately deliver the new one I was going to buy to replace it, I swung by my local Fry's and bought another. While registering the new Kindle I saw the broken one in Manage your Kindle. I'd forgotten that I'd added Service Net's 2 year extended protection plan. I re-read the coverage details and, Surprise!!!, the plan covers accidents. The plan description even mentions stepping on the thing.

So, still dubious, I called the plan's toll free number. I'm put into a phone tree for about thirty seconds, at which point a very friendly guy named Jason answers at a US-based call center. He asks for the email address used on my Amazon account, then the exact name on the account. He waits very patiently while I fumble around for a minute to find the exact name I registered by Amazon account under. Then, the name of the Kindle. I tell him. He sees that it has a protection plan in place.

Then he asks \\"What's the problem with your Kindle?\\" \\"Well, actually, I stepped on it.\\" \\"Oh, don't you hate that? Did the screen break? Touch screen doesn't work?\\" \\"Right.\\" Then he says \\"No problem, I can have a replacement sent out immediately. You should have it in two days.\\"

He told me that I had two options. If I agreed to let him secure the order with one of my credit cards on file with Amazon, he said the replacement out in advance. The card would only be charged if I didn't return the broken one within 30 days. I could use the packaging the replacement came in. He'd send me an email with a link to a postage-paid return label. Or I could send in the defective one and receive a replacement within two days of their receipt of it.

The credit card thing is standard on advance exchanges so I chose that option. Jason just asked me to confirm the last four digits and the expiration date on the card. Then he said \\"If you want to stay on the line another thirty seconds, I'll get the order placed and let you know when you'll receive the replacement. Still rather flabbergasted at the painlessness of the process, I waited the half-minute. Then our man Jason says \\"I'm sorry to say that, with the weekend, the new one won't be there 'til Tuesday. Is that OK?\\" This was late Friday night. \\"Yes. Tuesday's terrific!\\"

Now it's Saturday as I type this. I've obviously not received the replacement Kindle yet. (I'll update this review when the process is complete.) So far, however, this plan has been perfect and the process has been totally painless. No long wait on hold. No trying to communicate with someone in a third world call center. No need to find the plan number. They had that already. No need to find the serial number of my Kindle. They had that from the nickname I'd given it. And, best of all, no hassle at all for having stepped on the thing. The entire call lasted less than ten minutes and the rep was incredibly friendly.

I could not be happier.

Before I sat down to write this review, I took a look at the one and two-star reviews. There you'll read complaints that the plan is being misrepresented as a two-year plan when the Kindle comes with a one year warranty. None of the reviewers had actually purchased the coverage and, I guarantee you, none of them had stepped on their Kindles or dropped them in the bath. Service Net is very clear in the description of the plan that this is a two year extension to Amazon's one year manufacturer's warranty. I find the pricing for both the 3G and non-3G versions of the plan incredibly cheap. Really: I STEPPED ON MY KINDLE. BROKE THE CRAP OUT OF IT. THEY'RE REPLACING IT, IN ADVANCE, FOR NO CHARGE! Not even for shipping. This was a GREAT purchase! I highly recommend you add it to any new Kindle purchase.

[Note: this review is for the coverage on a non-3G Kindle. I just bought a 3G version and have added coverage to it based on my extraordinary experience with the non-3G coverage.]redibly cheap. PAID way too much for this headache. HP told us pay $400+ for repair. Labeled our problem customer damaged although they did admit no signs of external abuse shown.

Almost a few days after I got my laptop it showed a few dead pixels. We procrastinated in taking it in. Now it got so bad we decided to send it in since we owned it less than a year (got it nov. 2009 sent in March 2009). It has always just sat on my computer desk and almost never even closed it. They said it had an internal crack inside the screen glass and it was leaking and we would have to pay over $400 to repair. They claimed it was our fault, but this after the tech admitted there was no signs of external damage anywhere.

He said it would get worse, and sure enough as soon as it came back from their shop I now have twice the dead pixels I had before. I can't even see the right hand lower tool box anymore. I paid over $700 for this and although I have no problems with the performance (ASIDE from needing EXTERNAL SPEAKERS due to unaudible volume) ...their warranty was useless to me if they were going to reject any responsibility. I do however blame myself for not returning it as soon as I saw the first fleck of defective evidence....shame on me! don't wait take it BACK!
output: non honored warranty dead pixels low sound

On a general-use level read speeds are great and write speeds are OK. On a USB 3 port and no other I/O going on, writing to and then reading from 1,000 28MB files, I saw an average of 17.6MB/sec write and 115.9MB/sec read. This is not a carefully controlled test, I didn't do multiple iterations and average them, but it was done with a clean format before using it for anything else. Hope this data gives a general idea regarding what speeds to expect!

Well, since I own two 5.1 speaker systems, I wasn't sure what to expect from this one. I was very surprised. First the hookup. From what was posted on the product page, I wasn't sure how I'd hook this system up. On my two exsisting systems, you have wires that run from the woofer to each of the speakers and these wires are standard speaker wire with bare wires at the ends that connect to the woofer. This system uses wires that end in RCA type plugs that one plugs into the woofer. This works out pretty good if you have enough speaker cable to reach from the woofer to where you want the speakers to go. (I did notice that the front speaker wire lengths were shorter than the back speaker wire lengths so one would have to select a speaker placement that had this in mind. This did cause me a minor problem but it wasn't a major one.) I also wondered about how inputs to this system would work. On my other two systems, inputs are handled by plugging RCA type cables from the source to the woofer of this system. When I was considering buying this system, I couldn't at first figure out how the inputs were handled so I thought that the RCA to RCA plug route was how it worked. After I checked around a bit I discovered that this system truly is intended to be use with a Sound Blaster card as shown by the way the inputs are dealth with.
This system's input don't have plugs on the back of the woofer they just come out the back thru a gormet. The inputs end in 3.5 mini plugs that exactly match to jack on a Sound Blaster sound card. One covers L&R front, one L&R back, and one woofer and center speaker. This system plugged right into my SB Audigy card without any needed adapters. If you plan to use it with another sound card of some other output source then you might need adapters to do this.
This sound is prety darn good for a system at this price range. I've own systems that had 12\\" woofers on them and while this system can't match them, it does a really good job or handling what I throw at it. In fact, it's just to loud if I turn it up too far! The only thing I've run into were a couple of settling in pops and a bit of static that was taken care of by making sure the inputs plugs from the speaker were plugged solidly into the sound card's jacks. (This was one the thing I thought I had a problem with at first when I first turned them on, but that turned out to be one of the plugs wasn't all the way in the sound card's jack.
The only other thing that I feel needs to be mentioned is the location of the woofer speaker itself. This system's woofer speaker is on the bottom of the woofer's enclosure. So you really need to sit the woofer encloser on the floor to get the best sound, I minor point but I feel an important one. Also the woofer speaker has no cover over it so when handling it be careful not to touch the under side of the woofer encloser as you might damage the woofer.
Overall I think a pretty good buy!!

I've used only logitech mice for years and bought this on sale. It has a lower "hump" than the logitech mice, as well as being symmetric, so it doesn't fill my hand quite as much, but I have found it to be very comfortable for gaming.  I had to disable the pinky side buttons as I often press them and have just learned to ignore accidental clicks from them.  I really like the fact that the scroll wheel does not tilt as it makes the scroll wheel much easier to press down, vs logitech where I have to be very careful to press straight down.  The weight of the mouse is good and the cord doesn't bother me, which  I was worried about since I've been using a wireless G9 mouse for several years - the cord doesn't "push back" on the mouse as some do.  I game a lot but I tend to just stick with the basic buttons, so this mouse suits me fine, and while I installed the software I haven't done much with it.  Overall I was surprised at how much I like this mouse, and the only change I would make would be to remove the thumb/pinky buttons.

I purchased my first Kindle in 2010. In November 2011, I started having problems with my Kindle. Initially, it involved black lines on the index pages. So I was still able to read my books. Eventually, however, I started having problems on the books themselves and finally it stopped working altogether. I contacted Customer Service and since my warranty was no longer in effect -- BY ONE MONTH, I was told that Amazon would replace my Kindle for $85. I debated between replacing the Kindle or purchasing the new Kindle Fire. I finally decided to get the replacement for my Kindle since I basically just want to read books. I have thoroughly enjoyed my Kindle and the ease in purchasing books from Amazon. I also appreciate that Amazon offers free books daily.

The price of this unit is exorbitantly high, but if you have a laptop with a thunderbolt cable this is invaluable. All Thunderbolt docks cost roughly the same amount.

I originally purchased it to use USB 3.0 on my MacBook Pro that only has USB 2.0 ports. However, I didn't realize how convenient it would be to connect my external monitor, hard disks, ethernet connection and headphones - all with only one cord. Compared to other docks the front facing USB port was the selling point for me.

There are a few issues/concerns:
1) Ports do not provide high power. You cannot charge an iPad with the USB.
2) Thunderbolt is an old standard. Thunderbolt 2 already exists, although I could not find any Thunderbolt 2 docks. The Sonnet Echo, which was supposed to come out this summer, is supposed to be a Thunderbolt 2 dock, but it seems like it will never come out.
3) USB 3.1 Type C connectors should be coming soon. This connector will essentially replace Thunderbolt/Thunderbolt 2 since it has the same functionality. It also will deliver high power.
output: Best Thunderbolt dock, but not future-proof

As an IT professional I find Netgear's product quality to be, in large, utter crap. But every once in awhile they produce something I love.

Mind you, I am not using this switch in a commercial production setting, but in a home setting with a probably overly complicated network topology. That said, it replaced a much larger switch with extremely noisy fans with a unit that's barely bigger than the ports themselves, and draws a nominal 6 watts in normal use. All without losing the features I had to have, 802.3ad, 802.1q, etc.

It works, its reliable, and it's small and power efficient. Best home switch I've used to date.

The product looked great and was simple to attach to the wall - that was it.

When tried to connect to home gateway/router, keep in mind, you have to press the "wps" button on the Netgear Extender (in my case downstairs and run upstairs (in less than 2 minutes) and press the "wps" on the home router and wait to see if it connects. Luckily it did after my second try. From there it was a whole other world.

System appeared to be connected and working great. Connected my ipad and android tablet along with home security camera. Low and behold, a few minutes later - no connection (limited connectivity). Began to troubleshoot, reset my gateway/router several times, reset the Netgear Extender, after every reset, keep in mind, have to run downstairs then back upstairs every single time; everything again appears to work for just a few minutes. Tried to contact Netgear around 1pm cst. to my surprise, Netgear support online chat (OFFLINE). Wow, what a disappointment.

I have to say, the whole experience was terrible. Told the wife, sending back as defective (which it must be) and ordering the one I originally intended to order (Securifi Almond - World's 1st Touch Screen Wireless N Router + Range Extender (Booster)).

Hopefully others will be luckier.

First of all, let me say, based on the reviews here, I purchased the Core system that comes with the scout. I had thought that this meant I would NOT be charged the monthly fee as it wasn't the latest unit. I was wrong. I wanted this to replace my current phone company's local service - Century Link/aka Qwest... they were charging me around $28/month for home phone with no long distance service. I had some issues hooking this up as it turns out the wiring in my house was not done correctly but that did get resolved. I found out I didn't need the scout unless I wanted a 2nd line. I ported my phone number which Ooma charges $39.99 to do. What I do notice, and this may be because I'm on 1.5GB DSL, is that the service with Ooma in the evenings (when everyone wants to be online) is not perfect. I get intermittent times with dropped voice sounds... like every few words the sound drops out. During the daytime, especially mornings, it is fine. It is nice to have long distance for free. My monthly bill from Ooma is $4.15 or so which covers taxes only. I didn't have caller ID before, and that is nice. Like I said, you don't need the scout unless you want a 2nd line. I have mine set up so my home answering machine answers first. If I'm on the phone and someone calls, they can leave a message on the Ooma machine which I like. I would recommend this if wanting to save on home phone service... but buy the newer model - it's cheaper - if you only want the 1 line. If you want more than 1 line, get this one. The customer service has been good so far (India). The only way to save the monthly charge is if you activated your OOMA years ago and haven't changed it since. If you purchase a used unit, which was activated prior to the charges, you will have to pay to re-activate it and thus the monthly charge will happen.
output: Recommended for cheap home phone service, however the quality of sound is not  perfect in my slow DSL area....

New Trent keeps delivering solid case solutions that add protection and great usability improvements to your iPad experience.
This case is well designed into three parts that all come together easily to provide complete protection without sacrificing any usability. I installed this pretty quick, and really liked the new strap feature. I was able to hold the iPad Air with one hand underneath, and twist 360 degrees as needed for viewing. All ports with easily accessible and touch screen response was normal with the protective screen cover built into the case. Camera's and Microphones were not impeded on either. I really like the kick stand on the case, it is very durable and pops out and in with ease. This provides a really nice prop up stand for your iPad to view movies or play games on without holding it. The leather strap is quality material also and feels like its made to last quite a lot of use.
I'd say the case added about half a pound or so of weight to the overall iPad Air weight, which is not bad for so much protection it offers up. This would be a case for this who work outside or travel a lot with your iPad. It protects against the weather, and if you have a stylus the strap grip underneath makes it a nice tablet to write on with a stylus. Another overall win from New Trent.

Instances.input: I replaced my AMD Athlon 64 X2-based web server with something low power, this Atom D525-based system.  I've been running it for over a week now, with 4 GB of RAM, and it works quite well for what I want.  Certainly, my website comes up just as well, if not slightly faster, than the old system, but is using a fraction of the power that the old one did.    I have tried some media streaming with the system and, for the most part, it works alright.  For sending files to my PS3 to watch on the TV, it seems to stream quite well.  For Hulu, the video can get somewhat \\"choppy\\" (I have a 6 Mbps internet connection), but I think that's because I'm using the integrated Intel graphics chip.  I'm also using Ubuntu 10.10 as the operating system.    So I recommend this motherboard and processor combo for basic work and basic media playing.  2 GB of RAM works pretty well with it, but I'd go with 4 GB if you can, depending on your needs.  If you want to run an HTPC-style media system for your television, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND adding a video card.  I haven't tried it, but I really doubt that this system has enough horsepower to display anything seamlessly on a large LCD television.  With a video card, however, even a cheap one (e.g. GeForce 210), I think it would work well!

With an increasing amount of games being ported horribly from consoles to PC, use of a controller in PC games has steadily been on the rise. The Xbox 360 adapter for Windows is one of the easier solutions, for people who already own a (Xbox 360) controller, but wish to be able to use it for their PC as well. Sadly though, Microsoft itself does not sell the adapter as a standalone package, and requires hopefuls to purchase their complete pack, which may come with another controller users will have no use for. Luckily, we have the solution here.

The adapter sold as a standalone here (I purchased mine from Worldwide Sales) saves consumers the money from having to buy the complete pack, which costs an extra $25 or more. Installation of the adapter was easy, and the drivers that came in the disc was of the latest version. Simply follow the instructions on the leaflet, and you'll have your adapter set up in no time to play!

Fair warning though, there are a lot of controllers being sold by third parties, which although may be compatible with the official Xbox 360 controller, seem to have odd installation and continuous issues. To be safe, I purchased the official product, and am having no problems whatsoever. The official adapter has the word \\"Microsoft\\" on the top, instead of \\"XBOX 360\\" or variants as seen in alternatives by third parties.

This 256GB M.2 SSD was the perfect upgrade for my recently purchased HP Stream (model 200-010) desktop. This new flash drive performs just like the one that HP shipped with the system, but it has 10x the free space!

A few tips for anyone looking to upgrade the SSD in their HP Stream:
- for whatever reason, cloning the drive won't work (I think it has something to do with the Windows license key). My attempts to clone the drive resulted in a failure to boot.
- you'll need a spare USB hard disk/flash drive to create a system restore point.
- once you have created a system restore point to an external drive, swap out the original SSD in your HP Stream for the new, unformatted one.
- power on your system with your restore point's media attached. Follow the onscreen prompts to restore your OS install to the new drive.
- word of warning: this process WILL DELETE YOUR PERSONAL FILES/APPS. Be sure to back those up first if you aren't performing this upgrade 'out-of-the-box'.

All told, this upgrade took me about an hour to perform. It's a simple way to turn your new Chromebox/Stream/budget PC from \\"curiosity\\" to \\"fully functional.\\"
output: The perfect upgrade for my HP Stream Desktop

Instances.input: If you're looking for a computer case that will fit in with your home theatre equipment, you want an HTPC case.  These are in a different class than your standard desktop case, and are sorted by different features.    The main things to consider:  1. Motherboard form factor:  ATX, Micro-ATX, Mini-ITX  2. Expansion cards: do you want to be able to use full height expansion cards, half height cards, or none?  3. Built in display (VFD or LCD): Either the case has a built in spot for a display, or it doesn't  4. Optical drive bays accessable from the outside    This case has:  1. ATX motherboard (also supports Micro-Atx  2. Accepts full size expansion cards (which is why it is so tall  3. Has a built in VFD display with a remote and media center software  4. Only one optical drive bay available from the front    Pro:  Amazon's incredible price.  The display/remote combo usually costs like $100 just by itself.    Very solid construction, like all products from SilverStone.  Entire chassis is a very heavy metal, with a lighter aluminum front.    ultimate versatility with 4 hard drive mounting spots (a 5th with a 5.25\\" to 3.5\\" bracket), full ATX, and full height expansion cards    Remote has mouse emulation for navigating web pages (netflix?) without pulling out a real mouse    Con:  Dual 60mm fans in the back.  60mm fans are a waste of space.  The motor is bigger than the fan blade surface area.  They make a lot of noise for the amount of air they push.    No external drive bays (except of course the slot for the optical drive tray).  It would be nice to have the option of adding a card reader.    If your motherboards 24 or 20 pin power connection is at the very top right of the board, you will have to make a very sharp bend to get it connected.  The optical drive bay is only inches above this corner of the board.  You might want to plug it in before inserting the motherboard.    The cover for the optical drive bay just a piece of metal you stick to your optical drive tray with a piece of double sided tape.  This avoids the need for a spring loaded door that could break, but if you need to replace the drive, you'll need some more tape.  The case looks ok if you just leave it off if you have a black faced optical drive.    IR receiver isn't very sensitive.  You need to point the remote almost directly at the case for it to work.    I'm loving this in my entertainment center.  It's almost exactly the same size as my Onkyo 5.1 channel receiver (from the front).  It is very deep though, so make sure you measure before you buy.  The media center software is Ok.  If you have the option of using windows media center (XP media center edition, Vista home premium, or windows 7 home premium), I would recommend going with that.    The display is similar to what you would find on the front of a DVD or blu-ray player, but you can customize the content.  You can display system hardware info, network usage, and many other things.  Supposedly it can show you the weather, but the server it connects to seems to be down.  It does tell me how many unread e-mails I have (using pop3), and downloads news headlines.    Purchased with standard ground shipping, and it was on my porch 20 hours later.  Go Amazon!
output: Solid Home Theatre PC Case for my specifications

The first device I hooked this bluetooth keyboard up to was my 4th generation iPod Touch, and it literally only took a few seconds. You turn on the keyboard, press the bluetooth button you want to assign the device to (I picked the first Bluetooth button), and then navigate to the bluetooth settings in your device and select the keyboard (on the iPod/iPhone go to general -> settings and click on the keyboard).

To hook this up to a computer without Bluetooth built-in, you will need to pick up a bluetooth dongle to plug into one of your USB ports. The connection to the keyboard will be quite simple after that point but will vary based on your OS.

I was quite delighted to have the opportunity to review this item because it will allow those of us with smart devices but with larger typing requirements to get by when traveling without having to carry a heavy laptop about. I cannot bear to type for any length of time on a tablet or smartphone, and, as a writer, I need to type quite a lot almost all of the time. Packing this keyboard with a tablet will considerably lighten my load and keep me from having to use my personal carry-on item solely to transport a laptop and accessories.

Typing on the keyboard took just a moment to adjust to. The keys are full size and spaced exactly as they are on my laptop (I placed the keyboard across my laptop to compare). The only thing I lament is the absence of a dedicated home key and end key as I use these quite often in word processing tasks. However, I have gotten accustomed to using the \\"FN\\" key and the arrow buttons to navigate up and down and \\"home and end\\". (Note: use FN and the down arrow to skip to the end of a page; use FN and the up arrow to go \\"Home\\"). I also love the look of the unit - it is polished looking without trying to hard.

I think this is such a handy device that I will probably send my brother's family one for Christmas to use with their tablets and other handheld smart devices. The easy sharing and switching between units with the three bluetooth device buttons should make it a nice household item versus a one-user keyboard.

Edited to add: When I purchased my new iPod touch fifth generation in December 2012 running iOS 6.0.1, it booted right up on channel two beside my previous iPod touch (4th generation) on channel one. I fully expected it to but wanted to share this for the curious!

Edited to add (12/28/12): I just acquired a computer with Windows 8 and really like the addition of a dedicated app scrolling button on this keyboard. For the curious, it is the arrow in a box on the F4 button. This allows you to scroll through all of the open apps on your PC. It's very handy as it keeps me from leaving too many different apps open at one time since I can scroll through the open ones swiftly and close them.
output: Easy Setup with iPod Touch 4G and 5G; Convenient for Windows 8

This forced me back to my 2005 IBM Thinkpad Z60t that with $100 in parts was usable again.  .  My motherboard replacement option was to spend $185 on a used motherboard with a 14 day warranty! Got four of these in 20-foot, red green white yellow. The red is more of an ochre, in case that matters to you. They work, but frankly this 'snagless' design is bad no matter what version of it I buy. This one is just like the picture, with the 'snagless' idea supposedly protecting the plastic plug yet not overlaying it. Thus, your fingers can TOUCH the long 'finger' in the clicker portion. Well, if your fingers are small enough.

That's an improvement over the typical one which has a layer of rubbery plastic OVER the long hard plastic clicker, because that clicker won't plug in as easily, using the typical style. Even so, it's a pain. You must be very gentle, and of course you must be sure you HEAR that 'click' when you plug the thing into router or computer, or you're sunk.

The cables work. But frankly I'm not sure they protect the 'finger'. And, they are cumbersome to plug in, especially in tight corners, when you don't have small human fingers. Not sure there is any good way to do that, without preventing you from being able to use the 'finger' as you need, for a sure connection. Good news is, you can CUT the plastic alleging to 'protect' the finger.

By the way, if you're an XFINITY user, you should have gotten a new modem/router with FOUR ethernet cables now at the back, so you can hook up four computers to it at any one time. Back in September, XFINITY removed the bandwidth cap. So this is a nice thing, to have colored cables.

Finally, a note about the colors: a) I'm so sick of black in computers and cords, I could scream: who has black walls? Then b), I have many computers, so the color coding helps me know which cable at the router, belongs to which machine (I refuse to use wireless or wi-fi, even though I have it).
output: It's Tripp Lite, but the design could be better

Instances.input: I live in a 200 square foot studio apartment. That's small, in case you didn't know. Very small. And in this space, I have a full size bed, a standing computer desk, a Herman Miller computer chair, a dining room table, a digital piano, and a 32 inch LCD HDTV. The TV has terrible sounding speakers. I wanted something better. But I didn't have a lot of room to work with. I wanted speakers that had a small footprint, sounded great, and didn't need a subwoofer. Yeah, there are cheaper options, and yeah, I'm sure you pay something for the Bose name. But these speakers are fantastic for what they are. They have a small footprint, yet they sound very good. They don't have a subwoofer, yet they get great bass. I use them for TV and movies primarily, but also for music. And I have nothing but good things to say about them. If you live in a small apartment and just don't have the space for more speaker equipment, don't feel bad dropping your hard earned money on these. They are wonderful!

There are many reviews of this product already, so i will add focus on what i found lacking. That was support for the iPad Air 2.

It is supported by the iPad Air 2 and with a little tweaking it will work decently well. If you're comparing it Wacom tablets or devices made for pen inputs than you will be at a loss, since this is a 'hack' against what apple has engineered and that is complete touch usage. This is NOT a fine point stylus like the Fineline stylus' that are available but this is easiest to use and is by far the most accurate and works best really with the iPad Air 2. I've tried out a few Jot pro the creative stylus 2, 1 , Fineline and a few others. There is very little lag in comparison to my Fineline however being a fat tip it works best as an artist tool or for highlight and not really writing long pages of notes. I've made a little functionality and working video of how to plays with the iPad Air 2 and you can see its quite accurate given its thicker tip.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7SeVxJ5TBA0

For the non-fine tip stylus on the iPad Air 2 this will probably be your best bet at the moment without breaking the bank.

I got this router because my old 2.4GHz 802.11n router wasn't reaching downstairs well. I figured it could have been due to frequency contention and upgrading to 5GHz would solve that problem. I was wrong. The 5GHz signal does not travel nearly as far, maybe half the distance. The good news is that the 2.4GHz band on this router works a lot better than my old one, easily picking up devices downstairs. So even though 5GHz was a dud for me, the 2.4GHz band works better than ever! It also has a decent feature set, but still not quite on-par with OSS firmware like DD-WRT. Still, I haven't bothered to load DD-WRT on this router because it can be a pain to find a build without bugs and I'm not really missing the advanced features (much--I run a Linux server so I moved DNS server functions over to that.)

EDIT: I'm revising my review down to 2 stars. There appears to be an issue with this router where it stops routing WiFi connections to the Internet. Internet searches reveal the same complaint. My laptop will be connected and I can ping all devices on my private LAN including the router, but attempting to ping Internet IP addresses fails. It seems the router stops routing them, possibly a NAT issue. Rebooting the router temporarily resolves the issue but it soon returns. I'm also running the latest available firmware.
output: Working better than my old router except for one big issue

After popping off the bezel, I found that the holes on the screen's mounting tabs did not align perfectly with the screw holes in upper clam-shell of the laptop. The holes in the tabs were actually the correct spacing and distance apart, but all four were shifted ever so slightly to the right so that when I put the screws in, the screen would not seat into the recessed area behind the bezel--the left edge of the screen was too far over. I assume this is a manufacturing defect that would not be the case for every screen produced, but I'll put it on record so that other people are aware that this could be an issue.

Instances.input: When I purchased these speakers, I got exactly what I was looking for: A pair of easy to install, small computer speakers. I own a set of Logitech 5.1 surround sound speakers for my computer, but hooking them up is fairly time consuming, and for reasons I won't go into, I just wanted something simple to use for a while until I put my other set of speakers back. I didn't expect great sound quality or anything. My sole requirements were halfway decent sound and simplicity.  Having said that, here are some of the pros and cons.    Pros: Very small speakers. Easy hook-up (one cable plugged straight into computer. No need for a power chord.) Easy off and on button and volume control on the one speaker. Well built.    Cons: The cable that plugs into the computer is fairly short, I'd guess about 3 feet. So unless you get an extension cord, the placement is pretty limited. Also, the cable that connects the two speakers is only about 3' as well. Not an issue for me, but could be for someone else.   The sound quality is decent, but nothing stellar. A little bit on the \\"tinny\\" side, but like I said above, that's OK with me, and I didn't really expect anything else.    So in summary: It's a decent set of speakers for the price. If you're looking for great sound, these will disappoint, but for simple, no frills audio, these are perfect.
Nothing fancy, but everything practical.

Instances.input: This is a great company with wonderful customer service and amazing products! They ship quickly and their products are of great quality.

I purchased this item in a dream last night and don't know how I would live without it.  At first, I didn't know what I would do with a 1080p LCD with a 640x480 native resolution, but the 256MB of graphics RAM and ability to attach my old IDE hard drives won me over.  Some people can't understand why I would try to plug a hard disk directly into the monitor, but it does indeed work, although you'll need some basic soldering experience when using a blowtorch to melt the 40-pin IDE header into the VGA port.  Remember to keep applying heat until a proper electrical connection is made.  Of course, without any software support, there is not much you can actually do with this configuration, but the black screen and faint smell of burning plastic make for a truly soothing and meditative experience.    The 802.11b wireless support is obsolete by modern standards (get with the times, Viewsonic!), and the voices in my head told me that only WEP is supported, but do you really need more to change the contrast from across the room?    I can't wait for the SATA and 802.11n model with dual processors, instead of the single core specified for this model.  With just a slight overclock - simply jam a screwdriver through the two air vents furthest from the left when facing the back of the unit, pry the shielding back and adjust the yellow potentiometer clockwise until it pulls loose from the board - this one already breaks 240FPS playing back my America's Test Kitchen collection on DVD!

SR300 Wireless High Power Range Extender/Repeater
I fought with this thing for a day and a half, which was a complete waste of my time.
Problem: The repeater receives data from my modem/router at a rate of 25-28 Mbps. It outputs at 10-12 Mbps. Simple math says that is approximately a 60% drop in signal output. The range is fine. At the limits of my home, maybe 60 feet from the router, I'm still getting 10 Mbps, so it is sending out a strong signal, it's just sending out a signal that is 60% less than what it is receiving, no matter where you are in the house. At the limits of my home, I'm only getting a 50% drop off from the original router, so the end result is a stronger signal from the original than I'm getting from the repeater.
The first tech support person I talked to was mystified. \\"Can't be happening,\\" he said. \\"What did you do wrong?\\" He had me update the firmware. Same result. He had me change from 20 to 40 Mhz. Same result - always the 60% drop-off. His last ditch effort was to have me change the channel in a trial and error effort to find a better fit for my modem. Here we found another problem for this piece of junk. You can't really change the channel. You change it once, then on the next reboot it reverts to auto and picks whatever it wants. Watch out: there's a work-around for this on the FAQ page. It doesn't work. Finding that problem was just a bonus, because it turns out, I had the right channel in the first place. The channel is not causing the 60% drop off.
The next tech support guy I talked to was a bit more forthright. \\"Oh,\\" he says. \\"That's normal.\\" In fact, their own tech support guy advised me not to buy any of their higher priced routers because they would all have the same 60% drop off. His take on the matter was that you only use one of these things if you need to extend the range beyond the limits of your original router. The repeater will extend the range well beyond the original router, but always with a massivelyreduced signal. So, unless you are trying to increase your coverage area out to a hundred feet or you're trying to get around lead walls or something, don't waste your money. This product will not help you in a single family sized home.
I picked this thing after reading other reviews because I was snowed by the one that said he was getting 18 Mbps output while repeating a 20 Mbps source. Sounds great, but according to Amped Wireless's own tech support, that's impossible. Good luck.
output: Tech Supported Admitted it Does Not Work as Advertised

I learned a great lesson from this...NEVER EVER purchase a Compaq computer. I've had the most difficult time with Compaq's tech support. It's very hard trying to convince them something isn't a software problem, but a hardware problem. After Compaq supposedly repaired my notebook the first time, they sent it back to me in non-working condition. Clear your calendar and be prepared to spend many hours and days on the phone with Compaq tech support. After numerous conversations, with what felt like most of Compaq's tech team, they replaced the hard drive for a second time. Too bad they couldn't get it right the first time around. Oh...the problems didn't stop there. The individual at the Compaq repair center didn't even reseal my notebook before sending it back to me. So now, after using my laptop (which is on its 3rd hard drive - sad for such a young notebook), my computer is making strange noises. Apparently the hard drive hasn't been fixed, after all. The only reason this case did not get 5 stars is that all the thumb screws were way too tight. It took the supplied allen tool with philips to loosen all the internal thumb screws. The case thumb screws I had to loosen with my own screw driver. The hard drive bays are not a tool free design, but you can remove the thumb screw that holds it into place. The side latches hold the drives very securely with out them. I am glad that I did not have to buy a 2.5 to 3.25 holder for any of the smaller drives I have installed in my computer. Sigh - where to begin? From day one, the laptop has exhibited a sort of ghosting on the right side of the screen. Pushing on the back of the bezel, or swiping the screen right to left will make it go away for the most part. Because I had bought the laptop at a time where I was going to be traveling quite a bit, RMAing wasn't an option (mostly because of the horror stories/turn around times for MSI). At some point I learned to just ignore the problem, which, given this thing's cost.. is stupid of me.

Then a couple of months ago the left trackpad button started acting odd - the mechanism felt mushy, and you can tell looking at the left and right buttons, that something is odd with the left - it slants a bit in the bottom left corner. The fallout here is really that you hear a click/snap when you click that button, and clicking with the right most edge of button does nothing at all. Again, this coincided with a time where I would be travelling and need the laptop, so no RMA again.

And now we're at today - the laptop is 8 months old - I come home from work and notice one of the front lights is flashing orange; I've never seen that before! Low and behold, it's the battery charging light. Looking at the battery widget in Windows, it shows the battery at 88% and "plugged in but not charging". Rebooting does nothing. Reseting the EC controller does nothing. Running the battery calibration does nothing. Whenever the charge gets up to 88%, the battery charge light blinks red/orange, and it stops charging. Off AC, my battery life is now... a third of what it was? The laptop dies in about 30 minutes on battery, where as literally the day before, it could make it 2-3 hours.

So, this is the last straw - I'll RMA it and deal with out having a laptop for a month. And by the sounds of it, I'll get back the same laptop that MIGHT have the problem fixed.. or not, and get to repeat the process.

It's just discouraging for a laptop at this price to hit these issues, but also have a support system that leaves you without your hardware for weeks.

I've owned and used a dozen laptops over the last 15 years. I've had my TM2T for over year now and couldn't be happier. It boots quick, runs cool and performs lightning fast. The touchscreen rocks, though takes a little getting used to.  After squinting at the current crop of 7\\" & 10\\" tablets, I appreciate the bright 12\\" (1280x800) diplay even more. The discrete graphics (ATI/Mobility) makes HD video great--very easy to watch. The performance (i5/4GB/500GB) is *top-notch*! The TM2T also comes with a (stored) C/R pen which gives you pinpoint-accurate control if you don't want to use your fingers. And being a real PC, you can run eleventeen applications at once. If you run a medium-bright screen, the battery lasts 6 to 8 hours.   The only \\"issue\\" I had was that it took me a while to figure out how to set up the power-management to *not* time-out the touchpad after so many minutes. Now it's responsive immediately all the time. Do yourself a favor and upgrade to Win-7 PRO ($100) after you get it.   The TM2T is not a toy; it weighs a few pounds. But to have a 12\\" T/S display, RJ-45 jack, 3 USB ports, VGA-out *and* HDMI out, 5-way SD/xD slot, 1/8\\" mic/phone jack, Dolby-HD-audio, and a HD webcam all built-in plus the foldout keyboard, I won't be shopping for an iPad anytime soon. Get one while they're still available!

This is a bit of an older model gaming mouse (mine has a manufacture date of Nov. 2006) as 2000dpi is as high as it goes where the new 'gaming' mice tend to have upwords of 4000dpi.  However you're not going to get a 4000dpi mouse for $25.00.  But does one really need a 4000dpi mouse?    The look and construction of the mouse is very good, it feels great in your hand, and the blue lights surrounding it (in my opinion) are very cool and a nice change from the usual Red you see on every other optical mouse.    I was a little worried the two buttons on the top of the mouse to turn up and down the dpi would get in the way of gaming and the mouse wheel, but they're actually well placed and very accessable when you need them in the heat of battle and they don't get in the way in the slightest.    The reason I gave the Habu a 4 star rating is that it was an utter pain in the (pick your favorite body part, I'm going with posterior) to get the thing recognized by Windows.  At first I immediately pluged the Habu in my Windows 7 machine and it saw a USB device but it didn't know what it was and just said 'unknown device.'  I mean grr, A Microsoft OS not recognizing a Microsoft device?!?!  I'm guessing the device recognition problem was due to the mouse being manufactured in 2006 which of course is well before Windows 7.  I wasn't ready to give up though so I spent a few >>HOURS<< looking at forums and such trying to get this thing recognized by Windows and everything kept pointing to the firmware not being up to date.  Now don't get me wrong, I was more than willing to dive into updating the firmware, but again it wasn't even recognized by Windows so how could I update it?  And to boot, Windows 7 was disabling the Habu/device saying it was malfunctioning.  I finally decided to take the Habu to work where they're still using XP and try pluging the mouse in there... again, unrecognized USB device message... so I was about to give up and send it back but then I found the solution...    Now I can't speak for all of the Habu's as maybe you'll get one with the latest firmware or a later manufacturer date but I bought the one listed at $25.00 (if it's still available when you read this) so if you get that one you'll most likely need to do the following to get its firmware updated and recognized by Windows...    I had to jump through a few hoops and combine a few downloads worth of drivers and firmware, but now it's working perfectly so hopefully this will save you some time and a headache.    First get the latest driver from [...] and install it (without the Habu pluged in).  The firmware however isn't located in the latest driver (at the time of this writing).  I had to download an older driver (which indicated it had a firmware update in its description) that had a separate folder called firmware that I grabed and put to the side.    I then had to get their, what I'm guessing is a generic version of their interface software called 'Copperhead' and install that.  Basicly all we're going to use the Copperhead software for is to be able to point it to the firmware file for the Habu.  I tried the firmware update option through the latest Habu interface software but it just opened the Razer web page when I clicked on the firmware update option.    Next (still not having the Habu pluged in) hold the small button on the bottom of it down and plug it in and continue holding it down... it should hopefully be recognized not as a mouse but a 'Freescale USB JW32 ICP Device.'    Finally, open the Copperhead software and click on 'save/load settings,' you're going to see an update firmware option, click it, and point it to the firmware you downloaded and put to the side earlier... you should then see a progress bar indicating it's updating.    Once updated, unplug/plug the Habu and it should then be seen by Windows as 'Habu Mouse' and you should be good to go.    Other than the pain described above, this is an excellent mouse and I'd go through all the problems again for it as it's that good and you simply can't beat the price!

My daughter started using my Android tablet. It's hard to find good apps so we bought an iPad mini. We found good apps and bought a few books but they're still hard to shop for and the money adds up quickly.

Enter the Kindle Fire. For $3/mo, you get Kindle FreeTime. The apps are tagged by age and they seem to have found all the high quality Android apps. The videos are top notch, presumably also from Prime. You can find content by character (Sesame, Dora, etc). You can virtually unlimited high quality books. You can't put a price on the amount of stimulation that your kids will learn from this! FreeTime is very nicely refined and I love that I can control how time is divided up by activity.

After using it for a day, my daughter promptly announced that her younger brother can have the iPad mini. This one is hers! For kids, a cheaper $130 is perfect. My only concern is that it doesn't have a mic so some apps won't work for kids (Ubooly for example). I haven't found any, though, so bought the next higher end model in the mean time.

As a general tablet, I'm sort of bleh on it though. The OS is very nice but the lack of integration with Google services is a killer. Sure you can check your email and calendar but there's no Hangouts. You can use Skype instead if that works for you. Cheap 4G data plan isn't so useful anymore with the free T-mobile data plans now (supposedly the AT&T version here isn't locked and you can stick in a T-mobile SIM card). The lack of momentum for the Amazon ecosystem makes me leery of getting used to it as well. The screen is grogeous, better than the newer iPads even. You can download most Prime movies to the tablet for free.
output: Bought it solely for Kindle FreeTime

Instances.input: I really like this product. It is durable and reasonably priced. I certainly recommend it.

For my first PC build I decided to go with this motherboard after reading many reviews and other peoples experiences with it. I was a little nervous at first because other motherboards with similar overclock abilities cost twice as much and more so I had no idea what to expect out of this board. It arrived SUPER fast as usual, it took 2 days from my order date and it came from USPS. I tried to get the board from newegg but they are always sold out because of high demand. There are 2 revisions of this board and I was sure I was going to get an older model because I didn't think amazon pushes many motherboards. I ended up getting the newer revision 2 with a newer bios that supports 45nm chips. If you get an older version of this board with older bios, you may have a problem getting it to POST with a 45nm chip.  I've had my new gaming PC assembled for about a month now and this board is better than I was expecting. It is very easy to overclock within bios (you must press CTRL+F1 at bios menu to access advanced OC menu). I keep my E8400 at 3.5ghz on my stock cooler, once the new cooler comes in I plan to keep it 4.0ghz. Be sure to manually set your RAM\CPU voltage as well as your CPU\RAM\pci-express mhz speed, the factory setting for all of these can be different then what the manufacturer specifies for your part#. Try to stay away from the windows based overclock tool that comes on the software CD, it is seems very buggy and unstable. Assembly was a snap, the instructions manual covers EVERYTHING, including some of the advanced overclock features. I highly recommend this board to anyone interested in a low-cost overclockable motherboard.    My other components just for reference:  CPU: Intel Core2 Duo E8400 3.0ghz Wolfdale  Cooler: Sunbeam Core Contact Freezer (not installed yet, on its way)  PSU: Corsair CMPSU-650TX 650watt  Case: Coolermaster Centrion CAC-T05-UW  Video: eVGA 8800 GTS 512mb (G92)  RAM: 4gb (2x2gb) OCZ Reaper HPC Edition PC6400 - 800mhz (5-5-5-18, 1.8v)  HDD: Seagate Barracuda 7200.10 SATA - 1x160gb, 1x500gb

Although I am so happy to have a kindle fire again (my first edition fire broke) I am disappointed in a few ways. The first edition was around the same price, but had a much larger screen and while that may just be disappointing to me, especially since there are larger options, I liked that the base model was one size and affordable. I bought the 6" edition because it was affordable, and I really didn't want to dish out more cash just for a bigger screen.  My other issue is the battery life. I have it on power saving mode, I keep the screen dim, and yet the battery just seems to run out so quickly. My original fire only needed a charge once a week, and that was with consistent use at night. My new fire needs to be charged at least every other day, and often, every single day. I find this really annoying because if I have to be constantly charging my fire then I am not getting as much convenient use from it.  On the bright side, it's nice to be able to read on a kindle again. I am not a big fan of reading books on my phone, and the kindle paper isn't really an option for me since I do most of my reading at night and prefer to just dim the screen on my kindle and use a bluelight filter so as not to strain my eyes. This fire is as easy, if not more easy to navigate than my original fire and I like that when I purchase a book on my computer, by the time I turn on my fire later that night, it's already downloaded and ready to read even though it's on standby mode.  Overall, I miss my original. I miss the size and battery life. However, for the price I do think it's a great option. You can do everything you can do on a smart phone (aside from making calls outside of skype or texting) but on a much larger screen and I think the display is more clear. I don't regret my purchase and I am hoping that I find a way to make my battery last longer.  Updated 8/25/15: I am so disappointed and frustrated with this purchase. I will charge my fire to full, unplug it, and once I goto use it, the battery is completely drained. I get so little use from it because it is constantly dead. I have had to use my phone for reading my kindle books. It's almost a waste of time to even bother charging it since by the time I use it, the thing is dead. This is a huge flaw with this product and needs to be fixed. With my first edition fire, I could leave it in sleep mode, not fully shut down, for days and it would still have a battery that was at least 90%.

This one lasted 36 hours before the silicone started tearing. Way too easy for a kid to get the silicone off, and this is going back almost as fast as the Griffin Survivor did, and we're back to the GumDrop for now, because that at least she cannot tear. Ruggedized my rear. If the silicone doesn't stay on it doesn't do jack.

(The iPad is being used by a special needs child for communciation.)

ETA: For comparison's sake:

For an adult, this is probably a great option. But Otterbox is often seen as the \\"case of choice\\" for special needs children who use iPads for communication and learning. And for children who are capable of understanding concepts like \\"gentle\\" and \\"leave the case on\\" and \\"Don't chew on it,\\" it is probably fine. Weight wise, this was the lightest and sleekest of the three cases we have tried. (Otterbox, Griffin Survivor, GumdDrop)

But for a severely delayed kiddo who NEEDS her iPad but cannot resist picking, twiddling, twisting, biting and manipulating things, it flat out doesn't work. The silicone sleeve comes off so easily. It is not very thick, so it tears readily. Even if it doesn't tear, little fingers pulling at it were able to deform the silicone so that it would not lie flat. She should NOT have been able to damage the case so readily.

In fact, I found it challenging to get the silicone to lie flat even from first install. With great care I did succeed, but it did not take her long to simply roll the silicone off. The polycarbonate case was nearly impossible for me to get off, and she did not even try, but without the silicone the moisture resistance is very low. And this is a child who tends to drool a fair amount... so moisture control is essential. Anyone who is putting their iPad in the hands of a small child really needs to think about a case that is going to protect their iPad from the hands of someone who does not understand \\"gentle\\" and \\"Don't chew on the case.\\"

The Griffin case did not survive long either. I believe it was an older model with a flap, not a hinge, but the flap came completely off from the power port, torn, the first long usage session.

The GumDrop has survived months. It allows moisture to seep under the screen protector, but the iPad works despite being thrown, dropped, sat on, drooled on and gnawed on. She has not managed to damage the rubber housing *at all*, and that's the only case that that is true of.

So it is possible to make a case that a child cannot tear, damage, or remove easily. But the Otterbox isn't that case. Which is a shame since it is so often recommended.

I do network engineering for a living so I deal with a lot of networking issues and enterprise grade hardware. For home use, this is what I have had in my house for more than 5 years!

In my opinion this is the best home wireless router. The version I have is quite a bit older and probably doesn't even have all the features of this version, but it has most of them and the basic unit has stayed the same. It has a lot of features for WiFi setup and security settings, but is also easy to keep simple and it just works and keeps your network secure. The best things about the wireless are it is very fast, good interoperability with different devices, and has super range. After much waffling, I bought this tablet with a handful of specific purposes in mind. First and foremost, I am a musician and wanted a tablet to read music on. While I'd really prefer a larger screen in a perfect world, what sold me on this one instead of one of the (relatively few) significantly larger ones was the stylus. I need to be able to make annotations in my music the way I would with a pencil. Zooming in and then writing with my finger doesn't cut it when I want to be able to write in small markings like accidentals, breath marks, cues, etc, in the middle of a rehearsal. Unfortunately there aren't nearly as many music score apps for Android as there are for iOS, and they don't necessarily all take as much advantage of the stylus as I wish they did, but there there are some and I found what I needed. And there are more Android apps all the time.
But regardless, the stylus makes a big difference and I think it makes this device a very competitive alternative to an iPad, even though more musicians seem to use iPads.
Incidentally, the actual surface area of the screen is about the same on the Note 10.1 as on the full-sized iPad. I actually prefer the iPad's aspect ratio, but that's not such a big deal.
In terms of reading music off of it, I still wish the screen was a bit bigger since I have to stand far enough away to not bang my instrument into the stand. But at the same time, I think it's easier to read smaller-sized notes off this screen than it is off of paper at the same size, and at least lighting isn't an issue.
Second, I wanted something that could be a lighter, more compact alternative to carrying around my laptop, but something big enough to be reasonably comfortable for general internet use and getting actual work done without being frustrated about not being able to see enough of it at once. For that, it's perfect. The stylus makes even just web browsing easier because it's easier to click on small links than by poking with myfinger. And being able to write in the text instead of typing on the "imaginary" keyboard on the screen is really great. I only wish you could do it any time there is a text box, instead of only in some cases, in some apps, or on some websites.
Samsung did go to a certain amount of trouble to add stuff that the stylus is good for, some of which is useful, but even aside from that, to me the stylus just generally enhances the ease of use by more than I expected.
Other odds and ends: the display looks really nice. The camera is good enough that I can take a photo of my music and comfortably read it off of that if I don't have time to scan it. People talk about the molded-fake-leather-texture back feeling cheap, but it feels fine to me. I don't really care about that; I put it in a case and don't really see the back much anyway. It's sort of annoying that the port for the charger is right at the bottom, which makes it awkward to use while it's plugged in.
But on the other hand, that hasn't been an issue much because the battery life is quite good.
So all in all, I've been very happy with it. So far, I'm satisfied with my choice of a device with a stylus over a device with a bigger screen.
But hey Samsung! A Galaxy Note with a screen the size AND aspect ratio of a regular piece of letter-sized paper (or even just reasonably close) would be AWESOME!
output: Convenient, useful, portable, does what I bought it for. Love the stylus.

I will echo most other reviews and say that is not a quick & easy application. Watch the video first, then take your time and be patient. Do not skip steps, and you will have a perfectly applied screen protector.

My biggest tip is that it is much easier to push out large bubbles than it is to push out small ones. Given this fact, use the bubble scraper (or credit card) to push large bubbles into smaller ones. When a larger bubble touches a smaller one, they mesh and become one larger bubble.

Do this before removing any of the bubbles. When all you are left with are large bubbles, that's when you push them to the edge and remove them completely.

They will all vanish and all you will be left with will be a perfectly clear, protected screen.
output: Combine bubbles before removing them for clear & clean application
