Instances.input:
I am a software developer experiencing moderate RSI.

The keyboard won't perform any miracles, it's not an overnight cure. With that said, it has helped quite a bit with my RSI over the past couple of weeks and has been worth the purchase.

Even if a person didn't have RSI, it is actually comfortable and relaxing to be able to type at a more natural position. I would recommend it to anyone who works on the computer 8+ hours a day if they don't mind forking up the $$$.

The keyboard is well-designed; it feels as the designers actually used the keyboard and tuned it to real needs.

I love mechanical keyboards, something this keyboard is not, but the keys feel good to press and are surprisingly tactile for a membrane keyboard. It would've been great if they were Cherry MX brown/blue switches, however.

All the mac keys work and yayyy you get a few useful shortcuts back by having an eject key. There are also a few useful non-programmable macro keys. For~$150, it would've been nice if they were programmable.

Overall the keyboard is great and if you have RSI, it might just be the best option for an ergonomic keyboard that does its job while still feeling close to a traditional keyboard layout.

I will be changing my review for this product.    My board quit working. Drivers will not load for it. Contacted ftdichip.com support and they verified that the board is indeed a NON-GENUINE ftdi clone. Purchase at your own risk.

Instances.input:
I received my laptop a few days ago, and so far so great! It's a great size to carry with you without having to sacrifice the number pad, which iis definitely a plus.

What I like: It's lite and easy to carry around. The backlit keyboard is amazing and there when needed. The keys have a premium feel to them that are arguably better than any other brand. The keys are also spaced apart, but not enough to be even slightly uncomfortable. Windows 8, but I also do NOT like Windows 8. It takes getting use to, and that's why I'm neutral. Battery life is BETTER than what is listed. This laptop is one of the more stylish laptops. It can easily be set apart from other computers.

What I don't like: The touch pad. While it's a leap into next gen computers, the touch pad was not ready for this laptop. It's glitchy at times and takes getting use to, but once you figure it out then it's not a problem. Windows 8. Again, just need time to adjust but it seems like Windows 8 would make more sense on a system with touch interface. Until I get better acquainted with it, I'm using the desktop mode.

Otherwise I will return to Amazon (I only buy directly from amazon forget about 3rd party sellers)
Cheers,
Roger

Instances.input: Amazing..... Snappy .... Fast .... Have no problems with it

Even though the write speeds seem kinda on the low end it's still fast enough to capture HD with my Pentax MX camera. Noticeable slowdown if you are capturing continous RAW+jpeg though. You'll need a more expensive high end card to avoid the slowdown.
Speeds only 10MB/s write and 25MB/s read using SD slot in Mac to test. Since this is a Class 10 card, which means it must provide a minimum of 10MB/s read/write level of performance it seems to be barely making it. Then again I may have a defective card or the benchmarks I ran are wrong. Definitely the slowest of all my SD cards, then again my other cards are Sandisk extreme 45MB/s and a Sony 90MB/s.

Battery fits my Toshiba S755 just like the original. Original was 4400 mAh, this is rated 5200 mAh but so far doesn't last noticeably longer than the original when it was new. Have had it only a couple weeks so don't know how long it will last. So far works well; based on experience thus far I can recommend it to others.

I bought this case because I needed a kickstand case for my nexus 7. When I first got the package, it came in two pieces. The rubber piece goes over the tablet and then a plastic piece fits over the rubber. The rubber and plastic is pretty good quality and I really liked that you can stand the tablet in portrait or landscape mode. Unfortunately, the kickstand is built very weak. There are two small plastic pieces that lock in place when you pop the kickstand out. These two plastic pieces are very fragile and I ended up breaking mine in a month of use around the house. I tried to contact Fosmon, but they refused to replace it. I definitely was not happy about that. So basically I have this case and I can't use the kickstand anymore so I am in the process of using shopping for another case for my Nexus. I definitely do not recommend this product. Also as a side note, the kickstand is a pain to pop out.

I'm a tech and was asked to clean the system by my brother. First it has a 1 GHz AMD CPU so it's sort of slow running a Windows 8 touch system. However there is so much crapware and bloat on the system that the little thing is completely bogged down when you boot it.

The process of just cleaning up the bloatware takes a long time but if you don't do it you are left with a system that crawls along! ACER should be ashamed, or maybe it's Wal-Mart (where my brother bought it) I don't know, but the crap on this system is terrible and you will end up spending considerable time cleaning it. As I said I'm a tech and I consider Conduit (which comes preinstalled) a virus, and though it did uninstall, it's a hijacker. I also consider mysearch a virus (also comes preinstalled).

After the clean system ran much better but still pretty slow. About the only bright spot on the system is that the touchscreen is good. The display is not bad at all and the keyboard is something you can live with at this price point.

However, just be aware you will have to clean a lot of junk from this system and some of it is viral, and then it's going to be slowwwwwww.
output: Fixed this computer for my brother - buyer beware it comes loaded with junk

Instances.input:
5 stars is based on the price. Is this the best router you can buy, of course not. However, for the money you get an adequete QoS and a gig-switch. Fot those who arent sure, QoS lets you dictate what devices get the most bandwidth, if your kids whine about their online gaming, this will help.Gig switch means things that connect with an ethernet cables (like your pc) can connect up to 1000mbs vs 100mbs.

WPS button in the front is real nice for those who have dorkpads and other mobile devices with small keyboards. when connecting these devices, you can simply select the network on said device and press the little bottom on the bottom of the router... a few seconds later you are connected. easy as pie.

looks nice.

usb 3.0 on the back! usb 3.0 is fast, and fast is cool. you can use this slot to share media or files over the netowrk

The guest nework is a nice feature as well, but i did do not have a need for it, in sum it lets people connect to the net but not other devices on your network. eg. printers, usb drives ect.

the other notebale feature is a power swich in the back of the router. if i pass out in the living room, its nice to turn off the lights on the router, but thats just me, and heck, If you are leaving for the weekend, what better security is there than to press a small button and turn it off?

the only real con is the lack of dual band, but hey everything else is there. good buy, i would recommend to an everyday user who likes speed and the casual pc/xbox/ps3 gamer.

I have had Vonage service for over 3 years using this adapter. The setup is simple, just plug it to your internet connection and plug the phone to it. If you have a firewall you may need to setup your software to allow the adapter to access the internet(basic setting for a firewall).    The unit is small, does not have any special switches or antennas so you can really fit it anywhere.     I am very happy with my Vonage service. The $25 unlimited plan is cheaper than my broadband provider's plan and it won't increase after 12 months. Furthermore, the international call rates are much lower and calls are free to some countries in Europe    Reliability has been good. If for some reason the line goes dead, the calls get automatically forwarded to my cellphone. This rarely happens, to fix it, I need to unplug it for a seconds and the unit will reset automatically. My guess is that this happens because of problems with my broadband provider and not because of Vonage itself.
high quality, fast delivery

Works just as advertised.  Followed directions found on the web and it just works.  Using Arduino serial monitor while it is hooked up to the Arduino let me use the AT commands without any problem.  Did not use a voltage divider.
Just what I expected.  Arrived promptly.

I've purchased two of these cards now, and they work great. I've used them for capturing the screen from my tablets (verified to work with the Asus Transformer and Apple iPad 2 so far). Installation is very easy (pop the card into your PCI-Express port), the software works well enough, and I just use Camtasia Studio or Jing to record the screen (the stream from the tablet is detected as HDCP, so the software doesn't let you directly record it, so a screen recorder by-passes that problem).    Definitely would recommend the product. I've purchased numerous Blackmagic Intensity Pro capture cards as well, and while those work great too, their standalone software isn't the best (works well in other apps though). And at half the price of the Blackmagic card, if you're trying to do a simple capture from a tablet or other similar HDMI-out device, this is an awesome product.

I purchased two of these two stick kits. 16 GB of RAM for one tenth of the apple price. I pulled out the original two 2GB RAM sticks with a pair of pliers and should have wrapped some tape or cloth around the jaws of the pliers to protect the surface of the sticks. Not sure if the originals will work again but as long as the new sticks work then that will not be an issue. Pressed the four new sticks in place making sure to align the stick in the slot properly and being careful to ensure that they are properly seated in the slot. Take a mental note or a quick picture of the height of the original sticks before you remove them so you can visually confirm the new sticks are fully seated.  Replace the cover and tighten the screws finger tight ensuring the cover is flush with the frame of the computer. Plug everything back in and power up.  The system booted up in what seemed to be the regular amount of time it took with 4GB. Confirm that the system sees the new RAM by clicking on the apple and selecting the \\"about this imac\\" menu item. It sees all 16GB and seems to run about the same but some things seem a bit quicker after first use. Running a game \\"Call of Duty 4 Modern Warfare\\" definitely loads and runs faster. I expected iphoto to run a bit better without jerkiness when scrolling through albums but it looks like its about the same. If you are not a power user then I think you could get away with just one of these kits which would give you a total of 12GB with the existing RAM still in place.
output: Works for 2011 27" iMac i5 3.1 gHz with 4 GB OEM RAM on two sticks

If all you want is a portable AP (Wifi Access Point) and don't want to change any of the defaults like SSID or Password and do not need a full 300 - 500 MBPS bandwidth, this is the device for you. Just pull it out of the box, cable it to a router port (like the LAN cable in Hotel Rooms) and you are ready to pair your devices. However if you want anything more, read on.

First to be clear, what is the difference between an Access Point and a Router? A router lets multiple devices (Wifi, cable or both) share an Internet Line like a cable or DSL modem. The router provides all the functions to make this happen. An AP does NOT connect directly to a modem or like device. It REQUIRES that what you connect to a line that already has the functionality of some kind of LAN routing device like a router port. The AP has more limited functionality. It simply allows multiple devices (wifi only in this case) to share a single router port or similar type connection. It has less functionality than a router so is dependent on there already being a router behind it.

This device can also act as a number of other device types as the description details. There is also much more information on the TP-Link web site. Go there before buying if you want this to do anything other than use this as a default AP device.

If you do want to access the administration menu to do anything, it does not access like most other routers. Most routers work fine if your computer LAN poert is set to automatic IP and DNIS addressing . Because auto-DNS can cause problems sometimes on wide area networks like in a Hotel or large business, the addressing is static and you have to change your LAN port to a specific configuration if you want to access the menus on this device. That wouldn't bee too hard if their support web site or user manual was up to date and accurate. It is not. The support FAQs for this device haven't been updated since Windows Vista and the User Manual since Windows XP. In addition the instructions and FAQs give you a number of IP addresses to connect to this device and only one works. I documented the steps for Windows 7 and will provide them below. In addition, if you want your Ethernet port to work with other devices you might connect after you are done, you will have to change the configuration back when done.

How to access administration menu:

Disable Wifi:(there must be no other network connections live)

Control Panel>Network and Internet>Network and Sharing Center>Change Adapter Settings>Local Area Connection (right click-properties)>Internet Protocol Version 4>Properties>Use the following IP Address: 192.168.0.10>Subnet Mask 255.255.0.0>OK.

Use browser to log in to cable connected device at 192.168.0.254>admin-admin.

When completed:
Control Panel>Network and Internet>Network and Sharing Center>Change Adapter Settings>Local Area Connection (right click-properties)>Internet Protocol Version 4>Properties>Obtain IP Address Automatically>OK.

This reverts Ethernet Port back to normal.

Enable Wifi.

You are done. Once logged in to this device, it configures like any other router. There is no simplified user configuration interface, so don't go there if you aren't familiar with router configurations. The Quick Setup menu link in the Main Menu lets you set a few of the basic things, but that is all. Don't go any further if you do not know what you are doing. Worst case and you get it to where it doesn't work, hold down the reset button for 30 seconds, not 5 seconds like the manual says. It will revert to factory defaults again.

A note on telephone support: If you can eventually get through, they are superb!!! Knowledgeable, patient and English speaking.nual since Windows XP. In addition the instructions and FAQs give you a number of IP addresses to connect to this device and only one works. I documented the steps for Windows 7 and will provide them below. In addition, if you want your Ethernet port to work with other devices you might connect after you are done, you will have to change the configuration back when done.

Control Panel>Network and Internet>Network and Sharing Center>Change Adapter Settings>Local Area Connection (right click-properties)>Internet Protocol Version 4>Properties>Use the following IP Address: 192.168.0.10>Subnet Mask 255.255.0.0>OK.

Use browser to log in to cable connected device at 192.168.0.254>admin-admin.

When completed:
Control Panel>Network and Internet>Network and Sharing Center>Change Adapter Settings>Local Area Connection (right click-properties)>Internet Protocol Version 4>Properties>Obtain IP Address Automatically>OK.

This reverts Ethernet Port back to normal.

Enable Wifi.

You are done. Once logged in to this device, it configures like any other router. There is no simplified user configuration interface, so don't go there if you aren't familiar with router configurations. The Quick Setup menu link in the Main Menu lets you set a few of the basic things, but that is all. Don't go any further if you do not know what you are doing. Worst case and you get it to where it doesn't work, hold down the reset button for 30 seconds, not 5 seconds like the manual says. It will revert to factory defaults again.

A note on telephone support: If you can eventually get through, they are superb!!! Knowledgeable, patient and English speaking.
output: Great as an Access Point Right Out of the Box, but...

One "review" for this derisively asks why it's worth paying $70 for something that a stack of books could accomplish. I admit it, I thought the same thing at first. I put off ordering the HiRise for my iMac for months. It sat it my cart. Then it was "Saved for Later." Then it was relegated to my "Wish List."

"Do I really want to pay $70 bucks for this thing?" I kept asking myself. "$50? Maybe. $30? Sure. But $70? Really?"

The problem, though, is that I'd tweaked my back running and had been in-and-out of physical therapy for it for months and months. I did the stretches and exercises religiously. I iced. I took medication.

You name it, I did it -- except making an ergonomic workspace. I didn't want to spend the money, sacrifice my retro orange office chair, or rearrange my desk. But I sit at my desk for 8-12 hours a day working at my computer. Ergonomics needed to be dealt with. First, I jettisoned that orange chair and picked up the Ikea chair recommended as the "best budget" ergonomic office chair. That made a big difference. Immediately, I noticed the effect on my back.

But one problem lingered. I was slouching to see my iMac. I'm tall. The screen was too low. Most experts say your eyes should be near the top of the visible area of the screen when you sit up straight. Some even say closer to the middle. My eyes were all the way above the top of the fame of my iMac. Over the course of the day, I'd slouch more and more, defeating the lumbar support of the chair, since I wasn't sitting up straight. Something had to change.

I experimented placing the iMac on some books. Immediately, it helped. I could get to the proper sitting height. I was sitting straight. The lumbar support of the chair was hitting me in the right spot. My feet were on the ground. My elbows were resting comfortably on the armrests.

But there was one problem: Did I really want to leave my precious iMac (and all of my work) entrusted to a few old hardbacks? (And they'd have to be ones I'd planned to read but realistically knew I'd never get to. "Ulysses," anyone? Maybe "Gravity's Rainbow"?) The iMac is designed to sit on a table. It balances there well. It's not likely to tip on that surface and, were it to tip, it would only tilt a few inches before hitting the table. Not great, but not terrible. Balancing on some slippery hardbacks (or, worse, unstable paperbacks)? It's not designed to do that. And the fall? Now we're talking some serious height.

So, finally, I took the plunged and ordered the HiRise. When it arrived, I was worried. Would it be worth it?

Immediately, I was struck by how well-packaged it was. As I took the pieces out, I noted how solid (and heavy!) they were, along with how perfectly they matched the iMac. Contrary to other reviews, putting together the unit I received was easy. Everything lined up perfectly. (And it comes with a hex tool for the screws.)

Once I had it all together and my iMac placed in it (after some experimentation, I went with the highest shelf position -- like I said, I'm tall), I was thrilled. It looks great and, most importantly, it's sturdy. Using the screws to attach the back plate, it's safe to assume the iMac won't be going anywhere, forwards or backwards. And the base is wide and (like I said) very heavy. You couldn't tip the HiRise over, side to side, if you tried. (One other nice touch was a small grey rubber bumper around the opening where the iMac goes to prevent scratching.)

So, could you use some books? Absolutely. Would it be better if the HiRise for iMac was $20 or $30 bucks cheaper. Yes. But not if it meant a sacrifice in quality.

At the end of the day, $70 bucks is a small price to pay for good ergonomics (as well as the assurance that you iMac won't topple off that unread copy of "Moby Dick!).my precious iMac (and all of my work) entrusted to a few old hardbacks? (And they'd have to be ones I'd planned to read but realistically knew I'd never get to. "Ulysses," anyone? Maybe "Gravity's Rainbow"?) The iMac is designed to sit on a table. It balances there well. It's not likely to tip on that surface and, were it to tip, it would only tilt a few inches before hitting the table. Not great, but not terrible. Balancing on some slippery hardbacks (or, worse, unstable paperbacks)? It's not designed to do that. And the fall? Now we're talking some serious height.

So, finally, I took the plunged and ordered the HiRise. When it arrived, I was worried. Would it be worth it?

Immediately, I was struck by how well-packaged it was. As I took the pieces out, I noted how solid (and heavy!) they were, along with how perfectly they matched the iMac. Contrary to other reviews, putting together the unit I received was easy. Everything lined up perfectly. (And it comes with a hex tool for the screws.)

Once I had it all together and my iMac placed in it (after some experimentation, I went with the highest shelf position -- like I said, I'm tall), I was thrilled. It looks great and, most importantly, it's sturdy. Using the screws to attach the back plate, it's safe to assume the iMac won't be going anywhere, forwards or backwards. And the base is wide and (like I said) very heavy. You couldn't tip the HiRise over, side to side, if you tried. (One other nice touch was a small grey rubber bumper around the opening where the iMac goes to prevent scratching.)

So, could you use some books? Absolutely. Would it be better if the HiRise for iMac was $20 or $30 bucks cheaper. Yes. But not if it meant a sacrifice in quality.

At the end of the day, $70 bucks is a small price to pay for good ergonomics (as well as the assurance that you iMac won't topple off that unread copy of "Moby Dick!).
output: Yes, it's actually better than a stack of books. (Especially if you've got back problems.)

Upgrading from Santa Cruz, I expected Turtle Beach can deliver the same good qualify with value price. At first, everything seems to be okay. Using DDL through the optical output, the sound is unbeatable. Absolutely good experience with it. Music sounds very good. In games, do not experience something good enough to surprise you but nothing bad either.

The first problem with it is driver issue. The driver comes with CD has a bug such that you need to open its control panel after every reboot to get the sound out. Some said C-media's driver fixes it but I tried and it actually makes it worse. Turtle Beach's update driver Mar 2006 does fix this problem.

But none of the driver fix its second problem. Which is very important to me. The problem is that it's microphone is way too unsenstitive. Turn the microphone volume control all the way to maximum and you still need to speak very loud right in front of the microphone to have it output a tiny sound. I happen to have a webcam with microphone so I know how bad the built-in mircophone in Montego DDL is. It just doesn't work. Too bad without using microphone intergrated in sound card will cause echo. So I still need to get a sound card with working mircophone. If you do no plan to use microphone, buy this card which is a good value. Otherwise, don't try your luck. Its microphone just doesn't work.

I end up returning this card. Stick with Santa Cruz which still work fine.

I wasn't sure if I would be for changing from actual, hardcover books to a kindle, but I have recently ran out of all possible space to hold books. My bookshelves are full along with windowsills, bed, and even parts of the floor. Instead of investing in another bookshelf, my family bought me a Kindle for christmas. The Kindle fits perfectly in my hands and is actually easier on the eyes at times. It is also very nice for night reading, which would have been helpful when I had a roommate, but is still beneficial now when someone stays over. I was very skeptical from changing from hardcover books to virtual, and I still buy and read hardcover books, but the ease of the Kindle makes it much easier to fulfill my rapid cycle through various books. The books are (usually) slightly less expensive and I can carry around just one device with multiple books on it. It fits nice in my purse (which some books I have read did not, even though I bought my purse specifically to fit books inside), book bag, and even coat pocket (depending on your coat pocket size, this, of course, will vary)! I have had this notebook for a little over a month and I really like it. I was worried about the screen being too small but the size and form factor are perfect for my home and office uses. This is the first notebook computer I have owned.    Pros: Small, compact, lightweight form factor. Great screen. Fast processor(s), lots of memory. Unlike some other reviewers, I actually like the keyboard. Good support from Sony.     Cons: Pricey. Non-snug feeling battery. Lots of unnecessary programs initially loaded, and no Windows CD provided for a clean install. Issue with power supply (see below). Lower than expected battery life - I was expecting 3-5 hrs, get more like 2-2.5 unless you shut everything down.    Power supply issue: my computer had an issue with the supplied 2-prong A/C adapter where a small amount of voltage ran through the wrist/palm rest area of the notebook. A \\"buzz-like\\" vibration could be felt, that was only noticeable as you slide your fingers/hand across the wrist area, and disappeared once the A/C adapter was unplugged. After discovering the problem's cause on [...] I called up Sony and they over-nighted me a new 3-prong A/C adapter that fixed the problem.     Summary: a great powerful, portable notebook that fits my needs perfectly. Would definitely buy again. Not 5 starts due to shorter battery life, pre-loaded garbage, and power supply problem.

Instances.input: This modem has performed up to and beyond my expectations.    I decided to get this modem after i was having issues with my internet connection.  It seams my service provider upgraded their systems and wher using a new system that worked better with the type 3.0 bios.  My older modem only had 2.0.  The result was with my older modem i kept getting slow downs and odd disconnections.  After researching these problems alot i discovered this was the result of the upgrade and an older bios.  This modem was easy to install.  I simply just removed my old one and put this one in.    Contrary to other posts this didnt die or break down in less then a day....    The only thing i recommend people to do....is to remeber machines and items are like very small children...you sometimes have to be very patient and thoughrough with them.    After i installed it....i called my service provider and told them about the change.  Simple and easy the person on the phone asked for it seriel number and model number...both located on the unit.  he then reset the line and suggested i do the same on my end....once he had it up and giving him a good sugnal i was good to go.    So far it has increased my bandwidth speed and stopped my issues i had before.    I recommned this one to anyone who is thinking about upgrading as it works like the older versions.    I have yet to have any issues with it.
I got the hot pink,  I like the way it looks and I am getting used to the way it feels.  Looks really cool and it protects my key board.  LOVE IT!

Instances.input:
Personal perspective: I purchased an Airbender Air 2.0 direct from Idealpoint. After setup a number of keys were discovered to be bad and/or non-responsive. I was anxious to get a working keyboard; therefore, to save time, I received an RMA from Idealpoint and shipped the case back and ordered one from Amazon Prime at the same time. When reviewing the 2.0 on Amazon, I believe I addressed fairly the quality control issue regarding the keyboard as well as what I thought of the functioning keyboard I got from Amazon.

Airbender Pro:

The package was well organized and the instructions for assembly were clear, concise and easy to follow. The 1st thing I noticed after unpacking was the bulk of this case. It is built well and it is obvious that it will accomplish its protection mission easily. Additionally, it fits like a glove which provided comforting “clicks” as it went together. It is definitely designed for the Air!

It is heavy (2.58 lbs with iPad); however, I felt the weight was reasonable considering the level of protection it would obviously provide my tablet. When this case is closed it feels very secure (like a tank!) and provides access to all iPad ports and has the auto off/on feature in the cover that actually works well. However, there were obvious compromises made to ensure this security.

One of them is weight which makes the unit feel top heavy in your lap. After using the case in laptop mode for a week I began to understand that perception., However; in fact it only “feels” top heavy and does not really impact usage but is annoying. I have used it setting on the arm of an easy chair typing this review in lap top mode and it is very stable. Many people use iPad keyboard cases in their laps and if you have the extension arm directly in between your legs it can feel unstable If you move it right or left slightly it is stable as it is on a desktop. An easy solution for this would involve broadening the extension or provide an optional slide out piece that would establish a leverage base to one or both legs. Refinement of this one piece would silence many critics.

Other observations which could be complaints by some users are:

1. The locking and extension mechanism on the metal extension arm while innovative, is somewhat clumsy and could be improved. There should be a way to ensure the arm stops when it reaches its maximum extension without pulling away from the keyboard. Essentially, the release next to the extension should only serve to release the tablet from the keyboard

2. Initially there is a tendency to pull the outer protection loose at the space bar location when opening until you adjust your opening habits.

3. The ports are so well protected that they may be difficult for some to easily access. However, the only port cover I found difficult and needed a real fingernail was the lock/mute port but I use the software lock/unlock feature (swipe from below) and you can easily mute with the volume button so it’s a non-issue unless you really want to use the switch for manually locking the screen orientation.

4. Due to it's bulk and weight you can not maintain lower angles while reading without the tablet lowering to the keyboard.

5. The bulkier edge coupled with the built-in screen protector at times produces a lack of sensitivity on the edge of the screen when moving apps/folders to another screen.

The Bluetooth function found the iPad easily and has worked flawlessly as did the version 2.0 previously. The keyboard charged in 45 min and has outstanding battery life as advertised and every key functions as it should to include the iPad specific row on top.

The ability to remove the tablet from the stand easily, use the stand and iPad apart from the keyboard, 360 deg iPad rotation and the ability to position the screen at many different angle for reading, etc. makes this case extremely versatile.

In my opinion, at over $169 the Clam Case, which I owned, is this case’s only competitor and for all that money its only real advantage is it has a stiffer screen positioning mechanism. You can’t go wrong with this case and I would recommend it highly.

All the reviews are right, Excellent Range, No Dropout, Great throughput!

This is bar none the best mouse for the money. I've owned for approx. 3 months now with now issues what so ever.

PROS:
1. Extremely comfortable in your hand!

2. 7 buttons with 5 separate programmable modes that are VERY easy to set up for various games you may play. All buttons can also be keyboard customizable. Thus, if your game doesn't recognize a button on the mouse, you can record ANY keyboard function (multiple at once as well - eg: "Alt+G"). This means virtually no compatibility issues.

3. Thumb slider button to change DPI on the fly to any 4 modes you program.

4. Braided cable. Very slick looking and doesn't get tangled.

5. Essentially plug and play. I had no issues with setting up.

6. The package/box it comes in...WOW! You'd think you bought the best mouse that exist. Carrying case, nice instruction booklet, CD Drivers, and a slick looking sticker

CONS:

1. The middle wheel and current program button slowly flashes and there's no way to just keep it a constant color - however this is so miniscule and doesn't bother me too much compared to the PROS

I purchased this case for my HTC ONE for a couple reasons:

Cost: For the price I paid, the case meets my expectations. It was cheap, and the materials used reflect that, but this should be expected. The leather they used is holding up well, but I have numerous threads that are coming out of the leather. Grade: B

Screen Protection: I like the front cover on the case. It provides, to me, a sense of protection to the screen of the phone from scratches and drops. I do not know how much protection it provides, but there were times where I mishandled the phone and thought for sure my screen would be smashed. As it turns out, my screen is intact so far! Additionally they send a screen protector. If you take your time and are patient, you will not have any problems with it. I have no bubbles, and it works as intended. Grade: B+

Phone Body Protection: The plastic case that surrounds the phone and keeps it mounted to the leather is brittle. I drop my phone a lot, and I expected this case to be able to handle most of the minor bumps. After a week, the cheap plastic started to show its true colors. Pieces would constantly break off, and at one point had a sharp piece near my ear that would make it uncomfortable. After a while, all of the plastic that wants to break off will break off. However, despite the lack of plastic, my phone has remained in the case and in place. Grade: C-

Convenience: It is nice to be able to leave your wallet at home and only take the essentials for the night. Cash works fine if it’s folded and not in large quantity, and you can easily store an ID and credit card. The cash slot also makes a great screen wipe holder. The only disappointment was that the bottom slot became unattached from the case, and if I'm not careful the card will slide all the way down making it a challenge to remove. Grade: B (would've been higher if credit card slot stayed attached)

Design: This was not too feminine and rather conservative (which is good because I’m a guy!). The stand feature works 80% of the time (the other 20% the phone slides out of your viewing angle), and the magnetic flap gets in the way of viewing unless you bend it back (once you break it in it is not an issue). Taking pictures with the back camera is somewhat of a juggling act. I do not take pictures often, but if you do this will be bothersome. I have not experienced any flash glare. Front camera works fine. Also, the stylus is cheap, and I broke the clip on it the first week, which is sad because it was really nice to have. Grade: B-

Overall: I still use this case daily. I am not dissatisfied for what I got, for the price I paid, but there are areas that could be improved. Grade: C+/B-
output: Not the best but is convenient

Instances.input:
I have had this case for almost 2 months and I have no complaints and am enjoying it a lot.

It has several benefits:
- very low price in comparison to Apple-made smart cover
- sleep/wake function is flawless and works every time
- magnet to create stand is strong, stand never comes undone accidentally
- 2 viewing angles are just like Apple's Smart Cases and Covers
- has rear facing microphone hole for iPad Mini Retina Display
- has colors not made by Apple
- very sturdy, nothing is going to tear this case
- absolutely no obstruction from case for camera, volume keys, wake/sleep button, headphone port, microphones
- the part of the cover that lays flat on the screen feels like microfiber and will not damage screen

It has a few (negligible) drawbacks:
- no place to hook a stylus if you wanted to
- material is sturdy, but feels *slightly* cheap, which is ok, due to the price (it's really not bad at all)
- slight obstruction of speakers, as is expected with any case that is to fit snugly, but no sound quality lost

OVERALL:
Benefits are huge in comparison to the drawbacks, I have recommended this case to others and will purchase another should I need it.
output: very sturdy, exactly the color I wanted, fits iPad Mini with Retina Display perfectly, sleep function is flawless

Instances.input: I bought this drive due to the fact that it seemed rather inexpensive for a 1Tb model and was the best seller in amazon. When I opened it, it seemed very pretty and slick, the drive can have a password protection and there is also a way to encrypt your files. The problems started when I tried to do such things. The most simply of tasks, backing up, can't be done with this drive. It stalls if the backup is too big and after a few minutes it completely stopped. It has taken 2 hours just to backup 700Mb of data due to the fact that it has been halted to 100Kb a second, something that any modern drive can beat easily. Going through forums to fix the problem yields no results due it being a software error. Its also worth noting that this is IF you want to have password protection on your drive. If not you can just delete all the WD software and leave it completely bare, which is not the point of anyone buying this hardware. Completely disappointed in this product.
output: ... rather inexpensive for a 1Tb model and was the best seller in amazon

Instances.input: My old Apple battery was totally dead, and since my Macbook is 4 years old and probably about to die at any moment, I decided to go with a cheaper imitation battery rather than a (more than twice the price) Apple battery.  You get what you pay for, I guess.  I have followed the calibrating and charging instructions, but am lucky if I can get 2 hours or so out of this battery...less if i watch a DVD.  Still, it is better than no battery at all, and i have learned to minimize my power draw by turning down my display brightness to the lowest I can stand and not running multiple programs.  It looks and fits okay, but the micro-chip in it sometimes can't make sense of what it's current charge or time remaining is.  I initially wanted to return it, as i assumed it was faulty, but Amazon made it such a hassle that I am just gonna suck it up.  I am trying to drain it completely before charging it...completely, hoping this will extend it's life.   So, bottom line--- if you are like me and are at the cusp of getting a new Macbook anyway but just want to keep your old one on life support, go for it....I can't rationalize spending $130 or more on a battery for an old laptop.

I'll start by saying, when it works, it's a good router, which is why I didn't just give it 1 star.... again, WHEN it works.
When I first set up the router, it was working really well. The setup was annoying, because occasionally, when I would apply a new setting, the router would never come back online, after 'rebooting'. I usually had to go back to my basement, and power cycle the router. Eventually, I got everything set properly.
Then my wife complained that her tablet kept disconnecting. I changed some settings, and it appeared to work, for about a week. Then I started having issues where my whole house wifi would reset, usually while gaming on my PS4.
So, last weekend, I factory reset the router, and started over. The setup went much better this time, and everything appeared to be good. Then I went to remote into work, and my desktop PC (wired), would not connect. I then tried my server PC, which is wired, but had been off. It too would not connect. So, I tried to access the router, using the web interface, and it just sits on a screen saying 'waiting'. Looked on the Linksys forums, and I see this problem has existed for over a year, and has not been even acknowledged by Linksys.
So, I try the mobile app, and it connects, then shows the 'searching' screen after about a second. Then it finds the router, and one second later, it searches again. It's an endless loop. I even tried reinstalling the app (and clearing cache). As soon as you look at devices, it goes into the loop. Look at the comments on the app, and you'll see (again) this is a common problem.

Unfortunately, all this trial and error, has extended me past my return period. I just ordered a Netgear, and I'm done with Linksys. I bought this to replace my e2000, which had been acting flaky, and randomly resetting the wireless connection to my laptop (no other devices were dropped). I'm done with Linksys. There is too much competition out there to keep wasting my time with them.em.
output: Quite possibly the worst router I've had in a long time

Instances.input:
If you are reading this, you might be thinking of getting a Kindle. Specifically, the Paperwhite. I bought a Kindle 2nd Generation back in 2009 (?) and I truly think the Paperwhite is what I was looking for with my original Kindle. I have an iPad and people ask me all the time \\"Why do you need a Kindle AND an iPad?\\" The iPad is wonderful. I love mine but it has limitations. It's a little heavy after holding for a period of time, it strains my eyes, and try reading on it outside, because it won't happen. But you probably already know that. So back to the review.... let's talk about the benefits of the Paperwhite.

It's lightweight but still sturdy. I don't feel like I am straining to keep it held while reading, but it is also sturdy enough that I think it could stand some minor drops (I hope this doesn't happen, but it probably will). I love the fact that it is touchscreen. Not only that, but a fairly responsive touchscreen for the money (a minor flaw I'll mention later). My Kindle 2 had this round chiclet-style keyboard that may have been fine in the day, but always just seemed off to me. I am SO glad the keyboard is gone (and has been for a while, I know). Highlighting on the Paperwhite is a breeze compared to the old joystick style.

I also love the lighting feature. Duh, that's why most of us are buying them. I have been very lucky with my Paperwhite. I don't see any dark areas like some people have mentioned. It's a perfect amount of light that illuminates the screen. The E-ink is noticeably sharper than in previous generations. It's nice to see grey type on a white screen compared to the grey on grey with previous generations.

I also love the feature that tells me how long until the end of the chapter. Perfect for when I find myself yawning a little too frequently and need to finish up.

I know this sounds kind of odd, but I also like the rubber-type material that is the Kindle backing. It's not cold like an iPad andseems to be a little more scratch resistant.

What don't I like? Once you get used to the responsiveness of a higher end tablet, the Kindle can feel a little sluggish. But I have to remember that this is for READING, nothing else. That's honestly all I can say negative about it and that's not even a major gripe. The special offers on the screen don't really bother me.

For the money, I don't think there is a better e-reader on the market. I have enjoyed it at home and cannot wait to take it on the road and on the plane. After 10,000 feet, of course :)
very tight fit. a little nervous placing the Pi into it. once it works great. not really a downside just some insight

Instances.input: If I had written this review three days ago, I would have only given this item 1 star.  It was so messy to work with!  I have never been asked to spray a screen protector with fluid before.  It was a leap of faith for me to subject a brand new Kindle to such treatment.  The screen was very wet, and my fingers stuck to the sticky side of the film even though they were wet too.  I tried to imagine how I would explain to Amazon (after I destroyed the Kindle) why this seemed like a good idea at the time.  The result was a smeary screen full of tiny bubbles that would not smooth out.  I pushed so hard with the plastic device provided with the kit, that I was leaving marks in the screen protector.  I left it alone for a few hours, but it didn't look any better.  I pulled it off (and was relieved to see the Kindle screen was still okay) and tried putting it back on again with more fluid.  There were fewer bubbles this time, but more smears.    I couldn't look at it anymore, and put it away in a drawer for two days.  Amazon was prompting me for a review, so I pulled it out to take pictures of the crappy application.  I was willing to take some blame for the bad results, but I thought people should know how difficult this product is to apply correctly.  I work at a library and have successfully applied numerous screen protectors to a variety of devices.  Imagine my surprise when I found that all the bubbles were gone along with every single finger print and smear!  It looks great (actually, I can't see it), and the touch screen still responds as well as it did before.
worked great ^_^

Instances.input:
I use this keyboard to type multiple essays for college on my tablet. The typing experience is very adequate, despite the keyboard's small size. The keys are large enough so that my relatively-large hands are able to access them without any errors. Even as I type this review, I am not experiencing any issues.
So far, I have not encountered any problems regarding signal connection or latency. There have been times when I press a key and it becomes virtually "stuck," causing the same letter to appear repeatedly. However, this usually happens when I am typing while the tablet is busy performing some moderately intensive task, so I assume that the issue is not caused by the keyboard.
The keyboard looks and feels like a luxury item. However, there are two design features which irritate me:
1) The cover/stand's surface is a dust magnet! After only three days of owning the keyboard, the cover somehow managed to cover itself in a noticeable sheet of dust. It is relieving to know that the cover serves its purpose by keeping the keys clean, but I would have appreciated if the thing did not have a tendency to collect dust. Perhaps Microsoft did not consider that Arizonans would purchase this item.
2) That same dust-collecting cover has a third purpose. The only way to turn off the keyboard is to place the cover on it. This feature would not trouble me so much if the keys were not so close to the edge of the keyboard. There were times when I would place the cover on, unaware that I was pressing the shift key in the process. This caused some unwanted shift-click functions when I was attempting to use my tablet's touchscreen. To address this, I usually turn off my tablet's bluetooth receiver before putting on the keyboard's cover. I wish that Microsoft would have designed the keyboard with a basic on-off switch.
output: It works, but some design features need to be addressed.

I bought the KTU3FR-5O2U 4 months ago. It worked poorly from the start.  I have 4 external raid enclosures.  The card could only talk to one reliably.    I finally replaced it with another usb 3.0 card, which could talk to the 4 raid enclosures simultaneously.  When I looked at the KTU3FR-5O2U I replaced, I noticed that the card's 15 pin sata power connector was at an angle of 5-10 degrees with the back edge of the card.  I pushed it, and it moved.  Apparently it was not well connected to the board and the board was not getting enough power.    After some emails with Inateck customer support, Inateck sent me a replacement KTU3FR-5O2U.  I installed it last night and tested it.  It works flawlessly.  I am now very satisfied.

I'm extremely happy with this latest Sony tablet.

Pros:
- very solid build, engineered to perfection. The lightweight, the balance, the thinness, true Sony craftsmanship
- screen colors are rich, the resolution more than adequate at this size. I like the true HD and elongated form factor more than I expected.
- Sony Apps: SideView remote way cool -- it's made me enjoy using my television again. Sony Unlimited music doesn't get enough cred. This is really an excellent service with HD streaming, offline playback and playlists, and a virtually unlimited (as the name says) music catalog. I use this along with Tuned In Pro for my radio.
- Waterproof is more useful than I thought. When on vacation, I used in and around the swimming pool. Nice feature.
- Battery very fine, longer than I expected due to lightweight form factor.
- Speed very fine, no problems for me, snappy.
- Music and sound are quite good for a tablet. I pair it up with my Jambox, or else use headphones, so it is more than adequate in my opinion.

Cons:
- guest mode was removed. maybe this will come back in next OS update. minor, but nice feature for sharing in the family.
- screen is a bit smudgy. I may step up for the screen protector.
- the cradle is well designed and very useful. downside is the 3' USB cable. It needs a 6' cable to be able to use a floor socket. this was a compromise as the old Sony tablets had real power supplies.

Conclusion: I'm extremely happy with this tablet, with the speed and the business apps like Skype, box, and office I can finally use this as a real laptop replacement. The entertainment options rock, and this makes a true fun and business device for me. I think the price is fair. It's a real laptop equivalent but better in so many ways. The engineering and form factor that Sony puts into the product, I can see the difference. This is a 3rd generation product and it shows.

So here's the first and only review I've written from the stuff I've bought on Amazon. I did not base my decision on these other fake reviews as I did my own research to see how it holds up against all other sub $200 tablets. Everything I read seemed like it was a very promising product.  Cons: At one point, I turned on the tablet and the whole screen was pixilated. It eventually cleared up but this is not something that should happen with any tablet, ever.  You have to download and install your own .apk files. I've found that once the tablet goes into \\"sleep mode\\", it's very difficult to get it to boot back up. It took me 4 hours at one point to get the device to turn back on. The keyboard buttons are too flat and makes it difficult to type.   Pros: it has a beautifully responsive touch screen that responds just as well as an iPad. The internet ran screaming fast. It's really nice to watch movies on (even though the resolution is 800x600, but it's a sub-$200 tablet, to be expected). There is no choppiness at all like you see with a lot of tablets under $200  Overall it's a good product, but has a couple major bugs that need to be addressed. Hope this helps others make a decision on this product.

11/11/14:    I LOVE this tablet very very much. I personally do a lot of artistic things and go to school so this is very handy when out n about. Also very nice for organization! I carry much less than i used to, ie: binders and books , since iv'e had this. i have a small pouch where i carry my tablet in it's case, the charger just in case (you never know) ear buds, and a wireless keyboard.    Body: Slender but a good weight in the hand but I use it in a case( very light the backpack!!!) . Stylus tucked flush in the bottom right of the tablet, power button top right, volume right beneath it- windows button (toggle between screen on the left. There is NO USB port for your thumbdrive, only the smaller port. I suggest purchasing a OTG Micro to USB 2.0 Adapter if you frequently use a thumb drive.    Screen: Sensitive, the included stylus is perfect with the different pressure levels. that feature is taken away if you use another stylus, but still works with my backup pen. I suggest getting a screen protector for your tablet! Particularly if you have a heavy hand when writing or you think you will find yourself writing a lot in general.    ***CAUTION*** Research your cases for your tablet! Ask questions about it with the sellers! I purchased a case i assumed to have no magnets by the look and the description from a seller on amazon-but it ended up having small magnets to keep a back panel secure. Magnets WILL mess with the sensitivity/connectivity from any stylus to the screen- creating a fade-out effect. Always double check- even if it's said to be made for your tablet.    Battery life: Perfect for my needs! They say up to 8 hours, but it really depends what you do- If you have several programs you're going between- like listening to music on youtube and running a drawing program for a while- itll drain a battery a little quicker. just use common sense- tap the power button when you're done with it.    *A note on Apps!*  The tablet comes with really handy apps for everyday use- note-taking and organizational purposes.  I prefer the Windows Journal for my class Notes for its easy-to-edit ability. If you write a bit more neatly, the OneNote will work perfect- particularly if you like more visual organization methods. I wanted to add this so other students did not feel they had to rush off to get an app right away without looking at these included ones first! ALSO- you do not HAVE to have programs as an app from the app store! You can download programs as you normally would on your windows 7 (if that is what you are accustomed to) All the programs are listed in app mode when you swipe up (so you know where to find your new programs you downloaded in PC mode.)    Typing vs handwriting: I have smaller hands mind you, but i found this actually very easy to type on when in a case, (in lap or on a table for long periods of time) but I you have need for more wiggle room, id suggest a wireless keyboard if you see yourself typing ALOT in the foreseeable future. :) Handwriting was very fun- more so than i thought it would be- just takes a little getting used to how you write.    Interchangeable between modes! Very handy on both accounts- I have found myself using both modes on the tablet for different things- only thing i wish still worked is listening to music on one- switching modes and still being able to hear it. It instead continues where you left off when you switch back. Not a huge loss though!    I suggest playing with this for a day, after you charge it completely- just so you can figure out how windows 8 works if you are new to it. Overall , I am totally dazzled by this, and find myself taking notes as often as i draw! Once im done with my drawing, I save, plug in my USB with my adapter, and transfer it to my laptop at home to continue off where i was in photoshop. Very mess free compared to carrying a bunch or art supplies or a heavy laptop around!    Hope this helped! I will update more if i come across anything new~

Instances.input:
This is/was my third QNAP. The unit works as advertised and operates just like the earlier models. So why one star and why did I return it? .....Hard drives, HOT ONES.

As I mentioned, this was my third QNAP. Sitting right next to this one (TVS-463) is the TS-653 and further, a TS-559.
*In both the 463 and 653 I have installed identical model hard drives Hitachi's HDN724040ALE640.
**Sitting right next to each other and running identical firmware, the hard drives in the 463 continuously run 10 - 15 degrees F warmer than the 653.

WHY? A couple of reasons, perhaps.

I noticed that the hard drive tray face plate, for lack of a better phrase, no longer includes the lattice of holes that were present on previous designs. Maybe this is stifling the air flow across the hard drives.

I also noticed, while monitoring the system, that the [default] fan speed in the TVS-463 is apparently too slow to do much good for the hard drives. I stress default here because as soon as you change the fan speed from 'Smart Fan' to medium or better, the overheating issue is irrelevant, although the drives were still running warmer than they should be.

My fan, set to 'smart fan', was rotating around 450-600 rpm even as the system began to beep and present a hard drive over temp warning. Interestingly, the CPU and System temps were normal. Does this tell us the hard drive temperatures are not taken into consideration when calculating the 'smart fan' speed? Perhaps there was a bug; who knows.

In any case, I monitored the system and this behavior for a week. I contacted QNAP support to see what their response would be and they told me to "set the device to medium fan speed."

Are you familiar with the term work-around? :)

Right, what else could be done? Nothing. Wait it out for a potential firmware update addressing the issue or return it and get one that doesn't overheat drives.

Replacement candidates: TS-453 or TVS-471
output: tl;dr: QNAPs TVS-463s [default] design does not provide adequate ventilation causing hard drives to overheat...

Having used both the Audiotron and the SLIMP3 I can say (like others who have upgraded to the SliMP3) that the SLIMP3 is a vastly superior product. The Audiotron was very hard to setup, the SLIMP3 was just plug and play.
What else does the SLIMP3 have going for it?
- It's user interface is much easier to learn and quicker to use.
- It has a powerful web-based interface and a terrific remote control.
- The tiny display on the AudioTron makes it hard to navigate and find music, in contrast the SLIMP3 display is large and bright and easily readable.
- A single computer can serve many SLIMP3 players easily, and multiple SLIMP3 players scattered around your house can be synchronized to play the same music together.
- If your music collection continues to grow, you'll reach a hard limit on the AudioTron, not so with the SLIMP3.
- The SLIMP3 imports all of your genre/artist/album/title information from the ID3 tags.
- The SLIMP3 integrates beautifully with Mac OS X, Linux and Windows. The MacOS X integration with iTunes is particularly sweet.
- The SLIMP3 software is open source, so bug fixes and new features come fast.
- The SLIMP3 starts playing music much more quickly than the AudioTron, songs start in 1/8 of a second.
- The SLIMP3 technical support is outstanding.
- The analog audio quality of the SLIMP3 output is great.
What does the AudioTron have going for it that the SLIMP3 doesn't?
- WMA support (If your music is in MP3 format, this doesn't matter.)
- Digital out
Finally, the SLIMP3 is about 70 dollars LESS than the AudioTron. An easy choice.

Fits well, and doesn't add a lot of bulk to the iPad.  All openings are in the right position.  I can turn it on, adjust the volume, and charge it just fine with the case on the iPad Air.  There are also cutouts for the speaker.  The sleep/wake function also works, and the magnet is strong enough so that the cover won't unintentionally open up even if you were to flip the iPad upside down.  The cover lies relatively (though not totally) flat against the screen, but I think it will flatten out over time.  The stand function is not real stable, as the folded front cover does not want to stay folded.  The inside of the front cover has a soft felt-like surface to protect the screen of the iPad.  It is pretty thin, so don't know about how long it will last.  As for the durability of this case, I have only had it for a few weeks, so I can't speak to that.  I can only say that I have not had any problems with it yet.  As for some other reviewers comments about the plastic corners on the back breaking, I have not tried to remove the case since first putting it on the iPad Air, so I don't know if I would encounter the same problems.  (I'm not going to press my luck :).  This case provides protection from mild bumps and screen protection from scratches, but I don't think it would help that much if the iPad was dropped.  If you need drop protection, I would consider another case (maybe the Supcase, but that costs a lot more than this case).  All in all, for less than seven dollars, I think that this case is a very good value.
output: Pretty decent case for the money

Instances.input:
I bought the EyeTv 500 as a solution to my TV needs. Being a European in the US i miss very much widescreen broadcasts that i am used to there and so the HDTV option was the obvious. I have it running on a 20\\" 1.8Ghz iMac G5 with 1.26GB RAM and a 250GB HD (also another same external). I live in a ground floor apartment which has no external aerial hookup so i have indoor (rabbit ears) antenna plugged into it (i may get up on the roof later and see if i can patch into the antenna). The reception is not fantastic (though the strange thing about DTV signals it that you get no fuzz. it's a fantastic picture, but it can drop out for a few seconds at a time. it's not variable, it's either there and great looking or its not there.) The system requirements shouldn't really be so low. It really does require a dual G5. Unfortunately you can't live downsample the HDTV signal to a 720 or SDTV signal to suit your machine. HDTV signals are choppy. Not really an ideal viewing solution. Great if you have a dual processor G5 i'm sure. But for anything less, don't expect much. My solution is to record the HDTV programs (which is not proceesor intensive), then downsample and compress them (which still ends up looking better than a regular analogue US NTSC signal on a regular TV) and then watch the recorded downsampled programs.

Note: EyeTV software only records the unadulterated HDTV signal. If you want to compress or change format you can export it (in EyeTV) to another format. But beware this encoding take a long long time. Turning a 30 minute recorded program into a MPEG-4 640x360 movie (which still looks really good from a TV viewing distance btw) it will take 4 hours (on my system which ain't the slowest by far!)

To be honest with you i bought this unit to replace my previous solution of downloading bittorrents of HDTV recorded programs. These torrents have becoem less widespread due to certain file sharing law suits. I like to beable to watch only the programs i like. Most of the rest of american TV browsing i find to be depressing. I do have a solution in this. I now can replace these downloaded TV programs with a Legal alternative, however i now realise the work that the kind person who recorded those programs and compressed them and put then on the internet did.

Result: If you've got a dual processor G5 and a good antenna hookup then get one of these. If you've got a lesser Mac and need to have a widescreen program (as i do) then get one but know that watching live TV won't be so good, and you'll have to wait a while before you can watch your recorded programs (a similar time it might be noted was required to download a program over the web). If you want TV on your lesser mac and don't care so much about widescreen signals, then get one of the normal non-HDTV EyeTV tuners (the 200 i think?).

If your bugdet is not small.... fork out and get didicated hardware. i.e. a real HDTV and DVR. It may be much more expensive but you won't have to put in so much work to watch your TV programs!

I'm not disappointed. But i am very techy and very Mac oriented. I wouldn't recommend this to someone who doesn't spend so much time playing around with computery things. If you already have trouble programming a real VCR then purchasing one of these is gonna result in your having less hair.

hope this helped you. Sorry if i waffled.

If one is looking for a great feeling mouse this is the one.  The comfort and grip of this mouse is excellent.  There are two aspects of this mouse however that a potential buyer might want to consider.      First if you have a smaller hand print like mine, the buttons on the left side may be somewhat awkward to use.  It's hard for me to depress button four without depressing button five.  In order to compensate for my shorter thumb I have to grip the mouse at a slight angle which results in a less comfortable grip.  If I'm playing a game where the left mouse buttons are critical I switch to the R.A.T. 7 which has been optimized for my hand shape.      Also, even though there are five profiles that can be stored on the mouse, there is no button on the mouse specifically for switching from profile to profile without using the Mionix mouse software.   If a button like this were present, this mouse would be very near perfection.    Finally I have read several reviews of the Mionix Naos 5000 that criticized the weight distribution mechanism on the bottom of the mouse.  While it is true that the weight system is somewhat clumsy, I personally do not see this as a significant drawback whatsoever.  Once the mouse is weighted it would seem doubtful that the user would be constantly changing them.

This bag is great. I had been eyeing this as one of my co-workers has one, so I finally broke down, found it, and purchased.

PROS:
- lightweight bag, yet durable
- shoulder strap is adjustable and doesn't get twisted
- optional handles feel good - do not dig into hand/soft
- I like that there are NO obvious tags or names or images on the bag -- I like that it is all black/uniform looking
- holds the smallest to my large work laptop (one at a time obviously) - 14.5" laptop, could probably hold 15"
- for me, because it is vertical - helps to distribute the weight across my shoulder more evenly

CONS:
- the compartment for the accessories is a little tight - I manage to put in a couple pens, the power cord/adapter, and my travel mouse -- it is tight, but what do you expect right?

Overall a great bag for $30 USD. I would buy this again!

so i purchased this thinking it would be a nice cover for my notebooks, provide good storage for the pen and be a simple tote for all my livescribe writing - but because of its awkward design (informed by the sheer bulk of the livescribe pen), the usually slim area reserved for the pen at the spine in most covers has expanded into the cover itself making it wider. you can actually see this in the product photo but it affects the feel in the hand more than is apparent (to me at least).

instead of feeling like a tight, second skin for the notebook, it has the floppy feel of a photo album. imo, it would have been better to make the spine tight against the notebook and have a region at the top for the pen so you can get a solid grip with one hand.

the bungie fabric for the pen is plenty tight and the product does everything that it claims to just fine. it's made well and the fabric inside and the rubberized outside is great. but it just doesn't feel \\"solid\\" in a one handed grip and ends up feeling \\"floppy\\" and awkward.

i'm going to get the leather pen case and just put the pen in my pocket and carry around my notebooks naked.

EDIT: actually, just discovered a feature that took it from a 2 star rating to a 3 star! there are TWO elastic bungies. one is to hold the pen in the case. the OTHER is the one that i missed - it is a band attached to the rear cover that holds the top cover closed while carrying it around! that alone makes the portfolio much less \\"floppy\\" and unweildy. form factor wise, it is still a bit unwieldy but much better now that the cover is banded closed.
output: skip this and just get the leather case for the pen

UPDATED REVIEW  -   Initially I was very pleased with this keyboard with the only real drawback being the lack of the numeric pad found on larger keyboards.  I have used this keyboard and mouse for several months (nearly a year).  The major complaint is this keyboard often misses keystrokes during normal typing.  You will type a word completely and correctly and occasionally a letter will be missing.  I write invoices about 5 to10 times a day and this occurs in nearly every invoice.  If this keyboard were a few years old then I would understand but it's less than a year old. I have been dealing with this since about the 2nd month of use.  I have tried changing batteries, relocating the USB dongle to different ports on my laptop/docking station (even moved offices but not for this reason).  Nothing improves performance.  Now I'm not saying this is junk.  On the contrary....for light to moderate use this keyboard is awesome.  I would highly recommend this for travel as the size is perfect.  As for using in an office for daily use.....well it just barely misses the mark.  I wanted to keep my desk free of clutter, looks like I'll be searching or a different keyboard at some point in the future.  I'll keep using this for now.     ORIGINAL REVIEW  -  The keyboard is very quiet as described.  The spacing of the keys is similar to a standard keyboard while excess plastic and trim has been removed.  Type just as you do on a standard keyboard without missing keys. The mouse is very small but perfect for travel.  The mouse covers a little less space than a credit card making it ideal for cramped locations.  They keyboard and mouse use two AAA batteries.  The keyboard is raised by the battery compartment providing a comfortable working angle.  Both items are very slim and easily stowed for travel.  When not in use, the USB wireless receiver can be stored in the battery compartment of the mouse (and arrives this way when purchased).  This review is to help those who are lookingat this product for its size.  This product has not been used extensively enough to offer any advice on reliability.  Product operating on a laptop using Windows 8.1.
output: UPDATED REVIEW -  Perfect for travel, ok for daily use.....

I haven't really had any trouble with Vista but I find that it helps to verify what works with Vista 64 and install the latest version. And this card sounds wonderful. I was just hoping to get rid of the buzz created by my on-board audio card (Gateway FX4710). I did not expect to hear such a difference. My low-priced Cambridge Soundworks speakers really came alive. I have a spare pair of Proac Tablette speakers. I think I will give those a try. And yeah, the static is gone too.

I did have one small Vista-related glitch. [...] On re-boot and startup I would get messages asking if it is OK to run HsMgr.exe and HsMgr64.exe files. The solution is to go into the folder where you unzip the file you download (vista\SoftwareDriver\DLL) and unblock those two files (in file explorer right click). I had to uninstall the software and then reinstall it after I unblocked the files.

I couldn't be happier with this sleeve case for my Kindle Touch. This one is superb -- and after months owning it, I'm still as happy. I'd give it 6 stars if I could. It's well designed, it's built well, and it just feels good and looks nice. I'm confident it's safe - and I'm a worrier!

The design: Nice snug fit for the Touch, no slop nor too tight. The memory foam protects without adding bulk. I think it's the most streamline case (sleeve or not) I've seen with this much protection and ease of entry. The velco is just long enough to hold the case closed and short enough that the annoying ripping sound of velco is a quick.(A fact my spouse appreciates.) Since I don't have to stuggle with a longer piece of velco, it's no big deal to keep my Kindle in it's case.(An added bonus for when I don't want to look at the current screen advertisement.)The quilting on the cover helps me grip it better and adds to the case stability.

The build: I'm very very picky. My sleeve didn't have the tinest bit of stitching off or any flaw. The case feels substantial and solid, even though it's light.

Aesthetics: I was surprised how the brown color pleases me, since it's not a color of anything else I own. It's a rich chocolate brown with enough brightness to have some interest (vs black) yet still be subtle. It looks good lying on any surface -- it doesn't clash. I also enjoy the feel the slight yielding the memory foam will give when firmly pressed. (great for those boring moments....)

If you're on the fence about buying any sleeve -- get this one. It's just perfect. You'll soon forget the cost and just enjoy the product.
output: Terrific case - elegant, simple, it works

I expect the best from Logitech. My old MX 518, now deceased, delivered. Not so much with this one.

First impressions out of the box:
1. Loose parts near the wheel. The "lock" mechanism that turns the wheel from a free-spinning internet wheel to a clicking game wheel just feels incredibly cheap. The other buttons on the mouse feel cheap, too.
2. Sandpaper texture. The light gray part in the picture has a very rough texture, quite unlike the softer, slightly grippy surface I'm used to on the MX 518.
3. Balance. Very heavy near the back, very light at the front.

After a few days of use:
1. Battery life. Extremely short, basically need to keep it plugged in to get use out of it.
2. Friction. Doesn't slide over the pad nearly as freely as the MX 518 did. Feels like I have to pick it up to get it to move, resulting in....
3. Lack of precision. I can't make the minute twitch moves I need to make to get fast accurate shots in FPS games.
4. Sandpaper texture. Starts to hurt after a while, especially when you need to really grip the mouse to get it's heavy butt off the pad to start to move.

Wishing I could find a valid reason to return it other than "it sucks".

That being said, it is a full size wireless mouse, and fits my hand better than the wireless notebook mouse I use on travel.

One of the three fans stopped spinning after a few weeks. I called Gigabyte and got a person right away w/ no waiting. I asked for a new fan so I would not have to send the card in. I emailed them a copy of my invoice and was sent a replacement fan. All three fans are still working now. I think it was just a fluke, as I don't hear of other people having this problem.

The card is fast and overclocks well. The default fan setting is 30% and very quiet. It gets fairly loud at 100% but cools very well (as long as you have good airflow in your case).

The card is big and heavy. I can see it sag in my case. It could use a kickstand.

6 month edit:
I liked the card so much, I ordered a 2nd card. Right before I got it, artifacts started appearing everywhere (on my 1st card). I sent it back to Gigabyte, they fixed and returned it in 2 1/2 weeks, no problems (well, except that I had to pay to ship it to them). It works fine now. My main issue now is w/ the 2nd card I bought. It was not a reference board, but a 'B' or 'Boost' board. The model number and box are exactly the same. Stock it runs at 1000 MHz, but the voltage is locked at 1.25 volts. The end result is that this card runs hotter at 1028 than my original does at 1100 (I think it was at ~1.12V).

I have them cross-fired now, so they have to run at 1028 MHz. 1100 would be nice. I also had to pull a usb3 controller I had in a pcie slot as it was blocking too much airflow. These cards really do depend on good airflow through your case.
output: a fan quit working, artifacts, 2nd card runs hot

Instances.input: I had never wanted a laptop, but finally broke down and and decided to get one for school, because I needed something portable.    Looking around at laptops, I realized I didn't want a netbook, despite the price and battery life, because of the tiny screen and keyboard.  Then I saw a 13.3 inch laptop at the store, and decided that was the perfect size.  Not too small and not too large.  My Toshiba is light enough to stick in my backpack and not worry about breaking my back, and it's small enough to fit as well.  The keyboard is decently sized, though it's missing an actual number pad.  The number pad is a small section of the keyboard used with the Fn key.    I have not tested the limits of this laptop, as I only meant it for school work.  Typing and internet use.  It does great at both of those.  The only game I've tried on this laptop is Minecraft, and I can say that that doesn't run all that well.    I've noticed that the speakers can be amazingly loud sometimes.  It's nice when you want to show a video or song to some people.  Even in a noisy room, it's possible to hear.    I am pleased with the battery life, as I can get out of my three hour class with about half the battery left, if I've got the brightness set down.  I'm sure I could do more to get more battery life.    The downsides to this laptop?  Every now and then, it's been a disappointment that it doesn't have a cd drive, but that isn't too bad a problem.  However, I do dislike the mouse pad(mouse pads in general, this is a pretty good mouse pad.  I just dislike using it).  That was one of the big issues I've had with laptops.  I haven't got around to buying a usb mouse yet, so I try not to complain much.    Overall, I'm glad I went for this Toshiba.  It was well worth the price, as I will be using it for a foreseeable while, and have already used it for a semester and a half.  If you are looking for a decent laptop at a decent price, one that is lightweight and not too big, one for school work, then Iwould definitely recommend this one.

I made about 10 cables using these connectors, and I have seen intermittent connection problems with 3 of them. I noticed 2 problems specifically: 1) the plug does not fit snugly in the socket -- it can wiggle a bit, which can cause a disconnection in the line when the cable or switch is bumped. 2) the #1 pin (the orange/white wire connection using Standard 568B) does not always pierce the wire fully. Upon further inspection, when the connector is crimped, there is a tendency for pin #1 to be pushed aside rather than driven into the wire. This happened on two of the connectors.

I decided to measure the plugs against the plugs of 3 other manufacturers. The width of the 3 other manufacturers' plugs ranged from 0.457" - 0.460". These plugs measured 0.451". This may seem like a small difference, but my assessment is that this smaller width is the cause for both the loose connection and the crimping problem.

However, once I fixed the crimping issue, and if the wires/equipment is not jostled, the plugs work.

Instances.input:
I was a Kindle 2 owner, and the Kindle 3 is a great update. The contrast is incredible. The text is actually black now. There are minor changes in the OS that make the Kindle 3 superior to its predecessor, such as the disappearing \\"title bar\\". Because there is no longer a title bar while reading, it more closely mimics the natural reading experience.

The Kindle 3 is smaller and lighter than the Kindle 2. You can comfortably hold it in one hand while reading. The web-browser has also been improved. Before, most pages were in \\"Mobile\\" format, but now you actually view the entire website.

Also, the back of the Kindle is now matted, which helps your grip.

Battery life also seems to be improved.

Overall, this is a great product at a very reasonable price. Ultimately, it's all about reading. And as the Amazon advertises, it \\"disappears in your hands\\". Simply, it's a joy to read on.

. . .

After four months, the Kindle began to develop 2 cracks: one on the left corner below the screen, and one on the right. I called Amazon, and they sent me a new one the next day with free shipping. Though I was disappointed in the short lifespan of the plastic body, Amazon customer service couldn't be better.
