Instances.input: I got the airport extreme, because I bought a new Macbook Pro.  Almost nothing works as advertised, and the help text and website help is useless.  First, my ISP requires a MAC address, and the airport does not share the internet signal very well.  The Airport gives you a double-NAT error, and Airport recommends you disable internet--WHAT?  this is why I got it for.  After days and nights of figureing that out, I found where you could disable this message.  The help files and manuals do little other than tell you how to plug it in.  In troubleshooting, it tells you to disconnect the power and restart it.  The reset switch does not reset the base station.  If you go into the setup utility, your IP addresses and sharing and other things are the same.  The only thing the reset button does is reset the password.  In order to get my internet to work, I had to disable the NAT error, and I had to hard code an IP address in the DHCP screen.  Is'nt DHCP dynamic?  Why do I have to hard-code an IP in DHCP?  It was hell getting the internet to work.  The Wan port is advertised as a gigabit port.  That may be true, but the other three ports are 100 Mbit ports--that's false advertising.  USB port is the main reason I liked about this base station.  I wanted to share my printer over it.  Printer sharing: It only works with about 15 HP printers, unfortunately, it does not work with my printer.  I also wanted to use the USB port for my external hard drive.  It works with USB thumb drives, however it does not work with drives formatted in NTFS-it only works with FAT formatted drives.  This again is not documented or advertised.  You are hard-pressed to find any support on the website.  It is a pretty unit.  And I get good coverage (up to 250 feet outside the house)  Over all, the reasons I bought this base station, I cannot use.  And I cannot share resources with my Windows computers.  Apple computers and OS are good, but their other products really suck.  This thing is falsely advertised to work with USB printers and USB drives, but only a few of USB devices acutually work, and ISP sharing took me about a month (days and nights) to get it to work.  DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT.  BUY SOMETHING ELSE.
output: DO NOT BUY THIS.  Apple's falsey advertised, utter disappointment

First the good points. I really liked the form factor of this card, it sits flush with side of my notebook and adds an extra USB port. The drivers were available for both 32bit and 64bit Windows 7 (and earlier OS'es too) and seem to work just fine.

Now the not so good. First of all, the USB3 port is very tight, putting in and removing a USB device requires about twice the usual force. In my notebook, this means the card ejects itself every time you insert or remove a USB device. This is only a minor inconvenience though as it plugs right back in and works fine without rebooting.

My real problem with this card though was the performance. I bought it to hook up a [[ASIN:B007YXA5TC SanDisk Extreme 32 GB USB 3.0 Flash Drive SDCZ80-032G-X46]] to my notebook and while it works fine, it is not much faster than USB2. On my USB2 port, the drive reads/writes at 30.8/25.7(MB/s). Hooked up to this USB3 card, it is 37.7/36.6 or 22%/42% faster. Just for comparison, hooked up to a native USB3 port on my desktop, the same drive is 198.1/109.0 or 543%/324% faster than USB2. Note that the speed of my hard drive is not a factor here as I tested this speed using CrytsalDiskMark 3.0.1 which reads and writes directly to the drive you are testing, it does not copy data.

So, if you are really just looking for an extra USB port that will sit flush with the side of your machine, and you are happy with it being just a little faster than a USB2 port, then this card is a good choice. For me though, I wanted real USB3 speed and from that point of view I figure I only got a fraction of what I was expecting.
output: Nice form factor but only 22% faster than USB2.

Instances.input: If your computer runs windows vista 64bit or the new windows 7, DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT!    It will not work. You are then left with sending your print jobs to the servers IP address which is a) one way only so forget about that fancy printer/scanner you have and b) will not work anyway.  This unit refuses to work as a traditional print server.    The box and web site both say vista supported.      I called customer service and spoke to a level 1 tech.  He did not know what a print server was.  Level 2 was no better.  Level 3 began to tell me how I could set it up on a TCP/IP port.  I explained I wanted the bi-directional function I PAID FOR, and he said he thought he had a solution and would call back in a hour.   That was three days ago.

I use a lot of assistive technology because of wrist problems. When I first started researching foot switches online, I was amazed that some of them cost hundreds of dollars. I actually tried one foot controller that cost over $600. My problem was that the foot switch needed a lot of pressure to create the click, and that actually started giving me ankle and shin problems.

I decided to try the StealthSwitch 3 programmable USB foot switch controller because it seems like a cheaper alternative to other things I saw on the market. I was pretty confused by it at first – I bought the wrong foot pedal. Basically, the way this StealthSwitch FS – 1 works is you need both the programmable USB foot switch controller and the StealthSwitch FS – 1 momentary contact foot switch pedal with the 3.5 mm (1/8 inch) mono audio plug. Once I got both pieces though, it was awesome!

It was very easy to set up – practically plug-and-play, although you do have to decide what kind of "click" you want the foot pedal to create. There is a drop-down menu and you can basically click left click, right-click, double-click – pretty much anything you could possibly click, it is an option.

Once you assign a type of click to the foot pedal, you're good to click! This has completely revolutionized my ability to use the computer. By far, it is the best foot pedal I have found, because the StealthSwitch FS – 1 uses the least amount of pressure to create the click of any foot pedal I have found. I bring one to work and have one at home.

If you need a method for creating mouse clicks that does not use your wrist because of carpal tunnel syndrome or other hand or wrist problems, I really recommend the StealthSwitch programmable USB foot switch controller + the StealthSwitch FS – 1. Just make sure to buy the correct foot pedal to pair with the StealthSwitch 3 programmable USB foot switch controller– it has to be the one with the 3.5 mm audio plug, not the USB plug.o plug, not the USB plug.
output: Best value and easiest-to-click foot pedal  for making mouse clicks with your foot!

My refurbished TZ340 arrived today. These are my first impressions. (I own 6 other laptops.)

This thing is small and thin. Feels like it has no battery. Actually does weigh just a tad over 2.5 pounds. The carbon fiber is impressive.

Speakers are lots better than my netbook, not near as loud as my other laptops. At their highest, movies are, let's say, comfortable.

The keys are chicklet style--widely separated and little push. But unlike my older VAIO S150, the cursor won't skip around while typing, so no need for Touch Freeze. Tight here.

At 11 inches it is much easier to type on than the my netbook, but not at all like my regular laptops. Probably no extended typing on this one.

The screen is...OMG! It's not that the color is brighter it's the saturation! Colors are high contrast and just jump off the High Definition screen. Like nothing I've ever seen! It's the saturation, the WHITE (no yellow) background, and the razor (and I do mean razor) sharp HD screen. When desktop icons make you stare.....

Processor speed. The Core 2 Duo Ultra Lo Voltage chip is as fast as any of my other Core 2 Duos. With the Core 2 Duo and Windows 7 Professional, absolutely no need for more than a gig of RAM. It has infinite settings and adjustments for everything possible. I set the power on the chip at 75% to extend the battery life (and not dim the screen), and it is sufficiently fast, but you can feel the chip tugging on the bridle. Powered down to 75%, and the ubiquitos Sony fan turned down to 'quiet', the battery gets 4 hours. I guess that's OK for the (LOTS of) use it has apparently seen.

The blue tooth, fingerprint reader, web cam, etc., I haven't messed with.

Biggest unexpected surprises--the saturation and sharpness of the LED Hi Def screen. Second, how fast that processor is. I guess I was expecting what I get with Goggle Chrome stripped down on my netbook, not what I'm getting with a real laptop and full-blown Windows 7 Professional. Third, how light and thin it is--even with the dual-layer DVD burner. Fourth the wifi--picks up places I didn't know existed. Has wireless a/b/g/n--and I still don't own an 'n' router. Finally, how quiet and tight it feels. 'Lean' I guess is the word, No fat anywhere. Not a speck of wasted space.

Disappointments--impossible to type on in poor light (those dark keys and pale lettering), and the mouse buttons are right on the front edge. Takes getting used to.

All in all, how Sony packed all the stuff into what looks like a netbook, I don't know. Nobody else certainly did. It is aptly described as ultra portable.

Probably more than you wanted to know, but it is a powerfully packed little unit that once was prohibitively expensive, and beyond the reach of us mortals.light and thin it is--even with the dual-layer DVD burner. Fourth the wifi--picks up places I didn't know existed. Has wireless a/b/g/n--and I still don't own an 'n' router. Finally, how quiet and tight it feels. 'Lean' I guess is the word, No fat anywhere. Not a speck of wasted space. Disappointments--impossible to type on in poor light (those dark keys and pale lettering), and the mouse buttons are right on the front edge. Takes getting used to. All in all, how Sony packed all the stuff into what looks like a netbook, I don't know. Nobody else certainly did. It is aptly described as ultra portable. Probably more than you wanted to know, but it is a powerfully packed little unit that once was prohibitively expensive, and beyond the reach of us mortals.
output: A powerful laptop packed into a netbook-sized package!

Go ahead and buy it! I bought two to do a multiple-monitor setup at a trade show and they worked flawlessly. It's built for digital output, but includes adapters for analog and HDMI - that's a nice touch.    The setup was a breeze. I just plugged in, rebooted, and the extra monitors were running. There is a wide variety of ways to control the monitors -they can mirror, extend, and - best of all - you can set one to be the primary monitor! (That means your dock will show up on the chosen monitor in Windows XP, which my company still runs... VERY convenient for a laptop setup.)     It took all of ten minutes to have a three-monitor setup running and functioning to my needs. Refresh rate was clean, at least for my moderate demands. I'm impressed!
output: Expectations exceeded: portable, inexpensive solution for multiple monitors

How did I get mine:
===================
The seller sold 2x3014 @ $899/Ea plus $40 shipping with best offer option, I made $600/Ea for 2 and he accepted. So I paid $1,280 including the shipping for 2 new, sealed Dell 3014 :). Shipping from Canada to US took 5 business days.

The goodsss:
========
- Very nice color
- Text very sharp
- 30\\" with 16:10 ratio makes the actual view-able area is greater than 29\\" 16:9 and much greater than 29\\" 21:9
- There is no reflection in my room environment (general room with windows behind the two monitors, general lighting). I was so mad when I got the Dell S2740L 927M9-IPS-LED 27-Inch Screen LED-lit Monitor, I owned them for 1 hour and I had to RMA them (I turn off the light, I saw myself. I kept the light very dim, I saw myself. In general, Dell S2740L is a mirror)
- Nice Mini-Display Port to Display Port Cable. Saving $12-$20 to buy 2 of the cable
- I love the USB Hub. I am an engineer (well kind-off), I connect multiple data acquisition systems. EVGA Classfield SR-2 does not supply enough USB ports and external USB Hub sucks.

The badssss
========
- One of my 2x30\\" has control problem, it is very hard to get the menu appear. I \\"touch\\" the button, I \\"hold\\" the button, I \\"press\\" the button and...nothing happens. Then I try again and again, it finally appears. It is not too big of a problem because I know I do not use the control often - I only use monitor for my PC.
- White is not white, it is kind of yellow. With the settings, this can be compensated.
- Viewing dark images/movie/or whatever showings the bleeding. My old 2 x Acer 23\\" were worse but I got them $99.99/EA, while these 2 x Dell 30\\" 6.4 time higher with my purchase so I should raise my expectation.
- If I sit very close, I start to notice the \\"horizontal effect\\" but it has to be solid mono color. Otherwise, I do not notice. I wear glasses so my eyes are not as good as many people for sure.
output: Very nice but there are something

After experiencing the beauty of the new glossy black screens in the Garmin Nuvi [[ASIN:B003EYVHH4 Garmin nüvi 3790T 4.3-Inch Bluetooth Portable GPS Navigator]] , and the wonderfully thin case, I wanted the same experience in a laptop. I wanted an elegant experience and something lightening fast. This computer has it all!!! I have used it for 3 months so far without any problems. It is perfection in design and function. I still don't know how they put everything into such a thin, but sturdy chassis. The attention to detail is amazing. It doesn't run hot sitting in my lap, which was another requirement. There is a lot of subtle simplification in this computer. It only has 2 USB2 ports, which are all that is needed when you add a powered hub [[ASIN:B0006TIA8Y CyberPower High-Speed 7-Port USB Hub]], and connect it with one USB2 cable. The powered hub sits on a credenza that holds all the other devices I need (scanner, wireless mouse, DVD/CD drive, powered hard drive for backup, Scandisk flash memory, thumb drive, etc. I run wireless to a Cisco router/LAN [[ASIN:B003B48UQ8 Cisco-Linksys E3000 High-Performance Wireless-N Router]] with a LAN printer and that leaves only the power cord and the USB2 cable to plug in or unplug. I love the silence of a solid state hard drive. I love everything about this computer. It is an elegant and beautiful experience every time I use it. I have the 64 bit Windows 7 and 2010 Excel/Word/Outlook programs. What a wonderful software upgrade, and everything is so fast. The screen is like looking at a photograph, it is so beautiful!!! Welcome to a whole new world!!! I have owned Dell computers for about 10 years and have always been impressed with their service when needed. This was a replacement for a Toshiba tablet computer. I will update this review if I encounter any problems. I hope many of the Amazon readers will be able to enjoy this wonderful experience.

Note added 12/10/2012: Solid state hard drive died. Replacement was approx. $480, so I purchased a new Dell laptop. I still went with the SSHD on the new Dell, because it is just so fast. Also enjoyed every minute using this machine.
output: Lightening Fast Processing, Photographic Quality Screen

I just got my bag - and WAY faster than I expected. Great work, Amazon and UPS!

Now then - the bag. There are some design issues. The bag does not open flat - only a top zip. This is fine most of the time, but when one is taking the battery out, one needs both hands. Tough to do. And there is an additional USB port - but at the bottom of the battery compartment. Again, difficult to use.

If you are thinking it would be a simple process to re-route the included cords - nope. It is simply not doable. One of the pockets is clearly designed for your iPod. I do not own any Apple products - so one compartment is occupied by an Apple connector. Useless to me. The other \\"powered\\" compartment has both a micro USB and mini USB. The micro USB bent when I inserted it into my Android phone. It is no longer usable. I COULD return it - but I think I can get a little mini-to-micro adapter and be fine. If an adapter from Apple to micro exists, I don't know about it. I think this is flimsy construction, since I have never bent a micro USB before - though I know it does happen.

The construction of the bag seems solid. I like that the supplied charger cord (for the bag itself) can be used either while the battery is in the bag - or out of the bag. One could have more than one battery - and always have one charged. Due to the cost of batteries - I likely will not choose to do this.

The battery came charged - mostly. 3 bars out of 4 possible.

I bought two adapters. They arrived in perfect condition within the date range promised @ a competitive price. I use one to connect my mac to an external monitor and the other in a conference room to allow us to view our computer screen up on the 60 inch LED. Works great for both. Instances.input: Excellent product.
Comfortable, cute and girly... And the material this laptop cover is made out of is excellent! I'm very happy with it.

I tried to order one of these from their website but it gave no option for international shipping. I then found them on Amazon and ordered straight away. I am very happy with this and I have installed it on my cars dashboard. It blends in nicely, I don't have an ugly universal windscreen mount clogging up my screen and I can attach and remove my phone in an instant. It comes with all the attachments you need although I did use a different screw that had a nut on to allow me to fix it to my dashboard. All other screws are for wall mounting only and therefore do not need a nut to be tightened from the rear.
The grip is very strong when aligned with the supplied metal disc (comes with two) but it will still attach even when not fully aligned. This happened once and when I pressed my phones home button the phone tilted and came free from the magnet. Maybe there would be a stronger hold but I use an Apple iphone slim leather case which hides the metal disc and so there is not direct contact between the disc and the magnet. My phone has not fallen at all and it always holds in whatever position you want - even on bumpy roads.
I also intend to try this with my iPad in future. The magnet does feel strong enough but until I test it I cannot give any personal recomendations for this. I might try the Magbak magnets for this especially as the magnets are very slim and discrete. But with the shapes of iPads changing all the time I would have to keep buying a new model of Magbak each year too as they are not universal like the iOwall.
The only downside to the iOwall is that if I want to upgrade my phone I would have to remove the metal disc as I don't think I can buy these discs separately? Like I say I can't buy these direct from iOwall. I currently have one disc glued to one of the Apple stickers that comes with your iPhone and that sticker is stuck to the back of my phone. It doesn't look great but it won't damage my phone and it's also covered with a case so you cannot see it.
Over all I am very happy with this item. I did pay a little more for postage but it arrived at my home in the UK in just a couple of days and no additional import fees were required!!

I had previously tested and reviewed the "heavier" model of this device and can now compare the two versions for prospective purchasers. With both versions, installation was quick and simple and fit was perfect. Linking the keyboard to the iPad went without a hitch, too. Looking at the picture, you can see a round object where the iPad connects to the back support; this device has a "squeeze" release latch that allows you to remove the iPad from the keyboard for use without the keyboard - handy! Unlike the heavier duty version, this lightweight unit does not provide built in screen protection, so you'll want to take care of that with another product. When the iPad is removed for freestanding use, though, the lighter weight is nice.  When closed, the unit has a sturdy and dependable latch that keeps it closed but is easy to open. You may find the keyboard a little small for big hands, but it's limited by the dimensions of the iPad so that's to be expected. All in all, well worth the money!
output: Testing the lighter weight version of an already great product

So, I had to go through what I think is the laborious process of connecting the unit to my laptop by Ethernet, plugging it in, inserting the CD that is included in the unit and going through the setup process.

When I was done, some of my devices could connect to the Edimax as a repeater but most could not no matter what I tried. My Kindle said that it was an incorrect password so I went through the **** set up process one more time. Interestingly, it took 4 tries for the software to locate the Edimax which was hardwired to my laptop by Ethernet. I went through the process again making sure I had the password I wanted. My tablet was still not able to connect to the Edimax.

I had four computers on my home network hooked up to the router, and the router would divide all available speed with all the computers.  Even though I have high-speed internet, downloads were slow.  I bought this switch and hooked this up to the router first then hooking up the computers to the switch.  This way, the router gives all available speed to the switch, thinking it has only one.  My download/upload speeds on my home network has gone up significantly, and I am very impressed with the results.
output: Linsys by Cisco 5-Port Fast ethernet switch

Instances.input: I ordered my wife's kindle after 8pm 12/18/2012 driving back from Florida to Pennsylvania. Haven't even made it to DC and I just so happen to double check on delivery, and it was beating me to the house on the 19th. needless to say she loves it. Christmas well spent.

This is a very basic charging dock for an iPad or iPhone (i.e., no external speakers). It doubles as a stand, holding the iPad in portrait position for reading. Here are the pluses (+) and minuses (-) from my use over the past few days:

+ Charges both my iPad and iPhone
+ Small footprint (about as small as possible for an iPad dock)
+ Comes with an integral USB cable (about 2 feet), which plugs into a standard USB-to-AC adapter (included); makes for thinner, lighter cords and no bulky power adapter
+ If you turn the dock around, you can prop the iPad in landscape position on the back

- Fairly lightweight, so needs to hold the iPad almost vertically to maintain balance -- OK for viewing, but not for typing
- Having to spin the dock 180 degrees to prop the iPad in landscape mode is a bit clunky; also, can't charge in this position
- Does not work even with very thin iPad cases -- charger works only with "skins" or a bare iPad
- A bit pricey for a charging-only dock

Bottom line: Very basic dock. Fine if you want a dock to hold/charge your iPad in portrait position, don't need external speakers, and mostly view rather than type.

UPDATE: Feb 2013. After less than a year, this dock stopped working. There was no sign of physical wear, but the fit of the docking connector just wasn't there -- I had to push my iPad down onto the connector and hold it in place to make the connection and continue charging. I was afraid this might be damaging my iPad, so I scavenged the dock for parts (the AC-to-USB adapter that the dock plugs into was just a standard converter).
output: Basic, functional dock ... But lasted <12 months

I wish I could rate it 3.5 instead of 4 but am not given that option. So, anyone seeing this, my vote is a 3.5 rather than a 4!

Pros:
I'm new to the Kindle world, but my wife owned a kindle keyboard and I've used hers a few times over the years. I decided to purchase a cover to protect my new Kindle, since most assuredly my kids would drop it. This cover has a good grip, and it's durable; granted I've only had it a month. I like the feel of it, the grip, and the colors. It is fairly easy to hold (more on this later) and doesn't slip out of my hand.

Cons:
These two reasons are why I am not voting 5. It's over priced! I do think it's better than the other options, but I struggle with whether it's worth the price or not. Because of that, I struggle to recommend this.

Secondly, I wish it had some sort of strap to lock it open. If Amazon does do something like that, I'd like mine to be replaced, or at least they should send me a retro-fit kit. Anyway, I'm having a hard time figuring out how to hold it. Sometimes I hold it open, and other times I hold it closed. I find it most comfortable holding it with my right hand, but the left is a bit more uncomfortable and awkward. Amazon needs to figure out how to lock it open with a strap, magnets, button, or something. If that is addressed, then it would be more of a 4 to me rather than a 3.5. And if the price is lowered, then it becomes a 5 star rating.

This card works great.  I installed it on Windows 7 Ultimate 64-Bit with no problems.  I installed the card and downloaded the updated driver and it worked right away.  I'm using this to capture an HD signal from an antenna.  I use Windows Media Center as my DVR program.  After install and a quick channel scan I was up and running.  Initially this PC was my home theater PC used to stream my movies which were ripped to it.  In the other rooms I have other PC's that can connect to that one to watch the movies I ripped there.  The beautiful thing about this setup is that with the master PC in the living room and the other PC's in the other rooms I can record TV on the HTPC in the living room and watch them there as well as on any other TV in the house.  Anyway, the card works well and lets me record two shows as the same time which is nice.  It did not come with a remote but I didn't need that as I already had one setup for the HTPC and it controls this card just fine.  I highly recommend this card.

Instances.input: This was my first HP Computer, so I was a little apprehensive.  It came with better and more features than the competitions, so I felt it was a good risk considering the reasonable price. The makers of the Eyeball 2.0 clearly think the main thing a microphone and webcam should do is look good. Me, I don't care what IT looks like, I care what the video I record with it looks like.

Indeed, Blue Microphones is so laid back about functionality they offer no software support, and I quote from their website: \\"Blue Microphone cannot provide software technical support.\\"

I can see that selling stage mikes to bands might work like that. \\"Dude, you plug it in, what's to know?\\" But selling mikes and webcams to computer users? You would think they would try to help you use them. Here's their deal: You want to buy our cool looking stuff to look cool? Okay, but YOU figure out how it works!

My bad for not reading their website more closely before buying. I should not have expected, and neither should you, that it would be plug-n-play to record an iMovie on my Mac. That just doesn't work. BM offer a very clunky workaround with Photo Booth but the results are ugly (and not just because I tested using my face). Even on a short movie clip recorded with this workaround the audio was way out of sync with the video.

For my purposes, recording a video podcast on my Mac, this was a fail. I am now going to try it on my trust old Windows XP machine. If that works I will update my review.
output: Looks good, works maybe, and not worth it

If you are not as tech savy-as i am not-let me save you some time. You look at the drive space on this thing and scratch your chin. Dont bother trying to move the apps to an SD card. It is not yet supported. I've tried remapping an all of it. Once I learned a few things, what works and not, i came to be happy with the device. Yes, it is better than the chrombooks. Less work arounds. The thing is, doing it this way can be hard too. Have someone help you.

1. Create a virtual drive. Be careful, but its not hard to do on your sd card. get the large one up to 64gb, nothing higher supported atm. You need to create a script, use windows task manager and set it to run the virtual drive. There are good explanations on the net. Adding links will only get them removed by amazon anyway.

2. Even when things download, they love to go on the c drive. Copy and paste them to the virtual drive, then run them. They tend to run and download from there. ALSO ONEDRIVE AND DROPBOX can be a pain, so do them this way as well. (cut and paste). If you are not doing a ton ont he computer, you dont have to move it. Also, each has a setting to move the folder to another drive. They may not go to a removable device, hence making a virtual drive out of the sd card. You can manually move them if you choose. The HP drive comes with the computer and has no limit as of right now. It is just on the file size you upload, not how many things you upload.

3. Remove bloatware. Go through the reviews here depending on what you want to keep. Remove the junk. Or buy a clean setup from hp directly. Careful with APPs. they take a lot of room. I'd suggest getting things you can't download any other way. For example, skip the kindle app, and download the pc version onto your virtual drive. Besides, you do get a card to buy a few free things. I opted not to use word 365...i have another version that is subscription-less. I loaded the other version onto the virtual drive, but assumenot many people can do that unless its older versions. Open office is a free software you can use to write.

4. You can change settings using libraries. I didn't want my pictures and dpwnloads to stay ont he c drive. This is not too hard to get once you read it a few times. I mapped folders with the same names onto my virtual drive. Ex. Program files, Program files(x86), pictures, documents...i added them to link with the c drive libraries to "show up". I then removed the primary (c drive) which automatically makes the virtual drive ones Primary. so you may see Documents, and Documents (your name here). Don't delete the c drive ones. Just read up on this and you should find an answer out there. Make sure that everything points to the correct folders. Start with one at a time to make sure it works.

And that is just a few things that you can do. I know its a bit tech heavy, but for the price, I felt it was worth it. Now, I did this not know anything when I started. I prob can't answer a bunch of questions. Basically, this is what I found that works. No, its not really easy. Creating the virtual drive was hardest for me. Not the mounting part, but the script because I was making my own drive letter. So I have a c drive, a d drive which is my sd card, and a partition on the sd card that is virtual drive E.

I am new to windows 8.1, and there may be a better way to do this. This is just one way or one options. I'd look up how to show windows libraries first as they were not set up on mine. I hated windows 8.1, but i see some things that are easier. Everything feels hidden. Remember to leave space on your c drive to help the computer run fast. I love it, and its been hard and fun trying to figure it and windows 8 out, but i do think it is worth the price...even over a chrombook if you do nothing else. Good luck!

I bought the Transformer Prime 201 Asus in June through Amazon. I also got the keyboard. I expected it to be a delightful experience, but it has turned into an expensive nightmare.

I am not sure what happened, but one day when I picked it up, attached to the keyboard, the back of the tablet on the upper left side was hot as blazes. I tried to turn it on, it buzzed/vibrated once, and then it refused to turn on. I felt of the transformer of the power supply, the heavy black part into which the USB2 cable was plugged, and it was also blazing hot.

I disconnected everything and let it cool down. Then I tried to turn it on again. It buzzed, the light was green on the side, but nothing happened. I disconnected the tablet from the keyboard and plugged the USB cable back into the tablet and into the back of my computer. The screen was still black. I also checked my computer for any devices or drives and nothing showed up for the Asus.

Thanksgiving 2012. Today I realized that this review needed to be updated. Thanks to ASUS, I have no problems with my TF201 tablet, because they fixed it for me, no charge. Even the shipping was free both ways. I made a separate comment below. Thank you, ASUS Customer Service. Happy New Year too.

The price is well justified with this controller. You get all common RAID support plus their spans, 512MB cache, optional BBU support, four internal SAS/SATA ports (up to 32 max) and SAS II (6Gbps) support. Also love the sideband/I2C signaling support on the card which goes well with a backplane if you have one on your chassis.
What I like the least is the LSI WebBios option ROM where you set up the RAID array. I wish they would have gone with the traditional text mode BIOS. Mouse support does not work for me and I don't even use a wireless input device so have to use TAB and cursor keys all the time.
Another quirk is the fact that the controller disappears from your BIOS boot order completely if there are other SATA HDD devices present in your system. This should not pose a problem if you want to move all your existing HDDs from your motherboard to the controller but It took me a while to realize...not being mentioned anywhere.

To people having problems getting into the WebBios by pressing CTRL+H, you have to set the controller as your primary boot device in your system BIOS.

A note of caution, this controller does not support JBOD but works with a single HDD in RAID0. There is a hidden way to enable the JBOD option with megacli but the feature does not work regardless.

However, I give this a solid 8/10.
output: Solid SAS/SATA Raid controller, few quirks

Instances.input: I've been searching for a good PS2 to XBox 360 controller converter for the past couple of years to use for fighting games, and other classic arcade games that rely heavily on the D-pad. I'm sure converters like these would've been easier to find in Asia and if Lik-Sang's site was still operational... Thanks a lot, Sony!    I'm only giving this 4 stars because its design requires you to connect a wired Xbox360 controller to it in conjunction with the PS2 controller in order for it to function. You must use a Microsoft genuine wired controller for this to work.  It works by fooling your Xbox 360 by letting it detect the original 360 wired controller while it \\"maps\\" the control signals to your PS2 controller. It was an annoying realization at first because I didn't own a wired controller, and had to shell out another $22 to purchase one (Amazon has the cheapest price). But this shouldn't be a problem to those who all ready own one.     This is made in China and the instructions for this are horrible! Just make sure to put the switch \\"NOT\\" on Joystick position... you'll see what I mean when I say that \\"the labels are not the same as in the given instructions.\\"  If it doesn't work at first, just hit the switch the other way.    Aside from a somewhat tacky way of its design having to rely on a wired xbox 360 controller and its poorly written instruction manual, the quality and reliability is actually quite excellent. This is a great converter to have.  It's pretty inexpensive compared to the other types available in North America that are selling for at least twice the price. But then again those offer features not available on this device, such as support for PS3 controllers, keyboard, and built-in rapid fire.
It fits perfect, and i have not had a pro lem with it in months

I ordered two of these arrays. Both arrived ahead of the estimated delivery date.

Upon arrival, the packing material was a bit crumbled. It appeared that the units had been shipped fully populated in the same box that shipped the empty case to the manufacturer. Those styrofoam bits are made to be used with a certain weight item, and additional weight crushes them and reduces how well the protect the unit inside. Upon inspection, no concealed damage was noted, despite the rough ride.

One of the units was missing the drive bay keys. The other shipped with only two keys for 8 bays. Those bays almost invariably ship with 2 keys per unit. It's a good thing we ordered two arrays! This leads to the question: Who is hoarding all those spare keys at the Calvary Storage factory?

The SATA RAID controller shipped with the unit was manufacured by Addonics, a company I've dealt with directly in the past with good results.

The system is split into 2 4 drive channels, 2 SATA cables (included and lengthy) are needed gain access to the entire drive system.

All in all, at abit more than 3 weeks installed, I'm happy with the overall experience. Cavalry needs to make sure all the material that's supposed to be in the box is there, however.

This drive replaced the stock 40GB drive in my Apple Powerbook 12\\" (2003). The new Seagate drive is quieter, runs cooler, slightly faster and, obviously, is a lot bigger. The installation was pretty straight forward (with instructions from PB FixIt), and from start to finish took 45min (I used CCCloner to move my life from old drive to the new drive).

Conclusion: the new Seagate drive is a nice relatively inexpensive upgrade for my laptop. I like the fact that it's running cooler (runs at about 114F, whereas with the old drive it ran at 120F). The old drive is the new back-up, in a 2.5\\" enclosure.

*** update ***
after one year or serious use (changing climates and very serious traveling) this drive has performed flawlessly. as an added perk, i look at the new line of Mac laptops and see that only the highest end versions have drives this size; in any event, my daily use requirments have far exceeded the 40GB OEM that shipped , proving that while this is a great drive, it was also a necessary upgrade for me.

I bought 3 of these for some old laptop hard drives I had. All three worked great. These little cases are snug with the 9.5mm thick drives. You won't be able to get a half a mm more in height in these cases. There's no room left around the edges either. These are slide cases, so if your drive is too thick, there's no way to make it work.

They come with a short USB cord, screws, a small screw driver and some stick-on rubber padding. The screws are super small so they are easy to lose.

The reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 was because of the USB port. These are attached to the board via the small solder tabs. This is normal, but if you plan on using this as a portable drive, I would recommend supporting the port with something between it and the hard drive. I used a small piece of PVC I cut 7mm wide and a little tape to hold it in place. Whatever you use make sure it is non-conductive and will not compress, otherwise you'll still be putting stress on the soldered tabs and eventually the port will crack off and separate. Other than that, great little aluminum brushed cases. Has a little blue operation led too for hard drive activity.

I am also including a photo to describe what I did. It should help the drive to have a longer life as far as the USB port is concerned.
output: Great Little Aluminum Case for the Money

Instances.input: So far so good. Just as it said it would be.

I have tried several different cases for my [[ASIN:B00GQDBS7O Apple iPad mini with Retina Display]], and I've also had the unfortunate experience of dropping the iPad once (with a case in place), only to have the screen crack. (This case was not what I was using when that damage occurred). Fortunately the damage was only to the very corner of the glass and does not extend into the display area, and is something I can live with as long as it does not spread further. I also would point out that our home has very hard tile floors, which are not friendly to sensitive things that might be dropped on them. For that reason, I'm particularly attuned to the design of a case and how protective I feel it will be for these expensive devices.

This is a very inexpensive case, and I evaluate it as follows:

► Pros:

- I like the strap design, because it will serve to keep the cover well closed and in that way ensure a better protection to the iPad when not in use.
- The rotating design of the cover is very nice and enables the cover to be used to prop up the iPad in both vertical or horizontal position so that you can read or watch videos in whichever position desired.
- The cutouts are well sized and provide good access to the charging port, volume control, and so forth.

► Cons:

- It does not automatically wake up the iPad, or put it in the sleep mode, when opened and closed.

► Comments:

- Styling is really a matter of personal preference. I don't particularly like this color and style myself. The green color is somewhat more bluish than what the photos posted here on Amazon show. The top cover is fairly thickly padded, which I like from the standpoint of protection but it does add a bit to the bulk of the device when installed in the case.
- Fit of the cover to the iPad is just OK. The iPad fits into the bottom plastic piece reasonably well. Some covers wrap around the corners a bit more and provide a more secure attachment to the iPad.
- I think that the quality of the materials used for this case is OK but nothing particularly impressive. It is an inexpensive case, after all.
- I judge protection to be only fair, for the following reasons. When closed, it will provide a very good protection to the screen, and the top piece is also padded and for that portion of the cover does look good from a protection standpoint. The bottom plastic piece is going to be too rigid to allow any 'give' if the iPad is dropped onto a hard surface if it impacts on a side or corner, and I do not think it would protect the iPad from damage in all cases for that type of drop. This is not that much different from many other covers in this respect, but some covers do have a softer rubber corner piece, or full bottom piece, that I feel will provide much better protection to those areas of the device.

I'm giving this 4-stars primarily because it is a very inexpensive cover and I don't think it is fair to expect much from something at this price. I do think that someone wanting a more protective cover for their iPad will find others that will be more suitable. I'm presently using this [[ASIN:B00GOKXMUK Samsonite Punched Case for iPad mini (59076)]] which I purchased myself and which has rubber corner pieces which I am hopeful will be protective to the corners of the device. We have the Apple smart case for our full sized iPad, and it has a rubber base which provides really excellent protection to the corners and sides of the device. The Apple cases are considerably more expensive, of course, so it is simply a matter of deciding how much protection you want the case to provide, and how you use your device and whether or not you think you'll be dropping it very often and need to be sure it is well protected.

I received this case from the seller without cost and for the purpose of writing an objective review, and this is my own honest opinion.ore and provide a more secure attachment to the iPad.

I love reading on my Kindle.  The device itself is great, but I have 2 major concerns with the way Amazon administers the content:    1- No way to hide, or limit content to other Kindle devices on your account.  If you purchase a Kindle for your 12 year old son (like I did for Christmas), you can't restrict access to books in your library.  I purchased \\"The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo\\".  While I thought that the book was good, it definitely isn't for a 12 year old.  As long as both Kindle's are registered under the same account they both will have access to all content in that library.  Amazon's customer support suggests creating a separate account, but if you do this you can't share books between the accounts.  So, if we both want to read \\"The Hobbit\\" I would have to buy the book twice, once for my account, and once for his.......Lame!    2- Kindle book purchases use the \\"1-click\\" feature and there is no way to turn it off.  So, with my son's Kindle on my account there is now way to restrict purchasing on his device.  When you purchase from the device it doesn't ask for a credit card (it using the 1-click card on your account), it also doesn't ask for a password, nor does it even ask a purchase confirmation ..... if you click 'buy' it buys right then.  There is no way to turn this off, it's like turning your 12 year old son loose in the book store with your credit card.  Again, Amazon customer support's solution is to create a separate account, and use a gift card as the CC on the second account ....... double lame!    Like I said, I love the device itself, but if I had it to do all over again I'd take a closer look at how the Nook handles multiple devices on the same account.
output: Great device, but what they won't tell you

Bought this cable yesterday for $0.72+shipping (real cheap). Came in USPS within 5 days (great). Connected it to my old Canon Multipass C530 printer and Windows XP. Windows recognized the printer (good so far), and prompted for the driver. I had downloaded the XP driver already, so pointed to it. The driver will not install. I tried installing the driver by itself (as per instructions by Canon), but the software refused to detect the printer. It seems the driver is looking at port LPT1, while the cable installs itself on USB001 - Virtual Printer. I tried Generic Printer driver and other option but nothing seems to work. DO NOT waste your time and buy this cable if you are not sure that your driver will work on USB001 port (or if you know of a generic driver that works with your printer).  I am connecting my printer back to my good old slow Laptop with Parallel port on it (its slow but works great there). Wasted enough time already, there is no point wasting more time and return this cable.

Instances.input:
I've been looking for a good iPad stand for quite a while. Unfortunately the majority of the stuff out there is just cheap flimsy crap. This product comes really close but it just doesn't cut it for my situation: my parents want to use the iPad as a computer. I planned on pulling that off with an [[ASIN:B005DLDO4U Apple Wireless Keyboard MC184LL/B [NEWEST VERSION]]] and this stand. For most people, this stand should be more than good enough.

[Good]

Well Made: You can definitely see the quality of the product in the way it looks and its weight.

Stable: This thing will not fall or tip over.

Versatility: You can hold pretty much put almost any tablet on this thing, and I would guess most tablet cases as well.

Looks: It looks great. Personally I prefer the silver or white versions.

[Bad]

Tablet Stability: Because this thing tries to be versatile (which is a good thing), there's a price for it. It doesn't hold the tablet super tight. What do I mean by that? If you look at the picture, the tablet just rests on this stand. One consequence is that you have a limit in terms of the angles you can use before your iPad falls. What happens when you say, click on the circle button of an iPad? Depending the iPad generation, the cover you're using, how your orient your iPad (specifically if you rest it horizontally), and how you press on the iPad's circle button, your iPad could fall off the stand; which kind of kills the whole point of it. To avoid this problem, you need to have your iPad standing in portrait mode, or you need to hold the iPad whenever you press the circle button to keep it from falling (one finger behind the iPad, and another finger to press the button). At the end of the day, this isn't a deal breaker for most people, just for me and my particular situation. (My parents aren't very careful especially with gadgets. I can just picture their iPad flying off this thing.)

I reallywish there was a variant of this product that really held the tablet so it wouldn't fall. It would be great if it also managed to work with the tablet still in its own tablet case. Why? I wanted to put the iPad at near eye level (with the help of stuff like phone books to prop it up), so my parents wouldn't have to slouch while working with it. I would pay for the extra cost.

Packaging: I bought this product as a gift. Unfortunately its packaging is just a plain brown shipping box with a little sticker on it. Not exactly great when people open gift wrap. \\"O wow, a brown UPS box!\\" Moreover, this is for an Apple product. For anything related to Apple packaging counts a great deal. (I'm wondering if the product designers or company management have ever even opened an Apple product? Even the cheapest Apple products have really awesome packaging.) I'd rather pay 5 or 10 bucks more to get better packaging. At least it should look decent on the outside. In general people who tend to buy Apple products are willing to pay more for quality. If this wasn't called an 'iPad stand' instead a 'tablet stand', this wouldn't be as big of a negative. Of course, if this isn't a gift you can just ignore everything I just said.

[Misc]

I received a defective version of this product. The stand would not lock it's pivot position, which is really really important for keeping the iPad stable. Some dial for tightening the position was stuck and I didn't feel like using pliers to try to free it. I didn't want to damage the product in any way. If this wasn't meant to be a gift, I probably would have tried that route. Anyways I didn't put this in either the good or bad points since it wouldn't be fair to either the manufacturer or people looking to buy it. This is one of the reasons that I ended returning it.

[Summary]

Good, well made product that should meet most iPad users needs with a few caveats. I'm just really surprised that this product hasn't made it on any reviews on the big websites or magazines. I guess they didn't bother to send reviewers free samples for good publicity?
output: Well made, great looking, but not perfect

Instances.input:
Overall, I like my new Kindle very much. I made the transition from a B&N Nook to the Kindle in order to take advantage of 1) the internal light and 2) the capability of downloading books overseas, which I have need to do from time to time.

Customers should know, however, that the lighting system is not perfect...at least, it is not as a homogeneous light distribution system as the Kindle ads might lead you to believe. The way it works is that there are six LEDs (four embedded on the bottom, and one each on the bottom sides) that illuminate a thin sheet of fiber-optic that is positioned OVER the (in my opinion, superior) e-ink screen. The goal is that the whole fiber-optic sheet would be evenly illuminated. But, at least on mine and three others that I have seen in the batches shipped between 22-31 October 2012, the light distribution is somewhat uneven. The four LEDs on the bottom, for example, leave a series of soft shadows extending into the first inch of the screen; these shadows look much like a mountain range. On mine, as well, the light distribution in the upper-left quadrant of the screen is uneven.

Neither of these problems bothers me too much, and I have adjusted quickly. But, the customer should know that this is an area where Amazon has yet to perfect the new technology. Nevertheless, until they do, I am enjoying thoroughly the ability to read anywhere at anytime without worrying about exterior lights or eye strain from back-lit devises. Since receiving my Kindle Paperwhite on Tuesday (10/30/2012), I am nearly finished with the second book in Mark Berent's fantastic quintology on fighter pilots in the Vietnam conflict: [[ASIN:B001HN5J7S STEEL TIGER (Book II in the ROLLING THUNDER series) by Mark Berent]] This series is a must read for aviation fans, or those interested in air combat or the operation of planes such as the T-38, F-100, F-105, and F-4 Phantom.
output: VERY GOOD, but not yet perfect, Kindle

Earlier today I was photographing in Arches National Park in the Balanced Rock area. I use a Kodak digital camera with a full frame SLR and Canon lenses and take raw images (about 12-14 MP). I use a 10 sec timer and wait for the image to be download to the disk before taking another photo. At the BR area I used two 1 GB Compact Flash cards from Kodak (made by Lexar) and a Lexar Platinum II 2 GB CF card. All three were bought from Walmart in Silver City, NM, in May 2006. I then moved to the Courthouse Rock area and put in a 2GB Ultra II San Disk CF card. The card was previously erased on my computer and then with quick format in my camera (space for 63 images). After two pictures the card said it was full. I continued to click for photos and a card error saying that that the image could not be saved. I tried several quick formats in the camera. Removing the battery or turning off the camera did not correct the problem. I then switched to the 8GB San Disk Ultra II CF card and had similar problems at first, but was eventually able to take several hundred photos although I have not evaluated them to see if they turned out. The two cards were bought from the Mayfield Heights, Ohio, Micro Center store in May 2007 although both have a copyright of 2004. Today was not excessively hot or cold.  With the first three cards I mentioned I have often taken 2 or 3 images in quick succession without any problems, but not with San Disk cards. Also the three cards have never given any problems on days below freezing or above 100 degrees. In 2003 when I first got my camera I bought two 1 GB and one 2 GB San Disk Ultra II CF cards. The 2 GB card held only 600 MB and was returned to San Disk. After a few months San Disk gave me a new 2 GB card (not used today). I will have to buy some more Lexar cards because I no longer trust the San Disk CF cards. I was trying to take panoramas and with the sun light changing the delays caused by the card problems made it difficult. I suppose that SanDisk sells higher grade cards because it knows that these cards are of low quality. Howard McPherson, Moab, Utah
output: Poor results with San Disk Ultra II

Instances.input:
Without giving my life story, I have a 13\\" macbook pro, and an iPad. The bag fits them both comfortably and, I imagine the same would be true if I had the bigger 15\\" macbook. It is super solid, good stitching and overall what you would expect from the makers of the \\"Swiss Army knife\\". There are lots of compartments for other items like your wallet, cell, phone, chargers, and even a \\"Swiss Army knife\\"! Although I would not recommend trying to take a knife on an airplane, there is a special little pouch for one, or something of similar size like, I don't know, pepper spray. Maybe tick-tacks, or nicorette (you should really quit). What I am trying to say is that the items you could put in the pouches are only limited by your imagination. Even though I can't travel on an airplane with a knife, I would not forgo the purchase of this bag because it has a special place to put one. I would use my imagination to find something of equal size to put there. But enough about me, lets talk about the bag.

It has nice zippers, really nice zippers. There are three zippers, but only the biggest compartment's zipper has a place to put a lock. Which is crazy, because if you are a thief you would just take the whole bag (which I would recommend if stealing weren't wrong, because this is such a crazy awesome laptop case) Although a little lock to keep out nosey friends and family isn't a bad idea. Or, if you are a spy, and have top secret plans or government documents, this would be a good bag to go \\"incognito\\" with. It totally doesn't look like a double agents laptop case, which makes it the perfect laptop case for an undercover agent. Plus there is that pouch for a knife!

One other feature, is that is has a little place to hook your keys, which is nice. That way you always know where your keys are. The clip that you hook your keys (or anything, remember the imagination thing) is really cool. It's hard to explain, but it's got a little button you push, and then the ring \\"opens\\" and you can put keys on. Very nifty. The more I look at this bag the happier I am I bought it.

So in conclusion, I am impressed and hope to enjoy many years of using this durable laptop case. By the looks of it's quality, I will most likely use this for future laptops when my current one is so obsolete that it is no longer usable. So, like two-months.... just kidding, but seriously this is a good buy. Great for traveling/spys, yada, yada, yada, I like it.
output: Great Bag! Very rugged, yet elegant.

Of the thirty (30) PCs built with these cables, two (2) exhibited erratic \\"no-boot\\" or slow data transfer rate symptoms. While this number is 6.5% of total number of cables used, the failure rate is a bit high for the quality of PCs we build.

Caveat: once the malfunctioning cable was changed out with another one (of same make and manufacture) the erratic issues disappeared.

2 things are wrong with this product. 1) it puts the SSD (or 2.5 drive) centered in the cage. The issue is that on the 3.5 drives, the connectors are offset to one side. If your cables are just the right length for the 3.5 drive then they won't reach. 2) All screw holes are threaded for the 2.5 drive thread size. Thus the outside mounts holes are the wrong size...they should be threaded for the 3.5\\" threads, as this are the mounts used to hold the cage in place inside the computer.

This does not work for the 2008 24\\" iMac.

I needed a stand that would work well with my iPad Mini (retina) for my concession business. I needed something that would allow my tablet to use Square card reader, then swivel so the customer could sign without ever picking up or touching the tablet. This worked perfectly. The bottom is nicely weighed so the unit stays planted (although I do wish it had a mounting option). The clamps on the left and right are made of a rubber material along with the dark grey circle between the clamps, ensuring no harm to your tablet while its clamped in. The base can rotate the entire tablet 360, the same way a person can swivel around in an office chair. And for even more versatility, the hinge that connects the top half to the lower half can flip your tablet to be viewed by someone opposite from you, which is perfect for over the tablet encounters.

But looking at how the stand is set up, I can say I was one of the lucky ones. This stand probably wouldn't work with half of other tablets. The clamps that you see in the provided picture only slide out about an inch on each side, and are spring loaded. So whatever tablet that requires the clamps to stretch will fit nice and tight. However, like some iPad users here, when the iPad is in portrait mode (home button at the bottom), this doesn't stretch the clamps, leaving only the non slip rubber on the clamps to keep the iPad in place (thus the reason behind the 1 star reviewers complaint and loose iPads). I would think this is the case for only the iPad Air

Trying to explain dimensions on something square could be confusing (height, width, and depth can be confused with one another) so here's a general rule for this stand- if one of your tablets dimensions is between 6.5-7.9 inches, then it would fit one way or another. The dimensions for a Nexus 10 are 10.4 x 7 x .4, so it would fit. Same with the iPad mini. However, the Kindle Fire HDX dimensions are beyond 7.9 inches or below 6.5, so it might not. Also, forget about having a case on while this tablet is clamped in. I recommend a full body plastic film protector, like Bodyguardz or Skinomi

But all in all, the stand works perfect for my needs, and makes my business look very professional for a low price. And as many people have said after searching forever, its the only one of its kind at this pricet about having a case on while this tablet is clamped in. I recommend a full body plastic film protector, like Bodyguardz or Skinomi

But all in all, the stand works perfect for my needs, and makes my business look very professional for a low price. And as many people have said after searching forever, its the only one of its kind at this price
quick and easy to use take off and put back on plus cant complain about the price either i reccomend it!

This is a great little mouse. It is a touch smaller than I prefer, but I have larger hands so it might fit yours better. This mouse comes with a USB receiver which can fit inside the mouse for travel or storage. The mouse has an on-off switch which is nice to save the battery when not in use.

Love monitor. Simplifies genealogy. Made mistake of using cd setup, not necc. I made a selection of Windows Media Center. It hijacked my computer. DON'T  ever choose it.

Disclaimer: I bought this computer through the Microsoft store, so it came without any of the third party trialware attached.

1) Aesthetics. This laptop is a pure beauty. I keep turning it over to look it from different angles. The gorilla glass is soft to the touch and just feels really nice. The aluminium board feels really nice too. I can't tell if the bottom piece is metal or plastic, but it feels sturdy. The screen is incredible to behold.

2) Hardware. The keyboard is pretty good. Maybe it's just that I type too fast and am imprecise, but I do miss some keys/they don't recognize the strokes. The touchscreen is a joy to use, and very precise. The trackpad is OK. My last computer was a mac, so anything is inferior to their trackpads. Needless to say, it recognizes 1,2, and 3 finger motions very well. Skips around a little bit, and if I touch it too close to an edge then either the charms menu or the app menu-thing pops up. Very happy overall, however. Many other reviews mention the fact that the keyboard is 5 deep, not six. I did not think this would be a problem, but it is a little annoying now. What is especially frustrating is that to turn the volume up or down I have to use the function key, and BOTH hands, because my hand (and I doubt anyone else's) will stretch from one side of the keyboard to the other. Again, going back to the mac, it was nice having dedicated volume, mute, and play/pause keys.

3) Miscellaneous. The mysterious port on the right side (some people say it's a minidisplay port, others a acer proprietary port) works as a minidisplay port. At least it does for me. The 128 gigs fills up wicked fast. The fan is absolutely silent. I haven't played any games or done anything intense with the computer, but so far it hasn't gotten hot on the underbody at all. Warm, yes, but not hot.

Overall this is a five star computer. I am extremely happy with my purchase, and love my new computer. There are just a few design things that I would change, but overall it's an incredible experience.

If you have any questions, just let me know! Thanks for reading.
output: Incredible laptop; a few strange design quirks

I did a complete wipe of the machine, even installed a Linux distro and cleaned out any settings that may have been set by Windows. Did a second complete clean install of Windows 8.1 and for the most part the laptop was working flawlessly again. Sure minor vanity problems like the backlight not working but wireless was resolved.

However I installed the drivers for the Bluetooth and the wireless stopped working again. Yet if I disabled Bluetooth the wireless worked again. I don't know if it was the Bluetooth that caused my wireless problem or what but once I installed those drivers wireless stopped working again.

I was going to play around and try to figure out what exactly was the problem with it but then the battery stopped charging. It would tell me plugged in and not charging, I read a bit about a bug with Windows but I decided at this point to just give up and return it. After two weeks of just trying to make it work, it was more grief than it was worth.

I'm sorry to see it go because the laptop is great when it works! I think I might just downgrade to something a bit cheaper and get the new Cintiq touch tablet since I bought this laptop to do heavy graphic design work while I'm on the go. I tried but I decided that I'll return it now when I can get a full refund and just look for something new.

-- Also quick note but my touch pad gestures weren't working either. I had seen a few people bring that up but I used a wireless mouse most of the time so it didn't really impact me that much.
_________________________________

ORIGINAL REVIEW

Second day of owning this machine I decided to update to Windows 8.1 and it has been a disaster.

The Qualcomm Atheros network adapter no longer works and there isn't a clearsolution to the problem other than canned responses to update the driver. It was working fine first day out of the box and was even connected during the 8.1 setup process.

Yet as soon as it booted to the desktop it stopped working. Either telling me I have limited connection or none at all.

All other devices connect absolutely fine to my wireless.

I actually rolled back the driver and it was connecting but after a few hours I'm unable to connect.

Back light also stopped working after update but that's more cosmetic than anything else.

I'm returning it because this is a waste of time.
This is a must have
output: Don't leave home without it!  Five Stars

Here are my observations on the new Paperwhite running firmware 5.4.0

1) Cloud Library memory is now in reserved System space.
2) Available memory starts at 1,300 MB and doesn't change even after the maximum 15,000 Cloud titles are populated.

3) Only takes about 15 minutes to populate the most recent 15,000 titles (~1k titles / min)
4) While older titles are being scanned, NO new titles will appear in the on-device Cloud Library

5) ALL titles with \\"Dictionary\\" are added to the OLDEST title group \\"Dictionaries\\"
6) 2nd oldest title is the built-in \\"Kindle Paperwhite User's Guide\\"

7) Sorting by \\"Recent\\" or \\"Title\\" results in the hard-coded 15,000 titles.
8) Sorting by \\"Author\\" will get 15,000 PLUS however many Dictionaries the PW found in the Cloud (15,023 on my Paperwhites)

9) While the Paperwhite is scanning through all older titles in the Cloud, newer purchases WILL NOT appear.
10) Scanning seems to be ~20k titles / hour, took about 4 hours to complete my 68k Book Library

So, a heads up for those who have >15k Book Libraries.

When Amazon rolls out 5.4.0 for the 1st Gen Paperwhites,
don't be alarmed if new purchases don't show up in the Cloud Library on the PW.

Once the PW is done scanning through your entire Cloud Library,
newer purchases will appear as expected when sorted by \\"Recent\\"

I bought this enclosure to replace an Iomega StorCenter NAS which was configured in a RAID-5 that failed on me. The primary function of this enclosure was to allow me to connect all four 1TB drives from the previous RAID-5 configuration in order to allow a file recovery attempt. The bottom line is that this is a high quality enclosure that is very easy to set up and use. I was able to connect the drives in JBOD mode, reconstruct the RAID using software that I purchased, and recover my data.

I've now connected this to the eSATA port of my company's application server and am using it as a backup device. The Iomega that we were using was a nightmare, and I am glad that we've simplified life by using a bare bones disk enclosure that has excellent connectivity options (can't beat the speed of USB 3.0 or eSATA).

Great job on this little guy, I'll probably be buying a couple more to configure for other tasks.
output: High Quality No Frills RAID Enclosure

Instances.input:
I am a college student and I was looking for a portable laptop to take to class everyday. So, I bought this laptop about a year ago. At first, I loved it. It was light, fast enough, beautiful, and thin, exactly what I was looking for.
Once I'm a while the trackpad would act funny. But it never was a problem. However, the DAY after the the product was shipped (one year minus 7 business days from when I received it) the hinge got too loose, and the trackpad STOPPED working.
I called the company, thinking they would understand it hadn't been a year since I received the product, and apologizing because their product Stopped working like that. But, their answer was WE ARE SORRY but are no longer under warranty.

Now I must hold the screen and have a mouse in order to use this crap.

I would not recommend anybody that need a laptop for more than 11 months to buy this.

I bought one of these to go with a Kindle I bought my husband for Christmas. It looks and feels beautiful and he really prefers this smooth grain over the regular Kindle cover. That being said, think about how you would use this before you decide to put up the extra money. The leather is soft and smooth more like a fine wallet, not rugged like a briefcase. If you aren't careful with it, it will scratch.  Personally, I don't think the small scratches on my husband's case detract from the beauty of the leather.  It also protects the Kindle well and keeps it firmly in place, while providing the extra bonus of creating a more book-like feel.  The cover can be folded back like a real book and even the texture on the inside flap is very nice.  We are very happy to have splurged a little on this and would certainly buy it again.
output: Very high quality. Worth it if you're willing to take good care of it.

Instances.input: Excellent Product 100% satisfied recommend

Written June 1, 2013

This is a great tablet. It has a Wacom digitizer. It is lightweight and the battery life is great too. There are many particulars that may determine what may or may not make a great tablet. And it doesn't matter what you think they are when considering this tablet because... the power connector is an old-school barrel aka \\"tip\\" connector that barely makes contact, or doesn't make contact if moved only slightly. There is no light to indicate that it is charging, and if you look at the icon on any of the screens to verify that it is charging it is not good enough... after you set it down even very gently- this is enough to have moved the connector in a way that it will lose contact and stop charging. I had this about a week and two nights I left it plugged in and it didn't charge because of this. I checked two display models at the store and they did the same thing. It is unacceptable... unfortunately it is basically useless because of this.

If you want a good tablet, with a Wacom digitizer, windows 8 and good battery life--- I say go with the Thinkpad tablet 2 by Lenovo. Or wait 6-12 months for new offerings.

If you have any questions feel free to respond.
output: Seriously a great tablet... but the power connector renders it all but useless!

Instances.input:
I am admittedly not a super-technical guy. I just want to be able to get strong wifi anywhere on my half-acre of property, and my kids not to gripe because "the internet is slow", or my wife to gripe because "netflix is being stupid". We have about a million devices that connect in some way so, it just needs to work, period.

I upgraded to this router from a Cisco N900 model and holy crap, the difference.

My internet provider is hot or cold and I suspect that my neighborhood is a high demand area so, I wanted to squeeze every bit of available bandwidth out of my pipe. Instead or rewiring the whole house, I opted to drop very little money on this to see if it would help.

Out of the box, I was up and running in 3 minutes. 3 minutes. I swapped the old model out, plugged in a laptop, logged in using the quick start guide, changed the Archer SSID to my old one, same thing with the password and BANG! My son, who previously only got 2 bars in his room now gets 5. There is no buffering of Netflix, even at 10pm when everyone else within a 5 mile radius is also on. In fact, I get 5 bars anywhere on my property/ basement/ garage, etc...

This router rocks!
this thing seems a bit cheap made, but it works fine and for what i paid for i cannot complain.

[[VIDEOID:moP3B6GS5RL8LY]]I purchased the original Kindle Fire in 2011 and the second generation Kindle Fire in 2012. I gave my original one to my grandson and he is still using it for apps and reading. I liked both of them and I have to tell you that they have held up very well. One is over 3 years old and the other is 2 years old and I have not had any issues with them. Since I have not upgraded in 2 years I thought I would get a new one with a larger memory and a faster CPU and a higher resolution display. There are many improvements beyond even those features.

I have to tell you that overall I am impressed with this new one. I didn't feel the need to purchase a Kindle Fire every year and when I purchased the next one I wanted it to be a definite upgrade step to what I had. I stayed with the 7 inch size as I like to portability and weight for long term reading. I alternate between the Kindle Paperwhite for reading in the daytime and at night sometimes and I use the Kindle Fire for reading in the evening and at night plus browsing the internet and getting email. This new Kindle Fire HD 2014 version is very fast and easy to use. Setting it up for the internet and downloading my apps and books was a breeze. I like the fact that the larger memory allows me to carry more apps and books. The higher resolution of the screen is helpful in reading books as the text is clearer and easier on my eyes than the older Kindle Fires we own. The screen is better for playing apps and watching videos and movies and it is worth the upgrade from the older Kindle Fires.

I like that this version has both a front and rear facing camera. I use the camera a lot on all of my tablets and I own many Apple iPads, Apple iPhone and Android tablets. The camera is just handy for that spontaneous photo or video and I take a lot of them.

I also like the fact that the stereo sound output has been improved as I listen to a lot of books. I use the text to speech feature a lot and I also use the Audible book feature a lot. When Amazon sells the Audible version of the book at a good price when I buy the Kindle version of the book I usually get both. I like to use Bluetooth to stream the Audio book to my car's stereo system and listen to the book while I drive, especially on a long trip. My wife and I enjoy listening to books together. This HD tablet pairs with my car and I can now use it instead of using my iPad or using my iPhone. This feature keeps track of where I am in the book regardless of whether I am reading the book or listening to it with Audible. The better speakers and louder volume is also nice when watching movies.

The unit works well handling my emails and it makes it nice that I can switch from browsing, to emails to reading or playing an app on the same tablet. I also have Amazon Prime so I can watch TV shows or movies. This is a good tablet with a lot of flexibility. I am still not a fan of the push ads but I am so used to them now I just ignore them.

I won't discuss all of the specifications but I did include a table comparing the Original Kindle Fire to the first Kindle HD 2013and now the Kindle HD 2014. For me it was a quantum leap to go from a Kindle Fire First or Second Generation and I am glad I made the jump. This tablet is a good buy for the money as the specs are very good. The table below shows the differences between the different versions and you can see the progress that has been made in just a few years. I am buying this new kindle with confidence as my last two Kindle Fires have performed very well and I expect the same out of this one.

One word of caution is that if you are buying this for a child then make sure to pay attention to the parental controls. Turn off the ability to make In App Purchases (IAPs) and I also turn off 1 touch buying. It is so easy for a child to make in app purchases and some of them can be as much as $99.99 on one item. Children are used to playing games with fake money and they cannot tell the difference and you will be surprised when you get the massive credit card bill. A few minutes of proper set up of the tablet for use by a child can save you a lot of headaches in the future.

There are a couple of features that I do wish were in this product that I miss. I own and have tested many tablets and I love the ability of Android tablets to accept a Micro SD card memory addition. I even have some tablets that I use 128 GIG SD cards in and this is a great feature. A very good Micro SD card only cost $100 and if Amazon would add this feature this very good tablet would be a GREAT tablet. The second feature is the ability to easily use apps from the Google Play Store. Most of the office and game apps are on the Amazon play store and I really do like the Amazon Play store the best. There are though some powerful tools on the Google Play Store that will not work on the Kindle Fire Operating system and that is a shame. This limits the customer from being able to use the best available software available. This Kindle Fire HD 2014 is a wonderful top notch product but it would be a superior product if these features were included.

If you are upgrading from a first or second generation Kindle Fire then this is a great move. For someone that has the 2013 Kindle Fire HD this is a smaller leap in technology so you may have to really want one of the new features to upgrade. I like my new unit and I am glad that I got it. I am also glad that it came with the AC wall charger in the box. I rated it at 5 stars and recommend it based on the results I have seen so far. If you have any questions please send me a comment and I will try to answer you.

WARNING: False Advertising by Amazon: Everything shows pictures and claims that HBO GO is still available on this device and it is NOT. This is the exact quote from the product page: Fire tablets give you instant access to popular free and best-selling apps to help you stay productive or be entertained, including titles like Netflix, HBO GO, Facebook, Hulu Plus, Pinterest, The Weather Channel, Evernote, and Mint.

Since HBO GO and my FIRE HDX (previous generation) are my primary TV source, I am so upset that this app is NOT available. I immediately called Amazon and to the surprise of the \\"Mayday\\" Amazon agent it is not ready yet for this newest generation Fire HDX 8.9. This was the first time anybody became aware of this false advertising by Amazon, since I could not locate any article, video, blog post, or anything informing people like me who have purchased this device with the expectation that the HBO GO app is available and will work as advertised. The Amazon agent apologized and after waiting on hold said that there was no exact timeframe for it to be available except by 2015.

I spend literally thousands of dollars a year with Amazon and have owned five different Kindle and Kindle Fire devices. So disappointed in the false advertising and the way this has been handled.
output: WARNING: False Advertising by Amazon: HBO GO is NOT available
