I preface my review with the fact I received my item in a really oversized box that was poorly padded and 2x of the little elements were loose and moved and the ring element was bent but easily flexed back to the proper position. So it is possible that the antenna was damaged through shipping and was returned as so, but I will not be buying another one due to the overall lack of quality and performance seen during testing.

I already own a Swann Wireless 9DBI/13DBI (box says 9, the actual antenna is labeled 13) Yagi which was hoping to replace to gather some more signal. Upon of the receipt 18dbi unit my initial impression was this thing was built like a piece of crap. The elements are not riveted and are punched in to place. The shipping had two of them loose and many others seemed to be loose but hadn't yet moved but could spin touched. The antenna ring that the coax goes into is junky in construction consisting of mostly plastic and doesn't have the shrink wrapped element like my swann or other I have seen on amazon. Once the antenna was mounted and properly aimed, I couldn't even pull in my weak signal the other antenna sees. I would have to agree with the other reviewer and say the power of this antenna is grossly overstated. This isnt' to say it doesn't totally work. I could still see other access points but they had lost several bars in contrast to the Swann unit.

Pay just a little more and get the browning yagi antenna ([[ASIN:B003YL5WJG Browning 2.4 GHz - 2.5 GHz Enclosed Cellular Yagi Antenna]]); Name brands tend to have a little more realistic specifications.

I also didn't receive any other parts except the u-bolts, none of the brackets that were pictured came with my antenna. Again it is a RP-SMA connector too!
output: Either damaged or doesn't Work Worth A Crap

Instances.input:
How many pictures will it store? It is the most commonly asked question from digital camera enthusiast but usually the question that is the most difficult to get a straight answer about. Well, considering I worked in the memory industry for over 7 years I can help clarify this perplexing question and do so unbiased as I have since changed industries.

The X Digital Media 256MB REDLINE PROformance 70X Compact Flash Card, like most 256MB cards, will store on average 284 pictures when used with a 2 megapixel camera, 213 images when used with a 3 megapixel camera, 128 pictures when used with a 4 megapixel camera, 102 images when used with a 5 megapixel camera, and 80 pictures when used with a 6 megapixel camera. These numbers are based off the assumption that you are going to shoot your images at the highest quality JPEG setting available for the camera and understand that they are estimates and may be off by as much as 10 percent due to numerous factors including the complexity of the scene being shot and the compression algorithm used by your specific camera.

I truly hope this review was helpful to you in determining whether this card is the right capacity for your specific needs.
output: How many pictures will it store?

I have looked enough and tried a few. This one blew everything away. I agree with some reviews, the length is not enough if you have a bigger than little head, but I guess I am not in that group, so I am comfortable with it.  The distance, I have used it on skype, walked downstairs to the kitchen to grab water and my laptop in my bedroom, still have not been interrupted. I was amazed.  Many people complain about the PC using the headset as audio device as long as the dongle is inserted, even though the headset is off! I agree, but you can easily adjust your audio settings. I am on PC. In your control panel, make your other audio device(say your default sound card) your default audio and so programs don't pick the logitech wireless automatically. Only customize your chat programs, say skype, to use this device. this way, you can listen to music on from your speakers and use the headset for chat or internet calling.    The only piece that ticks me off is the fact that batter is not replaceable! For such a high price, I would not expect customers to have to through it away just because the battery has died. Bad design decision.    PS: Another, slightly less important, piece that I don't like is the charger! It should have been able to charge from USB of the computer.
output: Great product only for one issue!

This router is not worth its full price. If you are like me (desperate, current aging router dying and cutting off internet connection), then I guess this will be worth it ONLY if 1] the product's price is reduced and 2] you intend on investing in a better one later on.

I say this because this router has caused my wi-fi to become so slow, but given the alternative I have (slow internet or deal with a dying router), this is better than nothing.

I basically have this but the LAN port light is forever orange.

Customer support is a joke. I have contacted them so many times. The final straw is when they said I had received a faulty product and was told they would replace it for free. Surprise, its not free. It is left up to you to find a box (so don't throw out the package this came in) and pay to ship it back. What sucks is that despite the extra cash I had to shell out for this, I still have the same problem. So I guess every until of this product ever made is faulty.

So if you can, go to a different brand. NETGEAR has really gone down hill. You are better off spending your money elsewhere.
(On that note, if anyone can recommended a good router since I'm still in the market for one, please let me know.)
output: I only bought it because I was desperate.

Lightwave: First Impressions

Here in this forum, I want to give my impression of what it is like to own my first higher end 3d modeling, rendering and animating software. The price is quite more expensive than other modelers I have owned. In this forum, I have reviewed such modelers as TrueSpace and Carrara and I have never paid more than a couple hundred dollars for any modeler, animator, renderer or any 3d software.

So what do you get for nearly $1,500 ?

Answer, if you are looking for just a basic modeler, renderer and animator, you can do the same or better with any of the less expensive modelers. Feature for feature, you can often find many of the same features and more in software packages such as Carrara, Blender, Art of Illusion, TrueSpace, Amapi, all of which I have and absolutely love, and many of these modelers you can get absolutely free of charge. Carrara 8 (I have the 64 bit version, the more expensive version, called the Professional version) costs hundreds of dollars rather than thousands and has a huge array of features. But there is, of course, the prestige of owning a higher end modeler, and even this is certainly not the highest end modeler especially when compared with Autodesk 3D Studio Max, and Maya which can run $3000 to $5000 for a single license. But, like the high end software packages, this software does have the prestige. This is one that is used by the "big boys"; high end studios, such as Walt Disney, Lucas Film, and many others. This software is used in major motion pictures and television programs for the realistic animations and for many of the special effects you see in movies. If you see it in the movies or on television, chances are it was 3D Studio Max, Maya, or Lightwave that it was created and rendered in.

And this software is built with big studios in mind, rather than for a single one man ( or woman) studio, although a single person can certainly use the software.You are paying for the capability of running up to nearly 1000 cores of processing power for complex animation renders. You are paying for the name and the marketability of the things you can create with this software. If you go to a professional modeling website which sells high quality meshes for professional studios, you don't find much with the .cob TrueSpace format, or .car for Carrara, or even .cr2 for Poser formats. Most models are sold in .max or .3ds, formats which are 3D Studio Max and in .lwo and .lws format with is Lightwave format, and there are a few other formats, such as .fbx -- all high end modelers. You are paying for big studio power and level of professionalism.

The Lightwave software package comes with two parts. The Layout program, where you assemble all your modeled objects to create a scene, rig characters (that is, give them skeletons, for animations), and render single images and/or movies, and add special effects. The second part is the Modeler, where you actually do your modeling, where you can create figures and objects from scratch, edit existing objects, apply texturing (although you can also do this in the Layout program too.), and build basic skeletons for figures. These are actually two separate programs, but you can link them together with something called a Hub program where you can switch between programs, send finished models to the Layout from the Modeler, and synch them together. Most other modelers, on the low end, such as Carrara, have modeler, layout, and rendered all integrated together in a single program. Again, since this software is made for major studios, this type of system makes sense, since a major studio would likely have a single team using the software for building the models, and another team for doing the actual building of the scene and another team for the actual animations and special effects. They would only use the particular program that is suited for the job they would do.

People who have older versions will know that in order to use the full features of the software that you had to have a special key called a dongle. This served primarily as an anti piracy device, since you cannot use the software unless you have a legal registry number and the dongle as a sort of key. The dongle was a device that you could install into a USB port, and as long as you had the key in the computer, you could use the software and all of its features. But in the newer versions (I think above 11.3) the dongle has been discontinued, and all you need now is just the license number and to register your copy of the software. But you have to register to actually get the license number. The serial number you get with the software, if you get CD or DVD is not the same as the license number. So registering and activating your software is a little more involved.

I bought the original disk media version which was the 32 bit version of Lightwave 11.0, and registering it and using the dongle was a bit of a nuisance. But when you go to register your software and make an account online with NewTek, as long as you have Lightwave 11.0 or above, you can get a free upgrade to the latest version of Lightwave, which is, as of this writing, 05/31/2014, Lightwave 11.6. I downloaded and got the 64 bit version for use with my computer.

Lightwave 11.6 has all the latest features, including enhancements on its special effects machine, such as hypervoxels, which are similar to metaballs, but more dynamic. You can use these for such things as flamethrower effects, dynamic explosive effects, liquid effects and so forth. It also introduced soft body and cloth simulators, which the earlier 11.0 version did not have, in addition to its hard body dynamics and physics engines . You also have dynamic hair and fibers, morph targets, and skeleton editing, and kinematics and inverse kinematics. There is also more import and export capability. You can import .fbx (Filmbox) and .dae (Collada) objects and a couple of other mesh formats into either the Layout or Modeler, .3ds, .max, .dxf , .obj, or many other popular formats. You have a little more export capability, and you can export to .3ds, .obj, and .dae, and a few other formats.

I have been going through the .pdf manuals and playing around with the software, and here I will give my first impressions of it.

The interface is pretty straightforward in both the Modeler and Layout. And you can quickly find features and can often guess without too much thought what some things do. Unlike many modelers, Lightwave is more menu driven rather than icon driven. In other words, you can actually read what the buttons actually do instead of trying to figure out by the image what a button does.

The Modeler appears to be primarily a polygon modeler with emphasis on subdivision techniques. (Some modelers specialize in a particular type of modeling. Some modelers, for example, specialize in NURBS or spline curves for creating objects, others specialize in subdivision, some modelers can model in a wide range of modeling techniques including both subdivision and NURBS, some are sculpting modelers, etc.) But you can draw and create spline curves for use with such things as lathing and extrusion. And you can create NURBS like patches with the spline curves, by joining curves together and building a series of polygons between them. And metaballs and metaball like objects are supported. There is something called a "metaedge" tool in which you can create metaball type objects of various shapes.

Of course, it comes with basic tools for modeling objects, including drawing tools, spline curves are already mentioned, Bezier curves, simple polygons, etc. There are various types of extrusion tools. Path extrusion is supported as well as lathing. It has a rather comprehensive list of point editing tools, a few I have never seen before, such as a stencil tool, which can create on a polygon surface a polygon version of text, logos, symbols, artwork, etc, this in lieu of using a texture map or a decal. Of course, you can move position, rotate, and size entire objects or parts of objects, including faces and polygons, edges, and points (vertices). There are twist, bevel, tools. You can create text objects. Booleans are supported. There is a whole range of polygon, point, and edge manipulation tools where you can add, delete edges, faces, points, and modify geometry in various ways.
Subdivision modeling is fully supported with two basic types and various types of smoothing geometry tools, as well as tessellation, and triangulation tools.

UV mapping and other types of texturing tools are supported and allow a wide range of manipulation of surfaces for figures. And there is also a painting tool for doing various tasks such as weight painting for skeleton figures, to adjust the influence of bones on a mesh and surface color painting.

"Skelegons" is what lightwave calls its rigging tool, which is used for making skeletons or bones of animated characters. "Luxigons" is a tool used to turn all or parts of polygon objects into luminous objects i.e. light sources. "Powergons" can be used to execute various tasks using polygon objects such as manipulating lights, etc.

You can create complex hierarchical objects in the modeler, which Lightwave calls "layers".

The Layout program is just what its name implies. It is where you create your layout. You and insert objects that have already been modeled and arrange them and create a scene. This is also where you can do final setup of animated characters, pose them, animate them, and so forth. This is also where you can create particle effects, to create such things as smoke, fog, fire, and the like. We have already mentioned hypervoxels and physics effects. It also has a flocking tool, which for animations, simulates the actions of large groups of objects, such as a flock of geese, or a herd of elk, or a squadron of fighter planes. I have not yet tried any of these tools yet, so I cannot yet say how these work or how realistic the effects are. The Layout is also where your renderer is located.

The renderer is first rate. It is certainly capable of absolute photorealism. I loaded preset scenes of a model car and World War II planes into the Layout room and rendered it using just basic settings. Even in basic settings Lightwave rendered the scene very realistically. There is a reason why Lightwave is used for professional movies and television. The renders are certainly the kind you can use in movies and television. The renderer supports lens flares, caustics (light through transparent objects,) radiosity (diffuse light), shadows, soft shadows, ray tracing, reflections, refraction.

I have only started to work with this software, so I am still very new to it. But this is my first impression of it. I will provide updates and revisions as I learn more about this software and begin using it.

One last word, if you are new to 3D modeling, you will need to look for tutorials, if you want to know how to build objects in 3D. I myself have some experience in modeling, and learned much about modeling just by playing with this and other 3D software, so I never needed much with tutorials, although for TrueSpace, when I first started learning modeling, I did get Frank Rivera's book on TrueSpace (reviewed in this forum), as a sort of tutorial to help learn some aspects of that software and 3D modeling in general. But if you are the sort that needs some pointers, the Lightwave site and a few other sites have tutorials that will help you get started in learning how to do modeling. I think there are tutorial books on Lightwave as well. The .pdf manuals, that come with the software cover the tools and theiruses, but the manuals do not contain much instruction as to how to model objects.
output: Lightwave: First Impressions of a higher end 3D modeling and rendering package.

Instances.input: When I got the Wacom capacitive stylus in the mail I was very excited, but out of the box, it leaves something to be desired. I like to draw, but for fast, precise drawing - the feel of the bamboo was not as responsive as I would want.    The pen itself has an excellent feel in your hand overall. Nice heft. Well balanced, and at least an inch longer than the Boxwave - which means it fits better in a larger hand.  The clip comes off in case you just want a nice sooth cylinder. The clip even can be mounted in the opposite direction to achieve more length.    The drawing end of the stylus is nicely machined, and unscrews to reveal a removable rubber tip. One can use it with the end unscrewed and the tip fully exposed too.    Here's the bad part for me: Out of the box, the tip feels too sticky, and squishy. It gives too much. Initially it felt sluggish compared to the boxwave's responsiveness. So, I took it off, and stuffed it with a tiny bit of sponge (Mr. Clean Magic Eraser), and Voila! The tip is now firmer, and it glides better on the surface of the iPad. I decided that I should order some more rubber nibs. However, it was impossible to find them on the Wacom site -- for some reason they have the nibs hidden? Anyway I called Wacom and the sales rep told me to enter ACK20501 into the search box on the wacom.com site. 3 nibs for 5 bucks plus 5 bucks shipping. I'm going to experiment with stuffing the nibs with different materials to achieve the exact feel I like.     Wacom should produce tips/nibs with varying material densities, and feels. I give the pen 5 stars, but because the mod I had to do to the tip, I give the overall product 4 stars.
output: Tip too squishy for me. Needed modification. Now perfect.

Instances.input:
I recently purchased a Dell Venue 11 Pro as a laptop replacement for work. I ordered the Dell docking station that was advertised to support dual monitors. Unfortunately, the dell dock came with DisplayPort and HDMI connections neither of which are on my monitors. After many phone calls I eventually got that dock working with an active DisplayPort to DVI and a passive HDMI to DVI adapter. However, the resolution on the DisplayPort to DVI monitor was terrible and everything was distorted.
I purchased the Toshiba Dyndock Docking Station and within seconds had everything set up with great resolution and no issues whatsoever. I highly recommend this product.

I am an Apple convert. Previously I used an iPad 3 with a Belkin keyboard to take notes at meetings, review documents and send quick emails in a work setting. The iPad was my second computing device - I had a laptop, but I needed something lighter and with longer battery life to lug around from meeting to meeting. The iPad fit my needs, except for the terrible file management choices that Apple made, which make routine tasks like adding (non-picture) attachments to an email reply almost impossible.
Enter Asus T100. At least on paper, this has everything that I needed: small size, physical keyboard, long battery life, and an operating system that pays attention to productivity driven users.
What I like about it:
- battery life is as expected, when using the device
- the core Windows experience is still there. Boring, but it gets out of the way for productivity tasks, unlike iOS7
- touch screen laptops are the way of the future.

What I dislike:
- software integration isn't Asus / Microsoft's strong suit. You have to put up with random annoyances like the the volume overlay not disappearing off the screen once you're done with it, or the software keyboard appearing on screen even when the physical keyboard is connected.
- I've also encountered more serious bugs, like the physical software going AWOL - turning itself off. To get it back - a machine reset was necessary.
- the thing that's really disappointing is that in spite of the long battery life, the Asus / Microsoft combo hasn't quite mastered the standby. This thing would be dead in 24 hours, whether I use it or not. My iPad could last on standby for weeks.
- the Windows 8 split personality. Two applications for OneNote, both fighting for control of my notes. In general, the metro style apps are a bit too design oriented, and sometimes that does get in the way of their functionality.
- What good is being able to touch the screen, if I can't pinch to zoom? Most Windows programs support this, but on a 10 inch device, you really need this. Chrome (the web browser) does not support pinch to zoom, which basically makes it unusable. Pity, because IE (both versions) are not as good.
- Asus bloatware. I keep ignoring their offers for backup and other useless stuff. I'd gladly pay a bit more to be left alone.
- Physical design is mediocre. Buttons can't be controlled by feel only (I've pressed the Windows button numerous types when I was trying to operate volume), the trackpad doesn't have any feel to it, the keys are uncomfortable (after using the Belkin keyboard for the iPad, I know it's possible to make a decent small keyboard)

In the end, this does the job, but barely. I've had it 4 months, but I'm already looking for other alternatives.
output: Great promise, but rough around the edges

Instances.input: Great card. Even better price. Sturdier than other Sony cards Ive used in the past. Used on a D7000 for a while and held up well.

The picture doesn't do it justice, the hub is pretty slick and looks great, very slim profile, and the packaging was excellent. I was surprised by how good everything looks for the price. Also I got a free pack of sticky notes in the box, very nice gesture.

The functionality is spot on, the ports that raise up accommodate the extra wide SD card adapters and memory sticks. I have 9 devices plugged in currently and they all function, unlike some powered hubs where even a mouse and keyboard would be too much drain. The ports that raise up have a higher amperage which I appreciate, I charge my phone and tablet through those ports. As a hub, it's everything I wanted and for a great price.

Cons:
The output port (the port that connects the hub to the computer) is a micro B usb, which anyone with an android tablet, phone, etc. know is a weakpoint would eventually wear out. I would've preferred a more reliable full size or mini port, but I do not plan to travel with the hub so in my personal situation does not detract from the rating.
In the picture, there's 3 bright spots on the light bar, on the unit I recieved, only 1 works reliably and the other one has a delay when plugging in (about 10 seconds). Very strange, but I don't care about the blue lighting as I do about it's functionality.
Having five ports on one side and 5 on the other inherently makes a full loaded hub look very messy. It's personal taste, but if you are the type that wants things to look nice and tidy, I cannot recommend this device.
Big wall wart type of plug, common in usb hubs and externally powered hard drives, this is standard imo so does not detract from the rating, but it's a minus if you plan to travel with it.

Summary: Great on the desk unit that performs and is a good value. Perhaps not the best choice for a primarily mobile user.

Let me start off by saying this is one of the best purchases I have made in a long time. The Kindle works great and is a huge space saver, which is needed since I live in Hawaii. I was reluctant at first to buy one since I prefer paper/hard copy books. I started looking at e-readers when Borders closed down. I checked out the nook, sony e-reader, and Kindle since my friends had them. I decided that the Kindle was best for me. The decision was a tuff one but since the e-readers I thought of buying was the color versions. After looking at there price I thought I was better off buying an iPad or tablet PC. So I saved money and went with the Kindle. I figured with buying a Kindle if I want to read in color or could just download the Kindle app for tablet PC's/iPAD. I already have the app for the iPhone and it works great. Long story short I have been using my Kindle all the time when I read. The Kindle has grown on me alot and now I don't buy paper books unless they are cheaper (which is almost never). Downloading books is alot easier than trying to find them in the store. I also enjoy that I saved 50.00 by getting the kindle with special offers. Just to be clear they never pop up when reading. The offers show up as wall paper and at the bottom of the books screen. I would recommend this product to anyone who likes to read books since its light weight, easy to travel with, and reads perfect under the sun. I also recommend the case with a light so you can read at night with no problems (thats of course you have the lights off in your house). It reads under any light.
Great product, works as advertised!

I bought this to use as a keyboard for the times when my full size keyboard got in the way of other things I need in front of me (like paper). It performs this function well and the track pad is an added bonus.  It became the bonus after spending many, many hours getting it to work.  First I plugged the dongle into a port on a USB hub, inserted the driver cd, and installed it.  The \\"gesture\\" functions worked erratically or not at all.  I contacted the manufacturer twice, through its website, asking for help but received no reply.  It eventually worked after many hours of trying different things (and screaming a lot).  To get it working on my Windows 7 machine:  1) used the Device Manager to remove all drivers  2) inserted dongle into a USB port on the computer, not on the hub  3) then Windows installed the default driver  4) used Device Manager again to remove the driver  5) manually ran the setup.exe program located in the Windows7 folder of the driver cd  It worked, but only on that particular USB port.  This process was repeated several times because inserting the dongle in different USB ports caused the \\"gesture\\" functions to not work again.  Maybe it is intuitive after all.  The device slips on a hard surface, such as a desk, which I fixed by attaching small rubber pads to the bottom.  It worked properly and immediately on a notebook pc running Windows XP.  I would give the device itself a five star rating.  But I gave it a 3 due the trouble installing the driver and lack of manufacturer's response.

This product is as easy as pie to set up and use. AND...it includes two USB cables that connect to each of your computers. For the price, it doesn't get any better (or easier) than this! WOW! And...it works great! Tap the button to select the computer that you are going to use with the device, and you're ready to go! Life is beautiful.

The only reason I'm giving this product four stars is because there's no way to set this device on your desk and make it look good. There are ports on both the front and the back of this device, which means there are cables coming out the front and the back. I was hoping to set this device on my desk so that it was within easy reach when I wanted to switch my USB laser printer between my PC and my Mac. However, as soon as I set it on my desk, I realized that the cable coming out of the front of it was going to be an eye sore. I had to find a place that is more \\"out of sight\\" and \\"out of reach\\" in order to keep my desk looking nice.

Still, it's worth the money. Would I recommend it to others? You bet!
output: Easy as pie ... but one little drawback

Instances.input:
I bought MoKo Clear-View Cover Case since I didn't want to see any corner ribbons or anything else obstructing the device. The case works exactly this way and I like it.

However, my personal way of using Kindle doesn't require any cardholders on the left side. I think making the left cover just plain would make the whole set thinner and lighter, and it might fit into a pocket even easier.

Time to time, e.g. twice a week, the upper half of my Kindle needs to be slightly pushed to re-glue its back panel to the adhesive, but this is not a issue at all.

I have a Macbook air 11'', and I got the 12'' sleeve, because I think it may leave some space for accessories. When I tried it just now, I found it DOES NOT FIT AT ALL! This sleeve is TOO SMALL. I can barely put my mac air in it but can't close the bottom on top. It's even worse that I had to ask my husband to help me and pull the laptop out, because it was too tight and didn't fit. After reading the reviews I found this size really varies. I have to return this, and don't even want to have an exchange.

I love this trackball mouse so much, I use it on all my computers, including my laptop. The downside is that it's corded. I wish I could get the identical product in cordless, but I haven't seen it anywhere (If someone knows of one, just like this one, that's cordless, let me know! I've seen similar, but not the same.)

Okay, the downside: after about a year, each time I have bought one of these for my main laptop that I used daily, the USB plug has stopped work, where you have to wiggle it to get it to work for a while, then it finally give out. The good news: Logitech has given me a free replacement twice when it was within a year of purchase, just mailed it right to me, in the box, brand new. I didn't even have to return the broken one. The third time it happened, it was after a year, but Logitech sent me a coupon for a significant discount off the purchase price. You can't beat that kind of support of their product, so be sure to save your receipt to prove purchase. I don't think you'll have the same problem as I have had though, since I literally use this mouse for about 10-12 hours per day, nearly 7-days per week for my work and personal stuff. I have three of them for three different computers.

The way it allows your hand to sit still instead of having to move to mouse helps prevent wrist pain, and using the thumb to click with barely any movement at all is nice. The track ball can be moved with your fingers, whichever ones you like, and I've found the mouse to be super responsive. I can rest my hand over the mouse, and the shape of the mouse naturally curves to the shape of the hand, so I barely have to move any fingers or my thumb to use the mouse--which for someone who is on the computer as much as I am, saves a lot of repetitive stress on the hands and wrist, and helps with some of my health issues.

It does take an adjustment period and I'll admit it's tough for me now to use other people's computers who don't have this mouse, because I'm so accustomed to it. But for the price, for saving the wear and tear on my hands, I just can't say enough good about this product. If you do buy it, don't give up on it right away after getting it. Give yourself some time to get used to it, because I think once you do, you'll be like me and won't want to go back to a regular mouse or a mousepad again!

Oh, besides it being corded as a downside, I should mention that after time, the little rubber feet that keep it from sliding do wear off or fall off. I simply went to the hobby store and bought new ones to replace them, for about 60 cents. Really not a big deal to me.se, because I'm so accustomed to it. But for the price, for saving the wear and tear on my hands, I just can't say enough good about this product. If you do buy it, don't give up on it right away after getting it. Give yourself some time to get used to it, because I think once you do, you'll be like me and won't want to go back to a regular mouse or a mousepad again!

Oh, besides it being corded as a downside, I should mention that after time, the little rubber feet that keep it from sliding do wear off or fall off. I simply went to the hobby store and bought new ones to replace them, for about 60 cents. Really not a big deal to me.
output: Will Never Use Another Mouse Again

Instances.input: I've been using this case for a few months now, and I've haven't been let down by it. Initially, I was looking for the cheapest case I could find. Further inspection revealed that the strap wraps over a car seat headrest to turn your ipad into an in-car video screen. For my young son, it is a perfect distraction for the long drive, and even when including the cost of the iPad, it is a cheaper car solution than the in-car DVD units.    The unit also performs beautifully when propped up at various angles depending on your application. Cooking, laying in bed watching a movie, or even typing have all been improved because of this case. For the price, you can't beat it. And I'd argue, for ANY price you can't equal it's flexibility.

Instances.input: Screen is coming unglued from bezel and lifting up on left edge. Feels mushy in that area. Backlight is flickering during network access when wi-fi signal is low. Sending my Nexus 7 out to Asus on an RMA tomorrow. These are widely reported issues and neither Asus nor Google has owned up to them or reached out to customers. I'll be thinking twice about future hardware purchases from either company. When calling Asus technical support, I experienced long hold times, difficult-to-understand accents, and audio dropouts from their phone system while trying to talk to them.

Edit: December 21, 2014. I see this monitor is up to $150. I paid about $105 and that was after taxes and the environmental fee. There's no way I would pay $150 for this monitor, for that price there is definitely something better to be found. Probably bigger also.     Fortunately the picture itself is okay, but the monitor itself sits crooked. It's definitely mounted correctly. Screwed on firmly and snapped into place. Either the molding of the back of the monitor was poorly done or the base itself was molded askew. I have approximately a quarter inch thick magazine sitting under one side. I guess if I can get some extra rubber feet to stick onto the one side of the base all will be good. It this thing was designed with a way to tilt it sideways it would be a non issues. I got this router because my boyfriend needed a new router for his apartment and I had Amazon Prime. After getting it and setting it up, it became apparent that the wireless on the router didn't work. The ethernet worked perfectly fine, just not the wireless. All his settings were fine, his company said everything was fine, I even checked it myself. We requested help from Medialink and they decided to send us a new router.  After receiving the new router, we found that this one had the same issue. The wireless wasn't working. We're not sure if it was an issue with Windows 7 support or what... But we requested another one, and they sent it.  Finally, the third one worked. No settings were changed, we were just sent 2 routers that had wireless issues. While Medialink as a company for their excellent support deserves 5 stars, the product, unfortunately, did not measure up to my standards of an easy to set up router that would cause no problems.

The PNY Attache III 32 GB USB 2.0 Flash Drive sold through Amazon was delivered defective the first time. I contacted them and received a replacement within a few days. Their customer service is without question one of the best. The only issue I have directly relates to the quality of this product. I have this USB in one place only; it is used as a alternative storage drive and is never moved. I am stating this because I am aware that regular docking and transport of a memory drive will incur potential shock and damage. With that being said, I tried to transfer the saved information from the original location to another but the device broke for the second time and could not be recognized by the computer. I lost the information and now I'm out those $20 because it broke at two months which is outside of the acceptable return time frame. I am very unhappy with this company and highly recommend purchasing USB flash drives of this size or greater from brands other than this one.
output: It broke twice DO NOT BUY

Instances.input: This is a really great product for the price. we haven't used it yet but it looks like it would meet my son's needs.

OK I've had this for two months and it is fantastic. Though it is not perhaps as \\"touchy\\" as an iPad, with the real keyboard and the nice swivel as well as a good touch screen and a bright display, 160GIGs of storage... It is simply tons more performance with all of the standard software from the windows world for less than the price of the fully loaded ipad.

So I am happy with the battery life, the performance, the feel, the swivel, the connectivity the memory and storage... SO what do I not like.

First off I think the fan vents are in the wrong place... When I use it as a tablet I want to be holding it by the battery bump in my left hand... This means that the fan vents are pointing into my lap/chest when holding it close to me. I think they should go out the side where the charger plugs in.

Second the default values for the tilting of the screen when you swipe a circle with your finger are opposite for me... so I had to change the settings in the video options for page up and such to do what I wanted... not a biggie...

But the MAIN PROBLEM which is purely cosmetic is that the top outside of the case with the display has started to lose its paint along the edge. It is where my hand grabs the case to close it... I suspect that perhaps chemicals probably suntan lotion or other has caused the paint to warp and crack. YUCK. I thought the case was molded in this color otherwise I woulda just got black case.

For this reason I have to give it a 4 out of 5.
output: Love the hardware, hate the paint :(

I bought this for a 20-inch HPL2045w computer monitor.  I chose this particular wall mount because it folded up nicely upon itself to about only two inches or so of profile, whereas most were closer to four inches.  The monitor itself has a pivot feature and so installing a wall mount that does not have a vertical adjustment was much more difficult having to allow for extra room during rotation of the monitor to achieve both portrait and landscape modes. The wall mount came with all I needed and no extra hardware was required to mount to either the wall or the monitor.  It is a very heavy and solid mount and it moves well and smoothly thoughout the range of motion.  As I recall it was possible to tighten up the joints, but it wasn't necessary with this light monitor.  Cable management was respectable as well.  While this product may seem a bit pricey it is worth the money and other qaulity mounts are close to or higher than this price point. I would recommend this product and would buy again.  Ideally, I would love to see this product with a vertical adjustment, but continue to keep the same low wall profile making installation a breeze.

Instances.input:
I have an old computer upstairs where there is no ethernet wiring. The computer does not have a built-in wi-fi adapter. This gadget fit the bill perfectly. Not only does it work very well off USB (I didn't even bother connecting it to the included AC adapter) but it has very good range reception. The previous wireless device I had connected to this computer worked very poorly in this location -- the Netgear adapter works great. It is also much smaller than you might think from its picture. It is about the size of a deck of playing cards.

My only criticism of this adapter would be the somewhat poor instruction sheet. Anyone unfamiliar with computers and wi-fi connections would have a tough time setting this up if their router has wi-fi security enabled and you do not have a WPS-type router. If using WEP security you need to specify if it is 64 or 128 bit encryption. You also have to specify your router's HEX key. To set up other wireless devices in my home, like my wi-fi enabled bluray players, the connection is made with an ASCII key. But this Netgear device requires a HEX key. It took me a little while to figure this out because it also asks for a password, but once I entered my router's hex key and used the ASCII key for the password I was in business.

This is a very low-cost way to add wireless internet access to another room in your home. It is highly recommended, and I would not hesitate to buy another one if the need arose.

Extremely poor build quality. I order these types of boxes on a regular basis for my business and have had great luck with Minix and decent results with Rikomagic. Ordered this one because of the external antennas in a USB powered stick for demo use. First one rebooted randomly for a couple of weeks and then died. Luckily returned to Amazon within the 30 day window. Second one was stable but this brings us to the bigger problem with both of them. The casing on the units is not attached at the connector end. When inserting cables ( even gently) the force required to overcome the friction with the socket and the cable end will flex open the seam on the unit. In part because it doesn't align properly to begin with on the jacks. After 3-4 times of plugging in the power cord the socket, which is only attached to the unit by the surface mount solder joints on the circuit board detached and now I have a paper weight. The jack should have been attached with a peg, screw or tab that went through the board to anchor it. Otherwise it would never stand up to very many insert and removal cycles. BAD (read cheap) DESIGN

Would never be worth the money for freight and hassle to return it for RMA even if I could find the vendor who doesn't have a website that comes up in a web search.

Do yourself a favor and spend a little more money on a Minix Neo X5 or X7. Build quality difference is like a Yugo to a BMW.

This is a great screen protector. The anti-glare does cut down the glare when using the Kindle outdoor, but still not under direct sunlight since the Kindle screen isn't bright enough to begin with. The matte finish also slightly cuts down the brightness of the screen but it didn't bother me after getting used to it. The surface seems smooth and tactile when gliding my finger over it.

Application can be tricky since no cleaning cloth or applicator was included in my pack, so I had to dig out the old ones from my other screen protectors. The printed direction is minimal but the two tabs on sheets are numbered as usual. The screen protector fits all the way to the edge of the Kindle and has a punch hole to line up with the Kindle camera (make sure to line them up when you apply the screen protector). I had some bubbles formed right after application but I was able to squeeze them out using an old applicator (or use the edge of a clean plastic credit card).

This screen protector is made of high-quality Japanese films. Film transparency and uniformity is great. Rainbow effect is nearly non-existent. However, it's not fingerprint resistant since I can clearly see fingerprints and smudges all over after each use. It is easy to wipe off though.

This should install both the driver file and wireless configuration utility program. Then, visit Linksys support/knoweldge base website and search for article ID KB10934338. output: Here is how to make it work for your windows XP!

Update: 3/8/2012 - It's been a year since I bought this keyboard, and I'm still very pleased with it. I have purchased a Macbook Pro and use it instead of my 2006-iMac 20\\". The keyboard works great with the Macbook. Battery life is around 6-8 weeks.
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

I've had this keyboard about 6 weeks. I think it's a great value from Amazon. It looks and feels like an Apple product; it matches perfectly my 2006 white iMac. You can no longer get an Apple wireless keyboard, white or aluminum, with a numeric keypad.

It was easy to install. It works great both in Mac OS and Windows Vista; BUT, I use Bootcamp which requires a restart during which you hold down the options key. This keyboard doesn't work during the restart; so when I switch to Windows, I have to attach the USB keyboard. I'll look into installing Parallels to resolve that problem.

I paid $40 to Amazon for this keyboard, while the price in the stores is between $70-80.

I don't know about battery life; I assume I'll have to replace them every 8-10 weeks, according to the manual. This keyboard operates wirelessly ONLY. There is no USB option for it.

After six weeks, I'm VERY pleased; Five Stars!

Instances.input:
This is all it is cracked up to be ... except for one HUGE problem. The HDMI out will only work if you are not using the Thunderbolt ports for HDMI or Display Port video. If you are connecting anything other than a TRUE thunderbolt monitor, you won't be able to support two external monitors from this device. I was REALLY disappointed when I finally figured this out. My remedy was to buy a USB 3.0 to HDMI adapter and plug it into this device. It has given me support for two external monitors, but only the HDMI monitor is useable for video. The USB to HDMI monitor has full resolution with the additional adapter I found, but has some serious limitations.

Hopefully I will be able to find a different USB to HDMI adapter in the future that will remedy this, but for now it is a crude work around.

If you are expecting to add two external monitors to your computer, this might be your adapter if you have:
1) True Thunderbolt Displays
2) An additional adapter to convert USB 3.0 to HDMI or Display Port

Otherwise, you will be able to only support one external display with this device.
output: Supports one external display easily. Two is MUCH harder.

Instances.input:
I see many people complain about the tablet but have yet to have any of the issues complained about. I refuse to pay the crazy price for an ipad that does not even have a memory card slot at least.Yes I looked at other more expensive tablets but decided paying for a name was not worth $200-$400 more. You do get what you pay for, the Trio is only as good as your wifi and internet connection.

I do play games like angry birds, wordsmith, words with friends and others and have no problem with any. I also have facebook and skype and they both work well. I can view youtube but it can be slow at times. The sound is low but with a headset or ear buds the tablet comes alive. I added AndCad and it works great. The pinch and zoom works great and responds well. The camera and video quality are low but still work well and I have not seen the \\"green\\" pictures others mention. I have dropped this tablet three times twice on hardwood floors and once on carpet and it still works fine. The app stores that come with the tablet work well and you can add others as well just not been able to add google play store.

In summary: If you want a good large tablet that holds up and gives you access to social media, online news, music, games, books, searches for anything and everything online, front and rear camera, usb connection(s), HDMI connection, headphones, and an Micro SD card slot then the Stealth is a good cheap alternative. If it gets broken, stolen, or lost I would only be out $130 versus a much more $300-$500+ to replace and repair for the others. I would definitely buy it again once they add a bit more speed and better cameras.

I give it a 4 out of 5 since it does meet my needs and the price can not be beat but if the video speed and sound were improved it would be a 5 easily.
output: 6 months and still works great for the price

Instances.input:
If you're looking for a primary computing machine, this isn't it. But, if you're like me, with a workhorse on the desk, and you're on the move a lot, you can't beat this Chromebook. It's essentially a web browser that you hold in your hands and can take anywhere. Though it's great for keeping up on email, Facebook, reading, or just surfing, I wouldn't use this machine to do any serious work. Sure, you can view/edit/share files with the integration between Google Docs and Drive, but working with large, complex files can be a pain when you're stuck inside a web browser.

This little machine perfectly fills the gap between using a less responsive phone and the primary machine with all the expensive software. Great for taking to classes, or while travelling for work. It's snappy both in booting and while running. Video and audio quality is just fine, if perhaps a bit too quiet at times. Keyboard is visually appealing, very comfortable, quiet, and responsive. The lack of a delete key, is off-putting, however. The touchpad takes quite a bit of getting used to - I had to dramatically adjust scrolling speed so that a small swipe didn't send you instantly to the bottom of a page. Battery life is excellent; it's definitely an all-day machine without being perpetually tethered to a wall. I usually get about 6 hours of constant use before I need to plug in. The OS is wonderfully secure and worry-free, and the user interface is very clean and simple, yet looks great. The frame is very sturdy, as are the hinges.

My only serious complaints are that you're limited to a small set of provided wallpapers, and the necessity of an internet connection to truly be able to use the machine. A little overpriced, in my opinion, but I'm absolutely willing to pay the premium for a great little machine that vastly outperforms a similarly priced netbook or laptop.
output: Won't replace a PC, but it doesn't need to.

Otherwise, the features that I do like are how the Kindle Fire slides in. The case does do a good job rotating very easily. The holder roatates by a snap button, & works great. This machine is basically functional and it does what it is supposed to do. However, after going through 5-6 older $300 lap tops, I have to say this is the worst screen quality I have ever seen. The contrast is harsh, the sharpness is very low and the general skin tones are unrealistic. To be clear, the problems are with jpeg files and video, not graphics.

If you plan to watch anything of quality, just skip this series of Gateway. Regardless of how I adjust it, the same things I watched on my $300 D**l which just died are just trash on this machine. They really cut corners here. If this is the future of LED technology, I want none of it.

Added: I am beginning to wonder about this screen. I tried everything I could to adjust the screen and could not make it better. Then, for a different issue, I have had to do a few recovery cycles going back and forth and back and forth, ending up where I started and now the screen looks much better. Very odd.
output: Worst Screen Quality I Have ever Seen

Instances.input: I got the Microsoft Wireless Laser Mouse 5000 and followed the 3 required instruction steps (install software, put batteries into mouse, plug receiver into USB; and the optional set up step of pressing a button on the receiver and then the mouse) and the cursor on the screen didn't respond.  Tried again, no response, switched to another USB, no response.  Re-booted computer, no response.  I was about to send back and write a nasty review, but tried one more time with a third USB port and pressing buttons on receiver, shaking the mouse and then pressing button on mouse and it finally sprang to life.  Working fine and very happy ever since.    You should note that the receiver sits on your desk and is connected to the USB plug by a wire and NOT integrated into the USB plug itself, but since I use this with my desktop, I have no problem putting very small receiver on my desktop, especially for better reception.  It's not for notebooks, though.    I LOVE the feel of it, very smooth, and I like the scroll wheel without the clicks, very slick.  It's a full size mouse, which is what I wanted.  Love being not attached by a cord especially at this price.
output: Took Some Work to Set Up But Then Works Great for Desktops

First about the delivery -
I bought the part from Issaquah Highlands Tech, order fulfilled by Amazon. On the packaging it says Dell Outlet New, and as far as I can tell it looks completely new. It also comes with one year Dell warranty, but that year starts when the seller bought it from Dell, not when the product was shipped to me. In my case I received it mid-March, but the warranty already started in January. This is not a big deal, but I think it should have been disclosed. That is the only reason I took out one star. You will also need to send a message to the seller through Amazon by "requesting an invoice", and ask them to transfer ownership of the product to you. The transfer of ownership took one week. This is another thing that I think should be detailed with the package.

As for the product it self, it is great. Where else can you find an Intel Core i5, with 128GB SSD, and a removable battery, in such a compact packaging, for $500? Seriously, get it while supplies last as Dell is seen keen on stopping making tablets with removable batteries. It comes with all the Intel goodies, rapid start, TPM, rapid storage, and smart connect. It even comes with a fingerprint reader. As for the fan, when reading or browsing the web, I don't hear it at all. When using Skype I can hear it but it is still pretty quiet. It is only when stressing the computer that it becomes quite loud.
output: it is great. Where else can you find an Intel Core ...

Instances.input: I bought 6 of these secure USB memory devices.  One of them had an interesting experience.  It went through the washer in a pocket.  When it came out the password was not needed to get to the \\"secure encrypted\\" data.  Having the password protection disappear is bad enough but getting the data exposed is a BIG SECURITY VULNERABILITY.      About a week later another of the Corsair Padlock drive's data was accessible (without entering a password and without washing it).      --- updated a week later ---    Corsair responded, appreciating being notified of the bug, and in what is an unusual move, published a detailed workaround on their web site.  It is at   [...].  Based on their heads-up analysis of the situation and quick technical response I recommend their product and will continue using it. Note that the web commentary about easily defeating the encryption of the Corsair Padlock relates to a previous design, not the Padlock 2.
output: Serious security defect in Corsair Padlock

I love this thing! It comes with everything you need to get started. Currently, I have it connected to my Dell Inspiron 6000 laptop, my Dell Dimension E520 desktop with Windows XP, My Linux server running Centos, and I have one slot open for testing and repair of other equipment.     In some previous reviews others mentioned the delay when switching between pc's. I was concerned when I read that (after I placed the order and before I recieved it) but having used it I can say the delay is at most 2 to 5 seconds. Not really a big deal and very acceptable considering the fact it is using USB.     If your looking for a USB KVM this is the way to go. The sound option is great.    In case anyone is wondering it comes with 4 sets of cables. Each set includes two audio cables colored ping and green for mic and speakers on both ends and one cable that looks like a standard VGA connection on one end (this part connects to the KVM) and has a VGA connection on the other end and a USB connection (this is the end the connects to the pc).     Setup is a breeze and I did not even need the software or manual.
output: A great  choice for a USB KVM (with audio).

Instances.input:
I bought this unit for my daughter-in-law and stepson for Christmas. They wanted something that would hook to their television and also would sound good with their iPod/iPad. They have a relatively small living room, so a huge unit was not really necessary. After doing some research, I chose this unit based on some favorable reviews, and that it sounded like it would fit their needs.

They are not super picky about sound, but they expect decent sound. I on the other hand, am somewhat of an audiophile.
My wife sits somewhere in the middle.........she is somewhat discriminating on her sound, and expects speakers to sound lush and not tinny.

So here's the thing. We took the unit over to their house and I hooked it up for them. My daughter-in-law plugged her iPod into the port on top of the unit, and began to listen. She listens to current bands, such as One Republic. Right off the bat, I noticed that the sound on this Craig speaker was tinny. We turned the unit up, and I adjusted the bass to level 3. Immediately, we encountered vibration and creakiness (that's the best description I can think of) from the cones. You simply cannot turn the volume up very loud, without getting this negative vibration and sound. We then tried it with just the television sound. We were disappointed that it basically provided no better sound, than you would get from a large television speaker. Both my stepson and daughter-in-law were frustrated with the vibration, and the fact that you can't turn the unit up very loud without this occurring.

This unit provides some bass, but it is limited. There is not a subwoofer built in, so this is certainly a factor. Nonetheless, I expected it to fill their small room with good sound without the obnoxious vibration that I have mentioned. My wife told me later, that she was very disappointed with the sound that the Craig produced. She and I were so embarrassed that we had given them a gift of this low caliber, that I immediately began shopping around for a better sounding speaker. I have found one, and I am replacing this Craig speaker with a superior unit.

I do not want to come off like I am snobby when it comes to my expectations from a unit that is selling for basically a hundred dollars. But let's face it.........when you purchase a speaker that gets pretty decent reviews, you expect it to perform admirably. The Craig speaker may be just fine for some users who are not at all concerned with good sound (not to mention the ugly vibration). But for us, who run the gamut from not super picky, to very picky, this unit did not produce. I am not associated with any electronics company, and I am not someone who is writing this negative review, in order to promote another product. I do not like writing bad reviews, because it is not my nature to slam someone's product. But I had to put in my two cents worth, because my experience with this Craig speaker, was nowhere near what some of the positive reviews indicated. I would not recommend this unit.

Thanks for taking the time to read my review.
output: Way Less Than I Hoped For

I like these cables and they don't get tangles much if ever. From a design perspective, I know it might raise the cost to manufacture but rounding off the portion where the wires meet the USB might be helpful. I have to bend mine awkwardly when I plug it into my Xbox One, this part of the cable looks like it will become a weak point eventually from the odd bend in it, a round finish might help relieve all of the pressure in this one spot. other than that I like these cables a lot.

Update (1-18-2016): as I predicted before, the design flaw in the cable near the USB and micro USB connections is bad. Both of mine have become weak and would occasionally shock me and disconnect my xbox one comtrollers. After taking a close look at the cables I noticed that the wire (inside the liner) had become weak from the natural flexing of the cable... must be cheap copper. The flex life should be many years, not months.
output: Nice cables, try not to bend at tight corners or at odd angles

It holds all my computer stuff, my school books, and some other stuff that I use at school and home and there's still a good amount of room left for more. I have a big 17\\" Inspiron 1720 so I was worried that it wouldn't fit in the compartment but it does and there's actually room to spare. The padding is pretty good too so I'm not worried about my books doing any damage to the computer. Feels very well made too so I don't think it'll even show any wear for a very long time. It's also pretty comfortable despite its size.    Cons: Although the padding is generally very good, I think it could have used a little more on the bottom of the laptop compartment since that's where the hardest impacts occur but it's not bad. The bag can also be very heavy when it gets filled up but I suppose that's a con of physics more so than the bag itself.    Overall: It's a pretty good bag, especially if you need to carry a lot of stuff with you like I do. Definitely worth the money if you're looking for a big bag that's solidly built. I'd buy another Targus bag if I needed one.

I've been using a Passport 2TB Portable Storage Drive w/3.0 USB for over a year now to back up all the data for several computers. I'm a music and e-book collector and I have scanned hundreds of old family photos to store on my Passport. I almost filled the entire 2TB and realized that my whole life is all backed up on one drive, so I purchased a second Passport to be a backup for my back up. The transfer speed is great and something that took 35 hours on USB 2.0 now only takes 5 or 6 hours. Now I feel secure that in case anything happens to my master backup, all my data is safe. I'm not afraid of the quality of the Passport, I'm afraid I might lose my Passport as it fits in my shirt pocket and I carry it back and forth to work and on business trips all over including overseas. My data is worth far more than the cost of a Passport. I use my Passport every day and it never lets me down.
output: My Passport 2TB Portable Storage Drive is Fantastic!

Pros:

• Fits right in your CD player – innovative
• I like that there is a full 360° to rotate… I do this a lot of my tablet
• Padded – so it won’t scrape the edges of your tablet

Thoughts:

• depending on the setup of your CD player in your vehicle you could run into some issues. Take a look at the angle of your CD player and any obstructions that might be in the way. This will give you a good idea whether this thing works or not because it needs clearance.
• Don’t overstretch the holding arm or it could disassemble
• I use this on my iPad air and it feel secure enough… If you have something that’s a little heavier in May feel unstable.

The bottom line:

I think this is a great idea and really a good product. I just think that you need to make sure of a couple possible issues before purchasing. What kind a tablet will you use? Where is the location of your CD player? Are you okay if this blocks some of your controls? If you’re okay with all these questions and I think you’ll be pretty happy with this purchase. I was able to test this product at a discount for an honest unbiased review.
output: Cool Concept, and Really Does Work with the Right Tablet

I have been a PC gamer for years now, only getting serious in the hobby in the last 2 or 3, when I got my first pre-built gaming PC. In the years since I have upgraded my components to a respectable level so I can play the latest games at 1080P. However, one thing I haven't changed is my gamepad setup. I've always been a keyboard/mouse kinda guy on PC, but one of the strong points of console gaming is a solid controller setup, which I feel Xbox has. I decided to try something new, and purchased this, i'm very glad I did. I've been using it for a few hours now and it's great. I prefer their controllers due to their comfort, button placement, and weight. They have a nice, sturdy weight to them as well, but as this is wired, it weighs less. These features translate well over into the PC version.    The controller's cable is pretty long so you could easily game across the bedroom with it, but it's a bit short for console usage.    It has nice response and the vibration feedback is nice! This controller works with almost every game in my Steam library (I mostly play first person shooters and racing sims) and if you're a fan of the console controller, this is a wise purchase to make as a PC gamer.     You can pick this up around $30, so it's fairly cheap in terms of the hours of fun you'll get with it. It's very durable, i've owned Xbox controllers for almost four years without anything happening to them, but I take good care of my possessions. This controller would make a great stocking stuffer for your teen kids, or for somebody who enjoys PC gaming, as well as technology.     I'm not really saying anything new here, but I'm really glad that I got this, as it brings a new light to PC gaming. The comfort, ease of use, and feature-rich experience it brings to PC gaming speaks for itself, and it's really like playing the games for the first time again. There's no learning curve to using this or installing it, just make sure you install the software drivers included on theCD in the box, and you're ready to go!

I have been seeking a fully-featured wireless mouse for the past two weeks and have finally found my optimum choice in the Logitech Wireless Mouse M510. The attributes I sought out included the following:    1) Full-size and ergonomic shape. I have fairly large hands, so most notebook mice cannot provide a sufficiently comfortable experience for long periods of usage time.    2) High battery endurance. I prefer a wireless mouse that minimizes battery replacement to improve overall convenience and reduce my dead battery collection.     3) Laser technology. A setting of at least 1200 dpi is necessary to track subtle movements, which are particularly important for graphical applications (i.e. solid modeling and photo editing software). Laser technology also allows for usage on most surfaces.    4) Inconspicuous wireless transmitter. I find great appeal in a low profile wireless transmitter, as it saves the user from having to remove the device from a notebook during travel.    While many other competing products from Logitech offer appealing features such as \\"hyper scrolling\\" and any-surface tracking a la \\"Darkfield\\", they each carry their own weaknesses as well. For example, I considered various notebook-class mice, including the Anywhere MX and the Marathon M705, yet as a person with fairly large hands, I determined that they were simply not large enough to use comfortably.       Notebook Mice:    With respect to the Anywhere MX, while its touted \\"Darkfield\\" technology and \\"hyper scrolling\\" are admittedly persuasive, does not appear to yield the battery endurance that I desire. The form factor is certainly far too small to permit the ergonomics my hands require.     In consideration of the Marathon M705, while it certainly has the battery endurance I desire, as well as \\"hyper scrolling\\", it still remains too small, and the price tag currently does not justify its purchase. The Anywhere MX (at the time of research) could be had for nearly the same price after rebate,and if I were to choose a less-than-comfortable mouse, I would be more inclined to compromise some battery life for features.      Full-Sized Mice:    Moving on to full-sized mice, I spent some time researching the Performance MX. The Performance MX touts a host of features, including a low-profile wireless transmitter, but I am not fully convinced that they justify the price. Furthermore, this device utilizes a cradle for charging, and I would prefer high endurance, which typically entails the exclusive use of AA or AAA batteries.     While researching this category, I came across the M510, which although it carries less features than the aforementioned products, represents the best compromise to the attributes I desire in a mouse. Notably, this mouse has a great form factor, and while not as large as the Performance MX, fits comfortably and ergonomically even for my larger hands. Admittedly, I would prefer that the mouse were a bit longer to fill out my palm, but in the manner I handle the mouse, comes very close to an ideal fit. Logitech claims battery endurance up to 2 years, which far exceeds my expectations, and reduces my reliance on spare batteries. The device uses laser technology, which actually does not perform optimally on my aluminum desk, but tracks perfectly on my microfiber mouse pad with high accuracy. I honestly did not expect the mouse to function well on my desk, so this is more of an observation than a concern. The device also includes the low-profile wireless transmitter, which overall adds to the convenience of the product, and lends itself to a more travel-worthy full-sized mouse. As an additional note, the forward and back buttons work perfectly, and are quite easy to access. Extra buttons that are actually usable certainly add greater value to this product.      Conclusion:    While this mouse certainly has less features than some of the competition, it can be had for a reasonable price, which from Amazon lies in the range of $30 to $40. The form factor is excellent, the battery life is sufficient, the accuracy is great, and the wireless transmitter is convenient. For those seeking a full-sized and ergonomic mouse that still affords some portability, the Logitech M510 is a great option, and should represent a serious candidate for any mouse-purchasing decisions.

PLEASE NOTE: This review is for the Small Alley Case for 13\\" screens - not the Osprey Raptor Daypack.

After taking the plunge to return to school, I found myself on the prowl for a new notebook; all the peripheral goodies to be purchased following in kind. A few weeks of research and product comparisons later, and I finally pulled the trigger by purchasing an [[ASIN:B005JCWSNQ ASUS U36SD-XA1 13.3-Inch Thin and Light Laptop - Black]]. Given the hardware, expected purposes, and personal preferences; the Small Alley Laptop Bag by STM Bags LLC seemed like the perfect choice. I'm about a week into ownership now and so far I'm very happy with my purchase decision.

Pros
* Slim design, with vertical-carry: Minimizes the risk for an accidental broadside-bang into a chair, desk, car-door, toddler, etc. Further, the foam padding for the laptop compartment feels dense enough to add real structure to the bag, while thick enough to quell concerns about the inevitability of minor bumps and dings.

* Durable: Mileage may vary, and I'll have to update after a longer period of use; but, the ripstop polyester outer-shell is waterproof and that's awesome. Similarly, most stitches and seams (outer and inner) appear to have been designed/implemented with consideration to actual reinforcement - not just to hold the thing together while it sits on a shelf somewhere. I should also note that another reviewer did say that the edges of his laptop got wet in the rain (due to the open-sided design of the flaps). I'd have to assume his laptop was larger than the recommended 13\\", because mine managed to weather (Tee-hee!. . . sigh) a recent 100-yard dash across a parking lot during a significant downpour. The two protective flaps were securely Velcro'd down, keeping my new baby snug as a bug. I'll add a few customer images with references to the gaps just in case anyone wants a closer look.

* Style: I'm a big fan of the minimalist design. I don't need a bag that communicates \\"rugged-urban-outdoorsman-student-guy\\". As well, I don't need 10 exterior pouches made from 10 different materials, with 10 different creatively-marketed functions and 10 different fasteners. I already have plenty of options to consider when I want to lose something smaller than a can of soda, but thanks! I will say that the interior does have a sufficient number of areas/pouches for a few standard items; plus, a small snap-detachable key-ring for a spare set of keys or anything else (USB drive) you might want to store, while not allowing it to shuffle around at the bottom of a pocket.

Cons

* Slim design: I know, I know. I do really like the slim design of this bag, but once I neatly pack in my computer, power adapter/cords, mouse, portable hard drive, steno pad, and a few pens, the bag starts appearing as a slightly pregnant version of itself - kind of like an Olsen twin, somewhere around the beginning of her first trimester. If I didn't utilize e-textbooks for class, I can only imagine how I might find myself one day, enrolled in US History to 1877 and Intro to Psychology; peering at the bag's distended belly from across the room, face twisted in disgust as I try to work up the courage to blurt out that which would undoubtedly be turning over and over in my mind - \\"You were so beautiful once, now look at you.\\" - With such inevitably leading to, \\"Maybe we should think about seeing other bags. . . \\"
But again, I don't have the need to carry much more than I do now, so this point is largely moot; I just thought I'd offer the heads up.

All in all, I really like this bag so far. 4 stars until I get at least 6 months to a year in and see how it holds out. Until then, I'm making a strong recommendation all the same. Thanks for reading, comments and questions are welcomed!

*****12/05/2013 UPDATE*****

5 stars it is. I carry this same shoulder bag daily, and am pleased to report that it has held up excellently. Apart from some very normal and quite minor wear (like small, loose threads here and there, as well as the white text wearing off of the rubber label found on the bottom-right of the exterior flap), the satchel is in remarkable shape.

I should note that I don't tend to carry my laptop in this on a daily basis. However, I do use this to carry my Bamboo Create Pen + Touch pad, a portable hard drive, a few flash drives, some pens, steno pads, and some e-cig paraphernalia. To this, I haven't had anything break or malfunction do to regular carry/use, so I think that says something to the bag's basic functional build quality. I will try to update some pictures soon, but please feel free to ask questions and I'll do my best to reply promptly.

I purchased this cooler for the [[ASIN:B0044XU4IM HP 17-1181NR 17-Inch Envy Notebook PC]], which is a real beast when it comes to cranking out heat. The size matches it perfectly, and the fans can be placed right where they need to be to keep this baby cool. The build quality of the aluminum is top notch, and is also quite attractive.

While it works great while sitting on a table, it is very uncomfortable while on your lap, and the fans get stifled while on a surface that's not completely hard and flat. The wire management is just plain bad, the cord sticking out of the side of the plug blocks the USB port next to it, the fan controller clip is worthless and constantly pops off from the base, and worst of all the fans died after only a couple weeks of moderate usage.

If you're only using this on a desk, and won't be moving it around at all this should work just fine, but I recommend everyone else look elsewhere. Unfortunately, I really can't find another cooler that meets my requirements (most are much too small for my huge laptop), and am seriously considering making my own at this point. I mean, really, these things aren't exactly rocket science.
