When I saw the specs for the laptop online ([...]) I was particularly impressed by the low price point for an i7 processor (i7 2630qm @ 2Ghz per core) equipped unit.     Yes, there are other laptops as of writing that carry a $700-$950 price tag but finding one with 8 gigs of DDR3 RAM with a similar 1GB graphics card UNDER $1100+ wasn't easy, especially since most of them were 15.6 inches or larger and I was looking for a smaller more portable laptop. I picked up this unit for about $930 (shipping included, no tax :-D) through Amazon's circuit city store. Lenovo is selling the same one through their website currently for $1070 (after discount) plus shipping and tax.      So, how about the performance? Simply amazing. I've been downloading Demo's of games left and right through Steam and can happily say this rig could handle most of anything I can throw at it, like Metro 2033 (High settings, 1366x768, with DX10), Home Front (same, on high, and full resolution), to name a few (I'll update the list in the coming future). I did try running Crysis (first copy) and met some slowing down (26-30 fps, all settings high, DX10) I blame the graphics engine on this case since other newer games seem to run just smoothly. Oh, as a side note the laptop stays surprisingly cool even while crunching heavy graphics, nice.     Windows experience index gave it a 5.8 rating overall with the hard drive being the lowest subscore (weakest link) but here's the breakdown:  Processor 7.8  Memory (RAM) 7.6  Graphics (for aero desktop performance) 6.7  Gaming Grahics 6.7  Primary Hard disk (Disk Data transfer rate) 5.8    Hardware, Fit and finsh? Here's where I think Lenovo saved a buck or two to keep cost down... or maximize profit. Whereas I though I was getting an awesome Hp Envy alternative is when I was kinda (not really) let down. The casing is for the most part is plastic, even the faux aluminum lid which is  a plastic black, with red metallic flakes, sheet etched with lateral lines to simulate brushed aluminum.  There's one exception; the base which I believe is matte black painted cast aluminum (CORRECTION: I confirmed it to be simply black plastic by removing the battery and discovered the injection mold lines...those cheap bastards!) . So it could said it's on the cheaper end, but because of this the overall the whole unit is surprisingly light and unexpectedly sturdy. Cost cutting FTW!    Now, the keyboard: while it may not be like them chiclet types found on them fancy apple products or other fine hardware it is comfortable to type on. Its not without shortcomings though; There is a slightly perceivable amount of flex on the whole board when pressed down firmly, again cost savings may be the culprit. Furthermore the layout, although great for typing, isn't very gamer friendly, but it is 14\\" laptop afterall. I just wish they would've swapped the \\"Fn\\" key with the \\"Ctrl\\" like other conventional layouts. I'm considering a separate keyboard for gaming because of this.     So OK that nice, but how's the Sound? Impressive, them little JBL's can reproduce a good tune loudly, but sans the bass tones. They're an improvement over them standard laptop speaker anyways and good for conference calls and general movie watching. The web cam included is HD but otherwise like any other I've seen, so meh. The DVD drive included sadly is NOT BluRay, but hey what do you expect for this price range. The screen: It's sharp at 1366x768 speckles (like that word huh? I think it sounds cool) of resolution with a fairly good horizontal viewing angle, there's some washing of colors in the vertical plane when repositioning.    So, thats all I have say so far. Like I mentioned earlier I may update the games list at a later date. Ultimately even with the shortcomings I've very happy with this little laptop and recommend it.    Here's some Specs, because Specs are cool:    2nd generation Intel® Core(tm) i7-2630QM Processor ( 2.00GHz 1333MHz 6MB )  Genuine Windows 7 Home Premium 64  ATI Mobility Radeon HD 6550M 1GB  8 GB PC3-8500 DDR3 SDRAM 1333MHz  14.0\\" HD Glare with integrated camera 1366x768  Integrated 1.3MP Camera  Industry Standard Touchpad  500GB 7200  DVD Recordable (Dual Layer)  6 Cell Lithium-Ion  Intel 1000 BGN Wireless  Bluetooth Version 2.1 + EDR  HDMI (Out)

Instances.input: I purchased this together with some M Audio AV30 speakers yesterday. The difference in quality comparing to the motherboard sound card is so very noticeable, sound is pure and crisp with headphones or speakers, really a pleasure for me to listen, especially classical orchestral music with this setup (I am a classical musician myself).    It is true what other reviewers say about this not being a true Xfi since the processing for effects occurs in software not on the chip. The sound quality or Sound to Noise ratio was the thing that mattered to me the most and this card has 108db of S/N ratio, more than some other X-fi models and for the price range the best in the sound to noise category, maybe not true \\"audiophile level\\" but those cards cost more than twice as much as this one.    The X-fi crystalizer audio effect is great for listening to internet radio such as free version of pandora or other stations which use lower bitrate streams, it really livens up the sound though I dont use it for high quality recordings.    So if you are not a gamer and just want good quality music listening then its a great solution, I am very pleased. Of course having speakers that match the quality is a must and I am happy to report I find the AV 30's to be exceptional for listening to classical, jazz, and most other styles...    I installed the card with the latest downloadable driver from the creative support website (not the included disc)and had no problems in windows 7...    Just be sure to uninstall any previous creative software or sound drivers before you install this one to be on the safe side!    Enjoy!
output: very good for serious music listening

This unit sticks out 1/4 inch when used on a 15" MacBook Pro Retina latest model (2014). It is still usable and quite robust, it sticks out as much as the wireless USB dongle for a Logitech mouse. Performance wise it has been very reliable for several months now under fairly heavy use. I use it as my destination and work drive for stuff that has heavy disk read/write cycles such as Torrent downloads to avoid excessive wear on my Mac solid state drive for non speed critical applications. I also use it for my Parallels data file which frees up a huge amount of space on my hard drive.

It comes formatted ExFat which works fine but does not get backed up by Time Machine. So I eventually formatted it to the Mac format after which Time Machine adds it to the backup (unless specifically excluded).

At the time I bought this there wasn't a model that was made to fit flush on the new Mac Retina 15, there is one now so I will be replacing this with the Transcend http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00K73NWK0/ref=oh_details_o00_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
output: Sticks out 1/4 inch on MacBook Retina 15 - but otherwise pretty reliable

Caveats about non-standard usage: I run Linux on this thing, mainly Ubuntu. I use the discrete Nvidia graphics card exclusively for machine-learning and artificial intelligence applications, and I run display and graphics exclusively on the integrated Intel graphics card. I don't use this laptop for games.

The good:
- The CPUs are really fast. Jobs routinely run 10x as fast as on my AMD Phenom II desktop.
- The keyboard is surprisingly good. I'm not usually a fan of chiclet keyboards, but the keys on this are deep and responsive. It's still not as good as a regular keyboard (non-chiclet desktop-type).
- Build quality seems very good overall, but see the note below about the missing screw.
- Mostly well-supported by recent Linux distributions (Ubuntu, Debian, and Arch).

The medium:
- Looks: pretty good, not garish like many gaming laptops. I love the matte finish, but it's a terrible fingerprint-magnet [edit: somehow gets better over time!]. Also, I was worried that the print on the keys would be hard to see, but it's fine. The slightly-protruding lower-right lip is a bit weird but one almost never notices it.
- Trackpad: Gaming laptops for some reason like to put the trackpads a bit towards the right, which makes accidental clicks more frequent while typing. On Linux this is quite easy to fix: man synclient and look for AreaRightEdge.
- Keys: As a techie I wish the Home, PgUp, PgDn, and End keys were better placed, but I realize I'm in a minority on this.
- Heat: it can handle CPU loads very well (all 4 CPUs (8 threads) running hard and it didn't even need the fan on!) but with any GPU-intensive load it starts throttling. The laptop body doesn't get too hot, though.
- Battery life: I get 4-5 hours with all power-saving features turned on (no wifi, 30% brightness, switch off Nvidia GPU), 2.5 hours with a medium load, and 1 hour with an extreme load using the Nvidia GPU. I think these numbers are about average for a gaming laptop.
- Webcam: mostly works okay with Linux but occasionally flakes out after resuming from suspend.

The bad:
- Laptop-makers are increasingly trying to make the edges of laptops thinner. Presumably they hope this will make the laptop *look* thinner overall even if it isn't. Apart from being deceptive, this leaves insufficient room for ethernet plugs, so they have to spring-load the ethernet port so that the bottom moves down to accommodate the plug. This is not just a nuisance but adds an unnecessary point of failure.
- When I opened the laptop to replace the hard disk with an SSD, I noticed that the disk bed has 4 screw holes but only 3 screws: one is missing. This is the second Asus laptop (out of two) in one month on which I've noticed this problem. It makes me a little nervous about the build quality (which otherwise seems very good, but I'm no hardware expert).
- The wifi card is not very good. Connection strength drops quite rapidly.

The really bad:
- Nvidia's proprietary Linux driver is terrible. The driver causes system hangs at least once a week.

Other points:
- I immediately replaced the hard disk with a Crucial MX100 SSD, so I can't comment on the disk speed. Booting Ubuntu from the SSD takes about 2 seconds :-).
- This has a TN panel. I keep hearing that TN panels are terrible, supposedly because of poor viewing angles. This one works perfectly well for me, and the viewing angle seems fine too. On the other hand, I'm usually right in front of it so viewing angle isn't really an issue for me anyway. I'm not an expert on this but I believe TN panels have faster response times and use less power than IPS panels.
output: Overall a good laptop but has a few flaws

The star is really for Vizio's effort to build something using Android, which I now realize is even worse than its Linux ancestry would make me expect. As background, I have an iPad which I love but find a bit on the heavy side and have been intrigued by the 7in form factor, and Android in general. I pre-ordered the Kindle fire, but when I saw this tablet I decided to give it a try while waiting.  I use Linux for work and I know the user interface is still ages behind Windows and Apple, and graphically remains shaky even to this day, but I wasn't prepared for how terrible Android is (it is 2.3 and maybe ICS is better but I doubt it will address the core issues which are cultural).  There are many reviews already, with a majority giving good ratings but after spending a lot of time with this tablet I am at a loss to explain how folks can recommend this thing. Is it the price? I dont even think the 300$ difference with the base iPad is meaningful because it is like comparing a broken bike to a Rolls Royce.  Yes, there may be Android tablets out there with faster processors and better hardware but that is not the problem here, it is a course project like software that is unfinished, unpolished, shaky, and developped by Google, a company with no regards to esthetics and user experience. I won't list here all the too many problems I had with it, but in conclusion, this is going back and I am now worried about the Kindle.  Appendix [Added in response to comment]  Here is a sample of what is wrong with Android and this tablet:  1) Functionality  ----------------  Browser fails to display many websites correctly. Had to download Opera to get something usable.  Email stuck in endless \\"Downlading Messages\\" loop, I have to press on the menu button and race to click on Accounts to access the INBOX folder directly to see any emails  Gmail app is terrible, I can post a snapshot of the UI if anyone cares  Camera app is unusable and ugliness personified (and the quality is horriblebut that's expected in a cheap tablet)  Youtube videos and videos in general (HBO Go) look pixelated  Remote app is interesting but for my Denon the Power button doesn't work  I found that app quality for the same apps that exist on iOS (e.g. mobile mouse) is much worse on this tablet  Initially, I had set the language to French, then later on changed it to English but auto-correct insists on French and makes typing anywhere a chore  Video calling like everyone else says only works on an unknown app  Needless to say, flash video is no where near smooth and pleasant  Haven't been able to get GPS to work  Battery drains quickly even when not used, standby has been less than 24h for me  While they may be ok on a phone, the 3 keys at the bottom of the screen are bad UI on a tablet. You constantly have to move your fingers back and forth between the content and the bottom while using it.  2) Cosmetics  ------------  User interface is inconsistent across the various built-in apps and menus, only the Vizio specific ones look good  Zooming and scrolling is jerky, shaky and feels severely lacking  Typing on a button or link in an app sometimes selects multiple ones and zooms in with all selected - very unpleasant  Zoom in level when this happens seems to be random  Photo gallery app produces a terrible background based on one of your photos  ...etc...  This was really just a sample, I can easily list more issues if anyone is interested.  In conclusion, if you want to use this for Netflix or playing games but are willing to live with a mostly unpleasant experience outside of those for the price go for it. I however, find this product unacceptable, and it is my opinion that this disregard of user feel and esthetics is an approach that permeates all Google products, i.e. we're giving it away for free, so we will do what we want. Some are ok with that.  Finally, I personally find the negative reviews the most useful and interesting but I think there is a divide between the Android and Apple crowds which make any objective discussion impossible.

Instances.input:
Although the video quality is great with this camera, there are some driver problems that lead me to give it only a 3 star rating. The camera is advertised as working with Vista. I installed it under 32-bit Vista Enterprise with SP-1. The camera appeared to work great until I tried to use it with Live Meeting or Office Communicator.

The problem centers on the built-in microphones, or their driver. The microphones use the USB bus. They automatically find and use the Microsoft generic USB audio driver when the camera is plugged in. Because this device is not of the type \\"Microphone\\" it does not show up in most programs that are looking for \\"Microphones,\\" including Live Meeting and Communicator. There is a \\"Virtual Microphone\\" device that does show up; but, the driver does not route the audio signal to this device. So, what it boils down to is that the built-in, noise-cancelling, stereo microphones are useless with most software.

In order to use this camera as I intended, I had to purchase a headset to use for audio.

Which brings me to Creative Support. I exchanged a long series of e-mails trying to explain the problem to Support. They seemed utterly un-interested in actually solving the problem. Instead they kept pointing me to existing web resources that pertained mainly to XP or other operating systems. They ignored my repeated pleas to refer the problem to their software development team and kept trying to shift the responsibility of diagnosing and fixing the problem back to me. The responses were also painfully slow, with approximately 24 hours elapsing between each. Finally, they stopped answering my e-mails.

I recommend that anyone using Vista and looking for a camera and microphone to use with Live Meeting or Communicator look elsewhere. Some of my colleagues seem pleased with the Logitech camera.
output: Optia AF 2.0:  Not for live meeting

If you have a computer hooked to the EyeTV250 and the internet all the time, you can even remotely program recordings using the TitanTV website.

The only drawback is that it does not do HDTV and requires analog cable TV to be able to change the channels with the EyeTV. These are pretty serious drawbacks, but if your cable & TV works with these, the device is great.

Otterbox has made several products that have protected various devices that I own and have done so very well. Their latest addition for the Motorola Xoom is no exception to their continued efforts to provide great all-around protection, with the silicone / polycarbonate shell for the body and a hard polycarbonate shield for the screen. The screen-protecting shield can act as a 2-position stand. One angle convenient for typing and the other perfect for watching movies or set up for bluetooth keyboards. All the necessary port cutouts, including the charging port. There is a larger flap than the one immediately around the charging/USB/HDMI ports, providing enough room for a dock.

Some might not like the thickness of the case, but if you carry this in a bag like I do, it protects your device from other items in the bag and has the built in 2-position stand. Weight addition might be a concern as well, but not a discernible difference in my opinion. Overall a healthy addition to protection to weight ratio.

Overall a great protective case for people who need rugged. Great access to all the ports. The 2-position stand is even better than my iPad Otterbox case.

Instances.input: Bought this to replace a Logitech mouse that died after 3 months.  I did not save the package or receipt because who expects a mouse to die after 3 months?  In any event, this is the third Microsoft mouse I've owned, two of which are still in service after many years.  The other one was a folding Arc mouse, and these do fail after being open and closed thousands of times... One major thing to note is that the higher end Microsoft mice, such as this one, do in fact seem to track better and more accurately than the less expensive ones, so definitely worth the extra cost.  This is a solid and well-built feeling product, and I cannot recommend it more highly.  I will not buy other brands in the future.  Why take a chance?

I recently bought this product to ensure that my vista upgrade will provide the ability to use Aero. I am not a gamer and hence this review will probably not cover any of those aspects....
Vista Aero definitely worked pretty nicely. However, for reasons unrelated to this card (I certainly know that the card was not the problem since I had a printer that I really needed to use and could not get it to work with Vista), I had to downgrade back to XP. Luckily I had the old hard drive with XP that I just reconnected. XP before I upgraded was using the ATI 9250 card, and so now when I loaded it again it had to install the 9550 drivers. Right after I did this, windows media player was just not able to play any video file without any choppiness. I played around with some of the hardware acceleration settings, and was able to play wmv, and MPGs, but no matter what I did, AVI playback was horrendous. So I had to take it out and go back to my old 9250 and everything was working fine. I did try the latest drivers from ATI, but nothing helped. This may be a problem related to my configuraton, but I just wanted to mention it. This is an excellent card for the price, and I think it is a good deal for anybody that is looking for a cheap alternative to reach the specs that vista needs.

pros, really allows to set times, zone run times, and everything I wanted, very good interface could use a few more options like turn off one zone on all timed watering schedules.

cons:

loses wi-fi connection and needs to be unplugged and plugged back in to access it.

the wiring block with its little screws needs to be upside down to see where to put the wires. So do not put it on the wall before doing the wiring.
wonder why they did not use easy connect blocks like the 20 year old manual zone timer it replaced I will never understand.

getting it to work on your wifi. If you use an open hidden network forget it.

option one just use 169.254.1.1 and the SSID of the caddy, forget using it on your router

unhide your network, set static IP, on both the irrigationCaddy and your router, then program the irrigationcaddy, then hide your network, then
when you want to program it, unhide your nerwork, change the program and, rehide your network

what I will be doing, use the ethernet port, and some sort of ethernet to wifi adapter that will work with a hidden SSID..(spend money on extra device that should not be needed)

another pro is it lets you backup your programming times and zones to disk, which when you are playing with trying to get it to work with your hidden wifi SSID you do not lose everything with every reboot of the IrrigationCaddy. (many reboot before I guessed the problem)

another pro is the price, I was not buying a $250 controller to replace a $40 one whose switches no longer worked well. For $100 this is a good deal, hope they get it to work with hidden SSID, as between the wiring block and my hidden SSID it made installation a small painful problem. Once I realized that even with static IP, on both the unit and my router the unit can not see the router even when the SSID is saved. Every other product I use can log onto my hidden SSID with no problem. I was sure I got a defective one, but once I broadcast my SSID everything was fine.

Hi, I just ordered these speakers, and have always had good experience with Altec products. I see a few reviews of people with \\"hissing\\" problems with these speakers. With the powerful 200 Watt Amp these have, any system noise in your computer will be amplified and heard through the speakers, also.
This is not the speakers fault, it is just something that most likely can be corrected by going into your audio settings on your computer.
( I also notice no MAC people are complaining - MACS seem to have good native adjustment. )
So here is some helpful info I copied from a techie website!!! Just adjust your audio settings. ( Click on the little \\"speaker\\" icon and open up all the choices, MAKE SURE THE MICROPHONE SETTING IS OFF or Zero. ) That seems to cure most of the problems.
You may have to go to some other function to change things on your sound card--- read what is pasted below. I hope this helps!!!! try muting your line in and any else that is not in use in the sound options   makes a big difference
d_kuhn 08-19-2008 at 02:52:18 PM
-

+
Onboard audio is typically not high quality, it's possibly your problem, it's also possible you've got a component in your system that's injecting more noise than usual (maybe something that's close to failing... or that isn't intended for consumer use). I have Realtek onboard audio on my HTPC but I replaced it with an Audigy card a couple years back, using the optical output to my audio rack keeps everything digital in the PC where you're most likely to get noise.
Reply to d_kuhn
boofricketyhoo 04-29-2009 at 03:43:24 AM

Same thing happened to me. Tried numerous things and was ready to pull my hair out. I finally found the problem. I went into Realtek HD audio manager and then to Device advanced settings. Click on \\"Make front and rear panel output devices playback two different audio streams simultaneously\\" and uncheck the \\"Output mic in/line to front panel\\" and \\"Output mic in/line to rear panel\\" and the hissing should stop . Worked for me. I don't know how the settings changed in the first place but I had the same problem you described. And when I did as stated the hissing stopped immediately.
Reply to boofricketyhoo
Anonymous 03-17-2010 at 11:23:04 AM

I had to make an account just to thank you, I muted my rear mic input and it fixed the problem. Thanks so much.

grafixmonkey 08-08-2010 at 04:22:29 AM

You're probably hearing the EMI from your hard drive's read head moving around. Any sound board that does anything with analog is susceptible to interference like this. I get a lot of it from optical drives on systems with cheap sound hardware.   Some components are more susceptible to interference than others. Anything that's an analog input will react more strongly to interference than anything that's an analog output. (i.e. Aux, Line, Mic inputs.)   The most sensitive point of interference though, is the cheap onboard microphone booster that you have to turn on to get decent levels on your mic. The microphone signal is such tiny voltage, that baseline noise that Scotteq mentioned is much more significant in comparison. When the microphone booster amplifies that signal, the noise and the mic get amplified together, boosting the noise.

I must have a different version of the Realtek HD Audio Manager, but got the same results by going into \\"Device advanced settings\\" and checking \\"Separate all input jacks as independent input devices.\\"  Before that, I had hissing at anything over 20% volume. Now, none up to 100%.   Before that, I had hissing at anything over 20% volume. Now, none up to 100%.
output: Fix Hissing- It's not the speakers, it's your PC audio.

Giving this a low rating because the description is misleading. Please read on and allow me to elaborate.

When I purchased this cable, I was trying to find a cable that could be chained together at least three times to be used to extend a USB 2.0 device from my media closet to the center of my living room. I ready the description of this item and understood that it was an "active" USB extension cable, which means that it would contain a USB HUB chipset molded into the connector to allow the cable to be chained together.

The description of this product lists the following: "Supports up to 127 devices on a daisy-chain configuration. A tough, yet flexible PVC jacket and durable connector mold ensures secure fits and easy cable handling."

Unfortunately, after plugging this in I discovered that it does not contain a USB HUB enabling it to support the claim that you can "daisy-chain" this cable. After connecting three cabled end to end, I found that the length was too long to support USB devices and I started to receive driver errors and failures when capturing from a webcam.

DO NOT buy this cable if you are looking for an active USB extension that contains a USB hub to support daisy chaining to overcome the 5 meter limitation of USB 2.0.

DO buy this cable if you are only going to use a single extension cable where the overall length of all cables does not exceed 5 meters (16' 5").
output: NOT an ACTIVE USB extension cable!

Don't get me wrong, I like the Kindle, but it has a few nitpicks that are driving me nuts.

Pro
Fast
easy to hook into wifi and reliable enough to stay hooked in
cloud streaming without a hitch
able to allow music and video use while downloading into device

Cons
Battery life
Very bad charger included-slow enough you may want to look at 3rd party offerings
Programs don't always close out even if you close it
Book reader, video, and music players don't always allow the device to shut off/standbye even if criteria is met
limited compatibility with other apps
limited ability to customize screens

Since everyone is familiar with the pro side, I'll just clarify the cons to save time and space.

1) the charger isn't worth being included in the package. It is extremely slow. Hike the price up a few more dollars and include something that is worth it. I make heavy use of the Kindle as I'm on the road more then not for work. I usually end up having to run the device directly off the charger (and sometimes it still shuts down) due to the charger taking forever. One thing other people can do to reduce drain on the battery and also limit the charger time is to shut down wifi when not in use and to lower the screen lighting. I do it as often as I can, but don't always have the time.

2) This is my biggest pet peeve. Going through the process of shutting an app or a program down only to find out when your battery is almost dead that the program is/has been still running in the background.

3) This is my second pet peeve. I may be listening to music, and the player shuts down into song 3. Then later on, I put the player down thinking it will automatically shut off, and I go back to it and the device is dead because it kept playing well beyond that. This happens with all 3 of the programs with me (video is the best as it only happened once.) where it seems the device will decide when to place the device on standby based on what it wants to do and not to the programming.

4)This isn't as bad as it sounds like. It's just that many apps I've tried in the Amazon store say they are kindle tested and modified, but are still just android generics. Be careful of what you put on your device as I downloaded another music player to try it out, and ended up having to return the device to factory specs as the app allowed buttons to be placed on the standby screen and it conflicted with the Amazon preset standby therefore freezing the device. So look to make sure what the app affects.

5) I use the device when grabbing my laptop is inconvenient such as standing in line, taking the taxi to the hotel or meeting site, etc.... So I end up using some programs more regularly then others. I change things around to reflect what I do with it, and it randomly decides when to change it. My reorganizations may last a couple days, or a few minutes; but I end up having to go back and redo things again.

Overall, it is a great device, and far improved over the other 3 tablets I've used over the last few years. Personally, I have only a few nitpicks with it, but others (depending on how they will use it) will have no problem at all.

Instances.input:
My previous experience with capture devices is limited only to the Hauppauge Colossus, an internal capture card for PC. It was decent, for what it's worth, as it had HDMI

It doesn't even come close to comparing to the Elgato Game Capture HD.

Historically, HDMI has never been kind to capture devices. Your best option was always an internal card (which from my experience is okay, but you'll eventually run into problems with device recognition and the like), and the very few external devices that actually provided HDMI capabilities kinda stunk (BlackMagic, for example).

The Elgato Game Capture HD, however, rises above all those and is probably the best capture device on the market now. If you're looking for the simplest, most efficient way to capture footage from your PS3 or Xbox 360, this is it. No question.

The device itself couldn't be easier to set up. HDMI in. HDMI out. USB out. That's all. And looking at the device itself, you'll notice one BIG difference between it and other external capture devices: No external power supply is needed! This makes it possible for you to take it with you, hook it up to a laptop, and literally record anywhere you want!

Speaking of which, the device is pretty small, almost enough to fit in your pocket, and looks pleasant enough to display on your desk. I think aesthetics can be a problem with capture devices, since who is going to show off their little box that records them playing video games? But it's pretty sleek looking, all black and shiny, so go ahead. Show it off!

It helps that the software is excellent as well. Elgato really seemed to have gamers in mind when designing the program, as it is outfitted with what they call Flashback Recording. Basically, it allows you to play your game and not have to worry about hitting record every time you want to capture specific footage. It automatically starts recording temporary footage when you open the program, and onceyou get the footage you need, you can choose exactly what to save. This is a huuuuuge thing for me, since I record fighting game footage, and it gets annoying have to stop my recording every so often when I have trouble landing combos. It honestly makes the recording session all the more relaxing knowing that I don't have to worry about missing anything.

If there's one thing about the device I'd caution, it would be that you can only capture at 60 FPS with 720p, not 1080p. No word yet from Elgato if the plan to change anything about that, as it could just be a hardware limitation, 720p is not slouch, but it's something to consider if you're looking for the absolute highest quality in your footage.

Nevertheless, the Elgato Game Capture HD is a true sight to behold. Simple, sleek, FUNCTIONAL, and with awesome software to boot. It's everything I've ever wanted in a capture device (MAYBE minus composite video recording. My SNES will remain uncaptured for now...) all rolled up into a tiny little black box. It seems unfathomable that it could work as well as it does, but, well... it does! Sure the price is a little on the high end for capture devices, but it provides so much value in its ease of use and stability that it's definitely worth the cost of admission.
output: The capture device EVERYONE should be using

Bottom line up front - this motherboard works and it works well.  Is it perfect?  No.  Then again, no motherboard is 100% perfect but this one comes close.  I haven't built a serious computer in a long time, so I had to reacquaint myself with some industry standards.  That being said, the manual got the job done, but it sure could use a little love regarding the size of text and pictures.  I recommend going to the ASUS website and downloading the latest manual.  The installation wasn't painless, but that is mostly not ASUS's fault.  I took my time and planned everything out.  Heck, I'm still planning on improvements and the system is fully functional.  Please note that the 4-pin (PWM) CPU_FAN connector MUST BE USED.  I purchased the Corsair H100 Water Cooler for my i7 2600K and the installation went fine.  However, the H100 has a 3-pin connector so I couldn't use the 4-pin connector.  In fact, all of the fans in my chassis are 3-pin.  On initial bootup, the BIOS refuses to start because it cannot detect a CPU fan - pretty slick.  I was slicker and connected my now defunct stock CPU cooler to the CPU_FAN connector.  I have ordered a 4-pin fan to replace a chassis fan to remedy this problem.  My initial memory purchase was from Crucial using their web-based memory tool.  ASUS really needs to update what memory works with their motherboards.  After spending an hour with an ASUS technical rep., I had to order the Corsair Vengence memory and return the memory from Crucial.  This motherboard is very sensitive about memory.  However, the Corsair memory worked perfectly.  The manual should be a little more helpful regarding hard disk drives.  I installed Windows 7 just fine on my 120 GB SSD, but I couldn't find the 1TB HDD once the OS was loaded.  Again, not really ASUS's fault as this is a Windows issue.  However, it wouldn't hurt to mention this (and how to correct).  To recap, everything works great on this motherboard and when properly designed the temperatures are amazing (23C on the CPU, 25C on the motherboard at 4.3 GHz).  I would love to add the optional 50mm motherbaord fan, but I can't seem to find any description in the manual.  Again, ASUS needs to add a little more attention to detail regarding the manual.  I highly recommend this motherboard.  System Specs:  ASUS P67 Sabertooth Motherboard  HAF-X Chassis  (best chassis I've ever used)  i7 2600K CPU  (runs like a champ)  eVGA GTX-580 Classified 3GB VGA  (love it)  16 GB DDR3 RAM (Corsair Vengence)  120GB Kingston Hyper-X SSD  (love it)  1TB WD HDD  (cheap, slow storage)  Blu-ray Burner (amazing at $60)  HP ZR30w 30\\" Monitor (love it)

BACKGROUND
I recently purchased a new MacBook Pro from Apple. As must of you know, products from Apple come at a premium and I wanted something to protect the top portion of my laptop as I worked. I previously purchased a clear keyboard cover by Moshi and was rather impressed by their products. I spotted this clear palmguard and thought I would give it a chance

PACKAGE AND APPLICATION
The Palmguard arrives adhered to a piece of thick cardboard. The instructions on how to apply to the MacBook Pro are printed on the backside along with tabs to help aid in separation of Palmguard from the cardboard. Yes, for those wondering, the Palmguard stays in place due to an adhesive. The great thing, though, is the adhesive does not leave a residue on the notebook once removed.

APPEARANCE
The Palmguard is clear in appearance and blends in naturally on your notebook. The Palmguard is not very thick and so it rests relatively flush with the rest of the notebook.

USEAGE
The Palmgard is comfortable during use. It is not raised on the notebook and is flat therefore I can rest my wrists on it perfectly while typing. Unfortunately, I did notice a big problem. There are several multi finger swipe commands that start off to the side of the trackpad with movement onto the trackpad. With the Palmguard in place, these finger-swipes will not register and so these movements will not work.

The trackpad portion of the Palmguard I attached for a day but removed. Why? The palm guard for the trackpad was very smooth to touch. It took some getting us to but I realized I enjoyed the slightly textured feel of the trackpad bare.

Also, since the Palmguard is clear, after several days of usage, I have noticed bubbles forming under the guard. I have done my best to go back and smooth out the guard but some of the bubbles are present which gives my notebook, now, a tacky appearance.

PROS:
++ Perfect fit for the Macbook Pro 15
++ Blends in aesthetically with the rest of the MacBook Pro due to clear nature
++ Protects the aluminum casing from scratches & dirt from extensive use

CONS:
++ Many of Apples new finger swipe motions require you to use the side of your laptop surrounding the trackpad. This cover prevents those finger swipe motions from being preformed
++ The clear nature of the PalmGuard makes air bubbles very noticeable
++ After much use, the clear becomes discolored. Right now it is becoming a white milky color. It is not dirt. Usage is just changing color.

CONCLUSION
This item does have a premium over similar products. It protects your laptop, aesthetically is pleasing, and is comfortable in use. I recommend it if you want a clear coating to your laptop but, personally, I went with a black leather cover from [[ASIN:B0032Z8IIQ Twelve South]] as it fixes many of the defects I feel this Palguard suffers from.ok Pro 15
++ Blends in aesthetically with the rest of the MacBook Pro due to clear nature

CONS:

++ The clear nature of the PalmGuard makes air bubbles very noticeable
++ After much use, the clear becomes discolored. Right now it is becoming a white milky color. It is not dirt. Usage is just changing color.

CONCLUSION
This item does have a premium over similar products. It protects your laptop, aesthetically is pleasing, and is comfortable in use. I recommend it if you want a clear coating to your laptop but, personally, I went with a black leather cover from [[ASIN:B0032Z8IIQ Twelve South]] as it fixes many of the defects I feel this Palguard suffers from.
output: Great for clear surface pads but has it's flaws

Instances.input: Pros: Beautifully designed and built. From the perforated look rubberized area where your thumb rests to the brushed metal strips which arcs gracefully around the side of the mouse, to the low gloss plastic finish and the metal scroller wheel with rubber insert, it's a beautiful mouse, high quality mouse.    It's extremely comfortable as well. Perhaps not quite as much as my old MX Revolution, but very close.    Darkfield is extremely precise and works on every surface I've tried, from my shirt to my glass desk.    This is the Cadillac CTS-V of mice.    Battery is a removable and replaceable AA unit, a nice feature since internal battery failure caused the death of my MX Revolution.    Charging is done via USB cable, so no down time.    Battery life on its first full day of use is excellent, still 3 bars after hours of use.    Have a middle mouse button again! Now shifting between the wheel modes is done via dedicated button.    Nifty little travel case    Plenty of programmablity.      Cons: Cons are only a few.    Forward/back/zoom buttons don't quite fall into reach as naturally as they did on the MX Revolution.    Loss of shift-to-click. I'll miss this feature. Loved how the MX Revolution could be programed to switch from geared to free spin depending on how fast the wheel spun, then would switch back.      Other Thoughts: My dear MX Revolution bit the dust on me a few weeks ago, due to internal battery failure, yet despite buying the original four years ago, Logitech replaced it with the new model.    It's really worth saying that their customer support is superb, friendly, and helpful. They also send you return shipping labels now so you don't have to pay for shipping. Now that's progress. Turnaround was about 2 weeks total. I will continue to buy products from Logitech, they stand behind them.    My only other minor complaint is the Application Switcher. I don't care for it...distorts the windows and when many are up it looks cluttered. But that's just a keystroke assignment away to set it back to Document Flip, so it's not an issue.    Overall I love this mouse so far, and while I do miss my MX Revolution, this is a worthy successor. It's even better looking and very nearly as comfortable, very precise and works on surfaces the old mouse never could.    Hopefully it will last!

This is a very good media device. Cheap, long lasting, and can host a whole bunch of files!
But the upload to the stick goes very slow (~6MB/s).
The download is between 12 and 18MB/s on my pc, which is more than enough to use this stick for streaming a movie from. HD movies ~2MB/s, Blueray/3d movies ~4-10MB/s, this stick is more than capable of it.

I'd recommend it as a memory device for media players (audio/video); but also good for photo's. Also great for computer backups, but if you back up regularly, and large files, you may want to buy a faster drive.

Not good as an OS drive, since it's too slow; it can be done, but there are drives out there, that are 10x faster on upload.

For those looking at these with fresh eyes, Wacom has brought this technology a long way. Most people shopping for Wacom tablets probably have owned similar products in the past. This product is more affordable than the higher end Intuos3 models, yet powerful enough for many pros. While I have struggled with rating this product a 3 or 4, it is definitely a good product.

First of all, the \\"medium\\" sized tablet will look large to most people. This size is perfect for hard core graphics people who need to work at the pixel level for large images. However, most users will find the small size probably fits the needs of occasional graphics use. Those using this for the mouse and function keys may prefer this size. Either way, the pen function will map to your screen size for any of the Wacom models.

This unit comes in a variety of colors and configurations. The mouse is nice because it allows you to free up a USB port if you're using a USB mouse. Power users will need more from a mouse though. If you're anything like me, you prefer a mouse with many more options than this one provides.

The Bamboo software also allows you to customize the buttons. Left-handers will greatly appreciate this!

Upon plugging in the device, the mouse worked immediately! The pen also works as a mouse or as a pen/brush for drawing applications. Be prepared to spend some time tweaking this unit to your likes though. Installing the drivers and software allows you to access the settings and tools that make this device versatile and customizable.

The software included with this device is a nice to have. Many people who buy this will already have or need full blown Adobe Photoshop. Adobe Elements gives you everything casual users need. The Corel application is nice to play with. But other than a few \\"macro\\" type functions I have yet to find anything I can't already do with Adobe. Perhaps newer users may find the Corel product more user-friendly.

Pros
+ USB connection
+ Works on XP and Vista almost plug and play - before software installation
+ Nice customizable software
+ Nice bundled applications - Adobe Elements and Corel Draw
+ No additional power adapter needed

Cons
- Medium size is large for casual users not using the mouse
- The scrolling zoom function does not work uniformly on all applications
- The mouse with this model will not suffice for most users
- Default settings require a lot of adjusting for graphics editing
- The tablet would have been ideal with several additional USB ports

Overall, the graphic artist or visual junkie NEEDS one of these. If you are a casual user, it is worth getting one on sale. You just might want to lean towards the small one. The small model with pen only will meet most users' needs.

If you are a casual user, it is worth getting one on sale. You just might want to lean towards the small one. The small model with pen only will meet most users' needs. Enjoy.

I purchased a Lenovo ThinkPad Edge E420 from Office Max a few months ago. It is a fantastic machine! It came equipped with an Intel Core i5 2450, 6 GB RAM, and a 500 GB 7200 RPM Hitachi TravelStar HDD. As configured the ThinkPad booted very quickly to the Windows Log in screen in approximately 25 seconds, I was able to use Windows in about 35-40 seconds.

I just installed the Corsair Vengeance kit in the E420 and it recognizes all 16 GB of the RAM and it is booting up in similar times. What I do notice is that when multiple programs are running it is much snappier! The machine opens new windows instantaneously, even while performing multiple tasks! I have also ordered a Crucial mSATA3 M4 256 GB SSD which should arrive on Monday. The bonus is that my 500 GB HDD will stay in place as a mass storage device while I gain the SSD advantage of tremendous speed! I am actually going to clone the new SSD from the HDD so that I have the option of two boot drives. If a catastrophic failure ever occurs I will be covered.

The Corsair RAM Kit came as promised and took me less than 5 minutes to install and it improved my Windows Experience score:

Processor: 7.5
RAM: 7.5 (was 7.1)
Windows Aero: 6.3 (was 5.7)
3-D Graphics: 6.3
HDD: 5.9 (the bottleneck)

I will amend this review as soon as the new mSATA drive is installed and I have time to give it a thorough testing.

Instances.input: The case itself seems quite nice. Unfortunately after putting in all the parts, I found that the SAS/SATA backplane board had a power short, triggering the power supply's short protection most (not all) of the time once I actually received and installed the drives (6 WD Red 3 TB SATA drives). Otherwise, it's a nice, sturdy case. If there's one problem, it's that to accommodate the (low-profile, even!) SAS board I decided to use, I had to lose one of the drive bays - I thought it would only be necessary with a full height card, but no.    Also, the fans are reasonably quiet, but they're only 3-pin fans - so no PWM speed control, just tach feedback. I may end up replacing them with fans that can be controlled. Also, it'd be nice if they included a USB 3.0 to 2.0 header adapter; I had one laying around from my workstation build (Corsair included one with the case I used for it), so I was able to swipe that for this, but it's like, a $2 part. A lot of boards you'd want to use for a NAS application still don't have USB 3.0 onboard, so it'd be helpful to have. (Also also, do you really have to glue the HD Audio cable onto the board in the front of the machine?)    Otherwise, this will be a nice FreeNAS box, once I receive the replacement backplane board from SilverStone...    Edit: A hacksaw and a half-hour allowed me to rescue the lost drive bay. Fortunately the SAS board just barely intersects with the plastic retainer piece, so now I can put a drive into it (and the rails don't hit the board!) with no problem.
output: Good case, backplane needs better QC though

I just got this router set up yesterday and so far it's working. So I'll post what I find here and will just get to it as I test this router. As an techie guy I really needed more from a router and this one had what I needed. I have never used any of the asus routers, but I have used their motherboards and stopped using them since they would normally die after a few years as if they had programed them to do so. This was when they first came into the market though. I knew they made good stuff, so I thought I give them a try again after all this time. I have also changed routers so much that now I just wanted something more affordable and with the features that I needed. I spend so much on other routers and was just let down so I didn't want to spend too much on one this time around.    This one didn't prompt about the new firmware like the AC52-U did, but since I had set that one up the day before, I did it manually and found it and updated the router. I have done that many times before too so it wasn't a hard thing to do. This router makes is a piece of cake anyway. Configuring will take longer since there are many other features that need to be checked, but it all works just fine.    I wanted to add a picture but I can't never seem to be able to find that option on here.    Pros:  - Has support for more dynamic addresses which I needed in order to get to my network. Asus also has their own ddns which is really nice and doesn't expire like many others have and still do. Netegear only has one, dyndns which is no longer free.  - I like the GUI they use, it's nice and also has a lot more choices in features compared to many other routers out there. This software is similar to ddwrt in terms of features plus the cloud/streaming apps. Most people won't use them, but if you're in IT, you do use these and they make your life much easier when it comes to these things.  - I really like how they have also implemented a way for you to access your own network with these routers. Do read the security problems they had in the past though.  - The android apps are nice. So far they are not perfect since one of them tends to crash every now and then. Either way that's more than you get with other routers and you can use the apps to get to your network as well. I still have to go out and test that and the security of the apps themselves because I don't want someone using my phone to access my network. So I'll be checking this a bit more later.  - This one weights a bit more than the AC52-U which was just too light and the stand very weird and flimsy. Although still has the good software this has.  - Built-in vpn sever, how cool is that.  -I haven't experienced anything weird with the wireless yet on the laptop or phone so we'll see how that goes. It's only been a day.    Cons:  For whatever reason when you go to their site for help or knowledge search, all the icons don't work. Not really bad but I guess someone forgot to fix the site as well. It's nice that you can go directly to what you need help on from the router itself. Not to mention actual description of things you may want to know about in the setting pages themselves. That's very helpful. I sure hope they keep improving that and their support, that will make a huge difference. When you used these things often, it's nice to be able to reach someone if you have any questions or need help with something.  -After setting up the AC52-U model before this one, I noticed that it had a way for me to change the name of the network components in the network map so it would be easier to identify them. This one, for whatever reason doesn't allow me to do that. Both routers are very similar in terms of software which is nice, but I missed that on this one which I really liked. I do hope they will implement that on this router as well. The only reason I didn't keep the AC52-U model was because it's only a 10/100 router and no usb 3 port. Every other feature is there though.  -The AC52-U was manufactured in 2014, this RT-AC56U was manufactured in 2013, so I couldn't figure out why that was. I figured what the heck, I'll give it a go even after reading all the bad things since many of the reviews where a bit older.  - One thing I don't care much about is how the ASUS router cases are designed. The way this model is, you can only set it on the desk or shelf the way you see it on the pictures. It has a sort of permanent aluminum foot. I won't call it a stand as it's just something that looks like it's holding it from the front and the back. Well that metal square you see on the picture is what I'm referring to. If it was a perfect rectangle then it would be fine, but these are angled which take more room and you can't really place other thing nearby. For example I like how the netgear routers stand upright or can be placed flat. If they can make a stand that can be placed upright on either side so that you can use it for whichever side the wires stick out, then that would be much better because you won't be limited to only one side and other things can also fit in the front and back without any problem. Since the wires stick straight out on this one, it's sort of at an angle on my shelf, so placement can be a bit tough in limited spaces. Having the wires coming out of one side would be much better so this can allow it to face either way in an upright position, or even flat on a surface. Forget about wall mounting this one too. These are things that really need to be addressed with the design on these Asus routers, but this is just my observation. Also that diamond cut on the AC-52-U actually made me kind of dizzy so I don't care for that. Weird but true. With that said, that's minor compared to the features, that's what I really needed and this router has it, so I'm very happy with this part of it. They have put a lot of thought behind that so it's very refreshing to see this from a router that anyone can purchase.    Update:  -I just decided to set up an asus DDNS and it doesn't work. I also set up an ftp to test with i but can't get to anything. My no-ip address is working though.  -I found out that the Aiplayer will not control my nas. I just read that was something that would be added but the player was able to see the files when I had the dvd player on the tv. These have been out for some time though. Once I turned that dvd off, I can't see that anymore. I was basically trying to stream music from a nas. Although most of the app access is for what is plugged into the usb ports, I was able to see my nas and other internal computers from the Aicloud app. Yes, these are two different apps, but I'm testing both at the moment. My nas may be a bit old and slower than new ones so your mileage may vary. Once I connect through the Aicloud app, the nas shows up in the Aiplayer but it's just loading, loading and loading in that app. I am able to get to the files with the Aicloud app and stream from there if it doesn't crash like it just did. Streaming works but it's not as nice as the AiPlayer.  I'm doing this from an android phone to also test out the wireless connection. I keep noticing the wan ip being offline, I even saw this for my no-ip address. It's midnight so that may also have something to do with the isp, I'll change back to no-ip for now and test the asus ddns tomorrow. For some reason it looks like I have to keep hitting reapply to connect in the router settings. Okay, the app has stopped again when I tried closing it so it may just be an app problem since I know my no-ip address works and so does my nas.  -While changing back to the no-ip ddns I noticed that the hostname didn't change, so watch this as your ddns will still not work until you manually change that back again.  -In short, use the Aicloud for everything and the AiPlayer only if you have music/videos on the usb connected device that you want to stream as I'm having problems with just the AiCloud stopping but at least it works even with the lag while I'm still in my own network. The ready nas does show up in my AiPlayer but just keeps on loading. I should mention that the AiCloud on the browser does work well so you can still access your network this way without any problem. I'm not sure why it's not working as well on the android Jelly Bean. My phone has an Arm Quadcore Cortex-A7 processor so it's no slouch either. So yes, this seems to be the app and not the router which is a good thing so far because I just need access to my network for now, and as long as that works I'm okay.    Update November, 22, 2014  -Today I found out I locked myself out of the router. I enabled HTTPS only just to secure it a bit more but now I get a message about an ip address. Needless to say I can't get back into the router even using the https address. So don't set that up on this router. I have the latest firmware 3.0.0.4.374_5656 on it and it looks like it's not working.  -I found out that they have had a security problem as many linux problems, but this one has apparently been a problem as well and it's still not fixed, well I think they had an update now. After trying all the different options I could, I had to resort to the last choice which was to reset the router...the good thing is that this did work. Unfortunately it was the only thing that worked. The good thing is that I had created a backup of my setting so I got that restored, but had the https setup and got the ip message again. Since I was already logged in I was able to change that to http and restart and create a new backup. If you don't have a backup of your settings you just need to make all the changes again manually. It's working again so that's a good thing.  -I'm now testing the usb printer through the router and although it shows up, I still can't print. Windows won't find the network printer. Okay after messing around for two hours with this. I have managed to get a printed test page. Just use the utility found under USB/network printer called Asus EZ-Printer setting. It looks like you have to use this every time which sucks. Now I have to go install it on the other computers so this is why it sucks, I couldn't detect the printer automatically. I also tried adding a local printer manually and had no luck.  -Having all these problems I thought I test out the AiPlayer again...what do you know, I can now access my nas music from it...so it looks like if you set the https on the router, it just won't work. There is a small wait, but I think that is due to my older nas and how many folders it has. So it looks like I figured this problem out too. Cool.  -I just found another problem if you use the usb on this router. You won't be able to print from an android device. The Hammermill printing app can't find it. It sees the router, but doesn't see the printer. So if you need or want to print from an androd device, keep the printer connected to a network port instead of using the usb. I think that is the best choice at the moment since I had no problems installing and printing from anything on the network, at least until this gets fixed. I just noticed there's no way to disable the printer so I can unplug it from the router either...so I unplugged the usb, put the printer back on the cat6 cable and was back up in as long as it took the computer to put the printer back on. Okay I'm done testing for today.    Update December 16, 2014  I want to make this update before I forget things I have done lately. I was out of town in another state on the opposite side of the country and got the retail version of this router for a family member. They are exactly the same thing other than the letter on the box. This one is a U and the retail version is an R. The setup after the firmware update was still the same which was nice. Once I got it all setup, I wanted to get the ddns working on it, but they had a very old U-verse modem which also had to be updated. Once that was done I ended up having the same problem with the so called new modem/routerthat they gave us. There is no bridging option that I could find and tweaking the modem any way I could just didn't let me get that set up correctly so I could have them connect back into their own network. In short, At&T U-verse was a real pain to work with as they also wanted to charge me to get that set up for whatever reason. The old modem didn't even have wireless N and, but the new one did even though I didn't use that modem for anything else other than the connection itself and the modem also had gigabit ports but you have to log into the darn thing to find all this out as they don't even label any of the other ports. In short, the router was double NATted even with all the passthrough and firewall turned off and it will tell you that ddns won't work this way anyway. I got it to be connected, but it still didn't work. Unfortunately I was also limited on time so I couldn't wait to do much more testing, but I left it all set up as much as it would allow me. Towards the end I did have some trouble with the wireless for some reason, I just lost all wireless connection and I barely got that working back again before I left. I thought there was some interference since it had been working so I tried to change some of the settings which I can't remember now, but I got that back which was a good thing as it would be harder to trouble shoot it from across the country since I am not able to connect directly with it unfortunately. I can do it another way, but still, that modem setup just makes it hell to work with. The U-verse speed was nice, but the modem headache not so much since it's one of those things, so close, yet so far. I got the router to make my life easier, but if the modem doesn't let you through, your back to square one. Well at least I know the router seems to be okay. Everything else I wrote for my version still applies to the retail version. Both are running the same firmware. On the other hand I was able to log into mine just fine so I got a chance totest that, unfortunately my dsl line was so darn slow that the vpn was a slug but worked without a hitch. I'm sure that my old stuff also had much to do with that, but still, the router didn't skip a beat and that's what matters to me. I need stuff to just work.    Update January 24, 2015  There is was a new firmware update. They added the ability to change the client names which I really liked. Some clients have a bunch of numbers and giving these a name makes them easier to know what you're looking at. It's not critical, but it's a nice touch. So far the router is still working fine. I have also been using one usb drive in through the USB 3 port and I like that the drive is not always on. It sort of stays on a sleep mode until you need it which is really nice. So it's always there but won't actually turn on until you connect to it.  The only thing this router needs is its own anti virus to protect the network on top of what it already does. Now this would be a nice addition because then I would really not have to worry about each component connected to the network. Just in case I miss something of course.
output: I knew they made good stuff, so I thought I give them a ...

The MarBlue Vassen Kindle ereader case for the Paperwhite is a good fit. The four straps at the four corners hold the device in place and the case does not get in the way of the standard Amazon USB cable. The case looks good but it's not cutting edge style and design. There are no pockets for a stylus or business cards or anything else. On the outside there is a strap that can hold the case closed, which is a plus if you are putting the device in a bag or backpack with other devices that may come into contact with the screen.

When reading, with the cover folded under the device, the left side is slightly raised. This I find gives you a nice hold, with your thumb pressing against the hump. This may be even more useful with the basic Kindle since your thumb can be very close to the page turn buttons on the left side of the device.

In addition to the Paperwhite, this Marblue case is also a good fit for the basic Kindle (the one without a touchscreen and without a keyboard). It doesn't get in the way of the charging cable either. However, for the basic Kindle, I find that the official Amazon case (product code B004SD1XB0) is a much more organic fit if you like a slim easy to handhold setup that makes the case disappear.

The Marblue also fits the 6-inch Kobo Touch ereader, however, its power button is covered by the top right strap, so if you turn it on/off often, it may get irritating.

The Marblue also just barely fits the 6-inch Nook Simple Touch. Its power button however is on the back of the device, so you probably have to remove it from the case if you want to use the power button.

Since I was experimenting, I also tried the Marblue with the Kindle with Keyboard and the original Kindle Fire color screen tablet. They don't fit since both devices are bigger than the actual Marblue case.

Unboxing: it comes in frustration free packaging and friends of the environment will be thrilled that it does not include a foam padding. As with most cases these days, there is an initial smell, so now I air them all out for 2-3 days whether they need it or not. This one needs it but the smell is not as bad as some other cases. By air it out, I mean, I leave it open near a door or window that gets airflow, but I don't do anything special to it.
output: Good fit for Kindle Paperwhite and basic Kindle

Instances.input:
The only way this adapter *might* be useful is if you only own Netgear products, or you are in a sufficiently isolated or insulated environment that your network is the only one in scanning range. Every other device I have tested (4 brands of cell phone, 3 models of Kindle/Kindle fire, multiple laptops, and 3 other USB wireless receivers) can correctly detect and select my home wireless, and once set flawlessly reconnect if the device is rebooted, powered off, moved out of range, etc. Not this one. It consistently wants to connect to the incorrect network, and if you use the NETGEAR drivers and software to select the correct network will persist in connecting to the network it originally chose for you.

Once it decides to connect to the wrong network it can take 15 - 20 minutes and multiple cold boots to convince it to connect to the correct, secured, network. I've isolated the problem to the Netgear device through the simple expedient of swapping the Netgear adapter with the Belkin adapter from my wife's PC. Sure enough, my PC performed flawlessly with the Belkin adapter even without Belkin-specific drivers loaded, while hers could not find the correct network with the Netgear WNDA3100v2 with either the native Win7 drivers OR the latest drivers form Netgear.

Netgear tech support only knows how to tell you to use their "one-touch" setup button to correct connection problems, a solution which is only valid if every piece of equipment in the network is also Netgear.

Avoid this piece of garbage like the plague.
output: Horrible product with fatally flawed drivers

Instances.input:
This review is for the Fire HD 7 Kids Edition, 7" HD Display.

I really wanted to like this tablet but I just couldn't get over how cheap it felt in hand and how wide the bezels were. Compared to the refinement of other tablets that I own from Apple and Samsung, this just fell short for me. The software felt snappy enough, but the limited app store left the tablet feeling incomplete. The high level of parental controls available just wasn't enough to overcome these shortcomings for me.

If you have kids that have been exposed to iPads and Android tablets, this may feel like a step backwards for them. The simplified interface would be perfect for a first time user, but more advanced users (like my 4 year old) might be disappointed. Loading a book for the first time takes a little bit of time (30 secs to a minute), but opens quickly afterwards. Pages seemed to turn easily with a tap at the edge of the page - unlike the experience some seem to be having with the 6" version.

The two year "no questions" warranty,one year of access to Amazon FreeTime Unlimited and free case was what put me over the edge to pre-order this tablet before hands-on reviews were available, but the shortcomings of the Fire HD 7 Kids Edition just aren't balanced out by these benefits.

As much as I love Amazon for most things, this tablet is going back. Right now, there are better choices out there for the money.

This adapter works very well for the most part.  My only gripe (the reason I give it 4 stars) is that the DisplayPort connection isn't 100% secure...even though it has a \\"locking\\" feature to keep it in place, it is still possible to wiggle the connector in such a way that the connection is lost.  A common scenario is when I'm making a presentation from my laptop and for some reason I have to shift the position of the computer.  If I don't hold the connector in place while I do this, the force exerted by the HDMI cable will cause the connection to break.  This then causes the computer to think I have unplugged the display, which makes it revert to \\"internal display only\\" mode, which takes a few seconds.  Then I have to push the adapter back into place and wait until the computer figures out that I've plugged in an external display and adjust accordingly (which takes a few more seconds.)  Not a big deal, but it can definitely be annoying at times.
output: Works well, but doesn't always stay put

I got this skin for my 13\\" pro some months ago now and it still looks as new as the day I got it. If you like to skin your devices to personalise and protect them, then look no further and you also get great customer service to boot. Plenty of YouTube videos to show ease of install.

I got the 250GB Samsung EVO 840 for a client who wanted to upgrade their older computer's hard drive for better performance. Their old hard drive was a 250GB 7200 RPM WD Blue series drive which was over half empty. The older Dell Optiplex computer only has SATA II interfaces.

The Optiplex uses caddies for the 3.5 inch drives. I got a [[ASIN:B00G56ZNZU SABRENT 3.5 to 2.5-Inch drive bay adapter]] which is supposed to work well with screwless caddies. The Optiplex caddy had to be modified to remove a piece of plastic to work with the adapter's centered placement of the 2.5 inch drive. FYI.

Except for the above, installation was effortless. Closing the existing hard drive to the SSD using an [[ASIN:B000QY9KIS Apricorn USB to IDE/PATA/SATA Drive Adapter]] was very easy. When we could boot the system we installed the Samsung utility and upgraded the firmware. Easy and no problems.

The performance difference was stunning. The system booted in seconds and applications loaded almost as fast. The client was thrilled and felt it was like having a new computer at a fraction of the cost and hassle.

I found the utility for the drive very useful as it could give an assessment of the drive life and helped with some performance tuning so we could get the most out of the drive. Nicely done giving the impression of a professional tool rather than an engineering afterthought.

I'm giving the EVO 5 stars. It provides a great product in a great package with excellent supporting software. My only concern is one I have for all SSD drives and that is longevity. With Samsung utility addresses this issue well.

Hope this helps someone!

UPDATE: May 12, 2014

I recently purchased another EVO for installation in an older Dell laptop. It has only SATA II but got a great performance boost!

However, some settings of the Intel SATA interface (iastor - aka Intel Matrix Storage) do not play nice with the Samsung (or a number of other SSD drives). I checked for newer drivers and the Intel driver upgrade tool said I had the latest.

The symptoms are occasional hangs (maybe once or twice a day) for around a minute and log entries reporting:
The device, \Device\Ide\iaStor0, did not respond within the timeout period.

If you get these symptoms with your SSD and are comfortable with using the registry editor... WARNING: You can destroy your Windows installation editing the registry of your don't know what you are doing!!!

That said... This issue can be addressed as follows in Windows 7:

Go to the registry key:
HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\services\iaStor\Parameters\Port0
Your port number may be different. In my laptop's Samsung EVO was connected to Port0.

Next export the Port0 sub-hive (or whatever port number you are working with) to restore things in case of a mistake.

Inside there you'll find 3 DWORD keys: LPM, LPMDSTATE and DIPM. All three default to a value of 1. Change all 3 to a value of 0. Then restart your computer.

This worked for me and I hope this saves someone time if they run into this issue.amsung (or a number of other SSD drives). I checked for newer drivers and the Intel driver upgrade tool said I had the latest.

The symptoms are occasional hangs (maybe once or twice a day) for around a minute and log entries reporting:

If you get these symptoms with your SSD and are comfortable with using the registry editor... WARNING: You can destroy your Windows installation editing the registry of your don't know what you are doing!!!

That said... This issue can be addressed as follows in Windows 7:

Go to the registry key:
HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\services\iaStor\Parameters\Port0
Your port number may be different. In my laptop's Samsung EVO was connected to Port0.

Next export the Port0 sub-hive (or whatever port number you are working with) to restore things in case of a mistake.

Inside there you'll find 3 DWORD keys: LPM, LPMDSTATE and DIPM. All three default to a value of 1. Change all 3 to a value of 0. Then restart your computer.

This worked for me and I hope this saves someone time if they run into this issue.
output: VERY FAST, EASY install (UPDATED with iastor FREEZE/HANG FIX)

For 2.0 speakers I wasn't expecting much from these, but they sound pretty good. I recommend 2.1 (with a subwoofer) for avid music listeners and movie watchers, but these sound remarkably good for the price. The sound is crisp and clear. My only gripe is the bass is a little overpowering with music listening (the back of each speaker has a whole, a sort of bass port). Still the bass is much better than no bass at all. For movie watching people will appreciate the rich sound. Decent for mp3s, great for DVDs. I use this as a secondary set of speakers. I have a laptop and sometimes when I travel I don't want to listen to the built in 'tin can' sounding ones, that's when these come in handy. I also use them with my portable mp3 cd player, so they are versatile. Overall for what you pay, you're getting nice sounding speakers. As I said I would like a bass or tremble adjustment knob (that would make these a 5 star item) and perhaps they could be a little sleeker in size. They do not take up too much desk space because their bottom width is small enough, but they are a bit too tall. I can tolerate this though, because they are relatively stylish. Fairly impressed. Altec makes some really solid speakers and these are no acception (FYI: there is cloth covering over the front of the speakers). They feel like they are built to last, and I believe they have a one year warranty.

A definite recommendation for a 2.0 speaker set
especially for:
watching dvds and listening to music on a laptop and for using with discmen/ mp3 players.

After a disappointing experience with Logitech's Wave Pro wireless keyboard+mouse combo, the IOgear multimedia keyboard looked like the perfect solution.  For the most part, it was.  The form factor is great. It does not suffer from lag or dropouts, even from 15' away.  The trackball isn't great, as other reviewers have mentioned but it works and it's convenient for basic tasks.  (A separate mouse is highly recommended for any serious work.)  There are two fundamental flaws with this product:    1) If you press either of the integrated mouse buttons, the cursor begins to move erratically around the screen.  This makes drag & drop and any mouse+button action impossible and horribly frustrating.    2) The media keys are not programmable.  It's great for Windows media center, but nothing else.    I could have lived with the limitations of (2), but the button issues were enough to motivate me to return this.  I hope that IOgear fixes this in a future release, because it is otherwise a great product.

but they were a little bit off in execution. As has been noted in other reviews for this product, the included frame screws are VERY short. Also, you only get one chance to get any of them in right the first time, because they self strip if you manage to over tighten them even just the tiniest bit. Another reviewer stated that the rear screw can be replaced with longer ones as they do not obstruct or potentially damage any installed drives. The front ones however... go slow & carefully!

That aside, the design is good and being able to switch off the fan if using SSD's is a good option.

Now if only they would make one to fit 2x 5.25 bays and stand them on edge for those of us that like our RAIDS...
Untouchable machine!!!  Do not waist your money on anything but a Mac!!
