Instances.input:
I just got this bag about 3 hours ago, so please keep that in mind as you read this review.

First impression - it’s not nearly as ginormous as many were saying it is. I was nervous that this was going to be a behemoth, it’s really not.

Anyhow, now that the size thing is out of the way, it’s a nice, large rolling laptop/notebook case. I was disappointed that it did not have a water bottle carrier – I thought I had read that it did – it does not. The padding for the laptop area, I thought, was rather skimpy. For those of you that are wondering if there is padding on the inside of the bag where the telescopic handle retracts to, no there is not – disappointed in this one too.

I’ve had Targus rolling bags in the past and chose to purchase another Targus bag from experience; however this one seems lacking in quality as compared to the other bags I’ve owned.

My primary reason for buying this bag was size. Although I do not have a 17” notebook, for reasons I won’t bore you with, I do carry two 15.6” notebooks/laptops with their power cords and accessories (one of which I have an extra battery for), 3 textbooks, a 9.5” X 5.5” notebook, a TI-XX (large) calculator, several cables, 2 bottles of 5-hour energy, a PCMCIA memory card, some feminine products (sorry to the male readers who get skeeved), several pens and pencils, and a handful of other small techie gadgets – I have all of these items packed in the bag right now. While it’s close to tight, all that stuff fits nonetheless!

The zippers seem to be well made and the rest of the construction is that traditional duffel bag material. The wheels are a lot better than the Samsonite bag I’m coming from, which is actually the reason for my buying a new bag. The wheels on my old bag lost their bearings and stopped rolling. Interestingly, since I do carry two laptops, I cut out the padding from the old bag and put it in-between my two laptops in the new bag. So that’s yet another item in the bag!

As I said, the wheels are well made – they’re a bit larger, they sit in a little from the edge (which must help with the stability), and are very quiet. I guess I shall see how it holds up.

Would I buy this again? I think yes, but it’s really too early to tell. If you’re buying on size alone, as I did, I’d say yes. I’m just looking forward to not having to carry around 2 laptops :D

Lastly, the star rating - I would have liked the option to go 1/2 stars so that I could have rated it at 3-1/2 stars, but could not. The padding thing weighs heavily. For consumers who are buying this bag, that have already purchased a 17" laptop, they want to have it protected.
output: Full-time student and employee with a need for a large laptop rolling case.

Instances.input:
[[VIDEOID:54ffb4c17df4775a3ab84758aa744399]]Both headsets are similar in what they offer yet hold fundamental differences that hold true for all similar styles, IR versus 2.4GHz, AUX Only versus USB, and so on. Hopefully this may help you narrow down what it is exactly you are looking for in a wireless headset and determine which may be the best suited.

Video Contents:

Direct Comparative Look at the Similarities and Differences of the Able Planet True Fidelity Wireless Headphones and OAproda 2.4GHz Wireless Headset

Additional Individual Consideration of the Able Planet True Fidelity Wireless Headphones Construction and Qualities

Notes:

PC (and PS3) audio setup was super simple on my part - I plugged in the USB, my laptop did its immediate BLIP, and then I went into Control Panel > Sound and set the \\"2.4GHz Wireless Headset\\" as default. And done. The PS3 was pretty much the same thing. MIC on the other hand took a bit more tweaking on the PC (for the PS3, it was a simpler manner of just setting the MIC to the 3.5mm Input selection). MIC Quality is decent enough, but I would certainly \\"upgrade\\" the boom MIC with a nicer one, which is an advantage to the 3.5mm MIC plugins. Just go to your local Tech Store or even online, and you can find hundreds of cheap (and usually better) options. But the included one is, once again, decent enough. It is also a very flexible gooseneck style. Being AUX driven as opposed having an optical connection when considering consoles, some analog noise is to be expected, yet nothing that kills the performance both as Game Audio and Chat. Performed best, really, on my laptop once I finished tweaking the MIC settings.

Audio is good. It has plenty of BEWM BEWM bass while remaining crystal clear in the mids and highs. Comfort is \\"Okay\\". The padding is on the thin and firm side, and the headphones did squeeze a little on my head (I wear glasses, so I notice such things quite quickly). Extra kudos for providing two mini USB to USB cords along with two AUX cords and so on. They are all of average quality, but having two mini USB cords does allow you to keep the receiver plugged in, not having to swap out it to the headset when you need to recharge it.

Paring is immediate. The transmitter logo flashes blue, waiting to pair, and immediately upon turning on the headset, the transmitter went solid blue and was ready to rock-n-roll.

In the end, for those who may have experience trouble with optical cable connections with other wireless transmitters, this does offer a more reliable choice since AUX is AUX, and as simple and reliable as it can get for this style. Between the two headsets I compare, I do prefer this OAproda, mainly due to its 2.4GHz clarity and preferred audio performance, being deeper, richer.

Personally though, I think the comfort level, i.e. the padding, could be ratcheted up a notch and the included AUX cords a nicer quality (flat cable, gold plated) and the MIC, well, heh - it does work well enough, but it isn't all that special either.

-- I received this as a complimentary review product with the aim of hopefully elucidating features and drawbacks that may help you ultimately decide what fits your needs and budget best.cords along with two AUX cords and so on. output: Comparative Video of Two Wireless Headsets - Conceptually the Same, Yet Fundementally Different

Instances.input: I bought 2 of the 32 gb touchpads.  As an HP empoyee i got the 149.99 discount.  Would i have paid 400-500 for one? No way...that is not a knock against it, its just me not feeling pretty much any tech device is worth that much.  But for $149.99 its a great buy!  My daughter loves it.  I see reviews bagging on it, but hang in there touchpad uers.  Plenty of apps will be coming your way in the near future, and there is a group working on getting the android os to work on the touchpad enabling dual boot capabilities, and making all of those apps available.

this sleeve is not super thick so don't think you can drop this off a ladder while your painting your ceiling. But if your putting this in your backpack to walk down to the local Arby's for a good old beef'n cheddar, then this is the sleeve for you. It will give it nice protection against all the little nic'knak's you may have in your sack that you don't want rubbing up against your tablet.   also, this sleeve is tight, as in snug fit. So if you have a case on your tablet.. it may not fit. I have the \\"JustCase Clear Soft Skin\\" and it barely fits. so watch out. But for those peeps who just got a plain tablet with no case, you should be all good.   I have the HP touchpad and this fits it like a cozy little glove on a nice summer day after a long swim and a good nap.

I read a lot for grad school and was too damn lazy to hold my iPad. I mean, use my arms? Pshhhh. That's for amateurs. Now I can read while barely moving. Thank you LapGear pillow!

Oh, I'm using it with an iPad Mini. Yep, that's how lazy I am.
output: Too lazy to hold your iPad? This is for you!

Instances.input:
This has been working great with my Dell Studio laptop (which overheats like crazy). The two stands are sturdy and really stable. My only complaint is that they have to be put on/off every time you open/close the computer. If the shorter ends (that rest on top of the laptop) were flat, I think I would be able to close my laptop and have it in hibernate mode.

Two thumbs up.

I ran the battery all the way down, then charged and it performs well. The battery drain is slow and steady, and it has more than enough life for most of my sessions if on a full charge. Great product for the money.
Perfect for my laptop. Works great. Starts off kind of speedy but only for the first couple seconds. Shuts off on its own when not being used.

This case does not look expensive, but it is not expensive. What you get is a sturdy, plastic cover with some nice features.

Pros:
Fits snugly and securely
Flap turns cover into stand
Lightweight
Covers all of Kindle's parts well (even sides)
Access to buttons not obstructed

Cons:
Looks and feels pretty cheap
Cover does not always "stand" well

Bottom line: This is on my 9 year-old's Kindle. This is a good choice for her. It is bright (maybe too bright) and sturdy. The smooth pleather should clean up well I think. I am not sure I would personally buy this for me because of how cheap it looks, but if I could find a leather cover that fits the way it does, I would not hesitate. So...YMMV - if you do not mind the clearly not-leather look, this is a decent cover at a very reasonable cost.
output: Very Basic but well-fitting case for Kindle Fire

Instances.input: I bought this for the back protector, and it fits perfectly. What I wasn't expecting was the edges were not folding and staying there so I finally decided to put a hair dryer to it while holding the edges and it works. Buy Buy Buy!!!

I purchased this item because as it states in the description, its made of \\"squish soft rubber interior\\". So I was hoping for a comfortable pad to rest my wrists on, if this is what you want, this is not the pad for you. This pad is not in the slightest bit squishy, or soft. It is like resting your wrists on your desk, just a bit more elevated. Now this might be what some people want, and if you do, by all means get it. I have tried using it but after an hour or so my wrists hurt even more than without it. It gets so uncomfortable to the point where I cant type anymore and have to take a break. I have forced myself to try this and want it to be nice but I just cant make it comfortable.

Another concern is the build quality. I read several reviews before purchasing this, and didn't want to believe the few saying the nylon top peels off. But they were true in my case. I have only been using this since it was delivered January 9th, 2014, and already the bottom left corner is peeling up off the top.

Needless to say I am very unhappy with this product, I wish it was at least somewhat soft as stated in the description.
output: Not what I was expecting at all.

The stuff that comes up so you can go back to the home page etc. pops up every time I want to turn the page. It is also hard to type on it. I always end up going to a website I didn't want or some dumb thing like that.  I dislike it so much I just kept the Kindle app on my iPad and read from there. I love amazon but don't care for my Kindle.  It is now something that just sits around the house. I had originally bought it for my father but he didn't like it either and gave it back!

It took 36 minutes to burn 36GB movie and 55 minutes to burn 50GB full disk.

Instances.input:
Background: During the week of finals my old adaptor/power supply - a non Dell item which had worked fine up to this point - just quit and gave me an error message that adaptor was not a Dell 65 watt; battery not charging.
I found this product,a Prime item with the +benefit of 2 day arrival.
I plugged it in it seemed to work fine I could see the charge indicator moving incrementally up the scale then it stopped and I got same message as before. Ugh so at 8pm day before finals I have my daughter -also taking finals- frantically driving me around town. I ended up having to go to BestBuy with 7 minutes to closing and making a $60.00 purchase.
I don't blame this company rather I'm more aggravated with Dell specificity -just be careful if you are considering this purchase as it may not be work on your Dell Inspiron product - especially if you are facing pressing timelines necessitating a quick purchase.
Very nice change from the Kindle DX. Lighter and easier to see print. Nee a title time to get used to turning page so often!!!
I am happy with this product.  It reduced the glare on my Surface screen and I am more comfortable writing notes with the open with this protector on.
output: I am happy with this product

Instances.input: Perfect fit, light and yet seems strong. I use it everyday.

First of all, if you're wanting to buy one case/skin to protect your Kindle, this isn't it, you'll need to look elsewhere.  What the iPearl mCover does do is add color and grippy texture to your kindle.      The mCover slid onto my Kindle very easily, about 30 seconds worth of easy.  Given the grippy nature of the silicone it won't slide off on it's own.  Once on the Kindle, the keys, ports and screen are left exposed except for the page turning buttons on both sides.  While the page turning buttons are covered, the mCover provides small marks (arrows) which I've found are just as easy or easier to use by touch than by sight.  The silicone does not hinder the use of these buttons at all.  Since the silicone adds a nice texture which can make te Kindle easier to hold on to, especially if hands are very dry.  Once you become accustomed to it you won't want to be without.    Now for the downside and the reason for deducting a star.  The colors, while bright when seen on Amazon and even while in the package, are somewhat translucent.  On a white Kindle they would remain vibrant and show their true color.  On a grey Kindle, the darkness of the grey comes through and what was a bright color in the packaging turned into a muted and dull color on the device.  Since the mCover is a skin I'm really disappointed that the color no longer popped when on my grey Kindle.      Something else you may want to note is that the silicone picks up everything, dust, dirt, pet hair, etc. It's easy enough to brush off and the skin is washable as long as you remove your Kindle first (would I be liable for damages if I didn't say that???).  I was aware of the nature of silicone before ordering so didn't deduct anything for that.
output: Kinda nice for what it is.

It seems that tablet accessory companies assume everyone is riding the Apple bandwagon, therefore they only make accessories for the iPad and/or iPhone. Well for those of us who like our android devices, trying to find something like this requires trial and error and LOTS of research. To make a long review short, I love this pillow stand! I'm using it right now and it's the perfect angle for reading and for typing with my bluetooth keyboard. It's sturdy, the denim material is quite thick (it's like jeans for your tablet) and it's washable. I can use it with the tablet cover or without. The best part is the price. Levenger (whom I usually love) wanted nearly fifty dollars for a similar product. I think this is the better deal.

Added feature is the ATX adapted that comes with it so you could use it in ATX cases also.

This wireless card is amazing. If you have a desktop with extra PCI slots I highly recommend you get this instead of a USB card. According to ASUS' website, it has Windows 10 plug and play drivers. I still installed the Windows 8.1 driver and it works just fine. Something weird which may be on my end was that I had to put the wireless card in the longer PCI express slot instead of the one it is designed for. Maybe its my motherboard, but all in all this wireless card rocks!
It fitted perfectly

This has helped to assist with my daughter and keeping the kids on track with the options of profiles per family member more than the nook and the need for the children to complete reading before games.  this is one of the best out there for anyone needing parental control on internet access and protecting children from going to unapproved sites.
No wonder it was so cheap! Better pay more and not get so frustrated!

Instances.input: I bought this as a gift for my son who loves to read along with a paperwhite Kindle.  He loves it!
I chose this battery because of its power and warranty.  Easy to install and works great!

Plain and simple this is a handy little controller if you like to play basic games on the go.  I use it for Nintendo and Sega emulators.  It's small and compact so it's easy to fit in a notebook bag either freely when snapped shut or more flat when in the padded plastic case that comes with it.  The retractable USB cord is convenient and can be used with other peripherals as well (I use it with a PSP for transferring files to the memory card).  It feels a little cheap but it works well and has stood up to me playing with it on many different games.  No installation needed with Win7, just plug and play which is nice.  It has a directional joystick, four buttons on the right side and four \\"r\\"\\" buttons.  I haven't found a game where the \\"turbo\\" button works and can't configure the two middle buttons in Windows but the rest work well.  I would suggest this item for anyone who occasionally plays a game in their spare time and needs a small controller that doesn't take up much space.  Serious gamers will most likely look elsewhere.
Nice combo to get a physical keyboard for your tablet instead of using the on screen keyboard and a cover/case to protect your screen. keys close to the edges tend to stick though.
This case is great. I almost spent $40 on a case and I'm glad I tried this one out first.

This adapter works great. I've never had a problem with it. The only issue is that the cable is twisted on the inside so that the HDMI end is upside down when I plug it into my computer. It bothered me at first, but then I decided to stop caring because it's so cheap and looks exactly like the apple product.

Ordered two of these drives for a new Synology Diskstation - one drive showed up DOA. I went to the Seagate website for a warranty replacement and their warranty system was down for an update... for four days! Very unprofessional! Since it was a Saturday and their phone lines are only manned M-F I had to wait. On Monday the site was still down so I made the call. After taking all my information the rep tells me they use the same system (which is down) and I'll have to wait for a callback the following day before they could ship a replacement drive.

I honestly have no idea if these Seagate drives will be any good or not but right now while I wait for the callback I'm really wishing I would have stayed with the Western Digital drives I picked out first.

UPDATE #1 - 24 hours elapsed without a callback so I called them. The rep was apologetic but also struggling with the new updated software. Given the delays to date I asked for and received their \\"premium\\" delivery where it gets shipped via 2-day air and includes return postage. Sounded good until 3 more days elapsed with no shipment. I call again and they tell me that a reconditioned drive was not available so they're going to send me a new drive. I explained that I bought a new drive that was DOA so I'd expected a new drive all along. Truly wish I'd stayed away from Seagate...
output: 1 of 2 was DOA, Warranty Support is a problem

Instances.input:
I bought this stand for a fathers day gift and for the price it was well worth it. It works great, looks great and seems very well made.

Build Quality:
The base is a pretty decent weight so there won't be any worry if you switch from landscape to portrait views often. The part the attaches to your monitor has two twist-able pressure nobs on the top and another one towards the back of where the monitor sits that allow you to adjust the height and viewing degree (moving the monitor up towards you or down toward the floor.) of your monitor. The springs inside the stand are snappy and respond well to the weight of an older (and quite heavy) 24\\" monitor.

Look & Feel:
This stand is a simple matte back color on the backside going down underneath the base and the base itself is a matte silver/gray color and I feel it would blend nicely into any sort of office setup someone might have. The colors do not jump out and the look and design of this stand work very well together. Nothing fancy or over the top which is exactly what I wanted.

Overall:
I feel if your looking to buy a vesa stand then this is the one to get. The price is very reasonable for the quality of the product and it does not feel cheaply made and I feel that my money was well spent. It works very well in portrait and landscape views and switching between the two is almost seamless and is very fluid and easy to do. I am very happy with this stand and I'm glad I went for this one.
output: Great vesa stand at an unbeatable price!

Instances.input:
Torn between 3 and 4 stars as I really like the All-In-One concept. Firstly a complaint about Amazon from a guy that LOVES Amazon. The first unit delivered came in damaged carton, with the ACER box put in a larger Amazon box with ONE piece of packing paper and the Acer box “sloshed around” the larger box. I didn't realize the screen was damaged until after everything was set-up. Amazon replaced it quickly and picked up the bad unit, but it was a pain. And surprisingly the replacement computer came packed exactly the same, but undamaged.

The computer itself; Wow, Windows 8 has a huge learning curve and I'm still learning. It may be lots better under the hood, but simple and intuitive like XP it's not. I find the hand swiping not useful or easier than a wireless mouse. Further I can't stand the finger swipes and prints on the screen. It maybe more useful on a laptop (I don't mind it on my iPad) but on PC style it's not easier to reach for the screen than use the close by mouse.

Had two dealings with Acer support, and I use the word support very loosely. Jump through hoops (question after question) and everyone I spoke with had English as their second, or maybe their third language. It's pretty clear every time you ask a question there is a delay while they look up the answer which is haltingly read to you and clearly the reader had no idea what they're saying. If you ask any follow-up question the response is always to take the computer to an authorized Acer dealer. They're really useless. So you could buy a unit from someone that offers no live support as it's exactly the same.

Here is my major complaint; I intended to step up the RAM but that is no easy task. Acer instructions wrongly state to remove the stand and some screws and “slide” off the back. It doesn't slide, it is held in place with many unseen plastic clips. Research will find YouTube and written instructions on how to pry the back off. Everyone I found warns it will void your warranty (understand) and the fact that you will break a number of retaining clips during your removal. Also, to attempt this it requires (because of a very small gap) a tool with the strength of a screwdriver, but no thicker than a credit card. I guess there is such a tool, but I don't have one. This should be a simple do at home upgrade and it isn't. Not wanting to risk having some duct tape holding the back on, I've put off this upgrade.
output: Like this unit, despite its drawbacks

Instances.input: This is a great router. It has a lot of the functionality of the larger enterprise class but kept clean and simple for a small business. This was used at a church and has work flawlessly.
output: Great for small business, church or school

Instances.input: I love this cover!!I got the pink one and like the uniqueness. I like how it slips down into the cover rather than snapping in or elastic corners.
This is a very nice card reader- reading media that others aren't able to do. This is actually my second one.

I bought this battery after the original manufacturer battery experienced a \\"permanent failure\\", causing the laptop to shut down as soon as it came unplugged. Since my Inspiron N5030 laptop wasn't super expensive, I decided to risk buying a lower-priced battery. Turns out this battery works great, and at a low price. It came with easy-to-follow instructions on how to maximize the battery life and troubleshooting advice. The battery itself lasts an average of three and a half hours on regular power settings - it lasts even longer on power-saver options. A great fix for a battery problem, and at a great price! Highly recommend!

I absolutely adore my kindle. I received it as a present from my parents, and I honestly couldn't be happier.   Here are some things I love:    1. Can anyone say free books? I have bought one, yes one, out of the 200+ books I have on my kindle. You have to scrounge and check frequently, but it is definitely worth it.  2. Battery life. Amazon lists the battery as lasting a month with regular use. Now, I can't say I know for sure if this is accurate, but I feel as if I hardly have to charge my kindle. I love not having to worry if the battery is low or remembering to plug it in every evening.  3. Amazon saves all your books to your account, even if you delete them from your kindle. I love this feature, I don't like my kindle being too cluttered, so this is a major help.  4. The ability to organize your books into collections. Again, organization is key.  5. Reading outside. I can't say that I agree there is 100% no glare, there is some, but its hardly something to complain about. My manager has a nook and hers was much much worse than my kindle, and really the kindle is minimum at best.  6. The easy ability to highlight, add notes or get word definitions. This is pretty self explanatory, but you move the cursor over the area you want to add the note (or highlight/find definition) while you're reading and it gives you the option.    Things I'm not so keen on:  1. The flash between pages, it just gets annoying after a while, especially if you're a quick reader like I am.  2. It's almost too lightweight. I like the feel of a book while I'm reading, but this was easily remedied by getting a case. It adds to the feel of a normal book while also keeping your kindle shipshape.  3. I wish you could choose the background for when your kindle goes into sleep mode. As it is there are 15 or so (I haven't really kept count) different images ranging from popular authors to the definition of the word kindle that switch each time the kindle goes to sleep. I don't care for all the images so its a small thing I wish I could customize.

This is almost a great device. I have found it has some wonderful features - reading at night is very good since the light helps and I don't need a separate reading light. I would like to be able to dim it more, but it goes only so far and that's it. Don't expect to use this on an international flight - the battery will not go that long. Probably about 4 hours then you'll have to recharge. This is one of the big drawbacks if you are using this Kindle for reading a lot of books. Battery life really needs improving. When I got my Fire, I expected to do a lot of reading and have the added advantage of internet connection, email, etc. The internet part is great; the reading is not. Just not enough battery life before having to recharge. It seems I'm constantly have to charge this thing. Also, Kindle books are WAY over priced. For an electronic book to cost what I would pay for a hardbound volume is a rip, especially considering the poor editing, missing pages, etc, I get with my ebooks. On the plus side, you can find some very good new authors who are writing good books that you can download for a low cost - .099 - $3.99. You just have to ignore the very poor editing. Amazon need to make another change immediately - STOP SHIPPING THE FIRE WITH THE WORDS \\"KINDLE FIRE\\" ALL OVER THE OUTSIDE! It is an invitation for theft!

I've been using it for a week by now. Overall: it's a great product! Fast, energy efficient. Not sure if the battery will last 8 weeks, but 2-4 weeks with wi-fi turned of for sure.
I'm loading books from a local machine after conversion. No problems with the encoding within the book text, but sometimes book titles are hieroglyphs in the book catalog. Not sure if this is a device issue.
I like that the page is getting refresh every 6 pages (not every page), but once when the device woke up after a sleep mode this setting got reset and the pages got refresh after every page turn. After I went to the Settings menu and turn on / turn off Refresh after every page setting, everything started working fine again.
Also, I cannot figure out how to run a browser in a landscape mode. If there was no such feature, It would be pity. Otherwise the browser is pretty fast.
Also, I'd like to see the "number of Kindle pages / Total number of pages" as a reading progress metric.
Despite this small issues, I'm very happy to use this device for now!

Wow. These things are stunning. I bought two ENH500s to create a building to building bridge. It's maybe 100 feet between buildings - not that far, but across a medium-sized street with lots of traffic and other networks and interference. I tried a different product from a different company first and it didn't work due to interference, so I wanted this more robust system even though it is in some ways overkill considering the modest distance.  Set up Set up was easy in the sense that there is almost no included documentation. You simply call support. They were US-based, helpful, knowledgeable, and friendly. They guided me through the set up of both of the units. I'm fairly network savvy, but unless you're an IT professional in that exact field you'll never figure out the set up alone. Just call support. Seriously. They're rad. In fact, I'd recommend calling them before you purchase to discuss the right solution for your needs. EnGenius support = A+.  It's worth noting that one of my units is outside as directed; the other is actually inside but pointed towards a window. I know there is supposed to be absolute line of site between the units, but I do have some things in between (window, canvas curtain) and it's fine. And that is with the power turned way down on account of the short distance the signal needs to travel.  Also note that this isn't a substitute for a modem or a router. You will still need a modem in your main building, and a router in both buildings if you want wifi. These little guys are just to make the link between the buildings.  Results YMMV, but I'm experiencing no loss of speed whatsoever from the main network. None. It's freaking amazing. All my printers and network resources work seamlessly.  Conclusion I would absolutely recommend this solution to anyone wanting to set up a building to building network. No reservations.

This display has met all of my needs perfectly. The stand was easy to set up and is fairly sturdy. Display came with all cables needed (including VGA and DVI) and includes a DVI to VGA adapter. It automatically detects any input quickly so that you don't have to press any buttons.

I bought this keyboard four months ago and I have enjoyed it for the most part.  This keyboard replaced a Microsoft Natural Keyboard that bit the dust after nine years. As to its features, its a curved keyboard which better follows the contour of your hands such that using the keyboard feels more natural and comfortable.  The extra buttons on top will work with your default [windows] media player and web browser, and then there is a calculator button (which works too).  I don't find them to be that useful myself, except the volume control buttons which do work with the overall system volume.  Play attention to the keyboard layout; not all layouts are the same and changing layouts always drives me crazy ... thus, my choice in this keyboard was not mistake.  The keyboard is quite low profile so it fits nicely under the keyboard tray.    So now for the cons, the keyboard may be curved but it is not truly ergonomic.  After four months of using the keyboard, my right wrist began to hurt quite a bit.  So much so, that my 12 lbs baby would almost bring me to tears if I supported her with that hand.  I program 8-12 hours a day, so I am a heavy user, I am right handed and do use a mouse often; with these things in mind, I know the keyboard alone cannot be the only factor leading to my wrist pain.  After learning about what is and isn't ergonomic, and therefore what is good and bad for my wrist, I learned that this keyboard had to be replaced or used much less frequently. I got an ergonomic MS Natural keyboard again and MS Natural mouse. After about two weeks, the pains have been greatly reduced.  I still like this keyboard but I cannot use it.  I would not recommend this for anyone with wrist pains such as tendinitis, carpal tunnel or other wrist repetitive activity issues.
output: Good Keyboard for a cheap price

There is a mixed report from someone using the pen (Echo 8GB) since over 2 years. As of this writing, there are three versions available: LiveScribe Echo (2GB), LiveScribe Wifi (various capacities) and LiveScribe 3 (various capacities).

First, about the pro factors: The LiveScribe Echo (8 GB) that I am using since a long time is probably the most helpful invention since the ballpoint pen. It accompanies me everywhere, and I take lots of recordings. It changes the way I take notes, concentrating on the areas or topics discussed, rather than bothering taking detail notes. I'm setting aside all privacy concerns and assume you're doing the right thing, i.e., asking your discussion partners for their consent to record the meeting.

Having said that, here are the negative ones: Quite apparently, LiveScribe is trying to shape the market to what it thinks it should look like, rather than what it actually looks like. Their later products offer less functionality, and while they make them look like upgrades, they in fact are substantial downgrades. Plus, they ignore customer reported weaknesses of the products.

Examples:

1) LiveScribe Wifi: This pen removes the ability to synchronize your content with your device directly, as you can with the Echo. In other words, while before you had an (admittedly, slow) USB connection and could work completely offline, with "cloud" an option you only needed if you wanted to put data / pen casts directly in their proprietary format on e.g. your IPad, you now are forced to go through Evernote.

Counter-arguments:

a) If I am happily recording a meeting where even everyone consented, chances are, they're less than happy with my pushing that content through the cloud.
b) If I'm in meetings, I've very typically not a Wifi connection, and if so, it may be weak.

So in summary, the Wifi pen by and large removes your control over your data. If your pen breaks forsome reason, like my 8GB did recently, your data is lost as you may not have had the option of going online with the pen.

And here's an added argument against it:

c) From all I see, the Wifi option consumes substantially more energy then the USB version of the pen, which is not surprising, of course: Using the USB option, as you plug your pen into the computer, you're charging it as well.

2) LiveScribe 3: While the Wifi "only" removes your control over your data to a large extent, the "3" version is even worse. And I don't even think about the blue light which you can cover or switch off, more substantially, if I do one thing very very regularly, it is recording phone conversations. Guess what, while you're not only bound to having your phone not run out of battery as you are recording a meeting, the moment you are actually having a phone conversation, you cannot record using live scribe 3. So this pen is just a massively overpriced handwriting scanner where you could use one of the much cheaper ones that use a special paperclip and ultrasound location; all it does in addition is to remote-control the recording app on your iphone/ipad.

3) Removal of higher capacity pens: At least in some European countries, it is factually impossible to order 8GB versions. I just ran into a situation where, for all it appears, the USB chip on my pen stopped working, and while I'm happy to having lost probably only one recording, I cannot order a replacement. I went on and purchased a 2 GB Echo, as it is the only one that I got (and I calculated my most intensive recording having been 290 hours for one A5 notebook, which means, I'll probably get away even with less memory as they say they can record 200 hours on 2 GB (after removal of the tutorial, the pen actually shows about 1500 MB).

4) The problem with the USB port chip (and also others, like a display blackout which others have observed) are reported often,and not fixed.

5) The Echo features an SDK which Livescribe has decided to withdraw without replacement, to the great annoyance of their community.

6) Despite many requests of people for Livescribe to provide assistance on how to come up with a Y-type of microphone connector that will record Phone conversations, they actively refuse to do so on the grounds of not supporting "Spy" usage of their pens. They should leave legal decisions on how to use their products to their customers rather. In fact, if they have that potential issue on their end, they should remove recording altogether, from their product (which they admittedly do, in a way, with their "3" version.)

So in summary, LiveScribe has an excellent product, which is called the Echo. If you can get it, get three. If you get those 8GB versions, even better. I'm getting some of them now, and just remove the battery so it doesn't suffer (easy to do, just remove the front cap, unscrew four screws, remove the battery connector towards the tip of the pen, which is just fixed with some scotch tape.

HTH,

M
output: Excellent product (Echo) but company completely ignores their market.

I recently finished my first computer build. Everything works fine, to my great relief. On August 1st I bought this drive because of favorable reviews here at Amazon.
I have no complaints against the drive, it seems first rate, but I do want to warn other consumers about the bundled Nero 9 software. It's monstrous.

To begin with, the installation on my machine (Windows 7 Home Premium 64-Bit), was a mess. The first thing it did was to try (aggressively!), to install the infamous ASK? toolbar. This practice is reprehensible. Google does it, Micosoft's Bing, and Yahoo, as well. There's a lot of money in search-engines and they're tactics are becoming borderline criminal.
I can almost forgive Google since their search-engine is genuinely great. The others are garbage, with ASK? the worst of the lot.
Despite specifically (Un-Checking) the ASK? install box, Nero forced it onto my machine anyway.

Next, I was informed that my new complimentary software would not allow movie viewing beyond a 30-day trial period...UNLESS...
I was willing to cough up another $54, or so, for an upgrade. This is bait-and-switch. If it's not illegal, it's certainly sleezy.
I decided to give it the benefit of the doubt and proceeded with the trial run. It then went to the Nero site and began...
...Are you ready?...a half-hour long, 180 Mb download of the software. (Then, what's on the installation disc?)

On top of all of this the program was unintuitive, confusing, and even has a butt-ugly interface. I couldn't remove it fast enough.
One favorable point, it un-installs very smoothly. Just two crashes, warning screens, and multiple automatic re-starts.
Thank God, I had the forsight to make a Restore Point for once. It saved my bacon.

What adds to my dismay, is that I bought an LG DVD-drive at Best Buy some five years ago. It also came with Nero software bundled. Specifically, Nero 7 Essentials and something called CyberLink DVD Suite and PowerDVD. Both have fairly ugly interfaces and PowerDVD is slightly buggy. Nevertheless, both have served me well. But, Nero 9 is garbage. I will have nothing to do with Nero after this. It's always sad when companies take a good product and then \\"fix it\\" until it's worthless, or poison the waters with upgrade traps. For me, Nero is dead. I may consider Roxio if I should need a future DVD package. I still think this drive is great, but have no illusions that you are getting full functioned free software
....your not.
I have returned to my old software bundle. Five years old, but it works and it came without a sucker punch.

A quick follow-up. I had just finished struggling with Nero 9 when I wrote my scathing review. After an hour or two to cool off, it occured to me that I might have been unfair to Nero. After all, other reviewers had good things to say about it. So, to be fair, maybe I did rush through the installation procedure and missed some things. It's possible. I stand by my original conviction that the software is ugly and unituitive, but perhaps others can give it a fairer shake. Just wanted to be a little more balanced.PowerDVD is slightly buggy. Nevertheless, both have served me well. But, Nero 9 is garbage. I will have nothing to do with Nero after this. It's always sad when companies take a good product and then \\"fix it\\" until it's worthless, or poison the waters with upgrade traps. For me, Nero is dead. I may consider Roxio if I should need a future DVD package. I still think this drive is great, but have no illusions that you are getting full functioned free software ....your not. I stand by my original conviction that the software is ugly and unituitive, but perhaps others can give it a fairer shake. Just wanted to be a little more balanced.

Update: I was sent a replacement. It has the same problem with sleep when the cover is folded back, perhaps to a lesser degree than the first one. Also the second one is difficult to fold the cover back. I like the design but I still can't give it more than 1 star! Hope they send me another and get the design perfected.

Updat2 2: I was sent a second replacement. It has the same problem. It also has a horrid odor. I emailed Smart Shop and was issued a refund and didn't have to return the defective ones. Thank goodness for no return postage fees. I appreciate the service from Smart Shop, but am disappointed with the Poetic quality.

Instances.input: Simply not recommended for gamers. We own 2 other Linksys wireless devices and are strong believers in their products. Our router (310N) and adapter (WUSB600N) work flawlessly.     The WGA600N gradually deteriorated to 1 bar out of 4 on the XBOX connectivity test. This happened over the course of a mere 5 1/2 months from the date of purchase in late May of 2009. Initially the gaming adapter was around 18ft. from the router without obstructions. Self diagnostic tests typically showed signal strength of 52-65%. We then relocated the adapter to within 10ft. of the access point and the signal was still poor. After 3 extended sessions with tech support the adapter showed no improvement. As of yesterday the adapter completely failed to connect, despite its function lights showing the contrary. Please note all of our other devices are functioning at peak levels. Our remedy is to replace the unit free of charge. Unfortunately, we have to pay the shipping bill to the return center.    Other problems exist with accessing the administration pages. At best, it was hit or miss with the program loading properly. I'm hoping this is a defective unit because I've never had as many issues with any wireless device. Otherwise, this adapter needs to be reengineered.    After countless hours of frustration we have purchased the proprietary XBOX wireless N adapter. Spend a little extra for your wireless gaming and bypass the headache. Plug and plays sounds awfully good at this point. The replacement WGA600N provided to us by Linksys will function as a backup or secondary choice for another gaming console. Might even use it for the Dish Network DVR. Do yourself a favor and buy the XBOX 360 specific adapter. Performance has to be better.    UPDATE:  The XBOX 360 Wireless N Adapter performs beyond expectations. The connectivity test on XBOX LIVE registers at 4 out of 4 bars. We also tested our wireless network map and it read at the 100% signal level. The physical distance between the routerand XBOX wireless adapter is about 18 feet with a wall separating the devices. Thus far we are enjoying lag free wireless gaming.

DO not buy this product if you have a DELL or running Windows 7. Will read CDs but does not burn them, tried multiple burning software programs all with the same problem. Worthless and after spending hours trying to fix it i will be returning it.

Bought these as a gift for my girlfriend since her computer speakers aren't that loud. We watch tons of shows online and these have been great. Have never needed to go to as loud as necessary despite sometimes watching things with low volume quality.

Compact size, superb image with autofocus, clear wide field of view. I am very happy with the video and sound quality. This WebCam replaces my HP 1.3M WebCam [[ASIN:B000O77T3K HP RD345AA 1.3 Megapixel Webcam for Notebooks]].     INSTALLATION: 3 Stars [Update process could have been smoother]  Out of the box, the package warns you in several places not to plug the camera in until you have installed the software. They even put a small cover on the USB plug with a message on the cable. Very effective. I turned off AntiVirus protection per the instructions and then installed the software. I enabled automatically check for updates. It said no updates were found. Then I plugged in the camera.  After full install, it said updates were available and gave me a link to the website where I was supposed to select my camera, operating system, file version, etc.... I closed that link and found the \\"Check for Updates\\" link within the software (Right click on the Logitech Camera icon in the System Tray).  That worked smoothly without intervention from me. It updated my software from version 11.1 to 11.5.      IMAGE: 5 Stars  The 2 MP camera produces very clear images that work great on Skype.  Motion is no longer blurry, and the autofocus works great. The specifications say the autofocus will not work closer than 10 cm, but I find that if you move in slowly, it will work as close as 4 or 5 cm.  This is great if you want to show something up close like an image from your digital camera or a label on a product.      SOUND: 5 Stars  The built in Microphone combined with the Logitech noise reduction software eliminated all the echos and howling that I expereienced with my previous camera.  I no longer have to yell to be heard. I can speak in a normal voice, or even from across the room, and my sound is crystal clear.  Flawless.    CLIP: 3 Stars  The clip for this device does not hold it securely.  The camera can easily be pulled left or right if the USB cable is tugged even slightly. The rubber feet on the clip seem robust, yet it seems to be delicately balanced on the edge of my monitor.  It doesn't fall off, but it is not a solid perch. The camera can be independently tilted up and down, but not left and right.  There is no option for clipping the camera to the side of the monitor.  The included stand works decently.  It is made of three pieces that fit together and then the camera clips to the top.  I placed the stand behind my laptop and it worked very well...peering over the top.  Unfortunately, you cannot adjust height of this stand.  I will probably not bring this on future trips.    SPECIAL FEATURES: 2 Stars  There is a thin button across the top of the camera that allows you to take still photos. I found the camera button was too easy to press while trying to adjust the camera.  And since the camera does not clip securely, trying to press this button almost requires two hands...one to steady the camera and the other to push the button. The included software allows Avatars to imitate your facial expressions in place of your real image.  You can also add special effects like hats, arrows through your head, or goatee and mustache. When it works, this is a really neat feature that my kids loved! But, even though it was neat, something in that feature conflicted with my Symantec Antivirus. As soon as I turned antivirus back on, turning on these neat video features forced my machine into an immediate shutdown! I got a BSOD followed by a hard shutdown that I haven't seen since Win95! My machine hung in a state of limbo.  The power button wouldn't turn it off (software driven) but the machine as powered up with a blank screen.  I had to pull the plug and remove the battery to complete the shutdown.  Each time I turned that feature on while using Antivirus, my computer gave me the BSOD and performed an immediate and hard shutdown.  Needless to say, I no longer use these special features.    AUTO FACE TRACKER: ?  This is a neat feature, but I do not find it useful.  It really does a great job of following my face, but at what price?  It seems like the other person would get seasick watching the background bob and weave as the software followed my head around.  I think I am used to seeing the background stay put, while the person moves around in the frame.  Anything else is disconcerting.  Since I don't care for this feature, I did not rate it.  You may find it entertaining.    ACCESORIES: 5 Stars  The included soft-sided pouch, along with the velcro strap for wrapping the USB cord are nice touches as I plan to use this for travel.  Why don't more manufacturers offer these nice touches?     OVERALL REVIEW: 4 Stars  The video and sound are superb, and that is what really counts. But it seems that logitech could take one more step forward and improve the software to eliminate glitches with anti-virus, improve the software update process, and design a more robust clip. With a few minor changes this would easily be a 5-star item.      RECOMMENDATION:  After trying several different brands and models, this one had the best price/performance.  Cheaper ones left me wishing I had better video. More expensive ones had me wondering why they cost so much when this one offers everything I need. I would recommend purchasing this item.

It docks perfectly with my keyboard dock and the great thing is I don't have to take it out of the case to dock it. There is also a cover that you can protect the screen with when you are not using it, which also converts to a stand for you to sit the iPad on if you don't want to hold it or lay it flat. Instances.input:
I just own Toshiba table pc R10-P2301 since the end of november 2005. Because amazon don't have the exam product so i choose this product to be review because i found some configuration are similar but just differnce on its capaciy.

I own R10-P2301 which consist of 40Gb hard disk drive, 256 RAM but the seller increase to 512MB because of in the promotional stage and 1.6 centrino mobile technology.

I found this laptop is an excellence tool which offer a greate feature that really reliable for me to do my business:

1. The keyboard is very soft and easy to press and type.
2. There is build in microphone and speaker which is easy for me to chat with the other friend online.
3. The mouse pad is very smooth and the mouse movement is easy to control with my finger.
4. The pen that use for writting, erase, touch, click, db click is really comfortable like i write my own pen on the paper. The screen is really smooth and recognize a lot of difficult character that i have written. Sometime i suruprise because some text i difficult to be recognize but this tablet could convert it into a digital text is very easy.
5. The dimension is done in a good design for people to handle it for use on the way.
6. The battery life is 4 hours but as I remember during the time that i use the logest battery life is 3h 30mn. But it is OK for me because i always plug the power cord to charget the battery when the system has no more power.

OK, the below thing is the negative point that i think that toshiba would change it for the next release device:

1. In the software manual it indicate that there is a reserve pen in the machine near the battery. But in fact when i check for the reserve pen it is not include with this tablet pc. I also check the computer shop and they told me that the reserve pen is not included bye default. I don't understand about this issue too.
2. There is only one Ctrl key atthe left side, when i need to type any text that require to use the right Ctrl, i found it is very difficult to use it. On the other hand, the windows key is not locate at the under left hand. It is locate at the upper right of the keyboard.
3. There is less port for other device to be connect. There is no PS/2 port, LPT1 port. The port is develope in part of R10-P2301. There is no internal floopy drive, it include in the necessary option.
4. The wirless network is disconnect in every 10Mn. Until now i still do not know which that this problem came from the quality of wireless router or quality of my built in wirless network card.

That is why i choose this 4 star this laptop.

A good 2 in 1 Tablet / Netbook for under $500, however, the ad in Amazon's page should be more specific regarding the type of HD that the keyboard can lodge...as it says (literally):"Smart HD Bay in Dock allows for Self-Upgradable Standard 2.5-inch Hard Drive (up to 1TB)"
but it so happens that it can only fit a super slim (7mm) HD 2.5", NOT a STANDARD 9.5mm 2.5" using the aluminum enclosure that the keyboard has inside. The 9.5mm is too thick to fit with the enclosure, so if you buy an additional HD up to 1 TB capacity, you should make sure it's a super slim one, because if not - you will have to accommodate it w/o the enclosure, as it won't fit...besides, if you buy a 1TB capacity HD, than know you'll have to update the Bios of the T200TA, as according to factory settings, it's not made to "recognize" the 1TB capacity, only up to 500GB, and its Bios must be updated. For some reason these facts I just mentioned aren't included in the specs exhibited in the selling Ad of the Asus T200TA ??? It could spare time, money, and hassle to a potential buyer...! and don't really mean extra-work for those who create the Ads...just a bit more of attention...
output: A good 2 in 1 Tablet / Netbook for under $500

Instances.input: ive been using The live gamer hd for months now and i had purchased it while it was the most unique on the market,at $220 it was not worth it. it does do somethings right like recording mic audio straight to the video, which is my favorite feature, but it was completely worthless at doing the tasks that Avermedia avertised it would be able to do like being fully compatable with Xsplit. while using avermedias own software to stream to twitch it was very acceptable in quality for beginners and also not much strain on my computers CPU but trying to UP the quality on Xsplit it just sends my computer into a Tantrum and on occasion Shuts my computer down from too much strain on my CPU after the 1.1 xsplit update i thought it would fix those glitches but idont know because i have completly given up on Xsplit but it did give the option to use the Live gamer HD as an encoder to reduce strain on the your CPU but you need to buy another capture card to use this feature(i capture Console). With all due respect that is why i purchased this card not so you can bend me over and screw me into buying another card so i could do the things that you said i would be able to do from the very beginning and with all the new capture cards popping up on the market that can do the same and if not more than this capture card can do at a far cheaper price it is in the words of President obama, \\"its Imperative\\" that you drop the price at least $40-$50 to compete with the others because this product seemed unready for the Hyped claims behind it as if it were massed produced before it was properly fully tested?...Please take these words with my deepest condolences.

This keyboard sucks.    My big complaint is that the action of the keys is terrible.  If you press a key a bit off center or not perfectly straight down, then the key sticks and won't go down.  If you type fast like I do, you will type a couple of characters past the key that stuck before you can stop, then you have to delete those characters and start again.  It is terribly frustrating.  I find this design flaw absolutely inexcusable from someone like Logitech who has been making keyboards for decades.  Especially for a keyboard that costs this much.  I have typed on many keyboards in my life, and this is the worst.  If you are a hunt-and-peck typist, then maybe this keyboard could work for you; if you can actually type well, then you WILL be disappointed!      My second complaint about the keyboard is that it has no NumLock key.  I know most people don't use the number pad to arrow through documents, but I do.  When I was a software engineer, I learned that it was the fastest way to put my cursor where I wanted it to be in my code; the End, Home, Page up, Page Down, Delete, Enter, and arrow keys are all right there in intuitive locations, and you don't need to look at the keyboard to use them.  Definitely speeds up document editing.  But my biggest problem with the lack of the NumLock key is WHY?  WHY remove it?  Does it confuse other users to have it?  Did it make the keyboard somehow easier to use or cheaper to make?  NO!  So WHY would they piss of the few people who use the numpad for the arrows?  It's admittedly maybe .5% of their consumer base, but it's not zero!  DUH!  You can remap keys within windows via registry settings, which I did, but what a pain!    As for the mouse, it is pretty goofey, and I had to set up one of the buttons to be \\"middle click\\" (it doesn't have a middle button by default and the scroll wheel does not click), but it works acceptably well and I have no real complaints.    Range and battery life are both excellent.    Okay, so to sumup, this keyboard sucks.
output: Keyboard is terrible; keys stick, no NumLock

The shape is not conducive to normal sized notebooks, binders, textbooks, folders, etc. It doesn't open wide enough to easily pull anything out. I have to be careful of what I put in there because if it's too heavy (such as a calculator, chapstick, or lotion), it folds the front flap in half when the main zipper is open. While the backpack holds a lot (even my 17 inch laptop), it is an inefficient design, and I would not recommend it. The weight of the handle on top is really what irritates me the most.

We have used the Amped wireless repeater for about three years now so that we can watch movies on the Roku, which was far removed from our router. We have never had any issues with the repeater until about two weeks ago when we had a power blip and lost the connection to the repeater. This was a major crisis in our house, and I was unable to reconnect the repeater for a variety of reasons, including a new router.

I called Amped customer support at 8:30 p.m. East Coast time and Sam helped me update my firmware and reconnect my repeater. Sam was patient, gave excellent instructions, and did not hang up until he was certain that I could connect to the Roku.

I would highly recommend this repeater and Amped. Their customer service is fantastic.
output: Amped Wireless Repeater is the Bomb, and so is their Customer Support

You can't print any content downloaded on your kindle fire kindle pc software or kindle iphone app. Customer service is of no help at all.   I'm sorry, Kindle content cannot be printed.  However, bookmarks, highlights, notes, and clippings you make within a Kindle book are stored in your Kindle library on Amazon.com and can be viewed at http://kindle.amazon.com.   These items also are stored in the \\"My Clippings\\" TXT file on your Kindle. You can transfer and/or copy the file to your computer using the USB connection so you can share and use your clippings. You can also print this file if you wish to have a physical copy of your annotations. You'll find the \\"My Clippings.txt\\" file in the documents folder on your Kindle.  If you wish, you can make changes to the file using your computer and transfer it back to your Kindle. Changing your \\"My Clippings\\" file does not affect any notes, bookmarks, or highlights you've made in the actual content -- you'll still have them for navigation and reference.  If you delete the file from your Kindle, Kindle automatically adds a new \\"My Clippings\\" file the next time you add a clipping or annotation to any content.  I'm sorry for the inconvenience caused. I hope this helps.   Thanks for using Kindle.  Thank you for your recent inquiry. Did I solve your problem?  I'm still looking for \\" My Clippings\\"

I have purchased several of these wireless routers (MWN-WAPR150N), both new and refurbished.

This product requires a wet install, i.e. you need to spray the shield before you install it and squeegee out the excess. This had me worried at first, but now I'm a believer.

I've only used dry-install shields in the past, and there's a reason why you get 3 in a pack: you will screw up trying to align properly and inevitably get fingerprints or dust beneath the shield, then in frustration rip it off and start with a new one. This Skinomi shield makes install easier: because you spray down the shield, you can actually move it around once it's on the iPad and place it perfectly around the cut outs.

I've only installed the front at the moment, and it looks perfect. The trick is to carefully squeegee after installation, trying to get the bigger bubbles out and letting it dry for a few minutes. At that point you will see bubbles you might have missed, so I carefully squeegeed those bubbles out (it helps if you rewet the surface of the shield so that the little plastic squeegee glides easier). That got rid of most bubbles. You will see streaks, those do not squeegee out, it takes an overnighter for them to evaporate out.

So my shield not looks really nice. So why one star off? The top is a little more rubbery than I am used to, so sometimes my nail digs in a bit, but that's a minor complaint. As well, the black cleaning cloth they give you actually can shed a little bit, and on a white iPad it did peace a black speck or two under the shield right against the white border, making it very visible. You then have to rewet your fingers, lift up the shield, and try to scrape that off the shield. Luckily, wetting your fingers mean that no fingerprints will deposit, so it worked out. But if you have a white iPad, find a white microfiber cloth to clean the screen before install. Or be more careful in ensuring that no black specks are present.

Instances.input: I bought a new machine (Dell 9100, core i7-960, 9GB SDRAM, Win7HP, 64-bit) and needed another internal SATA port and another eSATA port.  After looking at a couple of choices, I settled on this card.  (Another review I had read said it worked with Windows 7, as does StarTech's site.)    Installation was painless, if a bit difficult to decipher due to less than perfect documentation translation.  The card worked perfectly with the internal SATA port.  Problem arose when you attached an eSATA disk.  When you shut down (or restarted) Win7, it would sync the file systems, park the disks, but wouldn't go the last step and actually power off.  You had to hold the power button to power off.  I tried the drivers that came with the card and the one's on StarTech's website, both failed the same way.    So, it was off to JMicron's web site and downloaded the latest drivers for the JMB36X controller this card uses.  (YMMV, it works for me.  Version 1.17.57.1 as of when I've written this.)    Works as advertised now.  Transfer rates (though I haven't benched it yet) looks okay, shutdown and restart works, eSATA port reports as ejectable.  The new drivers even mark the disks correctly in the device manager.  (miniport scsi...)    I've let StarTech know, I'll update this if they actually get back to me.    I'd give this 5 stars for a cheap internal/external sata card, one star off for not coming with a working driver. :-)

I have a mac mini that I use to download movies and stream soccer matches to my TV at the opposite end of the house from my wireless router.  Streaming was at best spotty and I could never get a whole match or download without having to reset the connection at some point.  But I knew that my WIFI signal was not great.  So I contemplated either getting a wireless bridge or buying a powerline network kit.  The rule of thumb being to reduce complexity of your home WIFI network, I decided to go with the Zinwell powerline adapter.  I am glad I did, it literally took 5 minutes to setup and I get 3X the speed of my wireless network!  But more importantly, the network is MUCH more stable than it was with WIFI.  I have streamed hours of video flawlessly to my TV since I installed it.  Worth noting:  1) The mac mini is on a different circuit than the router.  2) I can consistently get 10mb/s across the powerline network.  3)It's plug and play.  Easy as pie.  I doubt any wireless bridges can claim this.  While in theory a faster connection would be great, 10mb/s is as fast as my comcast connection gets anyway.  For the price, and the ease of use this product gets my recommendation.
output: Works as Promised.  Plug and play

I have a small computer, its an 11.6\\" Gateway. It's not a netbook, but its a very small laptop. I use it to DJ and I have tried all the standard DJ laptop stands and none of them work. They are either too wide for my machine or they are set up such that it slides off and is not held in place by the stand. This one actually worked!!! My computer fits perfectly on the table top frame created by the stand. Additionally, the slope of the stand is gentle enough that my computer doesn't fall off like it does with all the other ones. The best part of this stand is the FOLDING feature. It takes 2 seconds to set up and is completely sturdy. Unlike the Stanton stand it has no janky zip-tie holding everything together. It just unfolds and locks in to place. It is quite a genius design. I am not sure this thing would work for big, heavy laptops I would keep it 15\\" and under, but for a MacBook Pro 13\\" this thing would probably rock. My DJ controller fits fine underneath and everything has been great over 3 weeks of DJ gigs. Highly recommended!!! As an update, I now use this to hold my ipad when I am djaying using Traktor DJ. I keep my iPad in a case and put it on the stand and it works great for djaying! Double recommend!!!
output: The first one that works for me!

The Philips VOIP8411 phone is pretty good, I have been using Skype for over a year with no other backup TelCo, so I cannot say a thing about the \\"landline\\" features of this phone -I dont really care for them-    Setting the phone up was really easy. Signing in Skype was what took me the most time, because I had to figure out of to make CAPS/NUMS for the password. The rest was fine. The voice quality is as good as it gets. I had a DUALPhone for a year, and it was never as good as this one. I like being computer free, as I don't have to dedicate CPU cycles from one laptop or PC to the Skype line. In all, after over a month of use, I am happy with it.    Here are my two suggestions. The volume of the rings is pretty low at its highest setting. So if you happen to have a loud environment or a large house, you may miss calls cause you will not hear the phone if you are far from the set (unless you have multiple handsets). This is something Phillips should consider improving.    The other annoying thing is about the call waiting feature. The double beep or so when someone else is \\"calling\\" you, does not seem to go away when the awaiting party hangs. So, if you ignore the call from the other person while in an important conversation, you may expect to hear the nagging beep for the duration of the call. This is not a big deal for me, as I almost never get into this situation, and also, it may have a simple workaround.    I benefited from the forums where some other issues where addressed, such as making SkypeOut calls to a number out of your contact list, and making some config choices out of the defaults to make it more friendly for people who do not have a landline.
output: Nice VoIP phone, just a couple of improvements needed

Great case. Extremely well made and very adaptable.  Silverstone must have had Artists and Technicians designing this case.    I built this for my GF and now I want to keep it lol.  I will hold on to it and \\"test it\\" for a while.    Beautiful with tons of options. Just the right size. Not huge and not too small. Cable management is not easy but it's worth the time.  I spent a lot of time on cable management and it came out great. I routed wires between the fans and behind the fans.    I installed 5 Noctua 120mm case fans. In order to get the 3rd fan in the front I had to remove a drive cage. But Silverstone anticipated this and used screws to secure that drive cage rather than rivets. Kudos Silverstone!    There's enough space behind the front cover to store a couple spare SSDs and flash drives.  I installed a couple thumb screws to secure the cover. They call the regular screws \\"added security\\". That's funny :-).    A couple very minor Cons:  The left edge of my front cover is sharp and scratched me when I brushed my hand against it. The right side is smooth. No blood, I'm fine, thank you for your concern.    I don't much care for the fact that there are no screw holes on the left side of the 5 1/4\\" exposed drive bays. I drilled a hole on that side to add a screw to my hot-swap 3.5\\" drive tray. I felt it necessary because I will be pushing the door closed every time I install a 3.5\\" drive.
output: Stylish and Versatile - Excellect Case! Tons of attention to detail

I bought this USB 3.0 memory card reader in hope that I would be able to use the new SDXC formatted memory cards. I was dead wrong. Upon inserting a 64 GB SDXC memory card in the USB 3.0 card reader and putting the SDXC card/this USB 3.0 card reader combination into a USB port on my Windows XP SP3 computer, my computer did not recognize this USB 3.0 card reader. My Windows XP SP3 computer is formatted for USB 2.0 ports, so that might be part of the problem. To fix the problem, Microsoft has a driver on its website to make all Windows XP computers compatible with the SDXC formatted memory cards, which I downloaded and installed. I was able to use my older Dynex memory card reader just fine after installing the SDXC driver located here: [...]  Maybe this card reader will work on an Apple Mac Book Pro that I plan to purchase next summer. Until then, it's useless.
output: Unusable on Windows XP SP3 computer

I am writing this review because of the malfunction with my laptop and how HP is handling it. This computer has a problem with the space bar. I normally type 80 words per minute without any errors. With the spacebar issue I am typing less than 30. The space bar doesn't work every time it is pressed so your words get meshed together. For example if I was saying Amazon is a great place to shop, typing it normal comes out, Amazon isa greatplace to shop.
HP is telling me that it is going to take 2 weeks to fix the computer. I need my computer for school so not having it for two weeks is going to make school very difficult.

So I wouldn't suggest getting this computer because once you buy it you'll have to send it back in for them to replace the keyboard and be without it for two weeks and have them telling you tough luck for the inconvenience. Paying $800 and having this be a huge hassle is ridiculous. I suggest go buying a different brand. A company like this should make more of an effort to make their customers happy. I will not buy an HP again.
output: Malfunctioning keyboard and horrible service from HP

The Kindle 2 has various strengths and weaknesses as follows:    Strengths:   1. Overall size and weight is excellent.   2. Download speed is fast  3. Book selection is adequate.  4. It visually looks OK    Weaknesses:  1. The largest weakness is that the screen is not backlit. Reading is difficult in poor light and an accessory is needed to read in bed at night with the lights out. There should be an optional backlight button that will burn battery life but give you that extra 20 minutes you need without having to buy a cover, clip-on light and batteries.   2. Navigation is not terrific. This is clearly no Apple design. You have a toggle switch, forward and backward buttons; and a keypad. Not to mention a power-slide switch, etc...  3. You cannot clip newspaper coupons, some delivery days are absent from our newspapers and for some newspapers, some graphics are emitted.  4. The newspaper and magazine selection is still pretty limited.  5. You cannot print.  6. Unless I am mistaken, you cannot easily skim through a book or newspaper. There is no fast forward or 'skip-a-chapter' feature.  7. There are some slow functions such as waking from sleep.  8. It is not very ergonomic. Just grab it to carry it without a cover and you may accidentally press a button.  9. The main screen where you see your list of purchased items does not convey the full names of items with long titles. One shouldn't have to shrink the text.  10. I can skim through a physical newspaper faster than the newspaper version of the kindle.  11. Almost no skins.   12. A little overpriced.    Summary:  The Kindle 2 is excellent for waiting in lines, traveling, and getting the morning paper. It will even save money on books and newspaper subscriptions (minus the coupon issue). For those of us old enough to have a lifetime of joy reading real books and newspapers, it is absolutely no substitute for holding a hardcover of a great novel but where doing so is difficult or inappropriate, it is an excellent device to have.

It annoyed me but I still loved it, until this morning (my third day with it) I was editing notes and found that the rubber was ripped! With barely any use! Now maybe I just received a defective unit, but I am still very disappointed with this, especially after the initial usefulness and potential that this stylus showed.

I'll be honest, I bought this motherboard because my minimum wage job doesn't pay very much and a friend gave me his i7-920 in a computer with a defective motherboard.

After seeing the bad reviews I was worried but bought it anyway, and to be honest I'm quite satisfied.

I filled it up with cheap ram, 4 2GB sticks, 3 of which are kingston, 1 is some hynix blue ram, and 2 1GB sticks, and they run at 1066mhz.

It runs pretty stable regardless of what I do to the CPU but I have to underclock the ram to not go over ~1081mhz otherwise it doesn't post, but that's due to cheap ram(I'm planning on getting some 1600mhz for higher headroom in blck overclocking), and it doesn't really survive more than 1 run of LinX, but can prime95 for 12 hours so it has to be the ram.

Some issues I noticed with the board is that it does seem to start itself if it's been unplugged incorrectly while running, but that's not an issue cause it doesn't happen when I use the OS shutdown or hold the power button for a hard shutdown.

I've overclocked my i7-920 to 3.6GHz with no issues other than what I said above and actually played a few games without problems.

My computer before using this board was an i7-2600@3.9GHz with 16GB DDR3@1600MHz that I had been using as a temp computer till I saved up enough for a new system, but decided to stick it out with an older computer and maybe some newer components, such as this motherboard.

Well not ever but at this point I have not had one single issue with this card. I mainly use it for broadcasting on websites such as Justintv. I find it really userfriendly that I can choose the card from a drop down list to broadcast through Adobe Flash Media Encoder or Xsplit. I know on many other cards out there you have to use a third party program like VHscreencap or something like that and then choose the area of the video and then use the vhscreen from the drop down box. That uses so much resources if you have a regular pc.     I have this hooked up to my PS3. After you get everything plugged in and the HDMI from the tv to the slot NEXT to the fat input on the card where all the cables come out of. You want to hold the touch sensitive powerbutton until you hear it beep once. Once you hear the beep let go. Now go into control panel, view by (small icons) then click on blackmagic design control panel. You should be on the settings tab. Output should be at default (HDMI & Component) and then set input as (Component Video & Analog RCA Audio) Click Apply then Ok. Now under all programs open up Blackmagic Media Express. Click the View tab and select Compact. This will make the window easier to play with. Now click the edit tab. The first drop down will have a list of formats to choose from. Since you reset your ps3 earlier to default video settings by holding the power button. You want to select NTSC (should be the first one on top) Capture File Format set to AVI Motion JPEG if you have a single hard drive. Then Check the Continue playback when in the background box. Then hit ok. Now that you're back at the media express window, select the CAPTURE tab or MASTER to show something on the screen. Your TV should also be showing what you see in the media express window. That's all.    Screenshots seem to be a .TGA file and I have no idea how to set it to png,jpeg or anything else unless I open it in photoshop then save as one of the other formats. I hope you found thishelpful. Just comment and I will be more then willing to help you out.    PC Specs-  CPU- AMD Phenom II X4 955 3.2ghz  Hard Drive- 320 WD hard drive. Two was not enough for uncompressed since they're older and slower drives.  4GB of DDR2 800mhz ram is plenty.

After my local library started offering e-books I decided it was time for an e-reader.  Knowing that I did not want a Kindle ( Was not a supported devise at my Library) I started my search.   I was looking at both readers and tablets and was almost set on buying the Nook Color when I saw the T301 on Amazon.  After reading the specs, reviews both here and at Cnet and also the fact that the player was $177.00 ( and I had a $20.00 GF ) I must say that after an initial learning curve the first night I am very pleased with this very affordable tablet.  Is it an ipad?  No, of course not, but you get a lot of bang for your buck and as a small, fit in your bag, portable device you really can't go wrong.  As far as down loading apps, just by pass loading directly from Cruz market, and use your computer to go to the app site, and down load directly on to your dedicated SD card, then just open and download.  This this  is only 2.0 android, but as long as you don't try to download any app that needs higher, you should not have a problem.   The Cruz comes with a 4GB SD card, I have already purchased a 32GB as I can tell I will need it.  The nice thing is you can run multiple cards ( one for Video, one for books), and pop them in and out depending on what you want at the time if you exceed 32 GG ( or 4 GB) I down loaded some video and it plays great!!  I totally recommend this for anyone who wants a reader + tablet for under $200.00
