(Or "For the first time in my life, I am proud to"...own an LED monitor.  Paraphrasing a famous savage..) As a full-stack SQL/C#/JS developer, I have pretty demanding reqs.  I need to be able to have three instances of Visual Studio open simultaneously, as I am working on three different modules of an enterprise app.  Switching between screen tabs is a real pain, especially, because I also need to switch between documents in each tab as well.  Until now, I have been using two HP ZR24w (CCFL IPS).  Which are nice, other than the overly aggressive AG sticker.  But they didn't have the image pixel density nor the size I was looking for.  For the longest time, I have been hesitating to buy LED monitors because I hate the dingy dull blue tint that they all inherently enjoy.  Enter the P2715Q.  This monitor not only overrides the aforementioned attributes, but improves the image quality of the CCFL to an extent, I never thought possible.  Placed side by side with the HP, the HP looks like the LED :).  I bought a pair directly from Dell for around $500/ea. Great job Dell!! This has been the best $1000 I've spent in years..
output: I've hated LED monitors until now!

I was a bit skeptical buying this fan. I'd seen bad reviews for other fans & wasn't sure this one would do the trick.  I chose the dusty rose color & placed my order.  I used the fan for almost 2 hours earlier today with my laptop.  Usually, the left side of my laptop where the computer's fan is would get hot & I'd shut down after about 40-45 minutes of use to save my laptop.  With this cooling fan, my laptop didn't get so hot.  I was surprised to find I'd been on for almost 2 hours when I finally closed the laptop's screen.  The fan plugs in USB & ran so quietly that I didn't think it was on.  I had to touch the fan's covering to make sure it was working.  It was.  I love that this pad gives my laptop a few inches of height to use the keyboard more easily.  I also love that I can unplug it when I'm not using my laptop.  The plug tucks away under the bottom of the pad for easy storage.  This cooling pad is well worth your money.  Choose your favorite color, green, dusty rose or grey & place your order today.  Logitech's products are well worth their price.

This netbook is light, attractive, and has a usable keyboard. Initially, the battery life was great.

After a few months of gentle use, the hinges attaching the screen loosened up and tore apart. I contacted asus for an RMA, but didn't send the netbook in immediately, as I still used it sometimes with an external monitor.

A few weeks ago I sent it back and that's when the real nightmare began. Asus returned the netbook with repaired hinges and screen, but a completely broken keyboard. For over a week, I've been trying to get a replacement keyboard or an expedited repair, but asus doesn't care that the current problem is a direct result of their mishandling. Each time I call, the supervisor promises to \\"escalate,\\" and then never calls back or does anything. Tonight, the supervisor I spoke with said it would take 2 to 3 business days to figure out whether they could reduce the normal 7 business day repair time!

If you want a reliable netbook, don't risk this one. When it breaks, asus \\"customer support\\" will torture you into giving up.
output: Stopped working after a few months; no help from asus

Installed Ubuntu Gnome 15.04 (beta 2), and almost everything worked out of the box, including multi-touch. Wifi drivers don't work as of Linux 3.19, so you will need to buy a USB network adapter.  The built-in hard drive is terrible, but it is very easy to install your own SSD. Instructions are all available online. The keyboard is okay (a bit too small), but the mouse is terrible.  The matte IPS screen is free of glare and has excellent viewing angles, ideal for reading sheet music, ebooks, or PDF files. Also, it does not collect any fingerprints.  I compared multiple tablets side-by-side at Best Buy, and the Horizon 2s was the fastest and most responsive one on display. The closest competition was the 18.4" Dell XPS (SKU: 5942012), but the Dell had a tendency to stutter while scrolling through pages.  It is great for web browsing, reading, word processing, watching 1080p movies, and playing games (eg. Portal 2). However, it is probably too slow for, video editing, and other computationally intensive work.
output: Linux friendly -- best 19" tablet on the market

Instances.input: I am very disappointed with this item!    First of all, it did not convert digital cable channels eliminating the need for a top set box, as I was told it would over the phone by technical support before buying the card. It only converts digital to air channels!    Secondly, The package was too small for all of the stuff in the box, and the base of the digital to air antenna was broken right out of the box, so I couldn't even use it anyway! I got this as a Christmas gift and was excited about having a lot of networked storage at my disposal. I love dropbox but only have a small amount of space and didn't want to pay a monthly fee for storage.  Hooking up this drive was easy, it was plug and play to get it going on my router.  Setting up remote access was difficult as there were some router settings that weren't configured correctly and I had to manually change numerous settings on my dsl modem and wireless router. Using the drive is pretty straightforward, it pops up as a drive under the \\"network\\" on my windows PC.  One big gripe I had about the cloudbox is their misleading advertising on their website. It claims on the page that sharing files with others is easy through secure download links. This is a feature of dropbox that I used a lot and was excited to have that option with my entire library on my networked drive.  There is no documentation in the manual about how to do this, and after speaking with lacie, they told me it was not possible to do with the cloudbox.  I pointed out that it's listed as a feature of the cloudbox on their site, they apologized and said they would have their marketing dept look into it, but as of this review it's still listed as a feature.  The remote access app on my iphone does connect to the cloudbox, but even over lte it is painfully slow.  Bottom line is that it does offer a lot of networked storage that I can share with my family, but the features are limited and the iphone app looks and performs half-baked.  If the software for the lacie cloudbox had it functioning the same way that dropbox works, I wouldn't hesitate to give it 5 stars.
output: Okay, but glaring flaws need to be addressed

This will protect your screen from scratches and the horrible glare that accompanies the M11X. It depends on how much you want to keep that screen protected vs seeing the full crispness of the small screen you have. If you are like me these things don't last long on your phone, tablet, or computer. I hate having something on any of my screens that doesn't let me see how sharp and wonderful the images are. Despite that, this DOES stop glare for the most part, and will keep fingerprints and other scratches off your screen. If you use your lappie a lot like me, and carry it all over the place then you will probably notice that you can start to see the outline of your keys on the screen when you clean it, this will prevent that from occurring too. The only issue I really had with this, besides the image itself, was after about a month of use one of the corners got some dust under it, and did the obligatory lift. Of course that is through constant use, in and out of my backpack and carrying it wherever i went. Other than that I would recommend this to save your screen and reduce the glare.

New Ultra books have opened a new market for a whole slew of 'docking station', never mind that these new stations actually do not 'dock' your laptop. Rather they are combinations of USB hubs and various audio and video bridges.

This docking station is one of the above categories. USB 3.0 gives that additional mojo that you always wanted, even though you really did not know what for - the speed increase for regular or even professional operation is not really noticeable.

The plus point of this docking station over others beyond slick design and the boxy look is that Windows 7 support its drivers natively. So no problem at all installing it. The unit worked satisfactorily right out of the box with a Dell Ultra book.

One of the annoying missing features of this docking station is that it somehow does not work with USB wake signal. So if your laptop goes into sleep mode and then you bring it back, the station does not come out of sleep with a reboot of the laptop - even power cycling the unit does not help. This may be a Windows 7 problem or USB 3.0 driver problem or the docking station problem. Actually that part does not matter.

It came with a screen/lens cleaning cloth and a little thingy that has a brush on one end and a squeeze bulb on the other for blowing dust off camera lenses, plus a USB cable. The shortness of the little cord that's attached for plugging into my device is a \\"plus\\" in my case, since I do most all my Nook movie watching at the kitchen table while I'm eating. No long cord to have to keep out of the way. It was also delivered quicker than the \\"estimated delivery date\\". I highly recommend both the speaker and the seller. Nice!

Instances.input: I've had a half-dozen Gyration mice & keyboards over the years, needed a new set for HTPC, so I ordered this pair.    They keyboard shipping with it now is NOT the one shown/described here, though the combo part# remains the same.    Still a compact keyboard, but chicklet-style keys, and NO MEDIA KEYS.  That's right, bought for HTPC use and there are NO volume buttons etc across the top anymore.  Like a laptop, you can hold down an 'Fn' key and turn the F-keys into some media/browsing hotkeys, but still no volume even then.    Very disappointed.  I bought this to replace a defective set that buy dot com had shipped me previously, which DID include the older-style compact keyboard that I wanted.  (sadly the keyboard was defective, plus the combo was mispackaged and didn't qualify for rebate they listed on site)    As far as the product itself:  So far I find the mouse to be just as great as I've come to expect from Gyration.  They keyboard is very disappointing for me though.  It's attractive, seems solidly built, but it lacks the (to me) important media keys.  Full-size key layout is nice, but I'm not thrilled with the feel as I'm typing on it either.    If you don't care about the media hotkeys or the described keyboard cover that's not included with the new keyboard, then I can say that this is a nice, quality mouse/keyboard combo.  If - like me - you're buying for an HTPC then seriously consider if you are willing to do without volume controls.
Doesn't snuggly fit ipad 2, so the advertising is deceptive, but have seen that it fits the 1st generation ipad great.
It was almost new with the exception of the brown box, this give away that it wasn't new. Come with all the features like a new one.

It's as if they were expecting the drive to fail and knew this was a known issue.      I would advice not to go for these drives.

I purchased this for my kindle paperwhite. The stand does exactly what I am looking for. The best part of this stand is that the tablet is placed very firmly on the stand, which is very helpful when you need to constantly touch your screen when reading an e-book. I have had some other stands that are good for watching movies but does not hold the Tablet firmly enough for reading/typing.

Two main concerns (if there is any) are: (1) Even though it is claimed that there are 20 adjustable angles, but in reality it is more like 5 different angles as most of the 20 angles have similar effects (between 60-80 degrees). Another is the weight of the stand. However, if it is lighter, it may not hold the the tablet as firmly as I would prefer.

Pros: Inexpensive. Hold the tablet firmly. 3-5 different angles. Easy to set up.

Cons: Weight, not as many angles as claimed.
output: Inexpensive stand. Very sturdy and well-designed.

I have bought the new GA-990FXA-UD3 motherboard for my new system build to work with 3D. I've also purchased an AMD Bulldozer F-8120 Octa-core, 16Gigs of Corsair Vengeance 1600mhz Memory, an EVGA GTX 550TI 2Giga GPU and a SAPPHIRE 1050W PSU and two 500Gigs Western Digital SATA 3 Hard Drives.

Everything is installed properly, but I can't install a new fresh copy of Win7 x64 Ultimate in RAID or AHCI mode. All drives that are on the motherboard CD-ROM and even the ones in Gigabyte's site don't seem to work.

When I load the Win 7 installer, when it's time to choose the hard drive, it doesn't show (when the configuration in BIOS is for AHCI). I try then to load the drivers supplied, but I keep getting an message that says something like this: \\"You can't install non-supported drivers, because if my crash your system installation. Please refer to drivers that are assigned and approved, etc.\\".

The same thing happens when I try to install the new OS on a RAID-0 system. In that case, the drives show, but there are no suitable drivers for the installation of RAID on the system.

I've searched the web and found out that this a common problem with this motherboard.

So I guess is up to you to decide, but that really was a let-down of the board for me.
output: Crappy board at the driver-base side!

I bought this in order to transfer my information from a dead laptop to a new one. It worked with no problems.. I have no complaints. It is quite possible that the latch that holds the USB connector will break sooner than later. The product was supposed to be in a nice box as it was advertised but all I received was a flash drive in a small ziplock bag. If you are planning to give it as a gift (like me) and expecting it to arrive in a nice box then do not buy it. It is a false advertisement. output: The rooCASE is the best I've found

Instances.input: I ordered the wrong one, but I really like it. But it should be rated three stars. Thank you so much.

I bought this Chromebox to try it out and evaluate it at home. My overall impression after three weeks of usage is excellent. The Chromebox is really simple to setup; I am using it with a Logitech bluetooth solar keyboard, a regular USB wired mouse, and a Samsung 24 inch LED TV (connected through HDMI). I mainly use it to display streaming video and the image quality and performance are very good. I particularly like the speed in which the Chromebox boots up; it is a very dependable appliance. Web browsing is agile and I connected it to my HP Printer through the Google Cloud Print service, so I can read my emails, open attachments, and print them from the Chromebox. It is not a device for everyone, but if you basically need to surf the web, access web applications, and stream video, this Chromebox is ideal.

The product worked great up until the fourth day when I pulled it open to take notes on and the lock holding the neck broke so that the the keyboard can not stay connected to the neck supporting the iPad.

As others have said, the cable is heavy-duty and the USB jacks fit snugly into the the phone, charger, computer, etc. Finally I can sit in bed and not worry about being on a tether when using my phone.
Junk. Connectors separated within 6 weeks

After purchasing my Samsung NP700Z5B-S01UB laptop, I decided that the only upgrade I would really need would be a SSD. When doing some background research on which SSD to choose, I decided to stay brand-loyal and go with the 830 SSD.

The physical installation of the drive was a very simple and smooth process, no problems there. The problems started when trying to clone my existing HDD to the SSD. No matter what cloning program I used, I couldn't get anything to work correctly. After three days of trying to clone my existing drive, I decided to do a clean Windows 7 install...20 minutes later, I was up and running! Had no problems installing any of my old programs.

The 830 SSD is blazing fast, it scored a perfect 7.9 in my Windows Experience testing. I've had it up and running for a few months now and I love it! The computer's start-up times alone make the SSD upgrade worth it!
output: SUPER Fast in my Samsung Laptop!

I purchased this drive at the end of February and installed it in March. I noticed weird performance of my notebook ever since: unexpected shutdowns happening several times a day during a movie playback. I suspected several things including my video card to be at fault but with any other hardware you would get a BSOD and an error message would blame the driver or hardware piece. Not in this case, every time it was a sudden shutdown with no traces in the Event Viewer. I suspected the hard drive at the last moment and then updated my hard drive firmware to the latest firmware SD28. At first it seemed to work... No more shutdowns of Windows but after a while shutdowns resumed and now I know for sure it's the hard drive. I regret buying this buggy, overhyped hard drive. Shame on you, Seagate! Coming back to the old proven mechanical only drives.

This SCSI card is one of Adaptec's basic cards. Coming from Adaptec, you know this is serious hardware. Not just something that will break or go dead on you in a year or two. Adaptec quality is made to last for a very long time.
Mainly developed for Ultra SCSI certified devices such as hard drives, CD ROM drives, Jaz Drives, etc. Ultra SCSI devices have a transfer rate of up to 20MB/sec. Be cautious, this SCSI card was not made to be bootable(no bootable BIOS on board). If you need to boot from any of the SCSI devices attached to this SCSI card, purchase the AHA-2940 instead.
At an affordable price, this I/O card is highly recommended.
output: Adaptec Quality again in a SCSI card

Instances.input:
I got this about 7 hours ago and so far its been nothing but frustrating to say the least.

I was looking for a NAS specifically to stream Full HD content over the network either wired or wireless. I don't need this for anything else.

Let me start off by stating what I have:

[[ASIN:B000LIFB7S D-Link DIR-655 Extreme N Wireless Router]]
[[ASIN:B0010T8X54 D-Link DWA-140 RangeBooster Draft 802.11n Wireless USB Adapter]]
[[ASIN:B002KKFP9Y Western Digital WD TV Live Network-ready HD Media Player WDBAAN0000NBK-NESN]]
My internet speeds in case you were wondering: Comcast Business Class 20 mbs Download / 6 mbs Upload

I have had my WDTV Live set up wireless with no problems. I can access Youtube with no issues. I understand these files are not as huge as HD content. But I know it works ok wireless.

I was able to set the up Seagate BlackArmor 4 TB server within minutes. I could find it on the network as well. Next thing I copied a .mkv file about 10 gigs in size. Took about 5 minutes to transfer. Turned on the WDTV and was able to find the network share drive from the Seagate. As soon as I tried to stream the video it just stood there not doing anything. There was no way I could get it to stream.

Next thing I thought of was to change from Raid 1 to Raid 0 as I was under the impression it would increase performance. So it reformatted and I copied the file again. Same thing...the file loaded but would not play.

So next I tried it wired using the Gigabit Port connection on the D-Link. Same results. These files simply would not stream.

Since I had my WDTV Live already set up wireless I could access another drive inside the PC: [[ASIN:B001GQYYSQ Western Digital 640 GB Caviar Black SATA 7200 RPM 32 MB Cache Bulk/OEM Desktop Hard Drive WD6401AALS [Amazon Frustration-Free Packaging]]]
I was able to stream the exact same file with no errors wireless. No hiccups or errors...Exactly what I was hoping to achieve with the Seagate.

Why is this happening ? If you know something I don't please let me know. I would be more than happy to change this review. The only thing I could think of is the actual drive speed being too slow???

The Seagate is going back to Amazon. For a basic server I guess this would be ok...but for my needs...it's just not happening.

After exchanging for a Western Digital World Book I can now stream 1080p files wirelessly: http://www.amazon.com/1-Way-to-Stream-1080p-HD-movies-Wirelessly/lm/R2WSOOSTQSQW1M/ref=cm_lm_byauthor_title_fullyou know something I don't please let me know. I would be more than happy to change this review. The only thing I could think of is the actual drive speed being too slow??? The Seagate is going back to Amazon. For a basic server I guess this would be ok...but for my needs...it's just not happening. After exchanging for a Western Digital World Book I can now stream 1080p files wirelessly: http://www.amazon.com/1-Way-to-Stream-1080p-HD-movies-Wirelessly/lm/R2WSOOSTQSQW1M/ref=cm_lm_byauthor_title_full
output: Too Slow For an HD Media Server

Has the feel of a cheaply made accessory and I wouldn't doubt if it stops working after a few weeks but so far it works as advertised.  I left my tablet on the dock and came back to a full charge and the tablet still registered as connected.  The docking station does not however work with a case attached.  You can kind of force it on with a case on, I am using the Samsung Book Cover, but I don't suggest trying it.  Perhaps a slimmer case would work, but I also put my GS4 on there with its slim tpu case and it did not fit either.  I definitely recommend taking any case or cover off your device before placing it on this cradle or you risk damaging the micro usb port on your tablet.  The charging cable included is very short, so I also suggest being prepared for that.  It did work with my Samsung phone charger cable which is 6ft and plugged into a floor outlet at my desk.  The cable provided is more for hooking it up to a computer, so it is worthless if you want to leave your docking station in another location.  I have a phone charger at my desk, and another on my night stand so I have been just moving the dock to the location I want it.  Also, the tablet did not register the docking station as an accessory, meaning it is only a stand that charges.  If you want a docking station that sends the device into docking mode (clock displayed while cradled, more widgets displayed, etc.) you will need a compatible device.  So, in short I'd definitely recommend this docking station if you are looking for a cheap way to have your tablet stand and be able to charge while watching a movie or something and don't mind constantly taking off the cover and putting it back on.
output: I definitely recommend taking any case or cover off your device before ...

There is a huge shortcoming of this type device that I didn't see mentioned in the description. These devices only run "half-duplex". That means that they operate on one frequency and so as to not interfere with themselves they must receive and transmit separately. This means that whatever theoretical speed they are rated for, the REAL theoretical speed is HALF what is stated. Wireless routers run "full-duplex" which means they transmit and receive simultaneously, on different frequencies.

The manual seems incomplete. I think the received signal strength indicator automatically turns off after a period of time but could not find mention of this anywhere in the manual.

I personally couldn't get this thing to work using any of the three methods described but I'm not sure that is entirely the fault of the unit. It may be a problem on my end.

My old router is a Linksys WRT160n which has served me well but has built in internal antennas. That makes it look very stylish on my desk, but I'm sure they are a compromise and not very efficient.

After my failure with this device I did the research that I should have done before I bought it. The tech articles I read indicated that this type of device is the absolute last option one should try when attempting to increase wifi coverage. My final solution to the problem was to upgrade my 5 year old router with an ASUS RT-AC66U. I added the Super Power Supply® 3 x 9dBi 2.4GHz 5GHz Dual Band WiFi RP-SMA Antenna for Routers. With the state of the art router and upgraded antennas, I now have great house-wide very fast wifi.
output: Stuff you should know before you buy.

Instances.input:
I writing this after having the Synology DiskStation in place for over a year now. Fantastic product!!! In the proprietary UI, Synology has made a network attached storage device (NAS) that is an easy to configure cloud station, whole home network music interface that works with a host of products and software including AppleTV, iTunes almost seamlessly. My experience with the company to date has been positive. Synology appears to be a dependable company that continues to grow the capabilities, security and functions of there software controllers, apps and firmware.

I built my own NAS cloud and serve my music, files, photographs and NAS function to all of my devices (phone, laptop) whether in home network, cell network or guest networks with internet access.

Support has been excellent and there is a well developed community forum that resolves problems for the technically challenged to those with more savvy. In the last year I have had no hardware defects and am most impressed with the software Synology provides to make this a very effective and easy to use device. It should be pointed out again and again, this device does not come with hard drives, they have to be bought separately. All consideration to find compatible drives should be taken, there are a large variety of disk manufacturers from which to choose.

Installation/configuration was plug and play as advertised. Be warned anything over 1TB is going to take some time to format your drives so be prepared for that. The DiskStation provided one of those rare technological "it just works" moment of relief. I have logged lots of great usage with this drive array.

I was sent this Seagate Backup Plus 2Tb USB 3.0 External Hard Drive by Seagate to compensate me for difficulty I had with another of their drives (a mobile unit). Since the drive was sent gratis, I feel a bit sheepish giving it less than a stellar review, but…

Firstly, I was delighted to receive the unit which replaced a much older external HD. Setup was straightforward and simple with the illustrated Quick Start Guide. I like how easily the Seagate Dashboard helped me publish content to social media sites and also to back up data to Cloud Storage, even though most of my usage was to back up document, photo and torrent files which I did manually. The unit stands vertically so the footprint is small. Everything worked perfectly until three months ago when I started getting bad sector messages. I began moving files over to a smaller Iomega backup device. Then my old faithful Dell began telling me it was time for an upgrade (I loved my Dell and trusty Windows XP so resisted upgrading as long as I could). Finally, it was time: I needed to reboot every other day.

I transferred the Seagate drive to the new Windows 7 computer, but the bad sector problems continued. Finally, I couldn’t boot up my computer and had to disconnect the Seagate Backup Plus. A shame really, because I liked the drive’s functionality very much. However, this external hard drive had only seven months of gentle use, so, much as I’d like to recommend Seagate, I will be looking elsewhere for my backup needs.
output: Loved it, but drive only lasted seven months

I was looking to replace my white plastic unibody Macbook. On specs this machine is twice as fast as my Core2 Duo Laptop. On Specs. In reality it is completely different. I haven't used Windows since the XP days. Been using Mac for 4 years and Linux for 3. I know Windows 7 was supposed to be better so I wanted to give it a shot before installing Linux. Windows takes FOREVER to load.The interface isn't responsive either. In one word I would say it is a terribly bloated mess.

It's also pretty buggy. This is something I expect of Linux but a mainstream commercial operating system? The OS It has a fingerprint reader and I removed the function because it took even longer to boot. The function shows up as another user. Though I disabled it- it still showed up and then the control panel kept crashing and I kept being unable to change the settings. I couldn't stand Windows so I installed Linux. Opensuse and Linux Mint detected my hardware automatically. Still they were quite slow to boot. More stable than Windows but nothing like my Mac. Speed wise still not close.

On to the actual hardware- the computer has pretty laughable build quality. Press the trackpad buttons- they are the flimsiest buttons I've ever pressed on any laptop and I've owned an Acer Aspire netbook. Consider that this computer, when new was over $1200 and more expensive than my Macbook. Screen is tolerable but the colors are pretty washed out. Webcam is really bad- like trying to film something with a potato. The good is that the keyboard is about the most comfortable I've used. From trackpad to screen each row of buttons rises up a bit. It is a very nice feeling ergonomic keyboard to use.

In conclusion I plan to keep my Macbook and sell this computer off and wait another year until I can afford a new Mac. I just want a computer that just works. Maybe I can get it to work better if I put in an SSD but that my Mac with its 5200rpm drive and an outdated processor can mop thefloor with this computer shows that it just isn't worth struggling.
output: I know Windows 7 was supposed to be better so I wanted to give it a shot before ...

I've only had the monitor for about a day now, but I was so impressed by it that I just ordered another one. The contrast and clarity is truly amazing. I've used many different LCD monitors and while my favorite continues to be the Apple 20" Cinema display, this is now my 2nd favorite (and as I am getting accustomed to the pivot feature, the Apple display may be in trouble...). Yes, it comes with a pivot display mount that not only allows you to raise, lower, tilt and turn the montior to any position imaginable, it also lets you rotate the screen 90 degrees to portrait mode. Unlike the more expensive rotatable monitors that have an 'auto-sensing' thingie which automatically switch your display output between portrait and landscape based on the position of the monitor, this one requires you to use a software utility (included) to manually select the orientation of the output. To be honest, I didn't even realize this was a feature on this monitor. I based my initial purchase decision on the manufacturer specs and price. Since this was intended to replace a 21" Sony CRT on my development PC, image quality was secondary to form factor and price. I was very pleasantly surprised by the quality of the display and I was extremely pleased to discover the rotation feature.

I was originally going to mount this monitor on a VESA arm, but after using the included stand, I'm having second thoughts. The stand itself is the best that I've ever seen on an LCD monitor. It allows for good cable management and almost infinite adjustability while not presenting a huge footprint.

Anyway, so far, this seems to be an outstanding monitor for the price (actually cheaper than many crappier 17" LCDs I've seen). Though, you do need to shop around for the best price since I've seen it range from $549 to $800+. It's unusual to see such a wide range in the street price. I ended up getting it from Amazon because with the free 'super saver free shipping', it came out to be darn near the best deal (and I've had nothing but good experiences with Amazon so far).

Conclusion - do NOT buy one of these monitors! At this price and value, you NEED to get at least two (dual monitor setups are shweeeeet!!). :-)be darn near the best deal (and I've had nothing but good experiences with Amazon so far).

I bought this card for the sole purpose of running Android on the Nook Color. Several other people said it worked. Well, it does work, but very slowly. The reason is because the random write performance of this card is 0.012 MB/s, which causes Android to stutter and hang. In contrast, the flash memory built into the Nook Color has a random write speed of 1.16 MB/sec, or about 100 times faster than this SD card. So this card is horrible for running Android.  See the complete performance list at:    <...>    You can also read about another person who had a similar experience with another brand:  <...>    Now here's the good news. If you are doing sequental reads or sequential writes, which is what a camera needs, the performance of this card for both reading and writing is over 20 MB/sec (which theoretically makes it a Class 20 card.  However, this was tested on a computer with a fast i5 processor, so your camera will probably not come close to this speed.    Note that there's a company on Amazon that sells a high-performance 8GB SD card with Android already loaded:  [[ASIN:B00530GZC4 N2A Cards - 8GB microSD Card]]
output: Great for cameras, Bad for Nook Color

Instances.input: Very good product and fast service; easy purchase

The Aponyo Click stylus works well with my 3rd gen iPad. The input from the stylus is picked up by the screen pretty much all the time and allows for much finer control, especially in free-form drawing apps like the recent Draw Something game. The fabric tip glides smoothly over the screen (I do not use a screen protector with my tablet), and is a bit \\"spongy\\" -flattening out to a more blunt tip when force is applied. I really like the smoothness with which the fabric tip moves over the screen -the tip material is the best feature of this stylus.

The stylus works well, although I sometimes find myself wishing the tip was more firm. Due to the sponginess I have some difficulty highlighting when annotating *.pdfs of journal articles. Due to the level of zoom I typically read at, the lines of text are close enough together that I am frequently unable to precisely select a row of text without accidently selecting the row either above or below my intended target. I suspect this problem is amplified by the sponginess of the tip, causing the tip to \\"spill over\\" onto the surrounding lines of text.

I find the length of the stylus to be too short by about an inch. I have medium-large sized hands in terms of glove-size. The side of my hand always seem to rub up against the pen clip when holding the stylus with a normal writing grip, which becomes uncomfortable over time. The pen clip is also too rigid as I am unable to get it to clip around the fabric at the top of my jeans pocket. I have also occasionally had issues with the click mechanism becoming jammed, but I have thus far always been able to un-jam the mechanism with only a minimal of fuss.

This laptop was a steal for the price! I purchased this before moving overseas to restart my studies. At the time of purchase, it was one of the cheapest laptops you could purchase with a Haswell CPU. Intel's improved power efficiency and integrated graphics performance quite a bit over their last generation, so getting something with Haswell was a priority. The larger screen size surely doesn't hurt either!

Of course, at this low of a price range, compromises have to be made. As noted by other reviewers, this laptop does not have integrated Bluetooth, although it is inexpensive to add an adapter post-purchase. The built-in WiFi and Ethernet adapters also leave quite a bit to be desired. The 802.11n WiFi is fairly run-of-the-mill basic performance, and the Ethernet is only 100 Mbps, not Gigabit. Transferring files internally within a network can be a bit slower with this system.

The biggest compromise seems to have been with the hard drive. The 750 GB drive is spacious, but it is painfully slow. It's only 5400 RPM, and comes equipped with an absolute barebones 8 MB of cache. General use *will* be bottlenecked by the lack of disk performance. I upgraded this to a smaller 256 GB solid state drive, which substantially improved performance, somewhat lowered power consumption, and cut noise levels a bit.

Again, it's hard to complain about a laptop in this price range. Overall, I'm satisfied with the reliability and performance of this system and would gladly choose to purchase this option again, given the opportunity.
output: Great price and an excellent processor. Disk performance could be better.

Instances.input:
Awesome, amazing, seriously worth it.
Recently I bought the WD01, and received this WD03 for testing and reviewing. The first good things I noticed were:
-Its design is great, it actually looks better in your hand than in pictures.
-It is small, smaller than the WD01, it feels great in the hand, light and very compact.
-It has a matte surface, the WD01 has a glossy surface and as we know anything glossy gets scratched easily, but this doesn't, and that is very appreciated, it has a bit of a glossy edge but most of it is matte.
-It has great interfaces, I used the app "FileHub Plus" in my iPhone 5s and it was beautiful, far better than the app used for the WD01, everything worked perfectly except for when trying to set up wifi, I did that using my laptop. That is the other interface I want to talk about, simply by connecting with my laptop to the device and entering 10.10.10.254 (in browser) another beautiful interface comes up, again much better than the one for the WD01, and it helped me set up wifi, change the SSID, setup a password, etc.
This is a huge improvement compared to the WD01 (I have never used a WD02 so I can't say much about it), completely worth it, the only negative thing I can say is that it is so great that now I won't use my new WD01 as much.
If you're interested in knowing all the things it can do more than the improvements from previous versions, here are some of my favorites:
-You can attach an SD card AND a flash drive/external hard drive to it and access those wirelessly from any smartphone and computer, like your own personal cloud, you can even stream videos from it (I'm not sure what is the maximum amount of devices it can handle at once, but it is at least 5).
-You can have it connect automatically to wifi networks, so if you connect a device to the WD03 for file stuff, you can still access the Internet from your device, and never worry about switching between networks.
-You can literally use the WD03 as a router, imagine having a router that at the same time is your personal cloud, great for everybody at home.
-You can charge your smartphone with the WD03, 6000mAh is a lot, if the other uses were not enough to bring this with you every day, this should change that (just the charging function is enough reason for me).
-You can check the battery level by clicking its button, simple, yet great.

Aside from its weathered and faded appearance, the book is very attractive.  The red felt interior keeps the Mac cushioned and scratch free so far, while the tan leather lining gives a nice touch.  There are two nylon type corner straps to attach the monitor to the book cover, but I've found them to be unnecessary since the BookBook cover prefers to be closed stays relatively close to the Mac's lid stays. Time will only tell if this feature keeps up. I have taken the book out of the case a double of times to check for heat build up but haven't found any problems at all.  I must note, I do tend to keep my desktop fairly clean, no more than four or five programs running at a time, but so far, I have had no heat related concerns.  I Have referred this product to other Mac and iPad users but recommend finding a case or bag designed for a 17\\" laptop.  Otherwise, you would have to leave your BookBook at home.

I built out a pro rendering rig for HD video creation. I chose the X99 in order to take advantage of the higher Hawell line of intel chips as well as the DDR4 ram. So far the performance of the unit is remarkable. The bios setup is quick and easy, and allows for pretty seamless overclocking (even for those who don't do this normally, they can use the automatic OC feature, which will OC to within the limits of your hardware). The built-in RAID setup is great. Also, a great feature is the built-in WIFI directly into the motherboard. After turning the unit on, the WIFI paired easily with Windows 8.1 to locate the WIFI signal and allow me to log in.    Bear in mind that this motherboard is ideally designed for those who want professional level rendering and video creation and not ideal for gamers, hobbyists, or simple hardware junkies. Much of the heft of this unit supports those who need high CPU and memory output for video creation. Gamers will get nearly identical speed or quality out of a more affordable board (e.g. Asus X97) and investment in a quality video card.

So yes, the average gamer (me) who occasionally opens Photoshop or Paint to adjust the size of an image rightly has no use for this screen (or those like it). That said, it was on sale for $800 due to a "perfect condition item, dented box" Amazon had on hand. For people who keep hardware a long time (things like screens, speakers, mice, and keyboards don't become obsolete nearly as quickly as GPUs, CPUs or RAM) this is a good investment.

I was able to calibrate it using a borrowed X-Rite from 2005. By calibrate, I mean adjust the RGBCYMK settings until most dE's were as improved as they could be. The yellow-ish range is still way out (dE 11+) and nothing I can accomplish fixes it without messing up everything else.

I looked on the box but was unable to determine a revision number. That said, I do _not_ have the horizontal-line problem that seems to plague these displays. I feel like internet reviews are more likely to be left for negative experiences, so the sample size skews toward those with problems, giving an impression a product has more issues than it actually does.

Games run just fine--I notice no input lag or ghosting despite not being in "game" mode. I am referring to StarCraft II, Borderlands 2, and Mass Effect 3 here. I can see the frustration with the touch controls but they aren't nearly as bad to me as some reviews have suggested they would be. These are both "Your Mileage May Vary" items since it's purely opinion, but they didn't bother me.

It generates far less heat than my older WFP2408 despite being larger--likely this is new technology at play. The screen's many inputs (including USB3) come in handy for use with different computers (HDMI is more common on laptops than DVI).

I have also not experienced issues with the monitor waking properly when the computer it is attached to resumes from sleep or standby as had been indicated by some reviews across the 'net.

I got this baby in august 2011 from amazon. The reason to buy it- I need huge single logical drive on my desktop on that time for VIDEO files. Also i like to have redundancy for all my data. So, i decide to build single RAID 5 with 19,7 Tb total vilume. Nothing wrong with amazon. They are delivered controller in time. I got 2 cables mSAS-to-4 SATA for my RAID project + 8 pcs HDD from amazon too.
1 step- the controller BIOS was old and need to be updated. With old BIOS the controller do not support 3 Tb HDD. Update was done in 15 minutes. It easy- just need to follow the README.
2 step- i was build a RAID. It's also easy to do using controller menu command line.
After reboot my PC- my WIN 7 x64 PC with latest adaptec software versions including WIN 7 x64 driver was detected my RAID like 2.75 Tb logical drive only.
I read all about similar problems on the adaptec forum and... It's something new. O, i was a pioneer. Probably no many guys using server controller under Windows 7. Linux or 2003 server- for sure- many. But Win7+ adaptec witch cost 1.5 grand 1 year ago-maybe just only crazy guys like i was.
So, i was following instruction and create a ticket online on adaptec web site. It's hapen 6 months afer i try the controller first time(because of my job away from home). After around 20-30 days adaptec reliese new drivers and controller BIOS. I install it and... all works fine till now!
Look like nobody tested controller on similar platform to my PC. But software, according to adaptec controller description, must support my platform fully. I still have problems with ASM on the same PC even with last version of ASM and drivers. It's another story and not so importent as first one.
output: 8xHDD Deskstar 3.5-Inch 3TB 7200RPM SATA III in RAID 5 on WIN7 64bit Ultimate

I write code, I talk to people via instant messenger, I write letters and otherwise communicate with people via text. To put it simply, I type; a lot.

In the world of cars, there are those that like sport tuners, and those that like luxury sedans. This keyboard is a luxury sedan. I've read that it doesn't work so well with certain games (Shift + W + Space), but then the average luxury sedan doesn't do very well on the drag strip either.

In my opinion, this is a coder's keyboard. It feels great under the fingers and unlike so many other keyboards today, Logitech has kept it standard. No unnecessary extra buttons, no rearrangement/removal of home/end/pageUp/pagedown.
Even though I was a bit displeased with Logitech messing up the layout with the big delete button, I've found it to be not too much of a bother because [insert] is still above delete. Also, if you use the context-menu button, they've moved that too, but it's still there!

And that's why I like this keyboard. It's standard, but soo very wonderful to type on and fairly durable.

Other reviews mention keys falling off or the keyboard itself falling apart, I recommend you not drop it. It's a fairly heavy keyboard, so it's not for the lap and probably won't like being dropped. If you're not using it at a desk, buy something else.

That said, this keyboard has been in heavy daily use for over 2 years now, and has seen its fair share of dust and ash and just keeps on going. All the lights still work and everything.

PROS:
- Keys feel absolutely amazing
- backlight is adjustable
- standard layout with wide backspace and home/end/pageUp/pageDown in the right place
- print screen and pause/break
- 1-handed media functions via Fn key
- no odd curves or corners; very professional looking

CONS:
- somewhat expnsive
- F1 - F12 buttons have backlit icons instead of the keys themselves
- endof USB cable hard to get a grip to plug it out
- no odd curves or corners; looks too sleek and boring :)

I bought this for several reasons, and it succeeds on all counts.

First, I need a flat plug since this is behind our bed. I have a sideways/flat plug for my wife's surge protector, and this one goes straight down. So both fit nicely and the bed can be (almost) flush against the wall.

Next, I wanted good spacing on the plugs to accommodate wall warts. I have my cell phone charger next to the bed, and sometimes plug in other stuff. Most of the plugs on this device are sufficiently separated that device plugs don't interfere with each other.

Finally, I wanted something with a moderately short cord. Six feet is not short, but most of the flat-plug surge protectors I found had longer cords. This needs to go a whopping one foot, so the less slack the better. You will be hard pressed to find a shorter cord than six feet without going into the realm of "I would be scared to plug in anything more expensive than an alarm clock" surge protectors.

If I find myself needing another surge protector, I would strongly consider purchasing another one of these.

I was very excited to receive this yesterday. I pulled out my tablet and hooked it right up. The drivers installed automatically over the Internet and I was up and running in just a few minutes. All the cables and connectors I needed were included, including DVI -> VGA and DVI -> HDMI convertors. True as promised, it charges/powers the tablet and serves as a dock. The dock provides DVI output (with included convertors), 100M Ethernet, headphone & mic jacks, and four USB connectors. I used a USB keyboard and USB mouse, the DVI -> VGA convertor, and the 100M Ethernet and they worked seamlessly and flawlessly.

When first connected the tablet was set to extend the desktop onto the external display. I changed it to only use the display connected to the dock. I was very happy to see that it remembered this setting even after being unplugged from the dock and plugged back in later. I love that I can use the tablet as a tablet, bring it home, plug it into the dock and use it via the monitor/mouse/keyboard just like any old desktop. It's pretty simple and pain-free.
output: Turns the Dell Venue 8 Pro tablet into a desktop with a single connection.

I have to say I was a bit skeptical about reviewing this case, mainly because I currently own an Airbender mini case for my iPad mini retina and it works so well and I have never really been a person that loved gimmicky products and let’s face it an iPad case with a handle on it is kind of gimmicky.

I have to say though, I was absolutely surprised by the quality of this case, it has a very good quality feel to it and seems like it would be great protection. So let’s get in to the review:

Probably MOST IMPORTANT I NEED with a case for my devices is GRIP, and has to have a comfortable feel for hold for long periods of time. This out of all other aspects is an absolute deal breaker to me, and this also what I have trouble finding most with case especially with my Galaxy S4, but I digress. With the size of the iPad Mini, having a case with good grip for one handed use and holding for long periods during gameplay is almost a must. I am very active so having a case that will allow me to hold the mini with one hand is vital to me. This case absolutely excels at this and then some. I initially thought with the “hard to miss” handle on the back of the device would make it hard hold in two hands and play games fearing the handle may be in the way. This was not the case at all in fact I actually forgot the handle was there as I played my favorite games. And the grip and texture of the case made it even easier to hold. Then on top of that when I needed to hold with one hand I was able to slide my hand in the handle and hold forever while I surfed the web. This case made me a believer, I know feel like I almost have to have the handle there.

Next, I like a case to cover as much of the back and sides of the device as possible. This one definitely delivers in this department as well covering almost all outlets with buttons and plugs. The entire back and sides of the phone are covered with the cutouts in the appropriate places. And mostimportantly the power sleep/wake and volume buttons work flawlessly with case installed. The site claims the case is water resistant, dirt and shockproof, and so far I have found that to be the case in all but the dust proof only because I haven’t tested that, But accidentally dropped on concrete in the rain walking into my gym. The mini still works like a champ, and the case doesn’t even show any damage just a few scratches.

I am not big on style and looks exactly, so a case doesn’t radically need to change the look of my iPad, or be the most attractive to look at for me. As long as the functionality is there and it’s protected I am happy. This case isn’t the most attractive I have seen, but it definitely is still easy on the eyes. Some may really not like the brown handle on the back but I think the whole thing works especially adding the fact that the handle works great and makes for much easier one handed holding. But guess what, if the brown handle is really bothering you that much you can actually take it off and still have an awesome kickstand case that provides great protection. Speaking of the kickstand it has to be one of the best built I have seen on a case. Have you ever got an iPad mini kickstand case pulled the kickstand out and tried to use it only to find the case feels like it going to move or tip over during use. Well you never run in to that problem here the case feels very sturdy while propped on the kickstand.

Bottom Line: if you need a great highly protective case with awesome functionality look no further this is the one. Definitely earns a five star rating in my book, only one minor gripe I have is that the built in screen protection on the case seemed to be a little warped like it wasn’t stretched tight enough across the device. But I contacted the company and they are aware of this problem and are in the process of fixing it. Functionality is still very solid though.

Pros:
1. Great coverage of back and sides for protection, iPad dropped twice once on concrete in the rain, once on gym floor not a scratch on it.... (Deal Breaker)
2. Adjustable/removable handle on the back is awesome for holding the device for long periods of time, with no problems
3. Kickstand works perfectly and has a rubber tip for sturdy propping
4. Power/volume buttons still easy to press with case installed (Deal Breaker)
5. Texture of device is awesome allowing for MUCH better grip and overall fit to the device.
6. Overall case build and quality is outstanding, worth the price in my opinion, case does not feel cheap at all.

Cons:
1. Screen protection could be tighter, the company says they are aware of this problem and are in the process of fixing it. Functionality is still very solid though.

I have had numerous illuminated keyboards in the past, and this one is the BEST EVER, illuminated or not.  Great layout, key feel/touch, style, and legibility in the dark.  The back lighting only shines through the laser etched characters on the keys, it does not leak out that much around the borders of the keys, making the characters so easy to see, and is visible at all angles because the keys are not so thick that they obstruct emitted light! I got one of these for my birthday this year, which was much needed because my main hard drive was almost completely out of space.  So, I transferred files worth hundreds of hours of work onto it, stupidly assuming it would be safe.  About two weeks ago, the hard drive stopped working.  I worked almost every day, trying everything I could think of to get it working again.  When I eventually went to its support site, it was almost useless, and left me circling around the site with almost no success.  The one suggestion I did find, which was try a power supply with a higher amp output, failed, so I emailed their tech support.  They esentially told me that they did not really know what to do, but that I should try a different computer and/or USB cable (Which I mentioned in the report trying) and if that failed to get a replacement, and that my only hope to recover the files was with a software the company sold (There was a demo available though) that only worked with software issues, and my problem is obviously a hardware one.  So now my choices are get a replacement and forever lose my files, or try and pry the hard drive open and fix it myself, which would void the warrenty and if I failed I would lose my files and the money that would have to be spent on a new drive.  I am very unhappy with this product and the company who sells it, and am currently questioning whether or not I would even want a replacement, because I really do not want to go through this again.
output: Broke in 2 months and a terrible support center.

(Re-wrote this review 12/6/09)    This is an excellent budget notebook with a 15.6\\" screen that's only 5.8 lbs.  We just bought two for my wife's parents (don't buy it for 3D games, as it has integrated graphics, but office apps and browsing are fine).    Pros:  - T6600 Core 2 Duo (not the Pentium Dual Core, lower-end C2D, ULVs, or Atoms)  - Relatively quiet and light (5.8 lbs)  - Big hard drive (mine had a Seagate Momentus 5400.6)  - Screen has relatively good viewing angles, horizontal and vertical  - Pretty good fit and finish for a plastic casing (although there's a somewhat flimsy lid that is separate from the battery)  - 4 USB ports  - VGA output is crisp (to 1280x1024, didn't try bigger)  - I haven't noticed the palm rest getting warm at all ... but you're not playing 3D games are you?  - You can select one language during boot up that's set forever, that is, until you restore from the recovery partition.  The first time I chose Traditional Chinese.  Works great.  I restored (press F9 at boot) and selected English.  Works great, didn't need to put in DVDs, and all the software reappeared.  I even choose the option to use one C:\ drive, instead of the default 60% C:, 40% D:.  - Opening the notebook casing is easy -- find the \\"electronic - hardware\\" version (not the \\"hardware\\" version) of the manual on Asus's web site (search for K50, then click Download, then Manuals).  The hard drive is easily replaceable.  Relatively clean layout so I can imagine blowing out dust bunnies will be easy.  - Includes Office Home & Student 2007 (Word/Excel/PowerPoint/OneNote) pre-installed WITHOUT a product key.  It asks for that so I assume you just punch one in and everything's great.  - Includes a trial of Trend Micro Internet Security for antivirus protection pre-installed.  - Aside from the Asus utilities, relatively little bloatware  - Turned off all of Win7's eye candy.  Don't need that.  - 1-year international warranty.  Includes accident protection (register for this within 60 days on the Asus U.S. web site, and it's non-transferrable from the original owner).  No paperwork on extending the warranty.  We're trying our luck in case the computer breaks down in < 1 year and they give us a hassle about it being a gift and the warranty being valid.    Cons:  - A bit fat  - The screen has a blue tinge, just like with Asus's TN LCD displays.  You get used to it though.  - Glossy screen (reflections), not matte  - Two-finger touchpad scrolling is too sensitive out of the box with Firefox (although it might be okay with IE).  Turning it all the way down, it's fine.  - The numeric keypad uses smaller keys!  Difficult to use for folks with big hands.  - The arrow keys don't have space around them (and actually the right arrow key is bumped into the numeric keypad section), so you need to learn where they are.  - The keyboard and touchpad are on the left side of the computer because of the numeric keypad.  You quickly get used to that, though, so no biggie.  - The touchpad buttons require some pressure to click, but you get used to it.  - 4 GB maximum memory.  Just 1 user-accessible memory slot which contains 2GB.  No biggie.  - No DVI.  No port replicator option with that option.  - No Bluetooth, FireWire, eSATA, ExpressCard/PCI Express slot  - Integrated Intel graphics (not for 3D gaming, but great for 2D apps)  - The T6600 doesn't support Windows 7's XP compatibility mode.  Most of the Win7 Home Premium notebooks I've seen have a CPU which doesn't support XP mode.  Only Win7 Professional and higher supports VT mode anyway.  Does XP mode matter at all?  I have no idea.  Search the Internet for that.  - It doesn't wake up when you open the lid.  It does sleep when you close the lid.  Yes, I checked the settings.  Tip:  Change the close-lid behavior to Sleep instead of Hibernate for a faster sleep, but battery will drain faster.    Edit 12/10/09:    A few cons I've noticed:  - The two speakers are on the bottom of the notebook, at the front lip.  You really need a hard surface to reflect the sound up to you.  Definitely below average compared with other notebooks IMO.  - The Page Up / Down keys are above the numeric keypad -- way out of reach.  It's an incredible hassle with Internet browsing.  - Remember how I wrote the graphics are good enough for 2D?  If you watch a Yahoo! music video in full screen mode, that sucker will tear during fast motion.  It's fine at the normal zoom level and with computers with discrete graphics.  - I'm always accidentally hitting the DVD eject button.  Other notebooks I've used recess this button.

I recently bought this external/enclosure kit because I upgraded my newer laptop from a 1TB Internal Drive to a 250GB Samsung SSD. What a remarkable speed difference! I knew I would need an enclosure right away simply because I didn't want to keep the older drive in my laptop (since it would rarely be used - my laptop DOES have 2 drive bays, though), and it made a whole lot more sense to save the money on buying the caddy kit for my laptop to just buy this enclosure and make the internal drive an external one. Another benefit of this enclosure was that I was able to easily insert my Samsung SSD into it temporarily as I cloned the HDD to it. Worked flawlessly, and is high enough speed to where it can even keep up with the 500 mbps read/write that my Samsung SSD is capable of.

All of that being said, I'd like to just point out the pros and cons of this unit, as you may see a little of both as you read through reviews.

Pros:
-Doesn't hinder speed of any drive w/ fast interface & USB 3.0
-Incredibly easy drive installation, cable is concealed even while attached
-Comes with a USB extension cable, if needed, to run a longer cord to a desktop or to help keep the drive in a better location
-Reliable; Other external enclosures I've had would turn the drive off under load. No issues here.
-Works with both my SSD and HDD - The measurements are probably slightly different but this enclosure is able to compensate

Cons:
-Build quality: some people complain about the 'cheap' feel to it. I rather enjoy the light & minimal feel, however some may think this lacks protection. NO external enclosure is truly meant for protecting the drive from shock - you should not be dropping drives with the hopes that the enclosure will protect them.
-The included Short cable may not allow the drive to lie flat if the port you're plugging it into is a stretch. No issue... you can always use the included extension cable.

Overall I think this is an excellent enclosure for the price. Extremely portable, no dangling wire to worry about (granted you choose to use only the concealed cable), and works reliably. It's not perfect but it gets a 5-star rating for its value and functionality in my book.verall I think this is an excellent enclosure for the price. Extremely portable, no dangling wire to worry about (granted you choose to use only the concealed cable), and works reliably. It's not perfect but it gets a 5-star rating for its value and functionality in my book.
output: Works excellent for my SSD and HDD

I should have rated this higher... read futher to see why.    This opens up two drives, not one. One of them is detected as a CD.    I am sick and tired of these companies stuffing software down your throat that \\"they\\" think you need. Along with nagging upgrades for a price and commercials of things they just know you would want. Imagine buying a car and before it will start you have to listen to a commercial.    I quit buying HP printers and advising my customers not to buy them because a simple driver that should take about 30 seconds to install becomes a 30 minute exercise in answering questions that you don't have the slightest clue about such as, \\"Do you want to share your data with the Professional Viewer in a secure and encrypted manner?\\" No, of course I don't... I want to share it with a goofball hacker that is not secure and I want to read the data that I save.\\"    Anyway, my frustration was maxed out by this. They take what could be a simple and pleasing device and turn it into a pain in the rear end that makes you hate it every time you use it and leaves you guessing each and every time if it will work on a particular computer.    Until a little man jumps out of the package of these harebrained schemes, that are dreamed up by a 12 year old game player, and copies the files that I want when and where I want, I'm going to boycott these fools that try to give you what \\"they\\" think you need instead of what you want.    I only bought this because it doesn't have a cap and the connector is protected while in your pocket. So much for totally screwing up a great idea. Someone should be fired for this numskull idea. This is like protecting toilet paper with a password that comes with a toothbrush.    The key to the behavior of this boondoggle is called \\"U3.\\" Yes, U3. When you see it on any product, avoid it like the plague. Here is the criticisms from Wikipedia:    Freezing the Computer ('strong possibility' if certain software is installed on host computer)  Closed Platform  Uninstallation issues  Leaves Traces on Host PC  Data Security (The drive is supposed to seal itself after a certain number of invalid password entries, requiring a reformat)  Insufficient user privileges  Two Drive Letters  Windows requirement for removal    If your idea of a memory stick is one where a Skype logo comes up when you insert it, this stick is for you.    === The above was my rant. Since then I found SanDisk offers free software to remove not only U3 but the partition where you can make it into a simple big memory stick with one drive. Thanks to someone who replied I ran is software suggestion and it worked flawlessly. My first attempt was either the wrong software or for a different model and it still booted two disks. I am now much more pleased and would give it a 3 star rating. Why no higher? Because SanDisk does not make it clear that you can convert this into a true memory stick but offers software that removes the Launch Pad. It (unless there is more than one program that they offer) actually removes U3 and the partition.    Thanks due to the reviewers on Amazon, I now have a device that I like much better. If I can not change my star rating for this product, I will eventually delete my review so as not to affect the overall rating unfairly.
output: This is NOT a 4GB Memory Stick

When I upgraded my PC to a USB3.0 port with the [[ASIN:B00FDLK5BU iDsonix Uspeed PCI-E to USB 3.0 2 Port Express Card Compatible with Mac OS X V 10.8.2 Windows XP or Later Fit in Any PCI-E Slot Easy Powered with 4PIN IDE/ATA Connector]], I needed a super-fast way to copy my digital photos off of SD and CF cards. This multi-card reader seemed just the thing to do it. It worked great on my Windows 7 64-bit PC. It is quite small, only 2.3\\" x 4\\" x 0.8\\". The box itself is aluminum, so it has a nice solid feel. The back has 3 connections - CompactFlash (CF), XD, and the micro-USB3.0 connector for plugging into your PC. The front has MS, TF, M2, and SD. Unlike some other readers, ports aren't shared, so plugging in a card is easy. I tested it with both my SD card and CF card, and both were read just fine simultaneously. The device comes in a nice package, protected by plastic sheets, and includes a 24\\" SuperSpeed USB3.0 cable.

So why just 4 stars? First, it was a little disappointing that there were no feet on the case, so the aluminum can just slide around on your desk. It's not really portable and not really for your desk - it's somewhere in the middle. Second, there is a blue indicator light of power, but no indicators of activity. My previous all-in-one from Sandisk had a global power LED, and then a small LED on each port. That LED would light up when I plugged in a card, would flash while copying files, and when I ejected it from my system, the light would turn off letting me know I could remove the card. On this device, there is only the 1 blue power LED, and nothing else.

So 4 stars - it works, copies files fast, and is small. But for 5 stars I want the activity lights and status lights I've come to expect in card readers.

Note: I received a free sample of this device from the manufacturer in exchange for an honest review.
output: Works as expected but missing some key features of a card reader

Instances.input: This was my second case purchase after ordering my iPad 2, based on the experience I had had with my Defender for my iPhone 4.  Pros:  - your iPad 2 will be well guarded against drops and other mishaps with this case on - this is my #1 priority in a case like this and the main driver for my 4 star review  - rubberized outer shell makes the iPad easier to hold and prevents slips  - well designed product, the flaps and other covers fit nicely  - sturdy, the design of the Defenders in general is very good in my opinion  - attractive - well, I guess as attractive as a black case gets - people certainly notice and comment on it, which is a great lead-in for me to start talking techie (which my wife swears I look for any excuse to do)  - the current price on Amazon is well under what I paid originally for this case and actually makes it a darn good value in my opinion  - the provided stand also doubles as a protective device that can either be snapped on the front or back of the iPad  Cons:  - lacks a screen protector - I ended up getting the anti-smudge invisibleSHIELD installed, but wished that this case would have had one built in like the iPhone 4 model  - bulky and heavy - you will notice when you have this case on, not only from the additional weight but from the added girth - security and peace of mind come with a price and its not for everyone  - can't use a lot of speaker systems with this case on unless it has a raised 32-pin connector, like several Philips Fidelio models do  - the stand is terrible - only two positions, both in landscape and is plastic with little rubber feet - I bought an Arkon Portable stand and basically leave the provided stand on a shelf  - is not the right case for all activities - specifically when I travel on business, I need a keyboard, so I will take it out of this case and slip it into a keyboard/case - I'm starting to have concerns about how many times I can do this before something breaks as I don't get the feeling this was designed for the case to be pulled apart on a regular basis - however, that said, I've done it over 10 times now and it still is OK  - won't protect against a drop where the large screen opening strikes an object - but then again, no other case would either  - I have an invisibleSHIELD from Zagg installed on my iPad 2 and it marked up the shield a fair amount from where the case puts pressure on the iPad - that's why I have the screenshield in the first place though, and would recommend others to have one too with this product  Recommendations:  - build in a screen protector  - redesign the stand or just get rid of it - better yet, send everyone an Arkon Portable with it and make them happy  - potentially look to re-engineer the case to make it easier to get on/off as this case is not right for all activities - people need flexibility with their cases to change them as situations change - help enable them to do that by designing it into the product  Overall, I am happy with this case as it does what I want it to do very well -- protect my iPad.  This is the only case I've had for the iPad where I felt comfortable giving it to my young children and not having to worry if I was going to get it back in one piece.  If you have young kids, I highly recommend this -- or if you haul your iPad around a lot and don't need a keyboard, consider this before buying another case.

So, I've only had this drive a few days. I have already read that this SSD can get really hot, so I already got myself a small ball baring fan that I was able to screw on the heat sink. When installing the Windows Disk at boot, I followed the instructions to the T for this drive and when/how to instal the driver, it's very specific to do it correctly when you intend to use it for a Boot drive. So here is the thing... I have the MSI BIG Bang-Xpower (MS-7666) X58 mother board and I could not find a single thread online that stated this PCIe card would work on this motherboard in boot-up setup, even OCZ's \\"compatible\\" motherboard list doesn't include this board. So I looked and saw on MSI's website that they released a bios update on 1 7 2011 that specifically states it now supports the OCZ PCIe cards. So, here I am with a working card on this older mother board. It's a great board and I was not ready to upgrade. I also have the i7 990X processor, so I have a nice set up. Anyhow, a previous article states it's really a 700mb/sec card, which is still impressive. I did the test he did and I am achieving 900mb/sec. I'm a happy camper. I do suggest you use gloves when handling this drive, there is no cover or casing around it at all, and I highly recommend getting a very good small fan for the heat sink. I got this card as I do a lot of Adobe Premiere Pro and After Effects as well at Photo editing with Adobe products, this just helps me achieve a more effective workflow.

Some tips I learned. Be sure to set up your bios to run the drives as AHCI before you even start with the Windows Instal Disk, turn off \\"Defragment your hard drive\\", I guess this is for Windows 7. Prefetch and Superfetch disabled.
output: OCZ Revo Drive 3 X2 Works on MSI BIG Bang-Xpower (MS-7666) X58 board!

Instances.input: Great HD but needs charging too often otherwise easy to use and holds many apps and downloads. The Kindle Fire HD would have been just as good for my use.

Since I've started to game again, I figured I should upgrade my GPU to something that's a bit more current.  So I went from my trusty 9800GT to this GTX460.  The difference is simply astounding.  Burnout Paradise now looks like it's playing in fast-forward and is smooth as silk at 1920x1080, all settings maxed and 4x AA.  NFS Shift, which previously really stressed out my GPU runs perfect maxed out (I forget the settings, but probably everything maxed out, no AA).  Unigine's benchmark on all default settings (at 1920x1080 again) ran very well.  I do wish it were a bit smoother, but it averaged around 30FPS which is fine by me.    The card itself is a good size, not requiring a massive amount of space previous generation cards with similar specs.  Heat management is wonderful too, with the card running much cooler than other cards I've tested both at idle and maxed out.    Oh yes, and you'll get a nice little \\"upgrade\\" if you purchase one of these cards.  A bios is being offered (mine came pre-lodaed with it) that bumps the stock clock up from 675/1350 to 720/1440.  But of course if this isn't enough, these cards overclock like crazy.    Honestly, if you're looking for a good upper-middle range upgrade, you really can't go wrong with one of these cards.

I've read a ton of reviews about this modem with regard to the Black vs. White model issue. I especially paid attention to two items mentioned in quite a number of reviews:

1. The Black modem is a refurbished modem and comes with Firmware version 1.0.6.3. This firmware version apparently has a serious bug.

2. TWC will NOT push firmware updates to consumer owned modems. So, if you bought a Black SB6141 you're on your own and Good Luck.

OK...so here is my story.

1. I bought the Black version of this modem on November 24, 2012 from Amazon. I won't bet my first born female child on it, but I don't recall a White version being available at that time.

2. My Black version of the modem DID come in a Brown Motorola box. The label on the outside of the box says, "NEW." (Even though it is over a year later, I still have the box and all the receipts and packaging.)

3. I am a TWC customer in Durham, NC

4. I went to http://192.168.100.1 to access information about my modem. (BTW, when the home page opens on this site you need to tap on "Help" to get info about your Modem such as the firmware version.

5. This is the data for my Black Motorola SURFboard SB6141 as of 1/18/2013 as revealed by the site above.

Model Name: SB6141
Vendor Name: Motorola
Firmware Name: SB_KOMODO-1.0.6.12-SCM00-NOSH
Boot Version: PSPU-Boot(25CLK) 1.0.12.18m3
Hardware Version: 7.0

As mentioned above, many have said that the Black version I have was shipped with Firmware version 1.0.6.3. Perhaps that is true. I did NOT check the firmware version when I bought the modem. Many of those same people have also said that TWC does NOT push firmware updates to consumer owned modems. That may be true. BUT, logically speaking, both of these statements can't be true.

Right!

I suspect that TWC did push an update to my modem. I don't know if this is done everywhere by TWC, but in Durham, NC it looks like they do.

If anyone wants to check the firmware version on their Black SB6141, I think others might be interested to know what firmware version your unit is running.

Cheers, Mr. Luigi
output: Conflicting Information about Black vs. White version of the SB6141
